column2: The first "live" television program to be fed from Hollywood over a coast-to-coast network will take place next Sunday as part of a marathon telecast by the Columbia Broadcasting System in behalf of the Crusade for Freedom drive.
THERE were forty of them when the adventure began and three, just three, when it was over. The others had generally stopped in grimly picturesque places along the way.
LONDON, Sept. 19--Prime Minister Attlee announced tonight that he had asked the King to dissolve Parliament so that a new election could be held on Oct. 25...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19--Fearful that an increasingly serious beef shortage within the Army might mean a cut in the meat ration to troops both overseas and at home, the Quartermaster Corps disclosed today it had made a final appeal to packers for supplies before going into the foreign market to buy.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19--A "critical" personnel situation faces hospitals and if they wish to keep from losing their employes to defense work or private industry, they must raise salaries, Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals in New York, warned today.
OTTAWA, Sept. 19--Britain's $13,000,000,000 rearmament program will be carried out on schedule despite the firm stand taken by John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, against further financing ...
A decline last week of 553,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

CELLE, Germany, Sept. 19-- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower appealed today for greater unity among the free nations matching Communist unity and bluntly criticized politicians for not doing a good job toward achieving unity.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19--A "modest but adequate" level of living for a retired elderly couple cost $1,700 to $1,800 a year at October, 1950, prices in almost half of thirty-four cities surveyed, the ...

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 19 --Three young theft suspects from New York were captured late last night with the assistance of a band of eight local youths who chased them in three hot-rod cars and then engaged them in a free-forall fist fight.

EXETER, N.H., Sept. 19--Although he is hoping to prolong the success his charges enjoyed in 1950 when they won five and tied one in a seven-game schedule, head coach Bill Clark of the Phillips Exeter Academy is viewing the football season with a certain amount of misgiving.
TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 20 --The Communist High Command announced this morning its willingness to resume negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 19--At a meeting tonight the Iranian Cabinet pondered the course it should follow in the light of Mr. Harriman's negative reply to Premier Mossadegh's request that he pass on the Iranian note to Britain about the oil dispute.

TODAY, 9 A.M.: An exhibit of flowers and vegetables grown by Queens school children will be opened in the annual Chatfield Memorial Flower and Vegetable Show, Queens Botanical Garden, Flushing. Tomorrow at 2 P.M. prizes will be awarded for the best entries by Superintendent of Schools William Jansen.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 19--One of the initial tasks being tackled by the United States military advisory group here in its efforts to increase the effectiveness of the Nationalist armed forces is the problem of reorganization.

A serious blow at sound business judgment has been struck because the excess-profits tax has cheapened the dollar and increased the advantages of spending, according to most of the 125 manufacturers reached in a survey by the National Industrial Conference Board.

The warning issued by Mayor Impellitteri and Health Commissioner Mahoney of the dangers of carbon monoxide poisoning generated by defective and obsolete gas appliances and from leaking and broken gas fixtures is a timely one.

In his first major statement as president of the New York Stock Exchange, Keith Funston has made a plea for defending the competitive economic system by broadening the base of public participation in corporation ownership.

Awards of merit were given to five Protestant church leaders yesterday at a luncheon of the general board of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A., which held an all-day session at the New Yorker Hotel.

MADRID, Sept. 19--Shifts in high administrative posts announced here today tend to confirm the impression that the Falange is coming forward again in the Franco regime despite some foreign reports to the contrary.
From one point of view, the Sept. 15 short interest on the New York Stock Exchange can be considered most significant.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 19 (UP)--A bill authorizing the executive to sue the International Petroleum Company for more than $40,000,000 in alleged back taxes and interest was passed today by the Senate in its first reading.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19--President Truman was urged today by the Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report to give a "profound new impetus" to the program of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19--The Government faced the fact today that soon it must shop again for executives to fill two key posts in defense mobilization.
BOSTON, Sept. 19--The Red Sox were massacred, 15--2, by the Indians today and even the most rabid Bosox rooters conceded that Boston's pennant chances had become merely mathematical.

FREEPORT, L.I., Sept. 19-- People in the metorpolitan New York area were warned today against eating any of the large fish being washed up along the south shore of Long Island.

ALBANY, Sept. 19--The State Education Department overruled today a New York City Board of Education order denying the use of a public high school building to the Teachers Union, Local 555, for a meeting Friday night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19--The forty-four-member Defense Advisory Committee on Women in the Services ended its initial three-day conference tonight by setting an immediate recruiting goal of 112,786 women.

The appointment of Thomas F. Farrelly as assistant controller of customs and Henry J. Elmiger as deputy collector of the Money and Accounts Division was announced yesterday by Harry Durning, Collector of the Port of New York.

An organizing drive, with emphasis on rural and Southern areas, was voted yesterday by the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, independent, to meet what the union called a threat to wage standards from decentralization of several major industries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)-- Cass Michaels' bases-loaded single with two out in the eighth inning scored two runs and lifted the Senators to a 4-3 victory over the Browns' tonight. Bob Porterfield scattered nine hits to gain his seventh victory.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)-- The military today released 20,330,000 pounds of stainless steel for civilian use--a sizable windfall for automobile and household appliance manufacturers.

Defense industries will employ upwards of 6,000,000 persons by the end of the year, Robert C. Goodwin, executive director of Defense Manpower Administration, United States Department of Labor, predicted yesterday.

Tagged with the Green Room label, the collection of fall fashions offered yesterday at Bloomingdale's included the cream of this season's styles. With an eye to cold weather ahead, it opened with a wide array of coats, embracing the leading silhouettes and fabrics.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19-- President Truman, in a message today to the seventieth convention of the American Federation of Labor, asserted that the nation and its institutions were threatened as never before by a triple danger-- Communist aggression, inflation and reaction.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 19--The second round of the battle of the harvest has started in Yugoslavia. The corn crop, better than average this year, is ready for harvesting.
ROME, Sept. 19--The city of Rome rolled out the carpet for Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri of New York today.

MONTCLAIR, N.J. Sept. 19-- With a putting stroke that found its mark, Mrs. William Tracy of Glen Ridge today eliminated Miss Charlotte De Cozen of the home club in the second round of the twenty-sixth annual women's New Jersey State golf championship.

OTTAWA, Sept. 19--The North Atlantic Council meeting has brought together a more distinguished and influential group of Allied officials than any other conference since the war, but it lacked the presence of two figures it needed perhaps more than any other.

PARIS, Sept. 19--After the optimism inspired by the San Francisco conference and by the Washington three-power talks the French official tone has been considerably sobered by discussion of the facts and figures that has taken place at the Atlantic pact conference in Ottawa.

OTTAWA, Sept.19--In a cordial but forthright talk with the United States, British and French ministers, Premier Alcide De Gasperi has made clear to the Western Big Three that the Italian Government draws a sharp distinction between the revision of the Italian peace treaty and the solution of the problem of Trieste.
The talents of Paris and New York designers were combined to celebrate Arnold Constable's 126th anniversary in an impressive fashion show yesterday at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The police solved yesterday the case of the disappearing policy slips, otherwise known as the heatless heater.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19--To prevent Government inroads and ultimate control, the utility industry must finance expansion with private funds, Representative Richard Simpson, Republican of Pennsylvania, warned the Pennsylvania Electric Association here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)-- The Government today lifted price controls from tickets to football games and other sports events held by tax-supported colleges and schools.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 19 (AP) --Sampson Hanover today turned in the fastest mile ever recorded over a half-mile track in harness racing.
An 11-cent-an-hour wage increase offered by East Coast employing stevedores was rejected yesterday by the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L.
Short interests in stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange on Sept. 15 reached the highest level since May 16, 1932.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 19 --The College of William and Mary faculty charged today that a sports scandal at the college was caused by an ambitious athletic program that was "obscuring and corrupting" the real purposes of the institution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19--Jesse R. Hildebrand, since 1930 assistant editor of the National Georgraphic Magazine, died last night in the Georgetown Hospital from the effects of a cerebral hemorrhage suffered early Sunday morning during his sleep at his home in Georgetown.

Senator Estes Kefauver told the American Bar Association yesterday that passage of bills now pending in the Senate and House, to levy an excise tax on gamblers and tax their winnings 10 per cent, would be a "tragic error."
Tributes and congratulations upon its centennial continued yesterday to pour into THE NEW YORK TIMES from all parts of the United States and many other quarters of the world.
On the anniversary yesterday of George Washington's farewell address in 1796, members of the American Defense Society gathered under the Washington Memorial Arch at Fifth Avenue.

ROME, Thursday, Sept. 20 (AP)-- Tourist-jammed Italy was crippled by a twenty-four-hour strike that ended at midnight last night after stopping railroads, breaking telegraph communications, delaying telephone service and halting the mail.
LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP)--The text of Prime Minister Atlee's broadcast announcing general elections for Oct. 25.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19-- Hadassah, the women's Zionist Organization of America, adopted today budgets totaling $8,235,000 ...

Adequate enforcement of the city's existing smoke regulations under the present statute would make any basic revision of the law unnecessary, the general welfare committee of the City Council was told by several speakers yesterday at a public hearing in City Hall.

One of the few remaining veterans of the golden era of pleasure sailing so popular around the turn of the century, the coal-burning excursion steamer Sandy Hook, was sold yesterday to an industrial wrecker.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 19--Dr. Richard Morris of 12 Johnson Street, Highland Park, Professor Emeritus of Mathematics at Rutgers Univer sity, when he taught for forty-five years, died today in Middlesex General Hospital. He was 83 years old.

Showing unexpected speed in the stretch, Eternal Moon of the Emerald Hill farm won the twenty-ninth running of the Cowdin, over a distance of six and a half furlongs, at Aqueduct yesterday. Scorned by the crowd of 19,268, Eternal Moon ran as part of a mutuel field of three, and so unexpected ...

A collection of critical essays by friends and severe critics of William Faulkner will be published Oct. 10 by Michigan State College Press. Titled "William Faulkner: Two Decades of Criticism," the book has been edited by Frederick J. Hoffman and Olga Vickery.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 19 --The Bridgeport Brass Company demonstrated today a robot pneumatic conveyor that uses a "sixth sense" to "feel, think about and read" requirements for dispatching intra-plant communications and metallurgical samples.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 19-- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, charged today that "there are members of Congress and the Senate who have members of the Communist party on their staffs."

The season for New York's custom-Made collections is drawing to a close. Yesterday it was Mainbocher's turn to show. This design er made a high score in his fall collection, though he has not introduced any radical changes.

The twelve-story apartment house occupying a plot 102 by 150 feet at the northwest corner of West Eighty-fifth Street and Central Park West has been sold by Charles Ryan, operator, to a syndicate headed by J.P. Shulman.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 (UP)-- Murry Dickson scored his nineteenth victory of the season as the Pirates beat the Braves today, 7--3. It was Dickson's sixteenth complete game and assured him of his best won-lost record since entering the majors in 1939.

A general election in Great Britain is always an important world event and this year it becomes doubly so. The announcement that one is to be held on Oct. 25 does not come as a great sur prise, for the internal situation of Britain, politically and economically, is critical.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 19-- Julian C. Harrison, a member of the New York law firm of Reiley, Harrison Reinhardt, died of a heart attack last night at the Ridgewood Country Club after speaking at a testimonial dinner there for J. Robert Stout, president of the new Valley Hospital.

Driftwood and draperies, a transparent chair and some chirping birds, television sets and teapots-- both in action--two monkeys playing in a cage and a chicken frying in a pot are among the attractions that will greet visitors to Grand Central Palace this week and next.

The graft conspiracy trial of eighteen police defendants collapsed yesterday in Kings County Court following the renewed refusals of the chief witness, Harry Gross, former head of a $20,000,000-a-year gambling enterprise, to testify against the defendants.

Robert Augustus Chambers of 33 East Seventieth Street, a partner in the law firm of Swiger, Chambers, Kelley Harragan at 60 East Forty-second Street, died yesterday at home after a long illness. His age was 56.
The Warren Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday the acquisition of the 25 per cent interest in the common stock of the Devonian Company held by the Gulf Oil Corporation.

As a result of renewed refusals by Harry Gross to testify against eighteen retired or suspended members of the Police Department, the state's graft conspiracy case against them collapsed at 4:16 P.M. yesterday with the dismissal of the indictment.
ROME, Sept. 19--In a speech delivered yesterday to a group of French parents, the Pope severely censured Roman Catholic authors of books, articles and other writings dealing with "sexual initiation."

Kenyon Nicholson's latest comedy, "Out West of Eighth," described as "an eastern-western," will have its premiere this evening at the Barrymore Theatre under the auspices of Courtney Burr and Malcolm Pearson.

There was sharp disagreement on the role of television in reporting criminal trials and Congressional investigations at a panel discussion before the criminal law division of the American Bar Association yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)-- The problems of importing Mexican farm labor are being threshed out in conferences by a group of Texans with Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin and Employment Service officials.

The Fifth Avenue Association said yesterday that it had protested to Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan against plans to hold the Columbus Day parade on the avenue from Forty-fourth Street north to Eighty-fourth Street beginning at 1 P.M.

The Froedtert Corporation, formerly the Froedtert Grain and Malting Company, Inc., had a record shipment volume and the second highest earnings in the fiscal year ended on July 31, Kurtis R. Froedtert, president and board chairman, reports in the annual statement issued today.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, unchanged to 9 points lower from Tuesday's final levels.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-- Threats of a city-wide hotel strike in Washington at 12:01 A.M. on Friday and a strike of 30,000 workers in the brass industry on Monday were reported today by the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 19--Governor Dewey admonished today that this country would lose "hundreds of millions" of potential allies against communism if it continued to try to force on other peoples its pet views on government, culture and democratic freedom.

The cornerstone for the fourstory Jamaica District Health Center, being built by the Department of Health at a cost of $1,250,000, will be laid in ceremonies at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Sept. 19 (AP)--Francis Ouimet, one-time boy wonder of American golf, became the first American captain of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews today as an antique cannon boomed out the traditional salute.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)-- The Federal Communications Commission refused today to amed the authority it granted to Western Union Telegraph Company last month to increase rates.

OTTAWA, Sept. 19--The North Atlantic Council called on its members tonight to reappraise their rearmament programs and established an Executive Bureau to produce an Atlantic rearmament balance sheet by Dec. 1.
Commodity markets drifted aimlessly yesterday. Vegetable oils and sugar were virtually stationary. Coffee gained, but principally in the nearby contracts. Cocoa and wool both declined moderately.

Assistant United States Attorney Earl N. Bishopp, a Republican, who has served under twelve United States attorneys, eight of whom were Democrats, receieved a certificate yesterday noting twenty-six years of service in the Department of Justice.

New issues of railroad and public utility securities totaling about $12,500,000 will be offered to investors today by investment banking syndicates, following their purchase at competitive bidding yesterday.
The S. M. Manufacturing Company sold the ten-story loft building on lot 45 by 90 feet at 9 and 11 East Nineteenth Street, between Fifth Avenue and Broadway, to a client of Herman Agen, attorney.

HONG KONG, Sept. 19--A Chinese Communist official was quoted today as having reported that 28,332 "counter-revolutionaries" had been executed in the province of Kwangtung over a tenmonth period ended Aug. 15.

Immediately after eighteen defendants had been discharged in King County Court yesterday, Miles F. McDonald, Brooklyn prosecutor, said he had official information that a $75,000 fund had been raised for Gross if he refused to complete his testimony.

BUFFALO, Sept. 19 (UP)-- Only eight pupils reported for classes at Publie School 26 today as a mothers club kept children home to protest against the city's refusal to authorize $215,000 for a new school.

American Airlines announced yesterday that it had signed a $35,000,000 contract with the Douglas Aircraft Company for thirty new-airliners that will add 37 per cent, to the line's passenger capacity and double the cargo space.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 19-- Four members of the Adelphi College faculty have entered into a strenuous program at the home of an associate here to prepare study and living quarters for three undergraduate students who will register at the school next Monday.
Rose and Sadie Zebrowitz have sold the five-story twenty-fourfamily, apartment house at 927 Grant Avenue, the Bronx, to Betar Associates, Inc., for cash above mortgages of $41,000.

Both the Senate and the House of Representatives have now overridden the President's veto of a new veterans' pension bill. We think that Mr. Truman's position in this matter is decidedly right and that the position of the majority of Congress is decidedly wrong.

Testimony indicating that bigtime bookmakers and gamblers on Staten Island enjoyed immunity from prosecution by both Democrats and Republicans exercising joint control of the District Attorney's office there was presented yesterday to the State Crime Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19--W. Averell Harriman, special foreign affairs assistant to President Truman, has notified Iran that he believes a settlement of the bitter British-Iranian oil dispute is "possible and feasible."
TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 20 (UP) --Following is the text of a message from North Korean Premier Kim II Sung and Chinese Gen. Peng Teh-huai, Communist army leaders as broadcast by the Peiping radio:

Heavy reliance on newspapers for the first time for all three of its brands, Lord Calvert, Calvert Reserve and Carstairs, was indicated yesterday at the Astor Hotel by Calvert Distillers Corporation.

SIXTEEN major league owners will assemble in Chicago today, faced with the weighty task of choosing a successor to Kenesaw Mountain Landis as baseball commissioner. If they were confronted by the job of naming a successor to Happy Chandler, it would be easy.

WASHINGTON, Sept.19--Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, a wartime commander of the China theatre, asserted today that had he followed his State Department political advisers "communism would have run rampant over China more rapidly than it did."

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 20--In another sudden turn in the see saw battle for the heights above Yanggu, on Korea's eastern battlefront, the North Korean Communists recaptured yesterday a towering hill that had fallen to Allied troops only the day after bitter fighting.

Negotiations between the Packing House Workers Union, A.F.L., and the Metropolitan Slaughterers Association of New York and New Jersey were in prospect yesterday after 800 members of Local 5 had voted a strike.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19--Wheat showed a stronger tone today, especially the deferred deliveries, while corn was weak on long liqui dation induced by the fine weather conditions now prevailing.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 19 (AP)--Spartan Valor, a homebred colt owned by William G. Helis Jr., romped home an easy winner in the sixth running of the $7,500 added Boardwalk Handicap at Atlantic City today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)-- The Bureau of the Census reported today that consumption of cotton for the period Aug. 5 to Sept. 1 averaged 37,706 bales for each working day.

GENEVA, Sept. 19--The British Government, through Sir Hartley Shawcross, President of the Board of Trade, gave the first inklings today of what it considers ought to be the common basis of international economic policy for the West after the period of intensive rearmament has ended.

Gimbels opened its new thirdfloor fashion department last night with a cocktail party and an informal fashion show for 900 apparel manufacturers and fashion reporters.
