An improved tube that receives television programs in both black and white and color without the need of any color wheel converter, and which can be mass- ...
This is the time of year when the neighbors sit down of an afternoon and reminisce about the summer's activities.
Slot-machine parking went into operation here yesterday, sixteen years after the first parking meters in the country were installed in Oklahoma City.
BARRIE, Ont., Sept. 20 (AP)-- William Henry Wright, prominent Canadian mining man and founder of The Toronto Globe and Mail, died today at the age of 75.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 20--The Giants' hopes of overtaking the Dodgers in the pennant race received a serious blow today when the Polo Grounders lost by 3--1 to the Reds. This defeat and the Dodgers' victory over the Cards dropped the Giants four and onehalf games behind the league-leadink Brooks.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 20-- The meeting at which the Queens County Bar Association was organized seventy-five years ago was reenacted here tonight by present members of that body.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30--The forthcoming atomic tests in Nevada preface the production by the United States of atomic weapons for use against enemy armed forces.

Carrie Munn, who presented her fall collection yesterday at 640 Madison Avenue, continues to favor suits with circle-wide skirts and tight little weskit jackets. The one exception was a slim black wool suit with rippling peplum jacket and flowing revers.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20--The American Hospital Association voted after a vigorous debate today to approve the Bolton bill for Federal aid to nursing education, provided several amendments were made.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)-- Two of Washington State's top political figures--Charles Hodde of Colville and Herbert M. Hamblen of Spokane--collided head on today before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The New York City Opera Company will open its fall season at the City Center on Thursday evening at 8:15 with a performance of Massenet's "Manon," the opera which the company introduced into its repertory last spring.
The nation's railroads have led the way half a century in their attention to safety, R.W. Brown, chairman of the executive committee and former president of the Reading Company, said here last night.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 20--A resolution calling upon this country to sever all diplomatic relations with Russia was approved unanimously today by delegates to the twenty-eighth annual convention of the Marine Corps League.
ABSECON, N.J., Sept. 20 (UP) --A government power expert warned today that some industrial users will have their electricity cut by the end of this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--Gen Jean de Lattre de Tassigny, French High Commissioner in Indo-China and Commander-in-Chief of French forces in the Far East, warned today that a defeat of French and native forces in Indo-China would mean the loss of Southeast Asia, and place the Communists in a position to spread as far as Africa.

Any city that permits racial discrimination in its hotels or community facilities was ruled out yesterday as a possible site for the permanent headquarters of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A.

William Gargan has signed a long-term contract with the National Broadcasting Company to produce and star in "Barrie Crane, Confidential Investigator." which will be presented on radio and television.

LONDON, Sept. 20--Officially under British law the electoral campaign that Prime Minister Attlee set in motion last night cannot begin until after Parliament is dissolved on Oct. 5. But, in fact, it began in earnest today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20--Weather developments again were responsible for a strong tone in the grain futures market today. Corn registered a substantial advance on the possibility of a sharp drop in temperatures while the wheat harvest was delayed by rains in western Canada.

The description of the pitiful plight of Iron Curtain refugees in Germany given in this newspaper must arouse shock and indignation. More than six years after the war we have still not evolved any technique for handling these refugees which meets even minimal standards of decency, humanity and enlightened self-interest.

ANOTHER season like this one and the tuna fishermen will trade in their heavy tackle for bluefish rigs, or concentrate their big fish hopes on the Nova Scotia fishing grounds, for the rod and reel catches out of United States ports have been extremely low.
It is time that the males of the earth shot a strong illuminating beam toward the lamps that light their homes, and take a clear look at just what is going on with those lamps.

PARIS, Sept. 20--A period of difficulties and friction between the United States and France and the other countries in Europe was foreseen today by the two chief officials of the Marshall Plan in France.
The twelve members of the North Atlantic Council approved a recommendation for the entry of Greece and Turkey into the alliance at the closing session of its Ottawa meeting yesterday.

Mrs. William Woodward and Mrs. Donald B. Tansill, co-chairmen of the Belmont Futurity Ball, a dinner dance to be given in the ballroom of the Plaza on Oct. 4 have made known members of their ball committee.

Many reservations have been made for the dinner dance to assist the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue, Inc., which will reopen the Rendez-Vous Room of the Plaza on Oct. 4 for the autumn and winter season.

In a century of publishing "All the News That's Fit to Print," THE NEW YORK TIMES, like other organs of a free press, has experienced the displeasure of factions and individuals with opposing points of view.

In a statement telephoned from Washington, Representative Henry J. Latham, Republican candidate for President of the City Council yesterday attributed Newbold Morris' support of Rudolph Halley to annoyance over not having received the Republican nomination Declaring that Mr. Morris had not been noted for loyalty to the Republican party, Mr. Latham said:

PARIS, Sept. 20--Over the objections of Premier Rene Pleven, the National Assembly voted by 410 to 203 today a bill instituting a sliding-scale system of determining a minimum wage in France. The bill now goes to the Council of the Republic.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 20 (AP)-- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi warned feuding members of Parliament today that Iran faced a delicate situation and appealed for harmony in serving the people.
Traffic moved briskly on 125th Street yesterday, and the newly installed parking meters between Seventh and Lenox Avenues had a good deal to do with it.

At a meeting yesterday the six national officers of the National Maritime Union, C.I.O., voted to pursue the union's contention that the wages of seagoing personnel were not within the jurisdiction of the Wage Stabilization Board.
BOSTON, Sept. 20 (AP)--A New York hospital superintendent said today it might be possible for him to live to be 115 years old if chronic diseases were wiped out.
BERLIN, Sept. 20--A new agreement on interzonal trade was signed here today by representatives of the West and East German Governments.

An exchange of poems in 1943 between Fiorello H. LaGuardia and Gelett Burgess, humorist who died Tuesday, proved that the Maybe "could dash off a few verses as easily as he could dash off to a fire," the New York Historical Society suggested yesterday.

A.D. Juilliard Co., Inc., has priced its spring 1952 woolen line, it was learned yesterday. Planateen suiting gabardine has been priced at $4.75 a yard, as against the previous price of $6.05 and preKorean price of $4.57 . Shadow tweed suitings are offered at $5.07 , compared with the previous price of $6.75, and Birdseye suitings at $4.87 , compared with $6.47. A line of sharkskin suitings is offered at $4.50, compared with $5.47.

The Atlantic Union Committee, which has been seeking a common ground of agreement with the United World Federalists, ruffled the feelings of the latter group yesterday when, in its annual report, it commented pointedly that the Federalists had suffered recent losses in membership, in financial support and in Congressional backing.
Asking who paid Harry Gross to wreck the Brooklyn graft conspiracy trial, Rudolph Halley called upon the New York State Crime Commission last night to make a full investigation and find the answer.
Cocoa, coffee and wool, prices strengthened yesterday in New York futures trading. Sugar and vegetable oils were lower.

THE NEW YORK TIMES received yesterday scores more of tributes and congratulatory messages from many parts of this and other countries marking the newspaper's centennial celebration. Excerpts from some of them follow:

After twenty-eight days of vituperative propaganda, consisting chiefly of repeated accusations against the United Nations, the Communists in Korea have indicated their willingness to resume the cease-fire talks.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20--The Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions today recommended that $2,035,400 be pared from Secretary General Trygve Lie's 1952 budget of $46,568,300.

No one takes credit in the program for the direction of "Out West of Eighth," which opened at the Ethel Barrymore last evening for a limited engagement. Marc Connelly, who began the direction, and Burgess Meredith, who finished it, are not taking credit in public for what they have done; and, as a matter of fact, they shouldn't.
Most notable in the collection of Revillon Freres furs, shown yesterday at the Fifty-seventh Street salon, was the emphasis on quality and the lack of the sensational.
READING, Pa., Sept. 20 (AP)-- Three players tied today for the first-round lead in the $15,000 Reading golf open tournament.
GUELPH, Ont., Sept. 20 (UP)-- The New York Rangers today obtained Center Paul Ronty from the Boston Bruins in exchange for Defenseman Gus Kyle and an undisclosed amount of cash.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 20-- Football for some years has not been in a flourishing state at Harvard, and that has been of concern not only to its undergraduates and alumni. Every one devoted to the welfare of the sport would be happier if the Crimson, with its rich traditions and great teams of old, figured more prominently among the leaders on the gridiron, at least in its own section.
WEST POINT, Sept. 19 (AP)-- The nation's colleges have rallied to absorb many of the ninety cadets dismissed less than two months ago in the cribbing episode at the United States Military Academy.

Acting Mayor Joseph T. Sharkey, Democratic candidate for President of the City Council, a post he now holds by succession to Mayor Impellitteri, announced yesterday the appointment of Henry Epstein, former State Solicitor General, as chairman of his campaign committee and Richard F. Maher as campaign director.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquencourt, France, Sept. 20--As part of the over-all program for speeding up the formation of Western defenses, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower is seeking a 33 per cent increase in European military production during the fiscal year 1952.
Declared that American foreign policy was aimed at creating enough strength in the free world so that Russia would not only keep peace, but would live up to any future agreements.

Viscount Jowitt, Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain, pledged last night that no matter what Government came to Britain, the British Commonwealth of Nation would stand with the United States "in resisting the most appalling menace that has threatened mankind in many centuries."

One of the few recent successful attempts to buy working control of a company on the open market was revealed yesterday. According to a letter to shareholders of the Warren Foundry and Pipe Corporation, Easton, Pa., Solomon E. Shahmoon, formerly of Baghdad, China, and Paris, is now in control.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--President Truman asked the Senate today to stiffen the pending tax increase bill to provide revenue "that approaches as nearly as possible the $10,000,000,000 I recommended."

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 21--Early resumption of armistice talks in the Korean war were regarded as a virtual certainty today. Both United Nations and Communist semi-official sources discussed the proposal of the Chinese and North Korean High Command for a renewal of sessions at Kaesong and the establishment of machinery to deal with violations of the neutral zone around the outpost city.

The faculty of the College of William and Mary has said some things about overemphasis of intercollegiate athletics that the student body, administration and particularly the alumni of most other American colleges would do well to ponder.

Unimpressed by the public declarations of war recently exchanged by top national officers of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, leaders of the two groups in this state sat down together yesterday and mapped joint legislative plans.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept, 20-- Organized labor was challenged today by Eric Johnston, Economic Stabilization Administrator, to "stockpile" trained leaders for Government emergency work on the "defense team."

OTTAWA, Sept. 20--Creation of an international rearmament fund within the framework of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is being studied by technical experts with instructions to report as soon as possible. The purpose of such a fund would be to provide immediate and long-term financing for member countries unable to meet defense costs out of current revenues.

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that 20,691 employes of the municipal transit lines would go on a forty-four-hour week and 5,684 on a forty-hour week, starting Oct. 1. The shift in hours will require the employment of 1,174 additional men and increases operating expenses an estimated $9,900,000 for the current fiscal year.

A special committee of the American Bar Association will be appointed to study the Equal Rights Amendment. This is in line with a recommendation of the resolutions committee made yesterday to the assembly at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--The Army today was expected to turn to foreign sources to fill its beef requirements after domestic packers offered to sell only 190,000 pounds. The Army had called for bids on 13,000,000 pounds.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--Senate-House conferees agreed today not to tie any strings on the $5,000,000,000 for the defense of Europe in the foreign aid bill.

The Board of Education adopted yesterday increased salary schedules that will give pay rises ranging from $6 to $250 to 12,980 of the city's 35,000 teachers beginning Oct. 1 and which by 1954 will bring all teachers on maximum salary to a new top of $6,500 a year.

The print collection of the Cooper Union Museum was recently substantially enriched through the generosity of Leo Wallerstein, who donated a discriminatingly chosen group of graphic works, chiefly by the sixteenth-century German masters and by Rembrandt.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 20 (AP) --Fast flying Tar Heel, 3-year-old pacing son of Billy Direct, today won the $66,280.55 Little Brown Jug in straight heats.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin said tonight that Israel was following the pattern of the United States in making increased production the foundation of a sound economic structure.

A dispute that has been smouldering between Sidney Kingsley, Pulitzer Prize playwright, who adapted "Darkness at Noon," winner of the Critics Circle garland, and Arthur Koestler, author of the anti-Communist book of the same name, is to be settled by arbitration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--The American Lithofold Corporation of St. Louis, whose $645,000 of Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans are under inquiry by the Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee, was said in sworn testimony today to have paid $65,878 in commissions, fees and expenses to four men in key Federal posts while they still were on the Government payroll.
Quick (no-kneading) breads are presented today, interesting loaves chosen with this in mind: That they add good looks and good flavor to the teatime table.

A proposal for a new $37,495,755 slum clearance housing project along Central Park West in Manhattan, to be known as Manhattantown, was received yesterday by the Board of Estimate and sent to the City Planning Commission for study.
New York's 579 air raid sirens will be sounded as a test for the last time at 11 A.M. today. From then on the three-minute warble will mean that an enemy attack is imminent.

OTTAWA, Sept. 20--Whatever changes may result from the British elections next month there is not likely to be any change in British policy in so far as the North Atlantic Treaty organization is concerned. Foreign Minister Herbert Morrison said today he did not think that any changes were likely.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20--A third possible instance of Communist infiltration into the councils of the Democratic party in California was explored today by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--The President at his press conference today expounded the major foreign policy of the United States which originated with his Greek-Turkish aid proposal, and his words were plain enough for anyone to understand.

The American bar must see to it that young and indigent persons in legal difficulties receive adequate counsel, or it faces the possible establishment of a Government-supported system of "public defenders," Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, declared yesterday.

"Considerable progress" was reported yesterday in an all-day negotiation session between representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L., and the New York Shipping Association, representing 175 steamship lines and employing stevedores.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 20-- On the eve of his departure for Teheran to take up his new post as United States Ambassador to Iran, Loy W. Henderson tonight asserted continued United States friendliness to India.
TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 21--The United States Marines landed a reinforced company on top of a high mountain northwest of Kansong in Korea yesterday by helicopter shuttle system.

The apartment house at 764 East 176th Street, the Bronx, accommodating forty-two families, has been sold by Regina and Miriam Seliger to a client of Saul Greenstein, attorney. Louis Aronson was the broker and Isaac Anolic was attorney for the sellers. The property occupies a plot 100 by 90 feet and is assessed at $142,000.

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 20-- A new Finnish coalition government was formod tonight by Premier Urho K. Kekkonen. It is his third cabinet. Like the outgoing one it is made up of seven Agrarians, seven Social Democrats, one independent and two Swedish party representatives.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--President Truman stood pat today on his nomination of two Federal district judges for Illinois, pigeonholed, by the Senate Judiciary Committee after Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, had invoked an unwritten Senate rule by declaring the appointments "personally obnoxious" to him.

American metal importers disclosed yesterday that Canadian producers of lead and zinc have withdrawn from the market here. No further offers are expected, they said, until some upward ad justment is made in ceiling prices. Such a supply amounts to 4,000 to 5,000 tons a month of each metal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24--President Truman drove to the National Airport tonight to tell Secretary of State Acheson that he had done "a magnificent job" at the North Atlantic Treaty Council meeting in Ottawa.

CONSIDERING the fact that he once had a deathly fear of horses, Bob Skene has come a long way. To be blunt about it, he's come as far as any man can. He is rated at ten goals in polo, a ranking that has one singular disadvantage. It leaves a fellow with no chance for advancement because ten goals is the norm of perfection and he can't climb any higher. The Matterhorn has been conquered.

Francis Randolph Mayer of 230 East Rockaway Avenue, Hewlett, L.I., a steamship line operator and yacht racing enthusiast, died yesterday at a Hewlett nursing home after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

Law enforcement agencies in Brooklyn rallied their forces yesterday for a more intensive investigation of gambling after District Attorney Miles F. McDonald had disclosed that Harry Gross once rejected $150,000 for his silence.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 20--Israel will offer tomorrow to sign nonaggression pacts with the Arab states, which are still technically at war with the Republic of Israel.

Three hundred fifty youngsters reaped a rich reward yesterday in their annual harvest festival on their mid-city farm at the Rockefeller Institute between Sixty-fifth and Sixty-eighth Streets and York Avenue and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20--Assistant Secretary General Benjamin A. Cohen is scheduled to go before a United Nations committee tomorrow to back up a statement of his Department of Public Information defending the right of correspondents here to file stories on all United Nations, activities, public and closed-door.

Harry Gross' contemptuous and contemptible refusal to testify against the police protectors of his multimilliondollar bookmaking syndicate is a bitterly disappointing anticlimax in the Brooklyn grand jury's investigation into the partnership between crime and some members of the New York police force.
To those whose chief interest in sports has been in the red-hot baseball race, it may come as a surprise that football sneaked past the local diamond curtain last night at the Polo Grounds.

Facing a two-run deficit in the last half of the eighth inning, the Yankees yesterday appeared about to lose their slender hold on first place in the American League flag race when, in the twinkling of an eye, 13,712 Stadium fans were tossed into a delirium of joy.

The new forward push by the stock market got a limited extension yesterday from strength in a long list of scattered issues. Developments of a corporate nature provided the main spurs behind some of the exaggerated increases for several of the stocks while the best group performance appeared in the railroads under the sponsorship of a sharp rise in Nickel Plate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--Capital outlays totaling $13,400,000,000 have been planned by American business for the last half of this year, according to a joint survey made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Office of Business Economics of the United States Department of Commerce.

Negotiators for the National Organization of Master, Mates and Pilots, A.F.L., and some forty East and Gulf coast ship operators met for the first time yesterday with officials of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. The two-hour session was called following the failure of the two factions to agree on the terms of a new contract. Their present agreement expires Sept. 30.

FASSBERG, Germany, Sept. 20 --It will be a surprise and perhaps something of a shock to a number, of men scattered around the United States, Britain and Canada watching their waistlines and hairlines to know that Johnny Johnson of the R.A.F. is back doing business at the old stand.

John A. Hartford, chairman of the board of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack in an elevator at the Chrysler Building. He was returning from a meeting of the board of directors of the Chrysler Corporation, of which he was a member. His age was 79.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20--Ford C. Frick, 56-year-old president of the National League, tonight was elected commissioner of baseball.
There is an understandable feeling from time to time that when the Council meets there should be a whole series of world-shattering decisions which are made.

THE two Old Testament heroes who appeal most strongly to popular imagination have always been David, the shepherd king, and Moses, the lawgiver. The Bible stories about them are unusually complete; but they are not so complete that men have not longed to know more.

If commuters on the Port Washington branch of the Long Island Rail Road are slightly late arriving at their destinations for the next few days, it will not be, in all probability, because of the more familiar mechanical difficulties. The reason--installation of a new automatic speed control system for increased safety.
Labor's unaffiliated left wing unions will meet soon to discuss unification, John Clark, president of the independent International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--A bipartisan group of six Senators asked President Truman today to sponsor arbitration in the more than two-year-old railroad dispute. The President indicated that he was favorably disposed toward the proposal.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday, and closing prices were 23 points higher to 14 points lower than on Wednesday.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 28-- In a thrilling match in which she seemed doomed to defeat, Mrs. William Tracy of Glen Ridge, the defending champion, rallied to eliminate Mrs. William Hockenjos of Baltusrol, 1 up, in 19 holes today in the semi-final round of the twenty-sixth annual Women's New Jersey State golf championship over the Montclair club course.
A wide variety of school 'improvements, ranging all the way from minor repairs to construction of the $33,051,470 Junior High School 123 in the Bronx, was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

New automobile prices based on the recent Office of Price Stabilization regulation permitting increases were announced yesterday by dealers in this city. The upswing, it was explained, was permitted on cars shipped from the factories of the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation after Sept. 15 and the General Motors Corporation after Sept. 19. In many cases accessories prices also are higher.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 20 (AP)--The president-elect of the State Medical Society Dr. Edward T. Wentworth of Rochester, said tonight that opposition by the medical profession to use of Federal funds for construction or expansion of medical schools was "completely illogical."

Walter Schleiter, executive vicepresident of Muller Phipps (Asia), Ltd., called on the Government of India yesterday to establish soon a central agency empowered to rule quickly on applications of American manufacturers seeking to set up their own Indian plants or to have their products turned out by Indian factories already in operation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a five-for-one split of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad Company's com mon stock. At the same time it approved replacement of present preferred stock, Series A, the new stock being issued under amendments to the Nickel Plate stock to make clear that preferred holders, whether or not required by law, have full voting rights share-for-share with holders of common on all matters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--President Truman declared today the foreign policy of the United States was aimed at creating sufficient strength in the free world to force the Soviet Union and its satellites not only to keep the peace but to honor their treaty agreements.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--Predicting a Democratic victory in the 1952 elections, President Truman asserted today that the Republicans were resorting to smear and misrepresentation because they were bereft of issues against an Administration that had produced a record level of prosperity.
My Dear Mr. Vice President: As the Senate begins debate on the 1951 tax legislation, I wish to emphasize the urgency of keeping the Government's finances on a sound basis. In particular, I

A retail price rise next week of as much as five cents a pound on stew and hamburger meat was foreseen yesterday, caused in part by black marketing in the cheaper cuts of meat. There will be, at the same time, a reduction in ceiling prices of sirloin steak and other choice cuts of beef.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 20-- Television has hurt the movies and it will hurt them even more in years to come, but ultimately there will emerge a reconstituted motionpicture industry which will be "stronger, healthier" and even "more profitable" than that which exists today, according to Samuel Goldwyn, the veteran independent producer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--The Senate Banking Committee, seeking to meet President Truman's objections to the new price control law, voted today, 9 to 4, to require at least some cost absorption by manufactures, processors and the sellers of industrial services.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 20-- Claude Harmon, Winged Foot Golf Club professional, overtook Pete Cooper of Century in the closing round of the Metropolitan open championship at the Forest Hill Field Club today and went on to win the title with a 72-hole aggregate of 275.

A woman who had testified before the State Crime Commission yesterday that she had seen District Attorney Herman Methfessel of Richmond County in the home of Mrs. Teresa Dalessio, mother of three Staten Island racketeers, on an occasion when roulette was being played there, was arrested on a charge of perjury later on the complaint of Mr. Methfessel.

ANDOVER, Mass., Sept 20-- Faced with another trying schedule that includes four college freshman teams, Steve Sorota, head coach of football at Phillips Academy, Andover, finds himself in an unusual situation. He has lost all his starters from the 1950 team and, after ten days of practice, is unable to determine his first-string eleven.

For a few days now we shall be having two ballet companies in town, for last night the Ballet Theatre returned to the Metropolitan Opera House to open its only New York engagement of the season, while the New York City Ballet is still dancing up at the City Center.

A stirring finish in the main and a sincere and warm trib ute to Jockey Teddy Atkinson were the notable occurrences at the Aqueduct track yesterday. The crowd of 18,034 was thrilled by the star event and Atkinson was equally thrilled by the occasion, called Ted Atkinson Day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--The House of Representatives passed a series of bills today raising the pay of more than 1,500,000 Government employes by a total of $670,045,600 a year. The rises run from a flat $400 a year for more than a million civil service workers to $800 for some postmasters.

"What is your favorite color?" is the decorating query around which four model room settings have been planned at Gimbels. Opening today, they have been designed to illustrate a magazine article by Faber Birren, color consultant, which will appear in the October issue of Better Homes and Gardens.

Many steel executives have been maintaining for some time that some steel consumers have been over-ordering--inflating their steel requirements. One such case came to light yesterday, but the surprising aspect was the fact that the military forces were the ones involved.

Francis Gordon Caffey, formerly for eight years a judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, died yesterday in his home at Verbena, Ala., after an illness of several months, at the age of 82. He retired in 1947. While here, he had lived at the Royalton Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--The Wage Stabilization Board attempted today to answer the question of how management and labor could bargain for wages when wages were controlled.

Establishing a record level for the third successive week, loans to business by New York banks advanced $62,000,000 last week to reach $7,191,000,000, another new high. The rise during the week ended on Wednesday, brought the expansion since the end of June to $373,000,000, compared with an increase of $827,000,000 during the similar period in 1950.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 20--The Democratic Chairman of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, Senator Pat McCarran of Nevada, raised questions today about the loyalty record of Ambassador at Large Philip C. Jessup and demanded "explanations" from him.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20 (AP) --The United States Government filed a $656,151 tax lien today against the Leblanc Corporation, patent medicine manufacturer (Hadacol).

The Board of Estimate granted to 10,800 employes of the Department of Sanitation yesterday the $250 cost-of-living bonus given on March 1 to 112,000 other city employes. The board authorized the issuance of $3,750,000 in budget notes to cover the expense. The notes must be redeemed out of tax funds for 1952-53.

WELLFLEET, Mass., Sept. 20-- Cape Cod fishermen convinced a group of Army colonels today that the best way to iron out difficulties arising from the establishment of an off-shore gunnery range was to discuss them in New England town meeting style.
GENEVA, Sept. 20--France put forward today a new proposal for reducing world trade barriers.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP)--Ford Christopher Frick vaulted into baseball from the newspaper business in 1934 to become director of the National League Service Bureau.
OTTAWA, Sept. 20--The North Atlantic Council today completed its work here by recommending that Greece and Turkey be brought into the North Atlantic Treaty system.

LONDON, Sept. 20--The stock markets here were gripped by election fever today as industrial shares shot up on expectation that the Labor Government would be defeated. Volume of business jumped 50 per cent over yesterday and almost doubled that of last Thursday.

The daring of a young German seaman-stowaway, who jumped from the motorship Anna Salen at 10:20 P.M. Wednesday off Ambrose Lightship in an unsuccessful attempt to slip into this country, was the chief topic of conversation among 1,126 student and teacher passengers as the ship docked here yesterday at 9 A.M.

TOKYO, Sept. 20 (AP)--Japan's leading conservative political organization--the liberal party--today said the recently concluded Japan-United States security treaty did not necessarily mean the rearmament of this nation.
OTTAWA, Sept. 20--In assessing what the seventh conference of the North Atlantic Council has accomplished, the departing dele gates assert that it achieved what it set out to do.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--The Bureau of the Census released its final 1950 figures today on the population of all incorporated places and unincorporated places of 1,000 or more in New York State.

The assembly of the American Bar Association adopted a resolution yesterday calling on Democi ats and Republicans to pledge their 1932 candidates for President and the Senate, if elected, to consult the association and to appoint "only the best qualified persons available" to the Federal bench.

Ground action along the Korean battlefront yesterday (Thursday) was heaviest in the East-central sector where United Nations forces encountered stubborn resistance from well-entreched enemy units up to regimental size in several bitterly fought engagements.

The Long Island Lighting Company is planning to raise $27,000,000 of new capital and to refund $14,500,000 of long-term debt through the issuance of new issues of common stock, preferred stock and first mortgage bonds.

"What I think of Senator Joseph McCarthy can hardly be put into words," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday in answer to a question put to her after an extemporaneous address at City College.

The Long Island Lighting Company is planning to raise $27,000,000 of new capital and to refund $14,500,000 of long-term debt through the issuance of new issues of common stock, preferred stock and first mortgage bonds.

"What I think of Senator Joseph McCarthy can hardly be put into words," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday in answer to a question put to her after an extemporaneous address at City College.

Despite heavier meat receipts last week, which totaled 1,500,000 pounds more than the average weekly arrival since Aug. 1, the City Department of Markets reports there is an uneven distribution of supplies both at wholesale and retail.

Mulberry Street in downtown Manhattan was the Via Roma last night from Canal Street to Spring. The sounds, the heady cooking odors, the color, the unbroken arches of naked electric lights and even the accents were strongly Neapolitan.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 21 Lawrence Lachman, treasurer of Bloomingdale's, was the winner of the Simon F. Rothschild Memorial Trophy in the New York City newspapers' golf tournament staged under perfect conditions today over the Century Country Club course.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 21 The latest and potentially the most dangerous Russian campaign to divert the West Germans from European integration by dangling the lure of national unity before them has had two important results the Russians must find comforting.

Governor Dewey yesterday superseded District Attorney Herman Methfessel of Richmond County in any proceedings related to the State Crime Commission investigation into crime and official corruption on Staten Island.
Chico Vejar had his first taste of defeat last night in a boxing career that had gone through thirty-two uninterrupted victories.

We warmly congratulate Commissioner Robert Moses and his Committee on Slum Clearance Plans on their Manhattantown project which would clear approximately six blocks on the upper West Side for redevelopment by a private builder.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 21 Brazilian marines are being dispatched to Maranhao to maintain order in that state, where civil war is threatened, the Navy Minister, Renato Guilhobel, said today.
READING, Pa., Sept. 21 (AP) Three par-breaking professionals tied today for the midway lead in the 72-hole $15,000 Reading open golf tournament at the Berkleigh Club.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 Unmindful that they had not won a game at Fenway Park this year after eight tries, the Yankees, behind the effective hurling of Allie Reynolds, neatly polished off the Red Sox, 5 1 today. This was the opener of a three-game series, which is to be followed by a set of five in New York next week.
Ford Frick's first twenty-four hours as commissioner of baseball were spent in an atmosphere of excitement.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 Assistant Secretary General Benjamin A. Cohen told delegates to a collective measures subcommittee today that they should make the "trend" of their discussions known to the press and that in the absence of volunteered information, correspondents had every right to try to find out what went on behind the closed doors.
Attractive pairings in every section of the country will mark the first big Saturday of the football season today.
A cornerstone ceremony was held yesterday for the new Jamaica District Health Center and Queens Borough office of the Department of Health at Parsons Boulevard and Jamaica Avenue.

Chinese delicacies already are becoming scarce as a result of they stricter embargo on imports from Red China that went into effect last Aug. 15. To most Americans, this means foregoing luxuries such as Lapsang Souchong, Keemun and jasmine teas and crystallized and preserved ginger.

The International Boxing Club, at the suggestion of the State Athletic Commission, will use for the first time in connection with a ring event in this city a new floor covering when Sandy Saddler boxes Willie Pep in defense of his welterweight title Wednesday night in the Polo Grounds.

ALBANY, Sept. 21 Representatives of more than 250 trucking companies announced today they have started action in the State Supreme Court challenging constitutionality of the state's new truck weight-distance tax, which is slated to go into effect Oct. 1.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21 There's no doubt in William Holden's mind about the future of his career. With still a year to go on a contract jointly held by Paramount and Columbia, Holden has worked out a new deal with Paramount which will run for fourteen years., beginning in October, 1952.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21--Robert J. Blauner, president of the American Lithofold Corporation of St. Louis, disclosed to the Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee today that Matthew J. Connelly, secretary to President Truman, had received a "goodwill" gift of an expensive camera from the company last Christmas. The subcommittee is investigating loans totaling $645,000 to the company in 1949 by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
GENEVA, Sept. 21 Britain was sharply criticized by Canada today for maintaining special luxury taxes on certain imported goods, contrary to the terms of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

Despite the belief of some of the citizenry that yesterday was the first day of autumn, it was summer both in fact and temperature readings. The mercury mounted to 81 degrees at 2:50 P.M. as strollers shed coats on the eve of the last day of the season.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 21 General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, in his first visit to Pennsylvania since his return from Japan, received a hero's welcome today from cheering crowds along the lower Lehigh Valley.

WOLFEBORO, N.H., Sept. 21 The Rev. Dr. Albert Edwin Keigwin, pastor emeritus of the West End Presbyterian Church in New York, died here tonight at his summer home after a brief illness. He was in his eighty-third year. His New York address was at the Union League Club.

Pope Talbot Lines felt for the first time yesterday the effects of the current organization drive by the Brotherhood of Marine Engineers, A.F.L., when pickets tied up the cargo ship P. T. Adventurer soon after she tied up at Green Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The revised consumers' price index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood still between midJuly and mid-August, but the old index series, which is used for cost-of-living "escalator" agreements negotiated for pay contracts, declined 0.1 per cent.

Four squad to company-size attacks repulsed in area north of Yonchon. United States task forces conducting armored raids along the Central Korean front encountered light to heavy enemy resistance from platoon to battalion size enemy groups employing anti-tank fire and mines and a heavy volume of mortar and artillery fire. Stubborn enemy resistance continued in areas northwest and north of Yanggu. Attacking United Nations forces secured high ground in area west of Kansong.
The season is over now, to all intents and purposes, and the country during week-ends is a quiet place.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Fifteen sponsors of Israel's $500,000,000 bond issue presented a plaque to President Truman today in "warm tribute" for United States economic aid to the fledgling state, and for his "firm espousal of the aspirations of the builders of Israel in establishing a free nation as a homeland for the oppressed."

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 22--Several allied tank columns, made up from armored units of three United States divisions, probed in many-pronged thrusts yesterday at Communist positions on the central front in Korea.

Ford Frick is now Commissioner of Baseball. We congratulate him on his succession to the post and wish him well. His election ends a search that began last December when the club owners failed to renew the contract of A. B. Chandler, then commissioner. Mr. Chandler had not been an unquali-...
The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange showed renewed strength yesterday and rose 18 to 34 points net higher, with near months faring best.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 The House Un-American Activities Committee, on the fifth day of local hearings on Communist infiltration of Hollywood, disclosed today that it knew details of a leftwing meeting here Aug. 17 at which counter-measures to the hearings were mapped.
Hugh Gaitskell, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, promised yesterday that Britain would surmount her present economic difficulties and play her full role in the North Atlantic Alliance.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 21 (UP) Syracuse University took advantage of several Temple miscues and forged an ironclad defense to open its sixty-third football season tonight with a 19-0 victory before 18,000 fans at Archibold Stadium.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 (AP) The Reserve Mining Company of Cleveland has awarded contracts for immediate construction of a $75,000,000 plant to process magnetic taconite ore at Beaver Bay, Minn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Announcement by the Air Force today that it is turning over $351,000,000 worth of machine tools to help break the nation's major bottle-neck was received with restrained enthusiasm by Defense Production officials.

The successful fall meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club at Aqueduct will come to a close today with a program headed by the $50,000-added Beldame Handicap. Scheduled for its thirteenth running as a stakes event for fillies and mares, the Beldame has attracted fourteen that will compete over the route of a mile and an eighth.

The installations of the Atlantic Division of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service have been undergoing a minute, comprehensive week-long inspection by a team of officers headed by Rear Admiral Lorenzo Sabin, Inspector General and Vice Commander.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 The forecast for frost in the western part of the Belt gave corn prices a further upturn this morning, but late in the day the forecast was revised to indicate freezing temperatures only in the extreme west, and the market reacted from the early tops.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan said today that all reasonable and available measures would be utilized to help producers receive a "fair price" for cotton. In a letter to Representative Abernethy, Democrat of Mississippi,...

A review of the week's accomplishments at Ottawa, where the Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization met, leaves a mixture of satisfaction and disappointment, hopes and doubts. One did not need to be told in advance that N.A.T.O. has a long way to go before it is a really efficient, powerful, smoothly running instrument for the defense of the West.

Profit taking struck the stock market yesterday and returned prices to the level of early last week. While the railroad section exhibited a certain amount of strength, the remainder of the pivotal issues came under pressure. Selling never reached major pro-...
Commodity markets were quiet yesterday. Volume was down in futures with the exception of coffee, and prices moved irregularly.

PARIS, Sept. 21 After passage today of two disputed bills that provide financial aid for France's Roman Catholic schools, Premier Rene Pleven failed in his efforts to have Parliament adjourn until after the local elections next month.

LONDON, Sept. 21 Buying of industrial securities on the hope that the Labor Government would lose the election became much more selective today. The pace slackened and there was considerable profit-taking with the result that losses probably outnumbered...

CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 (UP) The latest find in northern Ohio's mastodon boneyard is a well-preserved 15,000-year-old tusk, the Cleveland Natural History Museum reported today. William Scheele, director of the museum, said the ten-foot-long tusk found south of here near Willard, Ohio, was in excellent condition.

BUFFALO, Sept. 21 (AP) The International Union of Electrical Workers, C.I.O., today urged legislative action to render harmleess what it called "the unprincipled hysteria-mongering of the Senator McCarthys and McCarrans."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming, opened a drive in the Senate today for a $600,000,000 increase in excess-profits taxes.
JENNINGS, La., Sept. 21 (AP) The United States Government's top oil expert hinted broadly today that gasoline and oil rationing may be necessary next winter unless petroleum output is increased.

Rayon yarn manufacturers, weavers, retailers and consumers indicated their approval yesterday of the revised trade practice rules of the rayon and acetate textile industry. Representatives of individual manufacturers and trade groups, speaking at the final hear-...

For the first time in nearly three years, Bishop James P. DeWolfe of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island will make a visitation to the Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, at 8 P. M. tomorrow.

OTTAWA, Sept. 21--The body that met here this week is already referred to simply as the Atlantic Council. The name may be an augury of things to come, for in this conference the Council took on the character of the permanent executive of a permanent organization.

In seeking to make more workable the Defense Production Act, the Senate Banking Committee has wisely voted to eliminate a rider that imposed severe new import limitations on cheese. Just what cheese has to do with national defense we leave it to Representative Andresen and his colleagues to try to explain.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 21--Three men confessed to Acting Westchester County Judge John P. Donohue here today that they assaulted William F. Cordon Jr., 29 years old, of 293 North Broadway, Yonkers, in Moray's Restaurant on South Broadway, Yonkers, in the early morning of March 28, 1950. Mr. Condon, a Yonkers attorney, is a son of State Senator Condon of Westchester.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 21 With American productive ability we can have a strong defense as well as civilian economy, and at the same time advance the standard of living, Arno H. Johnson, vice president of J. Walter Thompson Company, asserted here today.

Municipal workers throughout the city, as well as the pupils and other personnel of the city's 847 public schools, joined yesterday in the last regularly scheduled air raid siren tests to be held here. From all parts of the city word came that the drills were a success, with only five of the 579 sirens failing to sound.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21--Queen Juliana of the Netherlands appealed today to President Truman to take the lead in a new international effort to assist in the care and resettlement of refugees after the International Refugee Organization goes out of existence.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., Sept. 21 Railroad and communications officials met with townsfolk in this hamlet this afternoon to mark the 100th anniversary of the first transmission of a train operation order by telegraph.
Bay City, Mich., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Oct. 9 on $5,700,000 of general obligation bonds dated Nov. 1, 1951 and due Nov. 1, 1952 to 1981.
Ballet Theatre last night restored to its active repertoire at the Metropolitan Opera House its lavish production of "Princess Aurora," which has been out of service for several seasons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Industry members of the Wage Stabilization Board said today that the increase in overtime pay allowed by the board to three maritime unions this week "violates not only the rules but the spirit of stabilization."

Emanuel Shinwell, Minister of Defense in the British Labor Cabinet, used the Cunard liner Queen Mary yesterday as a springboard to launch his campaign for re-election in the Oct. 5 parliamentary campaign.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio. Sept. 21 (AP) An acute shortage of copper has shut down the Falcon Bronze Company's copper casting department and is seriously threatening iron and steel production here.
The British Navy, represented by the cruiser Superb and the frigate Snipe, docked at Pier 90, North River, yesterday with a touch of modernity that would have startled Admiral Lord Nelson.
The Rev. Dr. Howard William Hintz, minister of Old Spring Street Presbyterian Church, at Varick Street, will preach at 11 A.M. tomorrow commemorating the church's 140th anniversary.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 21 (UP) Scientists who spent the summer digging up Abraham Lincoln's back yard reported today that they had unearthed evidence of three "lost" outbuildings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Representative Ernest Greenwood, Democrat of New York, filed a brief today with the Clerk of the House of Representatives asking dismissal of the contest against him by W. Kingsland Macy, former Republican Representative.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UP) Four Senate Republicans introduced a new price control bill today that would go even further than the present law in forcing the Administration to raise ceilings whenever labor costs increased.
The Garage Realty Company was co-broker in the recent sale of the property at 211-15 West Street and 207-15 Franklin Street.
I am very glad to have the opportunity of addressing such a distinguished American audience on one of the most vital of our problems, the impact of rearmament upon Britain's economy.

One of the Jones boys made the Dodgers' homecoming a bit on the miserable side at Ebbets Field last night. This Jones, sometimes called Willie, sometimes Puddinhead, socked a grand slam homer in the first inning for the blow that led to a 9-6 triumph for last year's champion Phils.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) Civil defense leaders of thirty-two states urged Federal agencies to-day to give them more information on how to protect the home front: The state representatives adopted resolutions that suggested the following things:

The one-story factory at 10-14 Forty-seventh Road in Long Island City Queens, occupied under lease by the Carrier Corporation, has been sold by the Penford Realty Company to the Maltom Corporation. Edward Quiz and the C. Grant Keck Organization were the brokers.
BOSTON, Sept, 21 (UP) Pitching precision passes behind a stone wall line, Dickie Davis paced Wake Forest to a 20-6 victory over Boston College tonight before 20,587 fans.

DO novelists take characters directly from what is indulgently known as real life? More often than not they don't, exactly: they take, as they like to say, a bit here and a bit there. Thus one friend, or former friend, of the novelist may supply a character's fiscal and moral policies; another, merely a preening way of entering a room.

Although taxes took $5,225,000 more than in the year before, the Timken-Detroit Axle Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday an increase of $1,815,401 in net profit for the fiscal year ended on June 30. The net was $5,548,274, compared with $3,732,873 in the preceding year.

Unexpected opposition by a lone delegate to a "peace" resolution calling for an immediate cease-fire and armistice in Korea enlivened the final session yesterday of the convention of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, independent.

Dr. Andreas Nils Rygg, former co-publisher and editor of the Nordisk Tidende, a Norwegian-language newspaper published in Brooklyn, died yesterday in the Norwegian Hospital. Brooklyn, after a brief illness. His age was 83.

A policeman's wife had her shopping plans rudely upset yesterday, but she got instead an unrivaled chance to show an interest in her husband's work and watch him subdue a fleeing bandit after a nine-block chase through midManhattan streets.

In a deal for cash over a mortgage of $750,000, the Plaza Hotel at 91 Sip Avenue, in Journal Square, Jersey City, N.J., has been sold by Isaac and Philip Gershonowitz in a deal negotiated by the David Jaret Company, Brooklyn real estate brokers.
The Greenwich Village, Harlem and Dyckman areas were covered in realty transactions reported in Manhattan yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent over the week ended Sept. 18, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index, 176.7 per cent of the 1926 average, was 12.6 per cent above the pre-Korean (May 24-June 25, 1950) average and 3.8 per cent above the level of a year ago.
LONDON, Sept. 21 Efforts are being made by Labor party leaders to prevent the breach caused by Aneurin Bevan's attacks on government policy from imperiling Labor's chances in the elections Oct. 25.

ROME, Sept. 21 Pope Pius XII imparted today a special apostolic blessing "from the bottom of our heart" on the City of New York and its citizens and to Mayor Vincent Impellitteri personally to assist him in administering the complicated affairs of the city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner has recommended that the New York Central Railroad give the Peoria and Eastern Railway a larger share of the revenues collected from their joint business.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Moving quickly after the return of the United States delegation to the North Atlantic meetings in Ottawa, President Truman assigned W. Averell Harriman and General of the Army Omar N. Bradley today to prepare the way for the earliest inclusion of Turkey and Greece in the treaty.

John T. Danaher, vice president of the American President Lines, Ltd., in charge of its Eastern division passenger sales and service, died of a heart attack here yesterday. His age was 57. He resided at 161 East Seventy-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 President Truman decided tonight to certify to the Wage Stabilization Board a pay dispute in the copper and brass fabricating industry. About 30,000 employes represented by the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., were set to strike on Monday. It is expected the union will call off the scheduled walkout in view of the President's decision.

Miss Sheila Ann Morrisey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William George Morrisey of 200 East Sixtysixth Street, was married yesterday afternoon to Ian Leslie Potter, son of Mrs. Ruth Hewett Potter of Brockton, Mass., and Leslie Stephen Potter of London, in the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church Parish House.

TOKYO, Sept. 21 The Japanese Government has begun to establish the mechanism for the formal discussions of reparations payments that it agreed to make if possible under the terms of the San Francisco peace treaty. While it is not certain that considerable, if any, compensation will be available to countries wrecked and looted by the imperial armies, Japan is now ready to negotiate the matter.

HONG KONG, Sept. 21 The Peiping radio said tonight, "a young American atomic scientist" named Joan Chase Hilton was now in China working with her American husband on "an animal breeding farm" in Inner Mongolia.
Shorn of the world middleweight championship after one of the shortest reigns in ring history, Randy Turpin sailed yesterday aboard the liner Queen Mary for his native England.

More than 300 founders of the Washington Pilgrimage of America Churchmen will hear an address at 8 P.M. Friday by President Truman at the National City Christian Church in Washington. They will attend a three-day session.

Peace on Atlantic Coast docks for the next two years seemed assured yesterday as the existence of "a settlement pattern" was reported between representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L. and employing stevedores.
HONG KONG, Sept. 21--Communist authorities have rounded up more than 400,000 persons in South China in the last twenty-three months, according to Canton's official South China Daily News.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) The Army, balked at buying beef in the United States to supply American troops overseas, decided today to buy it in foreign markets, but it ruled out the Soviet bloc.
A group of farmers from Nebraska, Iowa, Kansas and South Dakota came to town yesterday on a self-financed tour arranged by Station WOW of Omaha.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 22--United Nations Headquarters remained silent again today on the proposal of Kim II Sung, North Korean Premier, and Chinese Gen. Peng Teh-huai that the conferences for an armistice in the Korean war be resumed at Kaesong with new machinery to investigate alleged violations of the neutral zone around the city.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 21 Intensifying their fight against noise resulting from the arrival and departures of aircraft at Newark Airport, the mayors of communities in the Elizabeth-Newark area adopted a plan of attack today at a conference at the Union County Court House here.
GREAT LAKES, Ill., Sept. 21 (AP) Lou Diamond, one of the United States Marine Corps' most famous fighting men, died last night at Great Lakes Naval Hospital. His age was 61.
Columbia University canceled its opening 1951 football game with Princeton University yesterday because two members of the Columbia team were believed to have contracted poliomyelitis.
Steel warehouse executives expect Government action soon to improve inventories of carbon steel products early in 1952, it was disclosed here yesterday in a canvass of the trade.

As acknowledged and anticipated in Governor Dewey's budget message last Jan. 30, New York State's debt increased considerably in the fiscal year ended March 31, 1951. The State Controller's annual report puts the total debt on that date at $736,240,183, an increase of $55,200,000 in a year.

LAWRENCE, L.I., Sept. 21 Beverley Randolph Robinson, a former New York political figure and a member of the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hope Hadley, died today at his summer residence here. His age was 75.

THE vanguard of the fall striper migration season has made its first sweep along the beaches from Jones Inlet to Montauk Point, with the bass right in the surf at several points, but such is the nature of this fish that tomorrow may find these schools off Martha's Vineyard of Block Island.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 A.B. Chance Company of Centralia, Mo., filed a registration today for 50,000 shares of its $5 par common stock now held by certain "selling stockholders."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UP) New York State will never get to operate the proposed Niagara Power project under terms of the pending Lehman-Roosevelt Bill, Chairman John E. Burton of the New York Power Authority declared today.

Elimination of the present system of assigning about 400 members of the Police Department to plainclothes duty appeared probable yesterday after a Brooklyn conference among Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan, Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz and District Attorney Miles F. McDonald.

Dr. Raphael A. Bendove of 19 Maple Avenue, Cedarhurst, L.I., a diagnostician who specialized in chest and heart ailments and internal medicine, died yesterday at his home of a coronary thrombosis. His age was 54.

Civil Defense Director Arthur W. Wallander made an inspection tour yesterday of installations of the 102d Anti-Aircraft Brigade, that guards the metropolitan area against the threat of enemy air raids.

GENEVA, Sept. 21 The Economic and Social Council of the United Nations completed its thirteenth session today about one week behind schedule. The session was devoted mainly to the "economic" half of the Council's broad interests.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 (AP) Jackie Collum made his entry into major league baseball an impressive one tonight as he set down the Cubs on a two-hitter to give the Cardinals a 6-0 victory.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 21 Mrs. J. Joseph Mason of Ridgewood won the Women's New Jersey State Golf Championship today by defeating Mrs. William Tracy of Glen Ridge, the defending titleholder, 5 and 4, in the thirty-sixhole final of the twenty-sixth annual tournament over the hilly Montclair Club course.

People who missed "Carmen' Jones" when it was produced in New York in 1943 still have a chance to repair that fracture in their culture today and all next week at Lambertville, N. J. St. John Terrell, ring-master of the Music Circus there, has put it on as the last production of the season in a well-sung performance that is remarkably enjoyable.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) Senator Allen J. Ellender Sr., Democrat of Louisiana, said today newspapers in this country were too big and he cited THE NEW YORK TIMES as an example.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 (AP) How many surgical operations are unwarranted? How many deaths are avoidable? Do patients who are seriously ill get the correct treatment?

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 21 A series of gas main explosions, cracking like thunderclaps at minute intervals, demolished thirty homes and damaged fifty others in a forty-block area of suburban Brighton today during a terrifying four-hour period.
The American Bar Association adopted a program of long-range objectives yesterday for the defense of American democracy and world peace. Its six points follow:

The latest Callot Soeurs collection was viewed yesterday in the salon at 42 East Fifty-seventh Street. Exquisite fabrics in designs that had a pleasing, easy grace were used in styles ranging from casual separates to formal gowns.

Thomas E. Stapleton has been appointed Eastern district finance representative for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, succeeding Jerome Hoag Jr., who has been named assistant to the New York metropolitan district manager of the television-radio division.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 Without discussion and without a negative vote, the annual convention of the American Federation of Labor amended the A.F.L. constitution today, increasing the per capita tax from member unions to bring an additional $1,000,000 into the treasury next year.
Courtney Burr and Malcolm Pearson, producers of "Out West of Eighth," have decided to close the Kenyon Nicholson comedy after tonight's performance, the fourth, at the Barrymore Theatre.
Classes for homemakers ranging from family budgeting to cabinetmaking begin in the next few weeks at local colleges and institutions.

MOUNT HERMON, Mass., Sept. 21 Football squads at the Mount Hermon School lost only once in each of the past two campaigns. Now, with only one first-flight veteran returning, Coach Bill Rineer is wondering whether he can whip up a formidable combination in time for the season's opener.

LONDON, Sept. 21 King George, who is suffering from an unspecified lung disease, will undergo an operation in the near future. In the absence of precise information the operation is considered a serious matter and the British public plainly is concerned.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 21 Under Dr. Eddie Anderson, Holy Cross last year started on the road back to a place in the football sun after the most disastrous season ever experienced by the Purple.

"The Autobiography of an Unknown Indian," by Nirad C. Chaudhuri, journalist and radio commentator of Delhi, will be published by Macmillan on Oct. 30. It is a personalized account of the changes in the social, cultural and political life of India and how they have affected the individual.

New York dealers in English antiques are scouring sources in England for increasingly scarce goods of quality. They are in lively competition with English dealers and collectors in a market that is higher than it has ever been.

DETROIT, Sept. 21 As 10,146 spectators at Briggs Stadium hooted in derision, the Indians frittered away a five-run lead and a 7-6 decision today to the Tigers. This defeat dropped the second-place Clevelanders one and one-half games behind the Yankees and increased their deficiency in the losing column to three games.

A bizarre story in which a 30year-old porter, employed by a Brooklyn department store, said he had been beaten, kidnapped and robbed of $49,000 by one, two or three men in blue uniforms, was recounted yesterday by Brooklyn police officials.

The first scheduled airline service between the United States and Europe at tourist-class rates will be started next April 1 by Pan American World Airways. The fare will be between $225 and $250, the airline announced here and in London yesterday.
Hicksville has regained its position as a leading residential building center of Long Island.

RETAIL sales figures now available tend to indicate that fall trade is getting off to a slower start than had been anticipated. Confidence continues in the outlook for the fall as a whole, and in the likelihood of holiday and Christmas trade volume that will surpass last year's peak. But the comparisons with a year ago continue on the minus side so far.

NEWARK, Sept. 22 The initial moves in a widespread reorganization of the Police Department here were made today by John B. Keenan, Director of Safety. The most important change was the appointment of Lieut. Arthur A. Weller, head of Mr. Keenan's confidential squad, to the post of Police Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Mrs. Frances Oliver Barry Dickey, daughter of Mrs. David Sheldon Barry of Washington and the late Colonel Barry, U.S.M.C., was married this afternoon to Peter Ladd Gilsey of Washington, son of Mrs. Gardner Ladd Gilsey of Southampton, L.I., and the late Mr. Gilsey, in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Georgetown.

VIENNA, Sept. 22 Austria has received with mixed feelings the news that the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France are to consider ways of reviving the Austrian treaty negotiations.

A sufficient supply of nickel, copper and brass is available for fall lines of men's' jewelry, but items for spring, 1952, now being produced, will use mostly "precious" metals, trade sources said last week. An increase in price is expected to result from this conversion. Platinum, silver and gold alloys are likely to be used in many instances.

LONDON, Sept. 22 Prime Minister Attlee urged the Scottish labor party at its annual conference at North Berwick today to close ranks against the Conservatives.

Because of the deferred opening of "Love and Let Love," the trustees of the Kips Bay Boys Club have taken over in its place the evening performance on Oct. 16 of "Glad Tidings" at the Lyceum Theatre as their annual benefit.

Robert Taylor Geyer, A.U.S., son of Mr. and Mrs. Linwood H. Geyer. The Rev. Dr. Robert Wells Youngs performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Scarsdale Golf Club.

Nearly 200 pints of blood for the wounded in Korea were donated to the American Red Cross yesterday at the Fltabush Branch of the Lincoln Savings Bank, Church and Nostrand Avenues, Brooklyn. Bank employes, as well as passers-by attracted by loudspeakers, were among the donors.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The State Department issued an informal but blistering denial today of protests by Czechoslovakia against the treatment of passengers aboard a Czechoslovak train that made an unscheduled dash for freedom into the United States zone of Germany eleven days ago.

A "retirement village" which may eventually contain nearly 6,000 small concrete houses has been started by two former New York builders near Homestead, Fla., twenty miles south of Miami.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 22 The marriage of Miss Cynthia Jean Haws, daughter of Mrs. Henry Ernst Haws of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Haws, to Glen Barkalow Miller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller of Bronxville, took place this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection. WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Officials of the Office of Price Stabilization conceded this week that a poll of public opinion would show their agency's popularity had plunged sharply in recent weeks. The agency, which was created to "hold the line" against inflation and prevent a rising spiral of prices, has had little to announce these days but price advances.

One of the keenest ping feuds of boxing history and, because of changing times, one of the richest, undergoes its fourth installment Wednesday night in the Polo Grounds, when Sandy Saddler, Harlem's holder of the world featherweight championship, risks his title against the ex-champion, Willie Pep of Hartford, Conn., in a bout scheduled for fifteen rounds.

Bourguiba formerly had connections with the Axis powers.

What has grown into size and prominence since the war as one of the leading speed boat regattas of the season will be continued next Sunday and Monday on the Ohio River at New Martinsville, W.Va. A special feature this year will be the national championship of the seven-litre class.

At many educational conferences held in the past year, the question has frequently been debated: Shall the Government subsidize our colleges and universities? The funds granted to the colleges up to now have been indirect, to be sure; but the amounts are staggering, nonetheless, and the implications are farreaching.

News of significant experimental results in preserving foodstuffs at room temperature over a long period of time with atomic radiation comes from the University of Michigan's Engineering Research Institute. The atomic bombardment does not make food radioactive but sterilizes it by killing bacteria. The university scientists are trying to find practical industrial uses for gross fission products, the waste produced when uranium-235 or plutonium is made for bombs.

The seventy branches and subbranches of the New York Public Library system will be directed, beginning Oct. 1, by a librarian who emphasizes the importance of public libraries as vital community educational agencies.

THE domestic airlines of the United States are winding up the best summer season they have ever had. Exact figures are not yet available, but almost all of the scheduled lines report more passengers in the summer just ended than last year. Some of the lines report that the usual September slump in traffic has not been nearly so sharp as in years past.

LONDON, Sept. 22 From dawn to dark today Britons of every age and walk of life gathered before the iron railings of Buckingham Palace to await with sympathetic anxiety news of King George VI. THE collection of work by European masters of the first half of this century at the Sidney Janis Gallery is not large but it should excite enthusiasm. Nor are they of jaded appearance from having been over-exhibited.

BERLIN. UNLIKE most festivals that draw audiences as well as artists from out of town, Berlin's September festival is being performed primarily for inhabitants of this outpost city behind the Iron Curtain. Since relatively expensive airlines provide Berliners with the only route completely free from Soviet controls to the rest of the Western world, most of them simply stay at home year in, year out.

The first pension law for U.S. veterans, passed by Congress in 1818, gave all Revolutionary War officers $20 a month for life and enlisted men $8. JUST about any plant can be transplanted at any time of year by an experienced gardener or professional nursery man. The wise home gardener, however, will try to choose a time when natural conditions are most favorable for the particular type of plant. Right now is one of the most opportune times to move or set out evergreens.

Two Columbia University football players were definitely diagnosed yesterday as having poliomyelitis. The remaining members of the squad began a limited schedule of light training and underwent the first of what will be daily medical examinations.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 22 Yale opened its eightieth football season today and came through its "breather" against Bates College with little exertion. The score was 48 0, the Elis dominating the contest from the outset as they tallied at least twice in three of the four periods.

WHEN the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe meets at Strasbourg next month six stamps in three designs will be issued by Luxembourg in commemoration. "United Europe" will be the theme, in association with economic and social progress, with human rights and with peace.

The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is one of the most extensive and potentially formidable alliances the world has ever seen. It stretches from Norway's North Cape to the Mediterranean shore, and embraces the two great powers of the North American continent. Its total population is 341,000,000. Among its members are the world's most highly industrialized nations, which control the major share of the world's strategic materials.

THE announcement the other day that New Stages had acquired Edward Caulfield's "The Idea" served as a reminder that the erstwhile Bleecker Street organization had never really succumbed following its production failures downtown or the wrangling that took place within the ranks and brass.

Today is the first day of autumn. Elm and ash trees look more brown or yellow than green, and scarlet branches call attention to the red maples. In the garden the rich hues of dahlias are testimony of sunny days and cool nights. Annuals are blooming more profusely than in summer, but the chrysanthemums are slower to indicate the season.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 22 The marriage of Miss Beverly Arlette Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy W. Campbell, to Albert Luscombe Foster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh F. A automatic buffet, a bank of five coin-operated food service machines that can dispense an entire light meal, is being tried out by the Pennsylvania Railroad as a supplement to regular dining car service. The machines have been installed at one end of a coach on a New York to Washington train, where their operation and passenger response to them will be tested for a month.

GERANIUMS set out in the garden or window box in early summer are now a mass of color; in fact, they are probably flowering better than they were two months ago. Chances are, too, that they have grown into tremendous plants. What to do with them so that they will live over for another year is a decision that must be made before frost.

ALBANY, Sept. 22 "Steady progress" in construction was reported today by the State Thruway Authority, which estimated that the super-highway from New York to Buffalo to the Pennsylvania border would have one-fourth of its 535 miles completed or under construction by March 31.

MAMARONECK N.Y., Sept. 22 Pete Smillie of New York, the defending champion, and Jack Marcato of Larchmont gained the final of New York Athletic Club's thirty-ninth golf championship tournament over the west course at Winged Foot today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 22 The electors of Australia in a referendum rejected today the request of the Government of Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies for power to outlaw the Communist party. The margin was about 153,000 votes.

Reorganizing and enlarging an interfaith committee of clergymen to cooperate with public officials in law enforcement and other civic problems was announced yesterday morning by Rabbi William F. Rosenblum at Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street.

Foreign developments held the attention of financial markets last week. CHICAGO, Sept. 22 An increase of about 5 per cent in meat supplies is in prospect for 1952, despite the uncertainties that are facing farmers.
