Industrial costs are steadily rising and the outlook is for a further increase in the fourth quarter, according to producers of durable goods who have participated in recent conferences with the National Production Authority in Washington.

AS September draws to a close, the annual fall foliage spectacle begins to spread through the woodlands of the northeastern states, starting in Maine and moving southward. It continues in full force until after mid-October, and with motorists planning trips of varying length to witness the color show, state tourist development boards and smaller...

THERE are still quite a few tricks left in the bag for those who wish to continue the fight against crabgrass. This persistent plant is still setting seed, and any treatment that reduces the quantity of seed formed is worthy of consideration.
HONG KONG, Sept. 22 Seventy million mou (11,600,000 acres) of autumn crops have been affected by drought, floods and insects in North China, according to recent domestic Chinese Communist dispatches.

For a group that never meets has no leader and no thought of taking concerted action on anything, the so-called "liberal Republican bloc" in Congress is a remarkably hardy phenomenon of Washington politics.
The life insurance and other savings of the American people are financing public works projects of Canada's provincial and city governments on a scale unmatched since long before World War II.

Despite some shortages of materials, manufacturers of the type of eating places known as diners are going ahead with programs for innovations to make them more profitable for operators and are planning to invade some areas heretofore avoided, it was learned last week.

The employe of May's Department Store in Brooklyn who told the police a bizarre story of how he had been beaten, kidnapped and robbed of $49,600 by men in blue uniforms, admitted last night that the fanciful tale hadn't a shred of truth in it. He was arrested on a charge of grand larceny after the stolen money was found in the basement of his home at 206 West 123d Street.
CARL Maria von Weber's Der Freischutz has not been presented at the Metropolitan Opera since the 1928-29 season, and to all intents and purposes it has dropped out of the American repertory.
DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 22 A 21-month-old black and tan Doberman pinscher, Ch. Rancho Dobes Storm, went to best in show today in the fifteenth annual event of the Ox Ridge Kennel Club.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 22 A month of festivities unprecedented for a new ambassador, no matter how close the friendship of two countries, was crowded last night for Baptista Luzardo, Brazil's new Ambassador to Argentina, with a dinner attended by President Juan Peron and most Argentine Government officials.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 22 (AP) Alabama voters who once wrote an anti-Negro amendment into their Constitution, then saw it knocked out, will decide soon on another approach to stricter requirements at the polls.

PARIS, Sept. 22 The optimistic statement made by the principal French delegates on their arrival here today from Ottawa did not conceal the fact that the French officials viewed the results of their negotiations as a prelude to new political fractions and to a desperate struggle with inflation in the months to come.

THE hero of Lonnie Coleman's third novel is a young novel ist at work on his second. His Roger Haynes suffers from an earnestness bordering on emotional coma, but not even his creator's really polished and sometimes poetic style can make us take Haynes' muffled musings seriously.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Fifteen Senators jointly announced today their participation in a movement for sharper tax increases than those provided by the pending $5,500,000,000 revenue bill.

Weakness in sterling forwards caused by heavy liquidations on rumors of possible devaluation highlighted the foreign exchange market during the past week. These reports carried over from the previous ...

Plans for the projected $3,934,000 vertical lift bridge across the east channel of the East River between Welfare Island and Thirtysixth Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, are being prepared for advertising of the contract by midOctober, the Department of Public Works said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--In a letter wishing President Truman "health and strength in shouldering the tremendous burdens ahead," former Vice President Henry A. Wallace has denied Republican charges of a Democratic "softness" to communism in Asia going back to the Roosevelt Administrations.
The United States, like so many of its individual citizens, is running out of money.

DETROIT, Sept. 23--Pennant talk among the Indians had dwindled to a discouraged whisper tonight following their third straight defeat at the hands of the Tigers. Red Rolfe's spoilers, going all out before 42,623 spectators in their final 1951 appearance at Briggs Stadium, gave Cleveland a sound thrashing. The score was 9 to 1.

With rain falling during the forenoon it didn't look as though there would be a game at all. However, when the drizzle let up shortly after 11 o'clock, the management opened the gates and the fans, a mighty hardy lot in this sector, came trooping in.

The Philadelphia Nationals, champions of the American Soccer League, opened the season yesterday by defeating the Brooklyn Hispanos, 2 to 1, at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island. The first half was scoreless, the Hispanos forcing a corner at twenty minutes and the Quakers five minutes later.

Formal discussions in Washington with Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny, commander in Indo-China, were concluded on Saturday, says the official announcement, "in an atmosphere of cordiality and unity of purpose."

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 23--A plan for a tobacco organization to unite the world's third largest industry is being worked out by 600 delegates from forty-three countries attending the first Tobacco Congress here.

The man behind the deal whereby Paramount last week acquired film rights to the life story of the Duncan Sisters is Richard Bare, who had spent more than three years preparing the original story about the famous entertainers of yesteryear and clearing the necessary rights.

A huge black market in meat was described yesterday at a meeting of 600 retail butchers who demanded to know when the city would start enforcing the Sharkey price control laws, which Mayor Impellitteri signed a month ago.

BERLIN, Sept. 23 (UP)--Hein Ten Hoff of Germany used his long left jab and right smashes to the body to win the European heavyweight championship from Jack Gardner of England today on a fifteen-round decision at Waldbuehne Stadium.

The engagement of Mrs. Alice Blue, daughter of Walter Blue of 118 East Fortieth Street, and the late Mrs. Blue, to Myron J. Nadler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Nadler of Youngstown, Ohio, has been announced by her father. The wedding will take place here in November.
The Spring Street Presbyterian Church began a three-day celebration of its 140th anniversary yesterday morning. The Rev. Dr. Howard ...

ANNE CRONE, the Belfast schoolteacher whose first novel, "Bridie Steen," aroused so much critical enthusiasm three years ago, particularly in the "Books of The Times" column, has a new novel out today.
ALBANY, Sept. 23--The State Banking Department has announced that Richard E. Speagle of New York City has been appointed chief of the division of research and statistics.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 23-- When you're riding against a middle-of-the-line-up polo combination such as Bob Skene and Cecil Smith, the country's only two ten-goalers, you must expect trouble.

With a retrospective of paintings by James Ensor, early Belgian modernist, opening on Wednesday, the Museum of Modern Art puts forth its first major effort of the new season. Another great European artist, Lehmbruck, the German ...
DENVER, Sept. 23 (AP)--Tony Bettenhausen of Tinley Park. Ill., won a 100-mile AAA national championship auto race at Centennial Park today and sewed up the 1951 driver championship.

This is the second of six columns based on "The Low Calory Cookbook," by Bernard Koten, to be published next February by Random House. The series, which appears on successive Mondays, will offer next week Mr. Koten's recipes for attractive desserts that are both flourless and sugarless.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Oliver F. Wadsworth of 7 Gracie Square, and Lloyd Neck, Huntington, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter Susan to Ensign Francis T. P. Plimpton Jr., U. S. N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Plimpton of 1165 Fifth Avenue and West Hills, Huntington.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--In a move to increase the tax yield, Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, proposed today to limit tax deductions for business entertainment and travel, to reduce opportunity for "high living at public expense."

ZURICH, Sept. 23--More than 250 bankers met at Locarno over the week-end at the annual rally of the Swiss Bankers Association to exchange views on the best way to tackle the crucial problems now troubling the international banking business.
Confronted by serious financial problems, American colleges and universities have opened their new academic year with an enrollment loss of 250,000 students. The institutions of higher learning ...

The assembly of the American Bar Association adopted a significant resolution last week. It was presented by John W. Davis, Democratic Presidential candidate in 1924. Its purpose is to strengthen the federal bench by a closer scrutiny of the qualifications of nominees.
Robert H. Bishop has been appointed vice president in charge of sales for E. F. Drew Co., New York, succeeding George H. Kent, who has been named executive vice president.

Any pennant panic in Flatbush probably was dissipated yesterday when Preacher Roe, Roy Campanella, Andy Pafko, Jackie Robinson and Carl Furillo completed their devastating operations that routed the Phils, 6-2.

WINDSOR, Ont., Sept. 22 (UP)-- The Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., announced yesterday that it would build several thousand automobiles for the South American market. The company also announced it would return to the five-day week on Oct. 1 but would not be able immediately to rehire workers who had been laid off because of a country-wide slump in sales.

"Twilight Walk," A.B. Shiffrin's drama about violence in Central Park, will open at the Fulton Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock under the sponsorship of Richard W. Krakeur. Nancy Kelly is starred in the role of a magazine writer. Featured players are Charles Proctor, Ann Shoemaker, Walter Brooke and Walter Matthau.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--Howard F. Vickery, a public relations officer of the Department of State, died of a heart attack at his residence today. He was 50 years old.
NORRISTOWN, Pa., Sept. 23-- The new Valley Forge Heart Institute and Hospital was dedicated this afternoon to the achievement of a "symphony in medicine."
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Sept. 23--World mine production of tin in July was estimated at 13,600 tons today by the International Tin Study Group compared with 13,700 in June.
The Port of Philadelphia, determined to attract more commerce to the Delaware River, has been carrying on an intensive promotion campaign for more than a year.

OLEAN, N.Y., Sept. 23 (AP)-- Xavier University, with a pair of fleet halfbacks and a powerful line, slammed St. Bonaventure today, 40--6, to end the Bonnies' 22-game, five-year home football winning string before 9,500 startled spectators in Forness Stadium.

The predominance of orders for aircraft and heavy ordnance in the rearmament program is resulting in a different company pattern of distribution of Government contracts from that of World War II, the National Industrial Conference Board said over the week-end.

All foreign freight forwarders who charge for insurance are required, under a ruling just handed down by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein, to show actual premium charges separate from other service charges.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 23--The International Court of Justice wilt open hearings Tuesday on the thirty-year-old BritishNorwegian fisheries dispute which may have a bearing on the legal conflict between the United States and California and Texas over tidal oil deposits.

A rare beauty and eloquence filled the television screen yesterday morning. It was the televising of the solemn high mass from St. Patrick's Cathedral, where the cameras caught all the reverence, solemnity and drama of the observance of the Last Supper.
Commenting on recent rumors in the financial district that the pound sterling was to be devaluated again, one banker is quoted as venturing the observation: "It must be the September equinox."

Constant vigilance to meet the attacks of "the merchants of hatred, bogotry and disunity" was urged yesterday by Acting Mayor Joseph T. Sharkey before a crowd of 4,000 gathered on the Mall in Central Park for the seventh annual Interfaith Day Service.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 23-- Britain's categorical rejection of the latest Iranian overture for the resumption of oil talks--on Iran's terms--was conveyed to Hussein Ala, Minister of Court, late last night.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22-- Approval by the American Standards Association of the first two American standards for the office was hailed here today by the National Office Management Association.
DETROIT, Sept. 23--Mrs. Marion Peck Miles, a society figure in suburban Grosse Pointe Farms, died today, apparently from the effects of overdieting.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 23-- Although the free world is in a much safer position today than it was a year ago, the huge military build-up will lead inevitably to a lower standard of living, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, declared today.

A referendum among members of the New York Typographical Union on the question of accepting or declining a "final" management offer of a new contract for the 4,000 union printers in the book, magazine and job printing field will be held Friday.

A helicopter marked yesterday the fortieth anniversary of the first United States airmail flight, by buzzing over the five-mile route between Garden City and Mineola, L.I., in two minutes. On Sept. 23, 1911, it took Earle Ovington's Bleriot monoplane a little more than three times as long.

"An example of a wide misunderstanding of advances in pure science" is the way in which President James B. Conant of Harvard characterizes the action of the House of Representatives in pruning to $300,000 the request for $14,000,000 which was made by Dr. Alan T. Waterman and which was designed to enable the National Science Foundation, of which he is the director, to begin work.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22--European machine tool produces are seeking a foothold in the American market and to build up export trade at a time when domestic producers are hard pressed to meet defense demands, A.G. Bryant, president of the Bryant Machinery and Engineering Company, Chicago, said here last week.

Cunningham Walsh, Inc., advertising agency, leased two floors in 260 Madison Avenue, a twentytwo-story office building nearing completion in the blockfront on the west side of the avenue from Thirtyeighth to Thirty-ninth Streets, through Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., the agents, who said the building was fully rented except for two lower floors.

BILL KLEM always had the theory that an umpire should be as inconspicuous as pos sible and that the better he was at his job the more unnoticed he'd be. Yet the living contradiction of that theory was the beloved Old Arbitrator.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--The Senate Preparedness subcommittee reported today that it had found "numerous instances of substandard housing and rent gouging" in a recent inspection at Fort Dix, N.J., although the housing shortage there was found to be less acute than at a dozen other military and naval installations.

Holiday merchandise and promotional goods for October selling were wanted in ready-to-wear and soft goods lines in the wholesale markets here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--The Administration soon will ask Con gress to appropriate funds to revive Federal aid to provide wartime day care facilities for children of mothers working in defense plants.

Yesterday (Sunday) in Korea, United Nations ground forces consolidated positions and continued to probe enemy defenses. In the east-central sector, friendly reconnaissance elements encountered heavy resistance from enemy forces up to regimental strength and repulsed several counter-attacks.

BOSTON, Sept. 23--Feeling that the time had arrived when dawdling along the trail should cease, Casey Stengel threw his machine into high gear today and the Yankees, behind big Vic Raschi, rolled over the Red Sox, 6 to 1, in the series finale before a crowd of 28,712.
Eric Kebbon, architect of the board of education and head of its bureau of design and construction, has filed his application for retirement effective Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday by the board.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--The United States announced here today that it was in complete agreement with Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny on the importance of Indo-China in the defense of Southeast Asia. At the same time it was announced that "considerable" improvement would be made in deliveries of military aid materiel to General de Lattre's command.

One hundred business and professional women--presidents and members of the boards of directors of business women's clubs in the city--attended a luncheon in the Brevoort Hotel yesterday marking the opening of "Business Women's Week," which will be observed through next Saturday.

Forty-nine survivors of the "Lost Battalion" of World War I held a reunion luncheon here yesterday and found little to say about their bloody adventure in the Argonne death trap--an adventure thirtythree years and two wars ago.

A bill embracing regulations designed to prevent collisions at sea and sanctioning rules similar to those approved at an international maritime meeting in London in 1948, is being considered by the House of Representatives.

LOUDONVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 23 --The marriage of Miss Sarah Jean Goodman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Goodman, to Lewis Stern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Stern of Bridgeport, Conn., took place here this afternoon in the Goodman home.
Sal Maglie staggered through to his twenty-second victory of the campaign at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Calling for an end of "war hysteria," the American Labor party made public yesterday its municipal campaign platform. It asked for the election of Clifford T. McAvoy, its candidate for President of the City Council, as a step toward restoration of honesty and decency in government, equal rights and a decent standard of living for all and a world at peace.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23-- In playing Willy Loman in the film version of "Death of a Salesman," Fredric March finds himself in the position of enacting a role that he had refused to do on the stage.

Seven of the city's leading civic and business organizations announced yesterday that they would ask the help of the courts in tearing down a "wall of secrecy" erected by the Municipal Civil Service Commission and Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson to balk their efforts to obtain information about city jobs and jobholders.
PARIS, Sept. 23--The United States has taken the diplomatic initiative in a new effort to settle the Palestine question and establish peaceful relationships between Israel and the Arab world.

The problem of Italy is the most paradoxical that the United States and the other Western Powers face. We have to think hard about it this week because Premier De Gasperi will be spending the next three days in Washington. Yet of all our riches and all our good intentions, what can we pick from the cornucopia to give to Italy?
SYRACUSE, Sept. 23 (AP)--The General Electric Company announced today it would supply the Signal Corps with an undisclosed amount of radio-telephone equipment to improve Army communications.
PARIS, Sept. 23--Either adjournment of the National Assembly during the week or else a new Cabinet crisis was the choice expected to be made in the next few days by the French Parliament.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23--The Soviet Union's leading philosophical journal proclaimed today that one of the best known Marxist theses-- the inevitability of war in an epoch of imperialism--could not be carried over unconditionally into the present historical period.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 23--Entries from Leon S. Haymond's stables of New Rochelle captured both championships as the thirteenth annual Watchung Horse Show for hunters and jumpers was staged in a ring pitched on the Union County park system's Watchung reservation today.

An indication of the quality of the horse-racing to be seen at Belmont Park during the next twenty days is the line-up for today's $20,000 added Fall Highweight Handicap.
TRENTON, Sept. 23--More people than ever before came to the opening day of the New Jersey State Fair today.

Austerity is still a long way off for the American consumer. Despite the growing part of the nation's metal that is going into planes, tanks, bombs and other weapons, it will be at least six months before buyers encounter any real difficulty in finding new automobiles, washing machines or vacuum cleaners.
LONDON, Sept. 23--Reaction of the city and the stock markets to the decision to hold a general election next month has, as was to be expected, been prompt and emphatic.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--Leon Keyserling, chairman of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, today predicted a continuously rising curve of American production.

The Third National Japanese Fashion Award Contest was held last week at the home of designer Tina Leser. As on previous occasions, large numbers of entries were eliminated in Japan, only 250 of the thousands of sketches submitted being sent to New York for the final judging by a committee of fashion experts and others interested in the problem of modern dress in Japan.
DUBLIN, Sept. 23 (UP)--Mayo defeated Meath by two goals and eight points (fourteen points) to nine points today in the All-Ireland senior football final before 80,000 fans at Croke Park.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--Following are the texts released today of (1) a letter from President Truman to Vice President Alben W. Barkley and (2) correspondence from former Vice President Henry A. Wallace to Presidents Truman and Roosevelt concerning Mr. Wallace's 1944 trip to the Far East:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--Last fall's winner of the President's Cup, the Detroit-owned Miss Pepsi, with Charles F. Thompson driving, made it a repeat triumph this afternoon on a Potomac River somewhat subdued from yesterday, when the first heat had to be postponed.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23--Dr. Herman L. Kretschmer, urologist and past president of the American Medical Association, died of a heart attack early today in his home. His age was 72.
AMSTERDAM, Sept. 23--The Dutch budget for 1952, published this week, makes a fairly good showing.

A man of inoffensive appearance who boasted of being the "best burglar in America" was in jail last night, charged with being the chief who took jewels worth $64,000 from a showcase in the Waldorf-Astoria lobby in midafternoon Tuesday.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 24-- United Nations and Communist liaison officers talked for an hour today over resumption at Kaesong of the armistice talks in the Korean war. Then the allied group returned to its advance base near Munsan without immediate word what a decision had been reached.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 23--Confusion in steel allocations by governmental sources was unchanged last week. Perhaps a new angle was added when it became known that a super priority--DX--had been established to expedite military and other defense work.
TORONTO, Sept. 23 (Canadian Press)--John Scott, a newsboy who became one of Canada's leading newspaper men, died today at the age of 77.

It is fitting that a week of our calendar should be especially marked by programs and events taking special note of the part played by women in our business and professional life.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23--The weather last week was the principal influence in the grain market. The week started with fine weather instead and as a result prices, which had advanced for all grains on the forecast of freezing temperatures, had a sharp tumble. Good recovery from the low spots was made, however, with another frost scare the latter part of the week.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 23-- All Jewish-owned agricultural land in Israel has been "sold" to an Arab. The transfer would not be upheld in any court but in the eyes of the Israeli rabbinate it was a valid and essential preparation for the coming year of Shmita.
Occupying a place of honor in the sanctuary opposite Cardinal Spellman, President Elpidio Quirino of the Philippines attended solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

Certainly nothing the Ballet Theatre has done so far in its season at the Metropolitan Opera House compares with the "Black Swan Pas de Deux," which Alicia Alonso and Igor Youskevitch presented on last night's program.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23-- Low wages and sweat shop conditions in some countries of Europe and South America are affecting the livelihood of thousands of workers in the United States, especially in New York City, according to a statement issued today at the convention of the American Federation of Labor.

Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were strong most of last week, especially at the close. Prices after easiness on Tuesday and Wednesday resumed their upward trend. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts showed net advances for the week of 74 to 140 points.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 23--John A. Amrhein, 37-year-old former airline ticket agent and a former partner in a telephone answering service, was arrested here late yesterday on check-forgery charges as he picked up some shirts in a laundry.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army in Korea, Monday, Sept. 24 (AP)-- A North Korean Communist regiment today threw the Americans off Heartbreak Ridge, north of Yanggu on the south central front, less than twenty-four hours after the United States infantrymen had captured the crest in bloody fighting.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23-- The Sailors Union of the Pacific, A.F.L., has completed a strike vote, but West Coast shipowners were hopeful today that by the deadline of midnight Sept. 30 a satisfactory agreement would have been worked out with the union and a walkout averted.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 23--The three Western High Commissioners met tonight to discuss the form in which they would present their detailed report on the results of the Washington conference on West Germany's future to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in their meeting with him tomorrow.

Ben Weber's one-movement String Quartet (Op. 35) was played for the first time anywhere at the second concert in the current Locust Valley (L.I.) Musical Festival, given yesterday afternoon at the Lattingtown Harbor Estates.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--A group of scientists who met here recently reported today that a simple, workable artificial heart-lung machine for emergency use might be developed within a year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--A group of scientists who met here recently reported today that a simple, workable artificial heart-lung machine for emergency use might be developed within a year.

Purr Awards will be given to advertisers and publications for outstanding artistry and humanity in the use of cats for advertising, and magazine covers by the Empire Cat Club, Inc., during the two-day championship Cat show on Nov. 16 and 17 at the Hotel McAlpin. Deadline for submitting advertisements and covers is Oct. 27 and the contest is not open to advertisers of cat products.

Here you are, you pay your money and you take your choice. Is the column or the bell silhouette the more appealing to you, or do you like both? Each has its place in the fall and winter fashions. It is plain to be seen from our sketches that they are equally at tractive.

The title of a new appraisal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur by Arthur Schlesinger Jr. and Richard H. Rovere has been changed and it will now be called "The General and the President." The book will be published by Farrar, Straus Young on Oct. 17.

Cutting down the number of accidental injuries and deaths among children is the aim of a pilot study announced yesterday. It will be carried on at the Babies Hospital of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, supported by a grant from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

LONDON, Sept. 23--While millions prayed for his safety, King George VI underwent a major operation at Buckingham Palace today for the removal of a part--or possibly all--of one of his lungs. Some nine hours after the operation ended his condition was stated to be "as satisfactory as can be expected."

HAMBURG, Germany, Sept. 23 -- Many political leaders from Western Germany, France and other Western European countries agreed today that a neutral Germany was impossible and called for inclusion of Western Germany in the European community and--in effect--the North Atlantic Pact.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 23 (UP) --The name of Ted Schroeder loomed larger in the Davis Cup picture today after he defeated Vic Seixas of Philadelphia in straight sets for the sixty-second annual Pacific Coast tennis championship.
Mrs. Annie Nathan Meyer, chief founder and trustee of Barnard College, died yesterday of a coronary thrombosis in her residence at the Hotel Croydon, 12 East Eighty-six Street. Her age was 84.

One American reporter at the N.A.T.O. conference in Ottawa came away with one strong impression. This was a meeting of twelve Governments, and in the nature of men and nations they looked at their common problems from different angles of vision.

An 80-year-old home on lot 13.4 by 102.2 feet at 214 East Seventyeighth Street has been sold by Frederick A. Jambes to Kenneth and Louise Miller through Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., brokers. The seller took title to the little three-story and basement dwelling last February.
LONDON, Sept. 23--Public opinion polls to the contrary notwithstanding, Labor party politicians in Britain today were predicting victory for themselves in the general election on Oct. 25.

Prayers for the recovery of King George VI were offered yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and all Protestant Episcopal churches in the diocese of New York, as well as in churches of other denominations.

Acting Mayor Joseph T. Sharkey has summoned Kings County District Attorney Miles F. McDonald and Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan to City Hall for a conference at 11 A.M. today on "matters relating to the Brooklyn crime investigation," his office announced yesterday.

A gentle easterly breeze and a gracious crew aboard the British cruiser Superb made the end of summer memorable for 2,400 visitors to the 9,000-ton ship between 2 and 5 P. M. yester... day at Pier 90, North River. Autumn arrived at 4:38 P.M.

Sleek Diesels will supplant the chunky, puffing steam locomotives along the entire fifty-three mile stretch of the New York Central Railroad's Putnam division, beginning on Sunday, the railroad announced yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 24--The Soviet Union was accused by Premier Marshal Tito today of massing Soviet bombers--painted with Yugoslav insignia and colors --in Hungary and other neighboring lands, ready to attack Yugoslavia.
LONDON, Sept. 24 (Reuters)-- Blueprints for a vast network of super-speed jet airlines throughout the British Commonwealth will be discussed in London this week.

PARIS, Sept. 24--United States East-West trade experts in Vienna have discovered the existence of a large-scale smuggling racket whereby quantities of industrial diamonds are being bought up in Brazil by Communist commercial agents and shipped to Prague in the Czechoslovak diplomatic pouches.

Despite rumors to the contrary, the Salary Stabilization Board will enforce its regulations just as rigidly as will the Wage Stabilization Board, it was said here yesterday by Gordon W. Hostetter, chief of the salary board's compliance and litigation division. The salary board has jurisdiction over employes who are exempt from the Wage and Hour Law and are not represented by unions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24--A Senate Rules and Administration subcommittee unanimously voted today to hear Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, state his case for expulsion from the upper chamber of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24--When John Cowles some days ago summed up the conclusions he reached during a recent round-the-world trip he could not have known that they would quickly follow a statement of our master foreign policy by the President.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24--The forecast indicating frost and freezing temperatures for the northern areas of the coin belt caused active buying of both corn and soybeans, with oats trailing the corn.

In the Polo Grounds clubhouse after their victory over the Braves yesterday, the casual observer would have had the impression the Giants were pennant-bound, as players clustered about Eddie Stanky, whose ninth-inning single had decided the issue. Most articulate, however, was Manager Leo Durocher.
LONDON, Sept. 24--King George gained strength today and was reported resting comfortably thirty-six hours after his lung operation. There was an improvement in the monarch's general condition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)-- H.L. Mitchell, president of the Farm Labor Union, A.F.L., today accused 100 members of Congress of promoting a "scandalous wildcat strike" by signing a statement urging farmers to withhold their 1951 cotton from the market for a higher price.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Sept. 24--Although still green in spots, particularly at the guards and ends, Lawrenceville School's 1951 football team appears "a little better off at the moment than our team last year."

TOKYO, Sept. 24--Difficulties here began to arise over ratification of the security agreement between Japan and the United States that followed the signing of the peace treaty at San Francisco.

Investment buying marked two apartment house transactions in Manhattan in realty deals reported yesterday. One of the buildings is on the West Side and the other is on the East Side.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24-- Senator Brien McMahon said today he had been informed that the uranium found recently in Dalhart, Tex., was two chunks that had been removed from the plant at Los Alamos, N.M., as souvenirs just at the end of the World War II.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (UP) --Archie Moore, 174 pounds, of Toledo pounded out a unanimous ten-round decision over Harold Johnson, 174, tonight to sidetrack the young Philadelphian's bid to unseat him as No. 1 challenger for Joey Maxim's light-heavyweight crown.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24--The National Production Authority, in an order issued today, gave the Department of Defense and the Atomic Energy Commission the sole right to use priorities in the purchase of chemicals. United Nations ground forces in the east-central sector of the Korean battlefront yesterday continued to encounter heavy resistance from well-entrenched enemy units and several small hostile probing attacks were repulsed. JERSEY CITY, Sept. 24--Capt. Ernest A. Hopf, director of the Fordham University band, died late yesterday in the Jersey City Medical Center at the age of 67. He had made his home here with his daughter, Dorothy, at 88 Summit Avenue. His wife, Mrs. Alice N. Hopf, died in 1947.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 24-- Charles C. Back home with a commanding hold on the situation, the Yankees were ready today for the final dash which most everyone believes will bring Casey Stengel and his Bombers their third straight American League pennant. The season ends on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24--The Senate voted overwhelmingly tonight to tax cooperatives on earnings that were not distributed or allocated to patron members. Columbia University will begin its 198th academic year this morning when it opens classrooms of sixteen schools and colleges on the Morningside Heights campus to an estimated 27,500 students.

Copy will be run monthly throughout the United States and Canada.
LONDON, Sept. 25 (Reuters) Air Commodore Sir Frank Whittle, inventor of the jet engine, forecast today that air travel throughout the world would double in the next five years.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 25 Hope of extending Daylight Saving Time to combat the Pacific Northwest's critical power shortage was dashed today when Governor Douglas McKay of Oregon announced that state law keeps him from acting and Washington's Governor Arthur B. Langlie indicated he would withhold decision. Daylight time officially ends on Sunday.
Martin H. Horchler will join Deering, Milliken Co., Inc., on Monday as head of the yarn division at 1407 Broadway. He recently resigned from Frances Wiley, Boston, Mass.

A BIOGRAPHICAL novel differs from a historical novel, says Irving Stone, author of severa1 immensely popular biographical novels, in that it contains no imaginary characters. A historical novel is about imaginary characters. But this distinction ignores the fact that many historical novels contain both imaginary and historical characters and that many others make historical figures their protagonists.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Bolivian Government will start discussions tomorrow on a long-term tin contract. Negotiators will seek a stable price for the metal.

The great majority of brand manufacturers have the necessary long-range point of view with respect to pricing and distribution of their merchandise, Joseph L. Eckhouse, executive head of Gimbel's, New York, said last night. For this reason, he added, "we at Gimbel's...

JERUSALEM, Sept. 25-- Mayor Vincent Impellitteri of New York called on the "civilized world" today to continue to help Israel carry out her inspiring task "of bringing oppressed Jewry to the country from all parts of the earth."

Optimistic notes on ultimate cure of cancer and progress in cancer research were sounded yesterday at the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases. Its new Tower Building, an outpatient clinic at 1269 York Avenue, was dedicated.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 26 Fighting in Korea was confined yesterday to a forty-mile area along the east-central front. On both the north and south slopes of the major ridge northwest of Yanggu, which has been fought for bitterly and lost twice during the...

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 25 Mutual savings banks will have to make "radical changes" in their management policies if the proposed Federal tax on their earnings is adopted, M.A. Schapiro, bank analyst of New York, asserted today.

American Woolen Company opened its women's wear line for spring 1952 yesterday with price increases of 40 cents a yard over the fall 1950 prices. This increase, according to Charles Silver, vice president, represents the increased cost of production brought about by two pay rises in the last year.

ATHENS, Sept. 25 Premier Sophocles Venizelos submitted his resignation to the King today. However, since the political situation remains obscure because of the close results of the Sept. 9 elections, the King requested him to hold the mandate until some other solution was found.
Are the British taking over American television? To judge by the number of English films being shown over the New York outlets, a viewer might be forgiven if he though so at times.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The Reconstruction Finance Corporation rejected today a petition seeking postponement of loan repayments by Carthage Hydrocol, Inc., of New York, which is headed by Guy George Gabrielson, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

What has happened to the moral tone of public service? How is it possible for a Government employe to consider accepting gifts or monetary fees from a private concern doing business with the Government? Why are the practices disclosed in recent weeks by the Lithofold-R.F.C. inquiry so often...
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Agents of the Office of Price Stabilization invaded virtually every major slaughterhouse in the country today, seeking violations in an effort to enforce price controls on meat.

Columbia University opened its 198th academic year yesterday. The keynote address at the exercises expressed that cheerful confidence and the value of perspective in judging present against past that are a major objective of education. Columbia has long been an institution that lived on the main highway of events. It renounces seclusion and withdrawal as an educational way of life.

LONDON, Sept. 25 A tribal proverb "If you sit on the same stool with a big-kipped man youll soon find yourself on the ground" was quoted by Colonial Secretary James Griffiths today to explain native opposition to the proposed federation of three British Central African territories.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 25-- Under trying conditions, the Long Island women's three-day medal-play golf championship started today over the Creek Club course.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 25 The nineteen Senators marked for defeat in 1952 by American Federation of Labor leaders showed no sign of alarm today and some took the view that these leaders controlled none but their own vote.

Italy has gone a long way since she signed the peace treaty she now wishes revised. The world outlook has changed, though the golf that now divides it was pretty clearly foreshadowed in 1947, when the treaties for Italy, Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania were negotiated in Paris.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower would seek a Presidential nomination only if he felt it necessary to do so for the preservation of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Gov. Walter J. Kohler Jr. of Wisconsin said here yesterday.

THE boys who beat the tom-toms for the beak-busting industry delight in discovering "grudge matches." They seem to think it adds to the excitement and the appeal of a fight if the two sterling gladiators hate each other with such intensity that they'd just as soon battle it out in the backroom of a saloon for free as with a referee supervising their efforts in a ring before paying customers.
DENVER, Sept. 25 A former Denver University football player today demanded $26 "back salary" he said the university owed him for a week he was sidelined because of an injury last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) The Defense Department identified today 341 more United States casualties in the Korean war, including 77 dead, 241 wounded, 11 injured, 11 missing and 1 captured. The following were from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 The American Federation of Labor's seventieth convention authorized today the issuance of a new merger bid to the Congress of Industrial Organizations. Without mentioning other groups specifically, it empowered the A.F.L. ...

An atmosphere of strife and criticism pervaded the Chanin Building Auditorium yesterday, where some 300 stockholders of the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation gathered at a special meeting to decide the fate of management control.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American World Airways, predicted here tonight that scheduled low cost tourist class trans-Atlantic air service could triple the $1,000,000,000 now being spent abroad each year by American tourists.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 25 Stanley Kramer, president of two independent producing companies, announced today that he was in "total disagreement" with Carl Foreman, his partner in the companies, and also a member of the executive board of the Screen Writers Guild.
Presbyterian lay and clerical leaders met here yesterday to plan a nation-wide drive to raise $12,000,000 for expansion of theological seminaries and construction of churches.

PARIS, Sept. 25 French Government officials contended today that they were saving the United States taxpayer thousands of dollars by not permitting United States Army procurement officials to deal directly with French contractors.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 25 Secretary General Trygve Lie has refused to reinstate two dismissed employes, whose, reinstatement was recommended three weeks ago by a three-member administrative tribunal. The tribunal had ruled that the United...

Plans for a motion picture exposition to be held at Grand Central Palace in March and thereafter taken on a tour of twenty or thirty cities were laid before the Theatre Owners of America in convention yesterday at the Astor Hotel.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept, 25 Latest varieties of kitchen equipment, home furnishings and architectural designs for house construction were exhibited by 100 manufacturers and retail dealers at the ninth annual Westchester County Better Homes Show that opened today in the County Center here.
Some new bond issues were posted for the competitive bidding calendar yesterday. Idaho Power Company will take bids on Oct. 2 on $15,000,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1981.
Was Abe Reles' death in 1941 murder or an accident in an attempt to escape from police custody?

The Kings County grand jury charged that in the ten years prior to last October the Police Department's plainclothes division, including its top officers, had engaged with professional gamblers and dope peddlers in "criminal combines."

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan said yesterday that eight detectives who made arrests in two recent major thefts performed "outstanding" work. "The city should be proud of them," Mr. Monaghan said.

A filly whose fame preceded her to New York registered an expected victory in the five-and-ahalf-furlong burst down the Widener course at Belmont Park yes terday. A Gleam of the Calumets Farm showed her class in beatings ten others to the satisfaction of a crowd of 13,241, who made her the odds-on favorite.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 President Truman assured Premier Alcide De Gasperi of Italy today that the United States favored the restoration of all Italy's rights as a free nation.

Forty-three designs comprising representative fall and winter wardrobes for today's smart matrons were displayed yesterday in Lord Taylor's fourth floor Woman's Shop. Although the clothes had an alert, youthful quality, they were, nevertheless, befitting to the older woman.

MONTREAL, Sept. 25 (Canadian Press) The Milwaukee Brewers probably will have to look at a lot of left-handed pitching when they meet the Montreal Royals in the little world series opening here tomorrow night.

The body of a Catholic Army chaplain, who died in a land mine explosion while administering the last rites to a mortally wounded soldier in the United Nations advance north of Chunchon, Korea, last April, was brought home yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25--The Senate decisively defeated today an Administration-supported drive for stiffer excess profits taxes and for elimination of relief provisions from the pending tax-increase bill.

Lilly Dache believes in putting her best hat forward and did so yesterday in a collection shown at 78 East Fifty-sixth Street. In the show were tall fezlike shapes, romantic turbans and bonnets that provided a combination of charm and fantasy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) The armed services defended today their recruiting campaign, which includes high-priced radio shows, on the ground Congress ordered it and it saved the taxpayers money in the long run.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Secretary of Defense Robert A. Lovett warned today that, despite a flurry of recent reports of sensational new weapons, no magic way of winning wars was yet at hand.
A new contract for Atlantic Coast dockworkers appeared closer last night after a meeting in which both union and employers made further concessions.

The retirement for the year of Battlefield was announced yesterday by his owner, George D. Widener, president of Belmont Park. The 3-year-old colt, who has won a total of $351,977, suffered a pulled ligament on his left front pastern while training a week ago Monday.

Following is a summary of the first two days of the New York City registration, by Assembly districts, as compared with the two-day totals last year, in the 1948 Presidential year, and in 1947, the Last comparable "off-year" election:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Defense mobilization officials said today they were "reasonably satisfied" with progress made to date in the defense production programs and in their efforts to check the inflationary forces that increased production had set in motion.

LONDON, Sept. 25 A meeting of British Ministers gave urgent consideration today to the renewed threat of the Iranian Government against British oil workers, a mat ter that may become an issue in the coming British general election.

Congratulatory messages to THE NEW YORK TIMES from individuals and organizations in this country and many parts of the world on the newspaper's centennial celebration were still being received yesterday. Excerpts from some of them follow: ...

PARIS, Sept. 25 France's National Assembly adjourned tonight for a recess. In principle, that will allow the present Cabinet of Premier Rene Pleven to remain in power until resumption of the session on Nov. 6. Meantime, on Oct. 7 and 14, local elections will be held.

The National Association of Broadcast Engineers and Technicians, C. I. O., will begin new contract negotiations with the American Broadcasting Company and the National Broadcasting Company tomorrow morning at 10:30 o'clock in the R. C. A. Building in Radio City.

The 162d anniversary of the Bill of Rights was marked yesterday at the Subtreasury Building at Wall and Nassau Streets. The day's celebration, usually held on the steps of the building, was moved indoors because of rain.

A young former G.I. whose left leg was torn off by a land mine in the Italian campaign hobbled off a witness stand yesterday on Staten Island and, in a breath-halting courtroom scene, walked up to Edward A. Ruppell, Richmond County Republican leader, and pointed him out as the man who had accepted a $1,500 bribe to obtain a liquor store license for him.

The Wage Stabilization Board has a "leaning toward broad social reforms" and probably will authorize higher minimum wages and other employs benefits, Frederick G. Atkinson, vice president in charge of corporate personnel, R.H. Macy Co., said yesterday.

BOSTON, Sept. 25 Mayor John B. Hynes and former Mayor James M. Curley, opponents two years ago were nominated for the Mayoralty again in Boston's first pre liminary election today under a new City Charter, Mr. Hynes won by 12,000 votes in 1949.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) The American Society Of Newspaper Editors disclosed today that it protested to the White House last July, when the information order originally was drafted, that such action would tend to suppress "much news to which the public is entitled."

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 Taking up where the Tigers left off, the White Sox tonight just about applied the final crusher to the jaded pennant dreams of the Indians. Held in check by Billy Pierce, the skidding contenders from Cleveland bowed to the Chicago South Siders, 4 2, before a chilled but enthusiastic gathering of 24,959 at Comiskey Park's 1951 finale.

The appointment of Dr. Abraham Raskin, formerly of the University of Chicago, to the newly created post of coordinator of science courses in the Teacher Education Program at Hunter College was announced yesterday by Eleanor H. Grady, Acting President.

TRENTON, Sept. 25 State Prison authorities and local judges are wrestling with a rush of inmate petitions for release on technicalities. The authorities attribute many of the applica tions to shrewd assistance of "jailhouse lawyers," a term applied frequently to prisoners with long records who have learned some of the legal procedure of sentence, parole and discharge.

BOSTON, Sept. 25 Even in the chill atmosphere of Braves Field, the Dodgers could feel the hot breath of the Giants on their necks tonight, but it didn't warm them. For the Braves beat them in both ends of a twi-night double-header, 6 3 and 14 2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) If one's bank failed tomorrow, the giant Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation couldn't come to its aid immediately despite the fact that the F.D.I.C. has $1,250,000,000 in cash to back up Bank deposits. It insures individual deposits up to $10,000 against loss.

I am today appointing Robert K. Christenherry as chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission to carry out the following objectives in cooperation with C.B. Powell and Commissioner Leon F. Swears:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 Eugene Ormandy, back from a summer European tour in which he conducted orchestras in a number of cities, said today that the great orchestras of this country should plan tours abroad to show the high level of American concerts.

The hand-hewn look is very much in evidence in a collection of furniture now on view in the gallery at America House. 32 East Fifty-second Street. All of the pieces, which are for sale, were executed by students at the School for American Craftsmen, a division of the Rochester Institute of Technology.

In a rush to achieve mass production, the textile industry has neglected creative ideas, with the result that the needs and desires of consumers have been disregarded, Harry Dalton, vice president of the American Viscose Corporation, asserted yesterday.
ALBANY, Sept. 25 Governor Dewey acted suddenly and vigorously today to reform prize fighting in New York State.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 It has been a long time since the Giants, once thirteen lengths out of first place, have been so healthy as they felt following a 5-1 victory over the Phillies at Shibe Park tonight. Not only are Leo Durocher's men still alive in the fantastic National League pennant race, they are breathing hard on the necks of the Dodgers.
Price changes in commodity futures in the local markets varied widely yesterday under generally active dealings. Wool, coffee and tin scored sharp gains but other commodities lost ground.
Sandy Saddler, world featherweight champion, and Willie Pep of Hartford, Conn., former titleholder, will battle fifteen rounds for the crown tonight in the Polo Grounds.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Sept. 25 Sir Frank Soskice, Britain's attorney general, urged the International Court of Justice today to declare illegal the fishing zones claimed by Norway. He said the decision would be an important precedent for the world in establishing rules for determining the limits of territorial waters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Senator William Benton, Democrat, of Connecticut, intends to ask a Senate Rules subcommittee to throw open to the public its forthcoming hearings on his effort to put in motion proceedings to expel Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, from the upper chamber.

Everybody, it seems, wants money from the Ford Foundation. Just a year ago the trustees, headed by Henry Ford 2d, issued their report. Since then the foundation has been literally deluged with requests for help. The Pasadena, Calif., offices alone get 1,000...

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 26--United Nations and Communist liaison officers resumed their talks at Kaesong today in a renewed attempt to arrange full-scale conferences for an armistice in the Korean war after a brief enemy walkout yesterday.

Two hours before a convocation was held yesterday to open Barnard College's sixty-third year, Mrs. Annie Nathan Meyer, chief founder and trustee of the school, was eulogized at a funeral service in the College Parlor of Barnard Hall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The special Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on nominations voted 3 to 2 today to report favorably to the full committee the nomination of Chester Bowles, former governor of Connecticut, to be ambassador to India.
An Army sergeant, who used his position as a member of an honor escort accompanying the bodes of dead soldiers to sell marijuana, was arrested by detectives of the narcotics squad last night.
Fresh strength in the railroad issues injected new life into the stock market yesterday. The radiotelevision and mining sections also made gains but of a more tempered nature.

Award of a new issue of $15,000,000 of bridge toll-revenue bonds of the Delaware River Joint Toll Bridge Commission was made yesterday by the bi-state authority to a nation-wide syndicate of investment banking houses headed by Bear, Stearns Co. at a bid of 100,525 for interest of 2.35 per cent. The bonds will be due on Nov. 1, 1984.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated over a fairly wide range yesterday and closed very steady, 15 to 28 points higher.

Deputy Mayor Charles Horowitz, who was recommended for his post by Robert B. Blaikie, split yesterday with Mr. Blaikie over the latter's endorsement of Rudolph Halley for President of the City Council.

Plans for the conversion of the three-family dwelling at 318-326 Merrick Road in Rockville Centre, L.I., into a funeral home were disclosed yesterday in connection with the announcement of the sale of the property by Margaret Neereamer to the Tommar Realty Corporation, of which Thomas Jordan is president. The Bulkley Horton Company was the broker.

The will of James W. Gerard, United States Ambassador to Germany prior to this country's entry into World War I, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday leaves virtually all of his estate to his widow, Mrs. Mary D. Gerard of 1014 Fifth Avenue, whom he named sole executrix of his estate.

Despite pleas for a large turnout by representatives of all the major parties registration yesterday was much smaller than for the comparable day in 1947, the last "off-year" in which there were no election contests for Mayor, state-wide or national offices.

Changes of agencies by major advertisers are not as frequent as has been indicated by recent and spectacular shifts in accounts. The Association of National Advertisers were told at their meetings in the Plaza Hotel yesterday that fifty-three of the eighty-nine accounts checked by the editors of...

GARDEN CITY, L.I.,, Sept. 25 The new Fairchild XC-120 packplane, a giant cargo airship with a detachable fuselage called a "pod," will make its public debut at the 1951 Long Island Industrial Exposition here next month in the role of the countrys first "flying bloodmobile."
The market for long-term Treasury securities was affected ad versely yesterday by the Senate's approval of legislation which would tax the undistributed earnings of mutual savings institutions.

Large-scale thieving, embezzling and swindling of the Soviet Government by officials and collective farmers have forced the Government to install the tightest system of checking ever known in its agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The Children's Bureau of the Federal Security Agency reported today that juvenile court cases in 1949 in 413 courts in twenty-two states totaled 70,616. This represents a ratio of about 12 for every 1,000 children in the country between 7 and 17 years of age.

At least nine alleged violations of beef price controls were uncovered yesterday in slaughter houses of this state and Northern New Jersey by the Office of Price Stabilization as Markets Commissioner Anthony Masciarelli insisted there was no evidence of black marketing in this city.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 25 Shipment from here of United Nations campaign ribbons for veterans of the Korean war has begun. They are being sent to countries participating in the United Nations action for award to their troops as they return home.

The involvement of additional college basketball players in bribery scandals was indicated yesterday as Assistant District Attorney Vincent A.G. O'Connor successfully moved to have the term of the fourth February grand jury extended to Dec. 20.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Net indebtedness of government, individuals and business concerns in the United States at the end of 1950 totaled $484,000,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today. This aggregate reflects a jump of $38,000,000,000, or 9 per cent over the previous year.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 25 Dr. Lewis Webster Jones, 52year-old president-elect of Rutgers University, declared here today that the goal of higher education should be well-rounded persons, not merely technicians who have little knowledge outside their special fields.

The First National Bank of Boston is offering until Oct. 16 to holders of its capital stock 375,000 new shares at $42.50 a share, at the rate of one share for each 5 4/15 shares held. The issue will increase the capital structure by $15,937,000. The offering is being underwritten by investment bankers headed by the First Boston Corporation.

Israel has ordered thousands of pre-fabricated houses from Germany to help solve the housing shortage, Dr. Nahum Goldmann, co-chairman of the Jewish Agency Executive, said yesterday at the Jewish Agency for Palestine, 16 East Sixty-Sixth Street.
Taking the practical elements of cotton and imbuing it with the town sophistication of other fabrics, M. W. Thomas, American weavers since 1880, have produced something new in fashion fabrics.

HIGHSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 25 Peddie's 1951 football outlook, Which had appeared pessimistic at first, has brightened considerably, Maurice (Mickey) Shuman said today as he sent his squad of fortyfive players through a workout in preparation for the season's opener against Admiral Farragut Academy Saturday.

Jean Babilee's ballet version of Richard Strauss' "Till Eulenspiegel" had its first Ametzcan performance last night at the Metropolitan Opera House as a new addition to the Ballet Theatre's repertoire. Whether or not it is a good ballet, it certainly provides the opportunity for another stunning performance by Mr. Babilee, and that is perhaps enough.

Columbia University announced yesterday that gifts of $25,000 each had been received from THE NEW YORK TIMES and The New York Herald Tribune to further the work of the American Assembly. This is the research and conference organization established at...
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) Washington's Bob Porterfield all but snuffed the Red Sox' flickering pennant hopes tonight when he pitched a masterful two-hitter to give the Senators a 3-0 victory.

The Museum of Modern Art will open to the public today a comprehensive exhibition of paintings and graphic work, by the pioneer Belgian modernist, James Ensor. The exhibition has been arranged in collaboration with the Institute of Contemporary Art, Boston; the...

Annakaboor D. Mani, Indian newspaper publisher and secretary general of the All India Newspaper Editors Conference, back in New York after a four-year interval, said yesterday that he has found "quite an important shift" in public opinion here about India.

Practical suggestions for those on special diets weight-reducing, low sodium and diabetic (sugarless) are presented in a new booklet by the Richmond-Chase Company of San Jose, Calif. This concern packs a variety of canned foods.

The sweeping, strongly worded indictment of a "hierarchy of corrupt officials" within the Police Department handed down yesterday by the Brooklyn grand jury is shocking because it is largely written in the present tense. Drawing on its experience of nearly two years in investigating the police...

Plans for converting three fivestory buildings at 158, 160 and 162 East Thirty-second Street into apartments of three and four rooms were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of the property by Abraham Yarmark through his newly formed Murray Hill-32d Corporation. Edward J. Crawford Jr. was the seller.

When General Eisenhower asks for something to help carry out his heavy task as Supreme Allied Commander we know by now that he has studied the matter carefully. He is grappling with vast problems against an unknown but fairly close deadline. Each intervention has been impressive, whether...

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 25 Pete Cooper of the Century Country Club who set the pace for three rounds in the Metropolitan open championship last week, assumed the pace-setter's role in the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association title tourney today.

The hold-over Kings County grand jury put it squarely up to Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan yesterday to rid the Police Department of graft and corruption by dismissing or demoting all top officers concerned with vice and gambling in the ten years before last October.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 25--Frederic W. Meert of the Colchester Hall Apartments, Scarsdale, a retired New York stockbroker and insurance broker, died last night in White Plains Hospital while undergoing surgery. His age was 78.
LONDON, Sept. 23 (AP) The Moscow radio broadcast today this North Korean Supreme Command communique:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 President Truman signed today an executive order tightening and standardizing the handling of security information by all Government departments, agencies and employes.
Columbia University's faculty and students were warned yesterday that only a devotion to reason would protect them from the temptation to seek relief in name-calling and bigotry.

Unless something upsets the apple cart, the following developments are as definite as anything can be in the theatre: Cheryl Crawford's production of "Paint Your Wagon" will have its Broadway premiere on Nov. 5. Originally, the opening was scheduled for Oct. 15 and then deferred to Oct. 29.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 (AP) Managing editors of 250 American and foreign newspapers begin tomorrow three days of analyzing Associated Press news coverage and discussing news production problems.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The Senate voted today to hold increases in corporation income taxes to $2,000,000,000 as recommended by the Finance Committee. This action followed rejection of a proposal to augment this increase by making the rises retroactive to Jan. 1, rather than to April 1.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 26 Cornell launches its football season Saturday with its most rugged opening test in years against Syracuse. When the returns are in, it will be fairly well established whether or not the Red is a powerhouse of the East.
PARIS, Sept. 26 In a note approved by the Cabinet today, France endeavored to keep the way open for renewal of four-power negotiations with the Russians.

PARIS, Sept. 26--Three proposals are now being considered by the North Atlantic powers as to how the newly nominated members, Greece and Turkey, can best be integrated into the Western defense program.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) Warren Giles, who stepped out of a stalemate so that Ford Frick could be elected to baseball's commissianership, today was asked to become Frick's successor as president of the National League.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 26 Three Harvard professors denied today accusations that they were members of a "pro-Communist group" among a committee of Far East experts who participated in a State Department conference on United States policy in Asia two years ago.
There still was no end in sight in Korea yesterday. Communist liaison teams were haggling over resumption of ceasefire negotiations, as localized, but increasingly bitter, fighting continued ...

Italy is restored, morally and substantially, to a position of equality with the states of the West. The stigma of the war is removed; the peace treaty is to be revised in Italy's favor. This is the meaning the very important meaning ...
