Dr. Roy V. Peel, Director of the Census, told the Association of National Advertisers yesterday that on the basis of the 1950 census "the face of America has changed." He described the growth of regions surrounding the metropolitan areas from rural into urban areas as a major development.

The projected Manhattantown, a $37,495,755 slum-clearance housing center to rise along Central Park West, was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission at City Hall. The plans are to go to the Board of Estimate for final action.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York opened a campaign last night for $20,000,000, the largest in its thirtyfour-year history, at dedication exercises at Yeshiva University, Amsterdam Avenue and 186th Street.
The Giants announced yesterday that they would begin accepting world series reserved seat ticket orders immediately.

HAWORTH, N. J., Sept. 26 The New Jersey Women's Golf Association regained the Mrs. J.J. Thomson Trophy by defeating the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association, 31 to 14, over the White Beeches Golf and Country Club course today.

LONDON, Sept. 26 The stock markets here continued in retreat today under the blows of the Iranian oil crisis and Chancellor of the Exchequer Hugh Gaitskell's reference to the size of the dollar gap and his warning of possible import cuts.

More than 2,000 persons, including 200 leaders in public life and thirty monsignori and priests, attended a Pontifical Requiem Mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral at 11 o'clock yesterday morning for John P. O'Brien, former Mayor of New York. Cardinal Spellman celebrated the mass.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 27 The hardest air fighting of the Korean war raged yesterday as 101 United States and Australian planes battled about 155 Communist jet fighters. An estimated fourteen Communist jets were damaged in the largest jet encounter to date.
The civil defense organization of Flushing, Queens, will go into action at 8 o'clock tonight to meet ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, strongly supported a major and immediate expansion of the atomic project in testimony today before the joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy.

LONDON, Sept. 26 Prime Minister Attlee sent a personal message to President Truman today asking his opinion on the international crisis threatened by Iran's order for the expulsion of British oil workers.
Only one-third of the forty-one arthritis clinics in hospitals and dispensaries here are operated under conditions favorable to good patient care, a medical study disclosed yesterday.

The Northern Control Corporation, which bought the six-story apartment house for forty-nine families at 150 Claremont Avenue, near Columbia University, from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, has resold it to Evelyn Gauvin for investment. Walter Scott Co. and Leonard J. Beck, Inc., were the brokers in the resale for cash over a first mortgage of $155,000. The assessed valuation is $215,000.

With the withdrawal yesterday of thirty-five Liberty ships from the Government reserve fleets the total number of vessels reactivated by the National Shipping Authority and turned over to private companies for operation under general agency agreements rose to 317.

The Yankees, poised to move in for a swift killing in their bid for a third straight pennant, had their plans rudely jolted at the Stadium yesterday. Jimmy Dykes' Athletics, a source of considerable annoyance to Casey Stengel all year, upset the Bombers, 4 to 1, in their final engagement of the campaign with the champions.
Contract talks covering 70,000 General Electric workers collapsed yesterday, but Federal mediators intervened at once to head off a strike in plants working on millions of dollars in defense orders.

Today Norway House, at 290 Madison Avenue, will be officially opened. Erik Brofoss, Norwegian Minister of Commerce, who brings greetings from his people and Government, and Norwegian Ambassador Wilhelm Morgenstierne ...

MOSCOW, Sept. 26 Pravda declared today that so great had been Soviet achievements under Stalinist Constitution that they had deprived President Truman of his "mental balance" and cost him his ability "to control himself."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The United States, Britain and France called on the Soviet Union and other nations today to revise the Italian peace treaty and bring Italy into the United Nations.
The opening campaign address of Joseph T. Sharkey, Democratic candidate for City Council President, over radio station WCB'S and television station WPIX last night:

LONDON, Sept. 26 At the suggestion of Louis St. Laurent, Canadian Prime Minister, Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh have postponed for "one or two" weeks their impend ing state visit to Canada and the United States.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) A "chessboard" method of applying powerful X-rays offers hope in treating advanced cases of cancer resistant to other treatments, a New York doctor said today.
WELLINGTON, N. Z., Sept. 26 (Reuters) Growers and marketing officials today approved a plan for marketing New Zealand wool under which growers will be guaranteed a minimum price at auctions.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 26 Apparently bowing to fierce opposition by orthodox Hindus, the Government has sidetracked the famed Hindu Code Bill, which ...

The State of West Virginia's decision to finance payment of bonuses to war veterans through the sale of $8,000,000 of the state's holdings of municipal bonds would, if effectuated, obviate a so-called "inflationary issue" of new bonds, but it would have no effect at all on the real inflationary factor the pouring of money into the spending stream.

Violation of the red traffic light is on the increase, in our opinion. Many motorists on New York City streets are purposely tardy in responding to the change of signal from green to red. But the most flagrant violation is committed by the professional drivers, the operators of buses and taxicabs.

A collection of the kind of solid, heavy, unadorned glass one has come to expect from Sweden is currently on view at Bonniers, 605 Madison Avenue. All of it comes from the Strombergshyttan glass works, and most of the objects on display have no functional purpose beyond holding a bouquet of flowers or providing a decorative crystal accent in a room.
Only 392,000 New Yorkers have registered so far for the November election. That is some 100,000 fewer than at the same stage of registration in 1947, the last comparable year.

Six more slaughterhouses in New York State and northern New Jersey were reported yesterday as violators of meat price controls, bringing to fifteen the number of alleged violators in this region since the country-wide enforcement campaign by the Office of Price Stabilization began Tuesday morning.
PARIS, Sept. 26 As a consequence of the national minimum wage rise, the Cabinet approved today 12 per cent salary increases for Government employes.
Hayden A. Glatte has been appointed general sales manager of the Tile-Tex division, floor coverings, of the Flintkote Company, replacing J.O. Heppes who has resigned.

Any corrective measures applied in New Jersey to rectify smoke conditions in that state are not likely to be of much help to this city, Rear Admiral William S. Maxwell, retired, deputy director of the Bureau of Smoke Control, said yesterday.

Continuing its post-war school construction pace of one or more new schools every month, the Board of Education broke ground yesterday for Junior High School 123 at Bruckner Boulevard and Morrison Avenue in the East Bronx. The school is the seventy-second project to be started since the school construction program began in September, 1946.

The Governments of the United States, France and the United Kingdom have considered for some time how best to resolve, in the interests of the harmonious development of cooperation between the free nations, the problem presented by the peace treaty with Italy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Basil O'Connor, president of the International Poliomyelitis Congress as well as the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, reported to President Truman today that "we are definitely closing in on the virus of polio."

The highest sales and earnings in its forty-year history were reported yesterday by the Magnavox Company in the annual report for the fiscal year ended on last June 30. At the same time, the company announced a backlog of military orders exceeding $35,000,000.
It was ten years ago yesterday that the Military Police Corps, the so-called M.P.'s of sometimes bitter G.I. memory, became a separate unit of the United States Army.

Harry Gross, Brooklyn ex-bookmaker, was indicted by the Brooklyn rackets grand jury yesterday on ten counts of criminal contempt of court as District Attorney Miles F. McDonald pre-... pared to read grand jury minutes of the Gross testimony in Special Sessions Court this morning.

Fred Atkins Moore, associate executive director of Save the Children Federation, which aids underprivileged children in many ways in various parts of the world, died yesterday in the Polyclinic Hospital after a long illness. He was 68 years old. He resided at 450 West Twenty-fourth Street.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 26 (AP) A former University of Michigan football star today denounced his alma mater and college football.

Although he has enough projects on hand to keep him busy for the rest of the season, Herman Shumlin already is looking forward to the next theatrical term. He has acquired a new play, his fifth, to be done around Aug. 15 of next year. It is called "The Wolf Has Eaten Grandmother," written by Mrs. Elizabeth McFadden Wright. The script recently won a $2,000 prize in the Arts of the Theatre Foundation play contest.

The stock market was unable to settle down yesterday. Prices for the better part of the day were pretty well mixed. While gains outnumbered losses by a good margin, the composite rate rose only 0.10 point on the day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Assistant Secretary of Defense for manpower, said today that a drive for about 72,000 more women in the Armed Services by June would be launched with nation-wide ceremonies on Armistice Day and the Monday following.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The need for additional Federal judges in a number of districts, including New York, was emphasized today in an annual report by Henry P. Chandler, director of the Administrative ...
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation plans to spend $296,000,000 for expansion to increase its productive capacity by 50 per cent.
Pledging himself to support every effort to eradicate graft in politics and government, wherever found, Acting Mayor Joseph T. Sharkey, Democratic candidate ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) Senate investigators were told today that a "Free Asia" pamphlet turned out by Henry A. Wallace in 1944 for the Institute of Pacific Relations actually had been written by the wife of Prof. Owen Lattimore, Far Eastern expert.

Edward A. Ruppell, Richmond County Republican leader, was accused yesterday of having tried to influence the testimony of a prospective witness for the State Crime Commission by intimating that "harm" might come to the witness' parents.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 26 The marriage of Miss Joan Elizabeth Whipple, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Mayhew Whipple, to Lieut. Philip Crane, U. S. A. F., son of Mrs. Rosemary Crane of New York and Thomas J. Crane of Lawrence, L.I., took place this afternoon in St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church, Noroton. The Rev. T. Chester Baxter performed the ceremony. There was a reception at the Whipple home, 84 Stephen Mather Road.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 The emergence of the New Boston Committee, a non-partisan, grass roots organization, as a factor in Boston politics shared the spotlight today with Mayor John B. Hynes' success in the first preliminary municipal election yesterday.
For the many people who must keep one eye on the calendar and the checkbook while they beguile themselves with the travel folders, the United ...

A campaign to raise $350,000 for the assistance of disabled veterans was started yesterday by the Disabled Veterans Service Foundation, 11 West Fortysecond Street, at a luncheon in the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street.
Some sound advice to the people and the Legislature for the protection of the Adirondack Preserve is offered in a recent talk by Lieutenant Governor ...
Because radio waves do not respect national boundaries it is necessary for nations to cooperate to minimize interference with one another's broadcasts. Until March, 1949, a treaty for that ...

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 Pakistan's Foreign Minister, warning that the situation in Kashmir had become "much worse," urged the United Nations Security Council today to try again to obtain Indian agreement on demilitarization of the Princely State.

A fugitive for seven years, Joseph Dentico, 55-year-old alien, the last of a sixty-four member East Harlem narcotics ring to be arrested, was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court to a ten-yearterm for narcotics violations.

Federal curtailment of steel allotments for highway construction has delayed indefinitely hundreds of road and bridge projects designed to relieve traffic congestion and attendant evils in this city and state and in twenty-eight other states.

Management must retain "chronological age," in the employe's own interest, as the determinant for compulsory retirement until a satisfactory scientific substitute develops. This was the theme of an address yesterday by A.D. Marshall, assistant secretary of the General Electric Company.

How to define "good taste" seemed to be the problem uppermost in the minds of three designers of contemporary furniture and a group of the press who questioned them at a breakfast meeting yesterday. The conference, held on the third floor of Grand Central Palace, where the National Homefurnishings Show is now in progress, was sponsored by the Decorative Furniture Manufacturers Association.

The State of South Carolina sold yesterday $12,500,000 of school bonds due from 1952 to 1963 to a banking syndicate headed by the National City Bank at a bid of 100.2299 for interest of 1 per cent, a cost of 1.46333 per cent. The next best bid, submitted by Chase National Bank, was 100.077 for the same coupon. Bankers Trust Company bid 100.06 for 1 s.
Customs agents seized $66,000 in jewels from a Brooklyn woman yesterday as she tried to smuggle them into the country by concealing them in the clothing worn by herself and her 9-year-old daughter.
BOSTON, Sept. 26 Despair in Flatbush must have diminished appreciably this afternoon when the news from windswept, chilly Braves Field burst on Brooklyn ears.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 19: increases of $611,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, $598,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks, and $1,286,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) The White House announced new draft regulations today under which 235,000 childless husbands may receive induction notices and about 150,000 4-F's will lose their deferments.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 Wheat futures assumed the leadership in the grain trade in the final hour today. Commission absorption early on the decidedly unfavorable weather in Western Canada was followed by active short-covering in the late trading, which ran prices up to the highest levels in many weeks.

BY this time most people who boast even a cursory interest in modern American litera ture have made up their minds about William Faulkner. The 1950 winner of the Nobel Prize for literature does not leave his readers indifferent. They either babble with enthusiasm or snort with contemptuous rage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Max Siskind, former law associate of William M. Boyle, Jr., now chairman of the Democratic National Committee, told a Senate investigating subcommittee today that in April, 1949, he had purchased Mr. Boyle's practice from him for $150,000, with payments to be made in installments.

Collapse of the Brazilian effort to keep cocoa prices high came yesterday. In the midst of the morning session of the Cocoa Exchange here word arrived that the minimum export price had been cut to 27 cents a pound, contrasting with the level of 34.65 cents set early in June and the 32 cent limit established earlier this month.
WAUPACA, Wis., Sept. 26 (AP) Two central Wisconsin rural areas were torn by tornadoes this afternoon and seven persons met death beneath the funnel-shaped clouds.
A taste of life in the British Navy was offered yesterday to thirty-eight boys from Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.

The regional office of the Department of Commerce here is stepping up its campaign throughout New York and New Jersey to expedite the flow of scrap from the area's automobile graveyards to scrap dealers and ultimately to the nation's steel mills and foundries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The Office of Price Stabilization announced tonight that it had caught 222 slaughterhouse violators in fifty-four cities during the enforcement drive it began yesterday. This campaign against violators of meat regulations is the most vigorous yet conducted by the agency.
TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 27 Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, United Nations commander, proposed today to the Communist High Command to shift the site of the armistice talks in Korea from Kaesong ...

Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to Washington throughout World War II, declared here yesterday that the maintenance of world peace depended to a large extent on continued close collaboration between the United States and Great Britain.

The International Boxing Club denied monopoly charges yesterday and hinted that Federal investigators who had been quietly looking into boxing here for two months had carefully avoided the best source of information the International Boxing Club.

Negotiations between East Coast longshoremen and their employers, which had been proceeding at a smooth, rapid pace for the last two weeks, struck an unexplained snag late yesterday afternoon after two hours of joint session.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) William N. Oatis, Associated Press correspondent, must be freed from ...

Lower prices as announced by the major producers of worsteds and woolens will be relfected immediately in the prices of women's suits for spring. Manufacturers figuring their costs reported yesterday that all-wool gabardine suits would be $5 to $10 cheaper at the retail level, while wholesale prices would be down $2 to $6 on each garment.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 26 (UP) A 37-year-old housewife was convicted today of beating a junior high school principal with his own paddle because he gave her son a "swift kick."

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Sept. 26 At Choate School football attracts more participants than any other athletic activity. Out of the school's enrollment of 504 students, 270 have elected the sport. Unfortunately, Coach Jack Maher is finding these formidable figures of little consolation as he prepares the Blue and Gold for its 1951 opener against Kingswood Saturday.

It is up to women to curb inflation in this country, Mrs. Hiram Cole Houghton, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, declared yesterday at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Fortythird Street.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 (AP) Leading American editors voted unanimously today to prepare resolutions formally protesting President Truman's new executive order classifying information.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 26 West Germany will counter the Communist offer on German reunification with a demand for free elections throughout all Germany.

Walter Florell's millinery collection, viewed yesterday at 29 East Fifty-third Street, seemed to bubble with holiday spirits. With his usual flair, he studded knits with large glittering stones, stole the silhouettes of men's hats for feminine styles trimmed with velvet and jewels.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The Treasury Department is considering a rule that would require employes to pay income tax on all their employers' contributions to group insurance and welfare funds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today that the free world's desire for "peace with freedom and justice" could be realized only by developing the strength to enforce that peace.

New corporate financing involving $56,625,000 of private and public securities flotations were announced yesterday. Included are public offerings of common stock and bonds of natural gas and public utility companies and private placements for three industrial enterprises. The public offerings are as follows:

Dr. Harold Jacobziner, who has worked in the pediatric services of the Department of Health since 1931, was named yesterday as director of the agency's Bureau of Child Health. He replaces Dr. Samuel Wishik, who recently resigned to become Professor of Maternal and Child Health at the University of Pittsburgh.
Directors of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation have approved a $40,000,000 financing program, Charles Allen Jr., chairman, announced yesterday.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 26 At the end of the second round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship at the Cold Spring Country Club today three competitors were in a tie for the lead with aggregates of 141.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) Amos E. Heacock, president of Air Transport Associates, Inc. of Seattle, said today his company would take every possible legal step to keep its operating rights.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that the worsening Iranian oil situation was under intense discussion by United States and British officials here.

TRENTON, Sept. 26 Uncertainty over the site of a New Jersey medical school increased today after Governor Alfred E. Driscoll disclosed that experts engaged by the state preferred Rutgers University at New Brunswick instead of Newark.

A witness, who had testified before the State Crime Commission on Tuesday that Edward A. Ruppell, Richmond County Republican leader, had accepted a bribe to obtain a liquor store license for him, yesterday charged that ten days ago Mr. Ruppell had threatened "harm" to his parents. [1:8.]

HUNTERS seem unconcerned whether the recent rains fell on the just and unjust, just so long as they showered down on the Adirondacks. For another drought would result in the closing of some of the forests to deer hunters.

George E. Parker has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Columbia Steel and Shafting Company, Carnegie, Pa., to succeed E.L. Parker, his father, who becomes chairman of the board, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The Senate Rules Committee held today that Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, was "well qualified" to sit in an inquiry ...
HONG KONG, Sept. 26 Sooner or later, everything seems to get "mobilized" or "organized" in Communist China. Now it's ducks.
A couple of bargain purchases finished necks apart in the $24,900 Jerome Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday and beat a leading candidate for horse-of-the-year honors.
A total of 871 pints of blood was donated in the New York Regional Blood program on Tuesday, the American Red Cross announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The National Production Authority announced today that cotton duck production in the second quarter of this year amounted to 95,000,000 linear yards, an increase of 11,000,000 yards compared with the first quarter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Heads of the nation's largest steel mills will confer here tomorrow with Charles E. Wilson, head of the Office of Defense Mobilization. The meeting, called by Mr. Wilson, is to discuss the Defense Production chief's demand that steel producers expand their output in the first quarter of 1952 by a minimum of 1,000,000 tons above present estimates of 28,000,000 tons.
A Federal production authority official warned American theatre owners yesterday that it would be increasingly difficult after Oct. 1 to build new theatres, or to alter older movie houses.
Though home cooks preparing for the Jewish holidays will find most species of fresh water fish both scarce and costly, kosher poultry of all types is reported to be in liberal supply.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 26 Mrs. Walter Reynolds of Miami Beach, Fla., a former Westchester player, and Mrs. J. Walker Hoopes of Wilmington, Del., shared the lead with 84's as 100 players opened competition in the twenty-sixth annual United States Senior Women's Golf Association championship at the Westchester Country Club today. Mrs. Reynolds carded 44, 40 and Mrs. Hoopes had 43, 41.

United Nations units in the west central sector of the Korean battlefront yesterday (Wednesday) successfully repulsed a series of sharp attacks from enemy elements up to regimental strength. Other United Nations troops fighting on the eastcentral area made limited advances in the face of heavy resistance from enemy units up to estimated battalion strength and then repulsed a series of probing attacks.

DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP) Ford Motor Company have announced shutdowns in many of its plants this week. The company said 25,700 employes will be made idle at its big Dearborn Rouge plant tomorrow and Friday for inventory An additional 1,560 workers in the Rouge glass plant and paper mill will be off Friday only.

A new outlook for older persons is being provided by Great Britian, which is trying to get rid of the large institutions for the aged and also is keeping the aged in their own communities, Miss Dorothea Ramsey, secretary of the National Old People's Welfare Committee, London, reported yesterday.
WOOD-RIDGE, N. J., Sept. 26 A deadlock persisted tonight between 9,806 striking production workers and management of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation over the employes' wage and welfare demands.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) Max Siskind, Washington attorney, tonight gave Senate investigators the following list of cases which, he said, were involved in his $150,000 purchase of legal practice from Democratic National Chairman ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) Supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower challenged today reports that the general would not run for President unless he thought that only in that way could he save the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

ALBANY, Sept. 26 The Public Service Commission granted the Western Union Telegraph Company today permission to make its new higher interstate rate schedule effective Oct. 11 for telegrams within New York State.

ROME, Sept. 26 The final communique on the results of Premier Alcide De Gasperi's conversations in Washington created a painful impression on the Italians who read it tonight. Only the Communists and other Left Wingers received it with jubilation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 26 Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will make a film based on the success story of Jean King, "The Lonesome Gal" of radio fame who nightly serenades disappointed listeners across the nation with romantic ballads and soothing talk in a warm, sultry voice. The lead role in the picture, to be made next year, will go either to Lana Turner or Ava Gardner, according to Dore Schary, studio boss.

A Gaelic football team from County Meath and a hurling team from County Galway, both of championship caliber, arrived from Dublin aboard a chartered Trans World Constellation plane at Idlewild Airport yesterday. There were forty-eight in the party.

Recommendations to improve the reproduction of advertisements in color comic sections were announced yesterday by the Joint Committee on Newspaper Printing of the American Newspaper Publishers Association and the American Association of Advertising Agencies. The report gives specific standards for all phases of color comic reproduction, including preparation of art work, engravings, colorproofing and duplicate printing material. Also recommended are standard colors for four-color comic printing.

Leon Rudin is a strong, dependable violinist, if his recital the final "interval Concert" of the season in Carnegie Recital Hall last night is any indication. He is the kind of performer you felt you would like to have in your orchestra, and, as a matter of fact, he plays in the Philharmonic-Symphony.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 Three became the magic number, so far as the Dodgers are concerned, after the Giants had overwhelmed the Phillies by 10 1 before 14,009 fans at Shibe Park tonight. Any combination of Brooklyn victories and New York defeats adding up to three will give the National League flag to Flatbush.
The first United Service Organzations clubhouse for the exclusive use of service men-since the reactivation of the U.S.O. was ...

The revenue bill now being considered in the Senate contains provisions which will go far to help large corporations solve some of their problems of bigness, Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, told members of the National Security Industrial Association yesterday at its annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Mr. Celler said this measure would enable "great industrial entities" to "spin off" or divest themselves of some of their subsidiaries without prohibitive taxation.
Sandy Saddler retained his world featherweight championship last night, stopping Willie Pep in the ninth round of a scheduled fifteenround battle at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Ever since the first collegiate wave of young economists, sociologists and lawyers swept into Washington with Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1933 and inundated the Government, official conversations and ...

Wasting no time getting started in his new role of prosecutor, William B. Herlands conferred in separate sessions yesterday with the city's Police and Investigation Commissioners shortly after he was sworn in as the state's special assistant attorney general for the Staten Island crime inquiry.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was active again yesterday with wide fluctuation, prices rising 71 to 100 points on the day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) Democrats in the Senate Commerce Committee today voted down a Republican proposal to recreate the Senate Crime Investigation Committee and give it $150,000 for a new inquiry.

NEWARK, Sept. 26 A 40-yearold father, accused of setting the fire early today in which his 17year-old daughter was burned to death and his estranged wife and 15-year-old son seriously injured, committed suicide tonight as the police searched for him.

An international trading division to conduct buying and selling activities between all countries of the free world has been formed by Transocean Air Lines, contract air carrier, it was announced yesterday.

GENEVA, Sept. 26 United States asked the Contracting Parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade today to relieve it of the obligations to apply nondiscriminatory treatment to trade with Czechoslovakia.

TOMORROW, 2:30 P.M.: First matinee performance of the twentysixth annual World's Championship Rodeo at Madison Square Garden. The "Lone Ranger" and his horse, Silver, will put in personal appearances daily through Oct. 7. The show will continue through Oct. 21 with matinees on Wednesdays, Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. Check with the box-office for admission prices.

LONDON, Sept. 26 The furor recently caused when a Cabinet minister advised housewives to start a buyers' strike continued unabated today in British business circles and showed no signs of quieting down.

A purported Raphael oil painting Madonna with the Infant Christ and the Kneeling Infant St. John will be the issue in an action to be heard next Thursday in Special Term, Part I, of the Brooklyn Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) Democrats in the Senate Commerce Committee today voted down a Republican proposal to recreate the Senate Crime Investigation Committee and give it $150,000 for a new inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, of Newark, N. J., filed a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for 249,942 shares of its $100 par cumulative preferred stock.

Mrs. Lane Bryant Malsin, who founded in 1900 the ladies' wear business that developed into Lane Bryant, Inc., with twenty-five retail shops throughout the country and a mail order plant, died of a heart attack last night at her home, 1056 Fifth Avenue. Her age was 72.

John E. McKeen, president of Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., announced yesterday price reductions of 15 to 40 per cent on terramycin, antibiotic "wonder drug" said to to be effective against more than fifty human diseases. The new prices are effective today, he said in an interview at the Roosevelt Hotel. The reductions were made possible because of increased production facilities, improvements in research and greatly expanded world-wide demand, it was explained.

The rodeo, common delight of those spectators who never roped a steer because they don't know how and those who have left wilder parts of the country for the canyons and plains of New York, opened ...
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27 (AP)--Lloyd Mangrum shot a 7-under-par 64 today to a tie a course record in the first round of the $15,000 St. Louis open golf tournament at Meadow Brook Country Club.

The wavering tendencies shown recently in the stock market gave way to a general sell-off yesterday. The inability of the railroad issues to maintain their position apparently was the danger signal for the chart followers and although selling never reached sizable proportions, the lack of support allowed prices to sag with ease.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--Some highly placed Republicans cried 'trickery" and "politics" today as President Truman proposed that all Federal officials be required to disclose all outside income and income sources, but the general reaction on Capitol Hill was good.

The chantry of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Harriet Isham Bermingham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Bermingham of Duncan, Wyo., and Chicago, to Dr. Robert E. Carroll of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Oliver Carroll of Fall River, Mass.
Proposed a new law to require all top Government officials, members of Congress and key workers in the major political parties, to file annual financial statements.

The New York Committee of Inward Far East Lines announced yesterday a downward revision of the penalty charges it plans to institute Monday to help eliminate congestion of steamship terminals by import cargoes.

OTTAWA, Sept. 27--Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent has gone to Washington to seek assurance from President Truman that the opposition of Congress to the St. Lawrence Seaway and power development will not be allowed to hamper longer an undertaking that Canada regards as essential to her prosperity and defense.
Eighteen local housing authorities will receive bids Oct. 9 on issues of temporary loan notes totaling $80,214,000 under the Public Housing Administration program.

Paul Revere did more than make his famous midnight ride, he founded a copper company and it was in connection with this that Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., presented a showing of fashions yesterday celebrating its sesquicentennial. Viewed at 270 Park ...
A seasonal upswing in the needle trades lifted total employment in this city last month to the highest level of the year, the State Employment Service reported yesterday.

A former Brooklyn patrolman was held yesterday in $25,000 bail as a material witness in the college basketball scandal. At the same time, two other witnesses, including a "small-fry" gambler already indicted for bribery, were remanded to City Prison after the prosecutor expressed concern for their safety.
BOSTON, Sept. 27 (UP)--Jackie Robinson of the Dodgers kicked in a panel of the door to the umpires' dressing room today as he left the park after his club lost a 4-3 decision to the Braves.

Although taxes of E.R. Squibb Sons, drug concern, and its wholly owned subsidiaries in the Western Hemisphere for the year ended on June 30 increased almost 100 per cent over the tax charge in the pxevious fiscal year, consolidated net income increased 20 per cent over the earnings in the year ended on June 30, 1950.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP)-- Members of Congress today demanded an investigation of the removal of white crosses from the graves of 13,000 American war dead in Hawaii's National Memorial Cemetery.

The Staten Island scandal involving public officials in "fixes" and job selling had swift repercussions yesterday, less than twenty-four hours after the State Crime Commission had ended the public hearings that brought the affair to the surface.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)-- The Red Sox were eliminated from the pennant race today when the Senators beat them, 8--6, to sweep a three-game series.

A package of cut diamonds valued at $50,000 to $100,000 was found yesterday aboard the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth in a stateroom that had been used Wednesday by customs agents when they searched a woman and her 9-yearold daughter.

Major aircraft producers with prime Government contracts are increasing the dollar value of their subcontracts and purchases from suppliers this year as much as 127 per cent compared with 1950. This was shown last night by Capt. Daniel C. Cady, Air Force small business specialist for the Eastern Air Procurement District.

The sweeping Presidential order providing for the classification of information throughout all the executive branch of the Government raises serious questions. It goes without saying that there are some matters essential to the national defense that need to be kept secret.

LONDON, Sept. 27--New stimulation apparently was given to the production of primary raw materials in the British Commonwealth at the meeting of Commonwealth supply and production ministers that ended in London today.

RUTLAND, Mass., Sept. 27-- Mr. and Mrs. Rufus Bigelow Dunbar of Bear Hill Farm, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Irene, to CarlGustaf Bjorklund, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Johann Bjorklund of Kristianstad and Angelhom, Sweden. The wedding will take place in the winter.

Harry Gross, "monarch of a criminal empire," was sentenced yesterday to twelve consecutive years in Rikers Island Pentitentiary by the Court of Special Sessions in Brooklyn on twelve counts of a sixty-six-count information charging bookmaking and conspiracy.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 27 --Sweden's Labor Cabinet is about to be revamped to include four Agrarians. Labor is keeping the key posts, however. The Agrarians will get the portfolios of Interior, Agriculture, Religious Affairs and Communications.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 27-- Official reaction to the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission's proposals for a settlement of the Palestine conflict indicates that the Arab governments are not interested in any type of definite peace agreement. It is now clear that the primary purpose of Arab policy is to seal off as far as possible the state of Israel and to avoid having either political or economic relations with it.

Cosmopolitan New York's City Hall took on a richly Irish flavor yesterday noon. Acting Mayor Joseph T. Sharkey and crowds of official and casual New Yorkers gathered to greet the Irish visitors who will meet local contenders in games of hurling and Gaelic football on Sunday afternoon at the Polo Grounds.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Sept. 27 (UP)--The first six Negro students admitted to the University of North Carolina were barred today from sitting in the cherring section at football games.
A special term of the Magistrate's Court, patterned after the War Emergency Court of World War II days, is to be set up to try price control violations under the city's Sharkey Laws.
