Mrs. Margaret Sanger, honorary chairman of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, declared yesterday that the objectives of her organization were being hampered in Great Britain by the payment of Government subsidies to large families.

An official of the Public Service Commission accused the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday of failure to justify its present gas rates. The charge was made at a hearing enlivened by noisy consumers' protests against the rates.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27-- Doubts were expressed by Capitol sources tonight that Miss Frieda B. Hennock, a member of the Federal Communications Commission, would be confirmed as a Judge of the Federal District Court in New York.

The first color television sets to be produced by C. B. S.-Columbia, Inc., are scheduled to reach the retail market today, but officials of the company emphasized that they would be available only in very limited quantity.

LONDON, Sept. 27--A final decision on Britain's reaction to the Iranian threat to expel British oil workers from Iran was postponed by the Labor Government today while both the United States and Britain were trying to obtain cancellation of the expulsion order.
RYE, N. Y., Sept. 27--Mrs. Walter A. Reynolds of Miami Beach, Fla., added an 83 to her firstround 84 for a total of 167 to become the new United States senior women's golf champion as the ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--The new regulations, standardizing throughout the Government the tests to determine which official documents should and should not enter the stream of public information, will serve their proclaimed purpose to the degree that they are administered with good faith and with good judgment and consonant with their purpose as stated by the President.

Nine tables festively set and heaped with holiday fare for the major Jewish holy days and festival observances will be on view tomorrow at the Brooklyn Museum. Much smaller than life-size, in fact, minute, the settings are carried out in accurate, if Lilliputian scale.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 27-- Joseph Mankiewicz, writer-director of such pictures as "A Letter to Three Wives," "All About Eve" and "People Will Talk," is terminating an association with Twentieth Century-Fox that began in 1943.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--The Labor Committee of the House of Representatives approved today a bill that would amend the TaftHartley Law by eliminating elections as a qualification for union shop agreements, including 4,700 elections that have already been held and will have to be held again unless the law is changed.
ALBANY, Sept. 27--The text of the Governor's order directing an extraordinary Supreme Court term in Richmond County follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)-- Attorneys for the Department of Labor advised Representative Victor Wickersham, Democrat of Oklahoma, today that present regulations pemit children under 16 years old to pick cotton in neighboring school districts, as well as in the districts in which they live, when their own schools are closed for that purpose.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--Conferees for the Senate and House of Representatives agreed today on an authorization of $7,483,400,000 in weapons, materials and equipment to help friendly free Governments rearm against the threat of Communist aggression.

Paul-Henri Spaak, president of the Council of Europe's Consultative Assembly, pleaded last night in a speech prepared for delivery before the National Industrial Conference Board for the integration of Germany into the western community "and from there into the Atlantic community."

FONTAINEBLEAU, France, Sept. 27--Western Europe will witness a demonstration of its growing air might in the next three days. The air forces of eight nations will send 1,000 planes into the sky beginning tomorrow to test the effectiveness of the defenses set up by the Central Command under General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

William G. Christy, director of the Smoke Control Bureau, announced yesterday that the departments of Hospitals and Marine and Aviation would be called on the carpet soon for repeated smoke violations.

In his first major action as new chairman of the State Athletic Commission, Robert K. Christenberry yesterday ordered reports from all officials at the Sandy Sadler-Willie Pep featherweight championship which ended in a ninth-round knockout victory for Saddler Wednesday night at the Polo Grounds.
The maximum retail beef prices that butchers may charge in New York and New Jersey, beginning next Monday, appear below.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Sept. 27--Claude Harmon of Winged Foot, posted a 4-under-par 68 in the fourth round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship at the Cold Spring Country Club today and won the title with an aggregate of 283.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 27-- Allegations of election irregularities in the disputed state of Jammu and Kashmir where the pro-Indian administration of Prime Minister Sheikh Abdullah has captured a majority of the seats in the Constituent Assembly without the casting of a single vote were published today by the Times of India.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 (AP) --Leading American editors, after a long, hard look at the effect of television on the newspaper business, indicated today that TV had sharpened the interest of readers in outstanding news events that had been televised. Only a few editors thought television would cut circulation.

Congratulatory messages on the one hundredth anniversary of THE NEW YORK TIMES continued to arrive yesterday from individuals, representatives of business and civic organizations and newspapers in all parts of the world.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--Meeting head-on the developing campaign issue of alleged corruption in his Administration, President Truman proposed today a new law requiring all top Federal officials, including members of Congress and judges, and principal officers of national political parties, to file annually a public declaration of all their income, including gifts and loans from every source.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22--President Truman ordered the Office of Price Stabilization tonight to withdraw a controversial directive it had issued earlier instructing employes of that agency to withhold information that "might prove embarrassing to the O.P.S."

BOSTON, Sept. 27--The Boston Maine Railroad obtained a temporary injunction today to prevent the State Department of Public Works from tearing up tracks and platforms at its North Station terminal to make room for a section of a $40,000,000 elevated highway across its railroad yards.

LONDON, Sept. 27--On his sickbed in Buckingham Palace King George signed today a royal warrant appointing five members of his immediate family Counselors of State to relieve him of most of his constitutional duties during his illness.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sep. 27-- The Milwaukee Polo Club moved into the final round of the national open polo championship on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club with a 9-6 victory over the Blind Brook Hurricanes today.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 27 (UP)-- Warren C. Giles, the Reds' general manager, who entered baseball one a dare thirty-one years ago, accepted the presidency of the National League today.

Progress in the drive to induce European manufacturers to adopt American production methods to speed military preparedness and further their economic self-dependence was reported yesterday by the American Standards Association.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27--The forecast for probable killing frosts over a large part of the northern areas of the Corn Belt solidified bullish sentiment here today and after a reactionary turn on profittaking early, buying again swung into the market and lifted all corn deliveries to new high levels on the crop.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 27 (AP) --Dr. A, $70 victor of the firs race and Bay Orders, $18.60 win ner of the second, today returned $843.60, the longest daily double pay-off of the current meeting. A total of eighty-two $2 tickets was held by the crowd of 10,000.
The urgent need for more blood to replenish low stockpiles of the armed forces was stressed yesterday at a meeting called by officers of the Defense Department.

Heavier receipts of medium and pullet-size eggs yesterday forced down the price not only of these specimens but of the large Grade A's, according to the City Department of Markets. Both large and mediums declined 4 cents a dozen to 89 and 75 cents a dozen, respectively. The pullets, down 2 cents, are now 59 cents a dozen.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 27-- Premier Thakin Nu of Burma will come to New Delhi within ten days to consult with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru on a bilateral treaty with Japan and other matters of high policy in Asia, according to reports current in governmental circles tonight.

The Bonn Government has replied to East Germany's resounding offer of unity with a demand for country-wide free elections, under international supervision, as a first step toward reunification. This counter-move of the Adenauer Cabinet is in response to pressure on the part of the leading groups in the governing coalition as well as of the chief opposition party, the Social Democrats.

Herbert Hoover, in a magazine article made public yesterday, declared that President Calvin Coolide, under whom he served as Secretary of Commerce, had "rejected or side-stepped all our anxious urgings and warnings to take action" against the "orgy of mad speculation which began in 1927."

TUPPER LAKE,H N.Y., Sept. 27 (AP)--Russell E. Dill of Bronxville, N.Y., former vice president of Franklin Simon Co., department store in New York, died in a hospital here today at the age of 59. He was treasurer of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States of America.

The responsibility of the Federal Reserve System for furnishing the banks with reserve balances needed for the current credit demands of expanding defense production is at last showing up in the central bank's open market operations. Financial markets all week have sensed the hand of the Federal Reserve in steps taken to permit commercial banks to turn around in an extremely stringent money market.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 27-- The laboratories of the Radio Corporation of America, were rededicated here today as the David Sarnoff Research Center in honor of the R. C. A. board chairman, who is celebrating his forty-fifth anniversary in radio.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 27 --Miss Cynthia Hodgson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Helms Hodgson 2d, was married this evening to Pfc. John Richardson Butler, son of Mrs. Alfred H. Tull of Larchmont and Charles Richardson Butler of New York, in the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Floyd E. Maguire. A reception was held in the Larchmont Shore Club.

Several books describing the Negro's situation in the United States have been published in the last two years. Now a book about the Negro's position in Europe has been written by Roi Ottley, Negro author of "Black Odyssey."

SALEM, N. H., Sept. 27 (AP)-- J.H. Homan's Adelantado, with Charley Burns in the irons, fought off a double challenge in a thrilling stretch run today to win the Center Harbor, mile feature at Rockingham Park, before 6,693 fans.
SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 27 (AP)--Mother Nature has dipped into seldom-used color pots this autumn to paint the Adirondacks in more vivid hues than even the oldest residents have seen.

The spectacle of a clowning German shepherd dog in the lower plaza at Rockefeller Center yesterday afternoon riled its owner, but won the longest round of applause from more than a thousand spectators during the eighth annual observance of National Dog Week.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 27--The Bundestag emphatically endorsed today Government declaration of West German terms for the reunification of this country.

THE opening gun in the local waterfowl season may be fired at noon today, when scoters, old squaws and eiders become legal game in waters "outside outer harbor lines" in Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New York and Rhode Island.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--Top officials of the steel industry, meeting here today with Charles E. Wilson, head of the Office of Defense Mobilization, pledged their full cooperation in raising output in the critical first quarter of next year.

Leslie B. Soper of 141 East Eighty-eighth Street and Huntington, L.I., a partner in the law firm of Beekman Bogue, 15 Broad Street, died yesterday in the Huntington Hospital as the result of an injury suffered in an accident last Friday. His age was 49.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would deliver today to City Collector Alexander E. Frontera five checks, totaling $2,077,292 covering payments in lieu of taxes on fifty-five permanent housing projects and site properties.

The world premiere of Bronislava Nijinska's "Schumann Concerto" took place at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. It is the single new work to be offered in the current season of the Ballet Theatre, and it would be a pleasure on several counts to be able to report favorably on the occasion, but it is impossible to do so.
In the shadow of the Statue of Liberty on Bedloes Island, the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs held a reception yesterday to presidents of its 200 member clubs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--The Atomic Energy Commission appealed to labor and management today to settle strikes that "will disrupt national defense production schedules."
TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 28 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 1,020 for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A.M., Friday (4 P.M., Thursday, Eastern daylight time):

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--William M. Boyle Jr., chairman of the Democratic National Committee, swore to the Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee today that a charge that he had received $8,000 as a result of a Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan in 1949 to a company for which he was attorney was "unfounded, distorted and false."

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (UP)--Subfreezing weather whistled across the Midwest today as rescue workers cleaned up debris from storms, including two tornadoes, that left twelve persons dead, twenty injured and three missing.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)-- A union leader told President Truman today that there was a great deal of unemployment in the clothing industry because people were not buying as many clothes as expected.

BRIDGEWATER TOWNSHIP, N.J., Sept. 27--Dispersal of industrial and defense plant concentrations to minimize damage in event of attack was urged today by Presley L. Lancaster Jr., deputy director, industrial dispersion task force, National Security Resources Board. Country-wide adoption of this technique is an "absolute necessity" if industry is to survive atomic warfare, Brig. Gen. William L. Barriger, Chief of Staff, First Army, Governor Island, said.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)-- Defense production officials said today proportionately more steel is being allocated to farm machinery makers than to the auto industry.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27--General Electric Company will invest about $450,000,000 for new plants and facilities in the next four years, Philip D. Reed, chairman, and Ralph J. Cordiner, president, said in an interview here today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 27 (AP)--An official of the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation intimated today that the explosions that cost three lives Friday in the suburb of Brighton might have been caused by something other than natural gas.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission refused today to disqualify two of its members from taking part in determining fees in a case involving the United Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--The Senate voted today to tax the expense allowances of the President, Vice President and members of Congress after Jan. 3, 1953.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--Retail prices for fresh beef will advance an average of 1 to 2 cents a pound Oct. 1, the Office of Price Stabilization announced today.

PRIMO CARNERA is one boxing champion who turned to wrestling once his days in the ring had come to an end. Perhaps Willie Pep has the same idea in mind even though a featherweight wrestler would be a trifle on the unusual side. But Willie the Wisp got a flying start at the Polo Grounds the other night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)--A Government-sponsored plan to save newsprint by voluntarily cutting down on the number of newspapers printed for street sale was disclosed to a House committee today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--Department store sales in the United States during the week ended Sept. 22 dropped 1 per cent below sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 27-- Princeton hit the football jackpot last year and carried off more honors than any other Tiger eleven of modern times.

Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson has taken action following a recent warning by the Citizens Committee on Children that the Department of Health is unable to find competent pediatricians to fill six top posts in its child health services because the salaries are so low.

Motion-picture theatre owners of America were told yesterday to "embrace" television as an opportunity to expand their operations, and that the adverse impact of the new medium on attendance was "greatly over-rated."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27--The five-nation committee that sought to find a formula within which the Union of South Africa would agree to comply with a decision of the International Court of Justice regarding South-west Africa, today reported failure in its efforts.

A Board of Education ruling that teachers may be assigned to extracurricular activities outside of regular school hours will be challenged in the courts by the High School Teachers Association, it was announced yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Sept, 27 (UP)-- Harry (Duke) Markell, rookie right-hander of the Browns, turned in his first major league victory today to defeat the Tigers, 7--4, in the final game of the season between the two clubs.

Estimates on canned-food packs for the new "pack year" just starting indicate that peas will be one of the few vegetables in greater supply than in 1950. Processing of peas was completed early in August and some already are on grocers' shelves. So far prices remain the same as those in effect for several months.

After thirty-two years of trying to establish a business and cultural center here, Norwegian interests yesterday opened Norway House at 290 Madison Avenue with the conviction that, at no time in the past, has the need for such an institution been as great as it is at present.
The Soviet Government's concern over widespread theft, embezzlement and similar malpractices on its collective farms is understandable.

Six teen-agers and a 35-year-old man were arrested last night by detectives who said they had amassed between $15,000 and $20,000 in burglaries and hold-ups in the last eight months, and then spent the money "living high' with Times Square girls.

No baseball report is considered fit to print these days unless it makes mention of "the magic number." Maybe mention of same should be included in the report on yesterday's proceedings at Belmont Park, where "how are the Dodgers doing?" was asked almost as ...

Loans to business by New York banks set a fresh new high last week, advancing $57,000,000 to $7,248,000,000. The rise for during the week ended on Wednesday brought the expansion since the end of June to $430,000,000, compared with a gain of $893,000,000 in the corresponding period last year.
Oliver C. Carmichael, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, called on women yesterday to pioneer in educational reforms that would exalt home life and the family.

Federal mediators intervened yesterday in contract negotiations between East Coast longshoremen and their employers and asked that the present agreement be continued past its expiration time of Sunday midnight so the "flow of vitally important cargo will not be interrupted."

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 27--Members of Hudson County's holdover grand jury who are investigating conditions on the Hoboken and Jersey City waterfronts made surprise visits to piers in both cities today to obtain firsthand information on the working conditions of longshoremen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, accused Ambassador at Large Philip C. Jessup under oath today of "following the Communist line" against aid to Britain during the Hitler-Stalin pact.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--The State Department released tonight the following translation of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's statement before the Bundestag in Bonn on the question of German restitution to Jews:

Don Meade, who has been under suspension as a jockey since 1945, submitted an application for reinstatement to the New York State Racing Commission yesterday. The board, made up of Chairman Ashley Trimble Cole, William C. Langlay and Leon Swirbul, gave the reinsman a thorough hearing, but reserved decision.
Uncle Milty, the self-appointed guardian of the nation's youth on Tuesday nights, is a rather trying relative this season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27-- James G. Smyth, Collector of Internal Revenue in San Francisco, and seven persons under his supervision were suspended today, John B. Dunlap, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, announced.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned somewhat irregular yesterday and closed 22 points lower to 1 point higher than on Wednesday.

In a resale of Brooklyn realty he acquired recently, Frederick Brown has disposed of the onestory taxpayer on plot 100 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of Avenue X and East Twenty-first Street and the similar building on plot of the same size across the street at the northwest corner of the two thoroughfares.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 27--The West German Parliament pledged in a dramatic standing vote today to make restitution for wrongs done to Jews in Germany. All the members rose.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--Manly Fleischmann, Administrator of the National Production Authority, warned today that the authority's self-certification plan would be ended, if it were abused.
DOUGLAS, Ariz., Sept. 27 (AP)-- The Phelps Dodge Corporation and the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, independent, today announced final agreement on a new working contract.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP)-- The House Armed Services Committee voted today to establish a new military reserve program giving Congress a close check on the President's use of the corps. The President now has authority to call all reservists to active duty.

GENEVA, Sept. 27--The Contracting Parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade adopted a declaration today releasing the United States from its obligation to refrain from discrimination against Czechoslovak trade.

Masonic support for the establishment of rehabilitation hospitals for teen-age narcotic addicts was urged yesterday at the forty-fifth annual meeting of the National League of Masonic Clubs, Inc., at the Astor Hotel.

Masonic support for the establishment of rehabilitation hospitals for teen-age narcotic addicts was urged yesterday at the forty-fifth annual meeting of the National League of Masonic Clubs, Inc., at the Astor Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) --Following is the text of President Truman's message to Congress today calling for the disclosure of incomes of United States officers and employes:
DEVON, Pa., Sept. 27--With some 350 thoroughbreds from several states competing for seventeen trophies and $11,000, the combined Bryn Mawr-Chester County horse show opened today.

A nation-wide educational campaign against illicit narcotics was started yesterday by the national board of the Young Women's Christian Association at its fall meeting. The drive will be directed primarily toward the parents of teen-agers.

Workers in scores of General Electric plants will strike at once if Federal mediation talks, opening today, prove fruitless in settling the contract dispute between the company and the International Union of Electrical Workers, C.I. O., the union's president declared last night.

A one-time wealthy stockbroker, who twenty years ago paid $100,000 for a seat on the New York Curb Exchange, said yesterday, he was penniless and asked for a lawyer to represent him at a Felony Court hearing of a charge that he had stolen "over $225,000" from clients.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27-- The Federal Trade Commission charged two corporations today with unfair methods of competition and deceptive practices in the sale of advertising space in classified business directories.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 27-- In a directive to local Congress party organizations published today, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, as party president, laid down a policy against choosing "persons representing large vested interests" as Congress party candidates in the January elections.

Commenting on disclosures by the State Crime Commission affecting borough and county officials in Richmond, Rudolph Halley declared last night that "the Staten Island story is the 'Big Fix' in miniature."

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 28--Fiftysix propeller-driven United Nations planes of the naval and air forces hammered and slashed at Communist positions north of Yanggu in east-central Korea in support of allied infantry yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 27-- When today's session of the Majlis or Lower House had to be canceled for want of a debate quorum, Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, not afraid of innovations in parliamentary procedure, went outside and harangued the people instead of the Deputies.

General agreement on a bill that would place the servicing of television receiver sets under strict city regulation was reached yesterday by the committee on general welfare of the City Council at City Hall.

Asserting that "two serious defects exist today in the organization of the municipal government," the Citizens Budget Commission has recommended that the set-up be changed in the fields of management and investigation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--Close upon a State Department appeal to Iran to rescind her order expelling British oil experts from the great Abadan refinery, President Truman said today that he still hoped for a peaceful solution of the bitter Iranian oil controversy.

With the National League suddenly confronted by the strong possibility that its 1951 pennant race could be thrown into a GiantDodger deadlock by Sunday night, developments on the baseball front yesterday fairly galloped to what could be another electrifying finish.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP)-- J. Howard McGrath, Attorney General, said today that a Federal grand jury would investigate the race riots that broke out at Cicero, Ill., last July, when a Negro bus driver moved into an "all-white" neighborhood.

DANVILLE, Ill., Sept. 27--Of the $550,000,000 in defense contracts held by the General Electric Company, more than half will go to about 17,000 sub-contractors and suppliers, it was reported here today by Chester H. Lang, vice president of the company. Many of the 17,000 companies, he added, are small businesses which in turn deal with thousands of others.
To date the new theatrical season hasn't led to any huzzahs, but, despite this deplorable situation, please remember that the season is still in its infancy.

LAST spring the inconstant lit'ry mourners were announcing the coming death of the novel. Now that the novel is obviously in a pretty lively state, maybe the I.L.M.'s will turn their sad eyes to old-fashioned travel books, which have been fairly scarce lately.

ALBANY, Sept. 27--The teaching of history through the recorded dramatization of major historical events in New York State was exhibited today at a preview attended by state officials and leaders of education and civic groups.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--President Truman told woman members of the Democratic party today that truth would be their best weapon in next year's Presidential campaign if they were to defeat the "confusers" endangering world peace with partisan politics.

Sugar was uncertain in action yesterday but other commodity futures markets made sharp gains. Cocoa recovered from its dip on Wednesday's news that Brazil had cut its minimum price to 27 cents a pound. Wool rose the limit in most deliveries on higher foreign prices.
KENT, Conn., Sept. 27--Kent School's football squad appeared unusually large today as it began its daily practice.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, accompanied by the State Department's leading expert on the Soviet Union, is flying to Tokyo for consultations with Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Far East commander.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)-- Secretary of the Interior Oscar Chapman gave his endorsement today to a bill to authorize the building of fuel-fired electrical generating plants in the Pacific Northwest. He was one of a halfdozen witnesses who appeared before the House Public Works Committee in support of the proposal.
Premier Alcide De Gasperi of Italy received an honorary degree at Fordham University yesterday and pledged the Italian people to stand with Americans in defense of democracy.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 28-- United Nations headquarters today awaited a reply from the Communist High Command to a proposal of Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway that the negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war be shifted from Kaesong to Songhyon, eight miles away, but there was unofficial skepticism that an actual ceasefire had come much nearer as a result of the new move.

BOSTON, Sept. 27--On a bitterly disputed decision at the plate by Umpire Frank Dascoli, the Braves today scored a run in the eighth inning to defeat Preacher Roe, 4--3, and cut the Dodgers' first-place lead over the idle Giants to a half game.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 22 totaled 864,310 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
The fifth convention for delegates of 10,000 units of the Roman Catholic Holy Name Society in the United States and Canada will be held in Detroit Tuesday through ...

The Avco Manufacturing Corporation reported yesterday consolidated net income of $7,660,372 for the nine-month period ended Aug. 31 compared with $7,712,538 for the similar period of its previous fiscal year.

Two suave and socially conscious bandits blended business with pleasure Thursday night to relieve a Brooklyn family, very politely, of cash and jewelry valued at $7,600. At the end of their bizarre visit they vanished with apologetic admonitions for continuing cooperation.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 28--The Soviet Union is expected to seek new four power talks on German unity, offering a cut in price as the bait, as the Federal Republic and the Allied powers progress toward the rearmament of West Germany.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept, 28--The independent stockholders committee elected three directors of National Airlines early today, but management succeeded in naming eight to retain control of the airline.

DENVER, Sept. 28 (UP)--A former University of Denver football player told the Colorado Industrial Commission today that a part-time job, free room and free board hinged on his ability to play football.

In a two-day drive to enlist its staff in civil defense operations, the Lenox Hill Hospital, Seventysixth Street and Park Avenue, enrolled 700 of its 800 employes, Edward V. Grant, assistant superintendent, reported yesterday.
ALBANY, Sept. 28--Governor Dewey ordered today a special grand jury investigation in St. Lawrence County, the third such inquiry he has set in motion in the last six months.

As might be expected there is more technical daring than playing safe in the exhibition at the Borgenicht Gallery, of graphic work by artists who have studied at Atelier 17. And, faced by fiftyone works by thirty-eight printmakers, in all graphic mediums and their combinations, both in black-and-white and color, one is bound to find favorites.

The annual celebration of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year 5712, will begin at sundown tomorrow and continue until sundown Tuesday with special services in synagogues, hospitals and community centers as well as on military posts and on the high seas for the Navy. Thousands of men, women and children will take part in many countries. Among Reform Jews the celebration will last but one day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--World religious leaders were chided tonight by President Truman for continued failure to unite in a common affirmation of faith at a time when "the very future of the word of God is at stake."

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 28-- An international film festival will be held in Bombay in December, it was announced today. R.R. Diwakar, Minister for Information and Broadcasting, told Parliament that the festival was being organized to afford an opportunity to Indian film producers and the public to witness some of the best pictures produced abroad and to gain an insight into new techniques.
ALBANY, Sept. 28 (AP)--Bond issues totaling $7,942,420 to finance school construction were approved today by the State Board of Regents.

PARIS, Sept. 28 (UP)--The supervisor of United States military cemeteries in Europe said today that the wooden crosses would not be removed from graves under his control until marble crosses could be obtained in replace them.

A 50-year-old business man who had been cited as a benefactor of the blind was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on a charge he had claimed falsely that he had reimbursed fourteen sightless employes when he was sentenced last March for failing to pay them overtime.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 28-- The marriage of Miss Patricia Anne Karl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Frederick Karl, to Kenneth Walter Sheeleigh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthias Sheeleigh of Little Falls, took place here this evening in St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church.

LONDON, Sept. 28--The British Government decided tonight to appeal to the Security Council of the United Nations to call upon the Iranian Government to adhere to the interim recommendation of the International Court of Justice at The Hague in the dispute with Iran over oil.
Robert D. Ross has purchased a cooperative apartment in 133 West Seventy-fifth Street from Andrew J. Poggi through the Houghton Company, broker.

The appointment of Capt. Edgar A. Shergold, master of the 26,300ton liner Empress of Scotland, as general superintendent of the Canadian Pacific line in the United Kingdom was announced yesterday. A veteran of service afloat through two world wars, Captain Shergold will supervise the operation of all of the company's ships.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 28--Arthur Fitz-James Crandall of Pleasantville Road, Briarcliff Manor, news editor of The New York Evening Post from 1891 until his retirement in 1921, died in a nursing home here yesterday at the age of 97.

To encourage the use of food products in season, Robert Krueger has calculated for the department of agricultural economics of the New York State College of Agriculture, Cornell University, the seasonal variation in New York City food prices for the more important groups of food commodities.

It was a good night for the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Everybody was in fine form, spirits were all up to normal and so were tempos. Give half a chance to this company of handsome and capable youngsters, and they will dance their heads off.
The following is a round-up of new items to assist the homemaker with the family laundering and ironing.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 28-- The Connecticut Superior Court has been asked to decide whether a woman war worker can be disqualified from collecting unemployment compensation if she refuses to work later than 5 P.M. because of obligations to her family.

Edward A. Ruppell, Staten Island Republican leader accused by witnesses before the State Crime Commission of shaking down Republican officeholders and exacting cash tributes for interceding for liquor licenses, announced yesterday his intention of resigning as chairman of the Richmond County Republican Committee.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--Canada formally offered today to construct alone the $219,000,000 St. Lawrence Seaway to open the way for large ocean-going ships as far west as Detroit.
For an hour tonight the world will stop turning while we set our clocks and watches back. Last spring the world doubled its speed for an hour, but no one noticed the acceleration.
BOSTON, Sept. 28 (AP)--The Giants almost lifted the roof off their Back Bay hotel headquarters tonight when they learned that they had been pushed into a firstplace tie when the Dodgers were beaten.

Despite extensive post-war dispersal of manufacturing plants and mines, the Soviet Union's railroad transport system still staggers under a heavy load of excessively long haulage as well as of irrational cross-shipments, the Government magazine Planovoye Khozyaistvo reveals.
LONDON, Sept. 28--The element of confusion was introduced into the stock markets here today by a proposal in the Conservative election manifesto for an excess profits tax.

The pressure of public opinion in Britain for a "strong line" in Iran is hard for the Government to resist. In answer to reports that the Iranians are seizing the Abadan refinery by force there is a rising demand in England for the landing of troops to protect British property.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--Demands for the bank records of William M. Boyle Jr., chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and for more information than he had furnished concerning his income tax returns for 1949 and 1950 were made by the Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee today.

Commissioner of Licenses Edward T. McCaffrey announced yesterday the revocation of the licenses of two Broadway theatre ticket agencies. The license deprivations, to become effective today, stemmed from alleged "digging," the use of "stooges" to purchase tickets at the box-office or through the mails, and of failure to account satisfactorily for prices of tickets billed to charge customers.

Five years ago, when Dr. Lewis Webster Jones was president of Bennington College in Vermont, he knew all his 300 students--many by their first names. Later, when he became president of the University of Arkansas, which has 5,500 students, he strove to keep in personal touch with his students in spite of the numerical odds.

Eugene Plotnikoff, a 'cellist under Tchaikovsky before the turn of the century and well known here as an orchestra conductor, collapsed and died at 10:45 o'clock last night in the City Center, Fifty-sixth Street near Seventh Avenue. His age was 73.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28--The City Council ordered an investigation today of the financial affairs of the Independence Homecoming Committee, Inc., which managed last July's four-day celebration of the 175th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence.

Israel's waterfront, its only border now open to the rest of the world, is being rapidly improved to handle its increased shipping activity and expanding young merchant marine, Raphael Recanati, general manager here of the Israel-America Line, said here yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28-- The effects, if any, of the uprising in Argentina on Twentieth Century-Fox's projected filming there of the Technicolor adventure "Way of a Gaucho," had studio officials guessing today.
Benjamin Veit, former Assistant Superintendent of Schools in this city, died yesterday at his home in the Mayflower Hotel after a long illness. His age was 84.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP)--Following is the text of the British Foreign Office's statement calling on the United Nations Security Council to intervene in the British-Iranian oil dispute:

Mrs. Leslie Coffelt of Arlington, Va., widow of the Secret Service guard who was killed last Nov. 1 while protecting President Truman at Blair House in Washington, received the first meritorious service award medal of the National League of Masonic Clubs at a dinner meeting here last night in the Astor Hotel.

The R.H. Macy Company has taken title to a thirty-acre tract at State Highways 4 and 17 in Paramus, N.J., which eventually will contain a branch of Macy's New Jersey subsidiary, L. Bamberger Co. of Newark. The seller was the Germain-Hegeman Company of New York. George H. Beckmann, Feist Feist and Charles H. Borg were the brokers.

The baseball dispute in Boston on Thursday had repercussions yesterday when Ford Frick, president of the National League, fined Jackie Robinson and Roy Campanella of the Dodgers $100 each and Preacher Roe $50. There were no suspensions.

A temporary shortage of beef at two large Army installations in the metropolitan area has impelled the Army to appeal to the Office of Police Stabilization for aid in locating local sources of supply, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- Following is the text of an address by President Truman tonight to the Washington Pilgrimage of American Churchmen:

The Perons can always be counted upon to furnish us with drama. The sudden flash in the pan with which we were entertained yesterday is in keeping with the general atmosphere of tension and histrionics that the Perons introduced.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP)--A Government official today advised manufacturers of increased metal shortages but a director of research said shortages "aren't in the cards and never were."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- The ninety cadets recently ousted from West Point for cribbing of examinations could be reappointed to the Academy, an Army spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--The State Department withheld official comment today on the reports of a revolt in Argentina, restrained partly by diplomatic propriety and partly by its professed lack of information on the situation. But there was less reluctance among other informed observers, and their speculation leaned heavily toward the view that the "revolt" had been staged by the Peron Government.

Taunted by children, a 5-yearold bulldog went berserk last night in the Bronx, mangled his master, terrorized several hundred neighbors and kept the policemen at bay until he was captured two hours later.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, charged under oath today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, had perjured himself before the Senate in his campaign against alleged Communists in the State Department.
ALBANY, Sept. 28--The Board of Regents recommended today approximately 2,481 additional state scholarships during the 1952-53 fiscal year.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 (AP)--Lack of a clear, authoritative voice on economic issues is endangering private banking, the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks was told today.
PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 28 (AP) --Three Negroes who were refused admission to the Pensacola Vocational School filed notice of appeal of their cases to the Florida Supreme Court today.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 29-- The Communist High Command remained silent for the second day today on the proposal of Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway to shift the site of the interrupted negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war from Kaesong to the no-man'sland village of Songhyon, eight miles to the southeast.

An article in the September issue of State Government, published by the Council of State Governments, tells of the new and modern method adopted by the House of Delegates of West Virginia to record its proceedings.

J.A. Bruderman Sons, plumbing supply distributors, have purchased the newly completed onestory warehouse and office building at 27-03 Fortieth Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, from Williamson Adams, builders and contractors, and will occupy it as a branch warehouse. Queens Industrials were the brokers. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that a prospectus offering 386,670 shares of Cristina Copper Mines, Inc., capital shares at $1 has been used to permit the unloading of at least 52,050 unregistered promotors' shares at 50 cents and less are being heard at the commission's offices, 120 Broadway.

PARIS, Sept. 28--While the Arabs and Israelis both are sparring for time and position, indications are reaching Paris that the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission conference may be able to take the first step toward a formal Israeli-Arab peace. No more than first steps are expected after three years of deadlock.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28-- An agreement between the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A.F.L., and the Pacific Maritime Association, averting a threatened strike by the seafarers at the expiration of their coastwise contract at midnight on Sunday, was reported tonight by Omar Hoskins, Federal Conciliation Commissioner.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M., Sept. 28 (UP)--Striking plumbers threw picket lines across roads to this top-secret atomic project today because they said "contractors were caught" using nonunion men to complete plumbing work. The Atomic Energy Commission had no immediate comment.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28--Premier Alicide De Gasperi of Italy said today that his country regarded admission to the United Nations as important as the campaign to revise the Italian peace treaty.

If persons living in daylight saving time areas remember to turn back their clocks one hour tonight they will regain the hour of sleep lost on April 29, when daylight saving time became effective. The official hour for reverting to Eastern standard time is 2 A.M. tomorrow.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 28-- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today told an enthusiastic and well-informed assemblage of high school students who seemed much concerned about events in Korea that the United Nations should have a strong police force.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- The Pacific Northwest power shortage generated developments all over Capitol Hill today. In quick succession:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that it would receive testimony concerning changed conditions since it approved a plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific Railroad in 1949, with a view to possible revision of that plan.

Alfred A. Tausk, principal since 1932 of Boys' High School, Brooklyn, died yesterday in the Swedish Hospital, that borough, after a brief illness. His age was 64. He lived at 780 St. Marks Avenue, Brooklyn.

KAISERSLAUTERN, Germany, Sept. 28--Western Europe's largest post-war air maneuvres got off to a bad start today because of poor weather. Theoretically this aided equally large-scale maneuvers by French and United States ground forces in which the Redland forces were counter-attacked east of the Rhine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--The Army's traditional O. D.--olive drab--uniform may be on the way out. In its stead, the supply sergeant of the future may issue a greenish-gray woolen dress uniform to which the enlisted man may affix resplendent gold chevrons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- The long-expected resignation of Mon C. Wallgren as chairman of the Federal Power Commission was accepted "with genuine regret" today by President Truman, his friend from their days in the Senate. It is effective Oct. 1.

Shorter work weeks for 26,375 of the 40,997 employes of the municipal transit lines became effective yesterday under informal agreements between the Board of Transportation and the labor unions representing the transit workers.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 28--The Tennessee Valley Authority announced today that it had approved contracts calling for delivery of 18,043,750 tons of coal over periods of from one to ten years at 2 total cost of $63,331,875.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28--Light to heavy frosts occurred according to schedule over the northwestern areas of the Corn Belt last night but the general opinion appeared to be that they were not heavy enough to inflict serious damage, and prices in th corn pit were reactionary. Weakness in both corn and soybeans affected the other grains and there was a general sell-off in all pits.

Commenting on the vote Thursday of the West German Government to begin negotiations with Israel and Jewish groups to make restitution for wrongs done to Jews in Germany, Dr. Nahum Goldmann, co-chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, said yesterday:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--The Wage Stabilization Board announced an interplant inequity policy today under which the lowest-paying employers in an industry or area would be permitted to raise their wages to "stabilized levels" to correct proved inequities.
OUTSIDE the field of the novel, someone was saying the other day, the majority of books published at the moment seems to fall into three main categories: How to Do, What to Do and Derring Do.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sent. 28--Torontina, a 14-month-old Canadianbred wire-haired fox terrier owned by the all-around judge, Anton Rost of New York, made her debut in show competition a noteworthy one today by becoming best in her variety at the fall specialty of the American Fox Terrier Club. It was held at the Meadow Brook Club.

The Stock market completed yesterday its final short week of the year with softening tendencies again prevalent. The list through the greater part of the session followed the line of least resistance-- buyers stepped aside when any selling appeared and only entered bids in the afternoon when pressure subsided. Cross currents ran through the market.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28--Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz, the self-exiled Buenos Aires publisher who is regarded as a symbol in the world-wide fight for freedom of the press, said here today that he was not surprised at reports of a revolt in Argentina.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--The International Monetary Fund abandoned its efforts today to prevent diversion of world gold production into private hoards. In a new policy statement the agency said that, while it was no less opposed to premium transactions in the metal, there was little it could do to police the $600,000,000 traffic.

A hiring clause covering the calling in of night workers remained the single block to settlement yesterday as contract talks between the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L., and East Coast employing stevedores were recessed until Monday morning.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 28--Groups of Argentina's armed forces revolted against the Peron Government this morning. At 3:30 P.M., in a speech from the balcony of Casa Rosada, or Gov ernment House, President Juan Peron announced that the bulk of the Army, Navy and Air Force had remained loyal and that the revolt had been crushed
Prospects of a long week-end including Rosh ha-Shansh on Monday, deadened commodity trading yesterday. Volume fell and prices generally moved lower as traders evened up for the break in trading.

ROME, Sept. 28--A surplus of world tin production over consumption was forseen in 1951 and 1952 by the five-day conference of the principal tin producing and consuming countries which closed in Rome today.

In furthering its efforts to provide improved building standards throughout the country, the National Association of Home Builders will conduct another neighborhood development contest this year. Entries may include economy and higher priced one-family houses, garden apartments shopping centers and complete neighborhood developments.

The "unknown and unsung" woman on the home front must be drawn into the labor pool to provide the quotas of the armed services, the nursing corps, defense jobs and community services, a conference on "Women in the Defense Decade" agreed yesterday.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 29--In what was probably the Communist forces' largest ground effort in Korea in recent weeks, the Reds struck yesterday along a sixtymile front from Yonchon to the Punchbowl, north of Inje, in the east. The enemy registered scattered gains.
The Studebaker Corporation reported yesterday that it is now receiving regular shipments of forging steel from several Belgian steel companies under contracts signed earlier this year.

NEWARK, Sept. 28 (AP)--Federal and state mediators acted today to settle spreading strikes that have paralyzed defense work at several New Jersey plants. Early today, a new walkout of 3,000 C.I.O. rubber workers closed the Passaic plant of the United States Rubber Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--In the Protestant Episcopal Cathe dral of SS. Peter and Paul here this afternoon Miss Lydia Clare Foster, daughter of Vice Admiral Edwin Dorsey Foster, U.S.N., Supply Corps, retired, and Mrs. Foster of Philadelphia, was married to Meade Carrington Patrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Lawrence Patrick of Danville, Va. The Rev. Crawford W. Brown performed the ceremony. There was a reception at the Army and Navy Club.

Good things come in small packages, the old saying goes. A new restaurant on the Manhattan scene presents excellent French cookery in limited space--too limited, this reporter thinks, in view of the deliciousness of the cuisine, which must certainly attract hordes of gourmets.

Refiners here received certificates from metal users yesterday for lead and zinc allotments in October, and it was reported doubtful whether all allotments for zinc issued for that month by the National Production Authority can be filled.

The split-level house is threatening to supplant the ranch home in Bergen County, according to B.J. Bergton, agent for many new housing developments in Northern New Jersey, who sees the splitlevel as a compromise between the sprawling ranch dwelling and the conventional two-story residence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--Average primary market prices ad vanced 0.4 per cent in the week ended Sept. 25, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The index, 177.1 per cent of the 1926 average, was 4.2 per cent above a year ago and 12.9 per cent above the pre-Korean (May 24June 25, 1950) average.

Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan ruled yesterday that E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.; Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., of Great Britain, and the Remington Arms Company, Inc., had conspired to divide markets in munitions, chemicals and small arms in volation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 28-- Navy, which turned in a startling 14-2 upset triumph over Army in its final game of the 1950 football season, will open its new campaign in a game with Yale tomorrow.

James Felt, president of James Felt Co., yesterday praised the Bowery Savings Bank's projected Harlem housing development as "an example of the type of program which private 'enterprise should sponsor in forward looking communities."

Harry Gross told the Brooklyn grand jury of a "bookie fund" into which regular contributions were made for the election campaigns of former Mayor William O'Dwyer, both in 1945 and in 1949, it was learned last night. Gross said his own contributions totaled $20,000-- $5,000 in 1945 and $15,000 in 1949.

The Bank of New York and Fifth Avenue Bank, as co-trustee, has sold to an investor the six-story apartment house for forty-seven families on plot 100 by 100 feet at 59 to 65 St. Nicholas Avenue and 133 West 113th Street in a deal negotiated by the A.J. Clarke Management Corporation and Fred E. De Mendez, brokers. The building contains four stores.

It was twilight in Hanover Square and the last piles of afternoon papers dwindled on Nat Kestenbaum's newsstand. The candies and cigarettes, the fruit and magazines were gone already. The racks looked bleak and empty, like a vacant house.
Premier Alcide De Gasperi of Italy urged the United States in diplomatic language yesterday to help his country solve its overpopulation problem by easing our immigration restrictions.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 28--The $156,445 estate of a department store doorman-Santa Claus will go to Williams College, his alma mater, according to documents filed here today with Probate Judge John P. Flanagan. The estate includes ...

Land costs may be the deciding factor in determining whether North Jersey home builders can get down to $12,000 on an attractive small home to take advantage of the relaxed credit terms applying to such houses, in the opinion of Arther E. Williamson, vice president and sales manager of the Edmund Williamson Company of Teaneck.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 (AP)--Quarterback Norman Van Brocklin set a new National Football League passing record tonight as he pitched the Los Angeles Rams to a 54-14 victory over the New York Yanks.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24--Soviet historians appear to have undertaken the examination of United States history and United States policy with a view to picturing United States actions as villainous not only with respect to the Soviet Union but toward virtually all other countries of the world and in all eras of United States development.
Eric Johnston, Economic Stabilization Administrator, replied to his business critics yesterday in a fighting speech defending direct economic controls for the next two years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- Representative Overton Brooks, Democrat of Louisiana, directed the attention of Congress today to the case of an Air Force sergeant who was fined $1,000 for beating to death his wife, mother of two small children.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- Following are the ten "case studies" listed by Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, today in support of his resolution to expel Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, from the Senate:

MANILA, Sept. 28--The No. 2 Communist leader of the Philippines, for whom a $52,000 reward had been offered, dead or alive, was slain today. The action capped a day of scattered disorders incident to initial registration for the Nov. 13 elections for Senators, Governors and Mayors.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28--With two men in Russian uniforms patrolling its premises, Station KMPC regaled Los Angeles radio listeners with thirteen hours of intermittent praise of Marshal Stalin and other Soviet propaganda today to show them what programs would be like under Communist dictatorship.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., Sept. 28-- The football team at Hotchkiss School last year created quite a stir in prep school circles. The Blue, fortified by a remarkably heavy line, won all six games in its most successful campaign since 1934.

Horace Murphy, a 30-year-old resident of Houston, Tex., described by Federal authorities as the leader of an eight-man ring that had been selling large quantities of marijuana in the New York area since last January, was held yesterday in $25,000 bail.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 (AP)--Duplicating his six-under-par 65 of the first round, Defender Cary Middlecoff led the field today as the $15,000 St. Louis open golf tournament completed its second trip around the Meadow Brook Country Club course.
Army, Navy, Princeton, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Michigan and Notre Dame are some of the big college football teams that will make their seasonal debut today.

In a brilliant display of allaround skill that included a nerve tingling no-hitter in one encounter and a seven-run explosion in the other the Yankees yesterday clinched the 1951 American League pennant. It was their third flag in a row and eighteenth in thirty years.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 28--Former State Democratic Leader Frank Hague, who retired in 1947 as Mayor of Jersey City after thirty years in office, spent today answering questions by State Attorney General Theodore Parsons in pretrial testimony in a $2,000,000 libel suit against Mr. Hague by former Judge John Warren, a local attorney.

The first weeks of autumn offer a bountiful supply of cut flowers, colorful as an artist's palette. They are for the most part long-lasting kinds, but the cooler weather is a great help in this respect.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 28-- A long winning streak will be placed on the line in Palmer Stadium tomorrow when a rebuilt Princeton eleven opens its season against N.Y.U.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--President Truman signed into law today a measure authorizing a $5,864,301,178 global military construction program, including a ring of secret overseas air bases close enough to the Soviet Union so that the Air Force could retailiate against attack and neutralize the enemy's war potential.

This morning's new film is "The Magic Face," a Columbia drama of Germany under Hitler, starring Luther Adler and Patricia Knight, at Loew's Criterion. The film was written and produced by Mort Briskin and Robert Smith, and Frank Tuttle directed. The supporting cast includes William L. Shiner, who also serves as narrator; Ilka Windish, Heinz Moog, Peter Preses, Manfred Inger and Jasper Von Oertzen.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28--The pennant hopes of the Dodgers were dealt their most crushing blow tonight when the Phils came from a 3-0 deficit to a 4-3 victory and dropped the Brooks into a first-place tie' with the idle Giants.

Television receiver sales in three major California cities are booming. The coming World Series was given yesterday by several set manufacturers as the principal reason for substantial and steadily increasing volume.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Sept. 28 (UP)--The Southern Conference, largest collegiate football league in the East, agreed today to vote out bowl games and ban transfer students from athletics.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--The Senate passed the tax-increase bill tonight, after rejecting all efforts to increase its annual revenue yield over the $5,500,000,000 recommended by the Finance Committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 (AP) --Censorship of Korean war news and photographs was erratic and "formulated as the censors went along," a Pulitzer Prize winning war photographer told managing editors today.

There are many good things about Sunday. The late breakfast is one, that breakfast distinguished by sausage and griddle cakes and, if the omens are right and the cook of a kindly nature, the one that sometimes even is eaten in bed.

The American Broadcasting Company has given Walter Winchell a lifetime contract as a radio and television consultant. The arrangement is separate from his services on his Sunday night radio broadcasts, which have been renewed by the current sponsor in a deal said to involve cash payments and transfer of company stock.

VIENNA, Sept. 28--At a stormy meeting of the Allied Council today the Russians accused the Western Occupation powers of "creating a bridgehead for a new war and threatening the peace" in their zones of Austria.

ATHENS, Sept. 28--King Paul today addressed a personal letter to Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, imploring him to change his mind and head a three-party coalition composed of his own Greek Rally party, Gen. Nicholas Plastiras' Progressive Union of the Center and Sophocles Venizelos' Liberals.

POUND RIDGE, N. Y., Sept. 28 --Thunderclaps echoed through the wooded countryside last night and swallen streams cascaded across highways, but inside the Pound Ridge schoolhouse bright lights glowed and gay voices rose as the town folk--old-timers and newcomers alike--showed how the only church in town had become a dynamic part of community life.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP)-- The Standing Committee of Correspondents said today that it had refused to expel the Russian news agency, Tass, from the Congressional press galleries because the presence of Tass' representatives was not a violation of the present rules.

Duane Jones, president of the Duane Jones Company, Inc., agency handling packaged products, said yesterday that he expected to announce in a few days a list of clients who will place billings of about $1,500,000 a year with him. Some of these are accounts formerly with the agency. Mr. Jones resigned all his accounts ...
MONTREAL, Sept. 28 (AP)--A hummingbird that missed a flight south will get a lift on its way to warmer climes tomorrow by DC-4 airliner.

LONDON, Sept. 28--Only the Conservative party can give Britain a stable government "free of doctrinal prejudices" and the "passions of class warfare," Winston Churchill declared today in an election manifesto calling for a halt in the socialization of the nation's economy.

Secretary of Defense Robert Lovett emphasized yesterday that the armed forces depended upon the civilian population to replenish "dangerously depleted" supplies of plasma, and made clear that the Red Cross was the only organization officially collecting blood supplies for the services.

Stockholders of D.A. Schulte, Inc., tobacco store chain will meet on Oct. 5 to vote on a proposal to issue 792,157 shares of presently authorized but unissued $1 par value common stock. Proceeds from the sale would be used for conversion of part of the company's stores to the food and soft drink dispensing field.

Business in the apparel trades in general and the dress business in particular will show marked improvement with the approach of the holiday season, it was predicted yesterday by David Schwartz, president of Jonathan Logan Inc., one of the largest junior dress manufacturers in the country.

Aided by Allie Reynolds' second no-hit, no-run game of the season the Yankees clinched their third straight American League pennant yesterday. In the National League, a 4-3 Dodger defeat at Philadelphia last night dropped the Brooklyn club into a tie for first place with the Giants, who were idle.

The four-story commercial building at 301 Broadway, Brooklyn, has been sold by Aaron L. Glickman to the Poplar Realty Corporation. The property occupies a plot 25 by 85 feet and is assessed at $28,000. Martin J. List was the broker. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.
NORTH BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 28--Charging that many stables are cleaner and better than this township's courtroom, Magistrate Nathaniel Brittingham resigned today.

There are only two books being published today. The F.W. Dodge Corporation is issuing at $8.50 "Planning and Building the Modern Church," by William Ward Watkin. Putnam his at $6 "The Yale Football Story," by Tim Cohane, a history of the game at that university.

Gray iron foundries in many industrial centers are cutting back operating schedules as a result of reduced allocations of metals for the production of consumer goods, it was revealed here yesterday by members of the Gray Iron Founders' Society, national trade organization.

Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has led his West German compatriots in the first step in the right direction in dealing with the crimes against the Jews by Hitler's Germany. His declaration of the intent to make restitution and reparation within his country's ability is a phase of moral regeneration.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28-- Robert Pyle, internationally known rose grower and president of the Conard-Pyle Company at near-by West Grove since 1906, died today in Chester County Hospital, West Chester. He was 74 years old.

Richard Everett Dwight, senior partner in the law firm of Dwight, Royall, Harris, koegel Caskey, 100 Broadway, who had been a member of the New York bar for fifty-two years, died yesterday in his apartment at 375 Park Avenue. His age was 76.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28-- Pennsylvania opens its football season tomorrow against California on Franklin Field, and it appears that the team ranked first in the Ivy group, if not in the East, is biting off more than it can digest.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28--America's superiority in weapons for defense may be lost unless the Defense Department recognizes the necessity of assigning technical men to jobs to which they are fitted by their training, according to Carey H. Brown, manager of engineering and manufacturing services...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--The Federal Loyalty Review Board, the highest in that field, has notified a Senate subcommittee that it has reviewed and found justified the State Department's loyalty clearance of Ambassador at Large Philip C. Jessup.

CLINTON, Conn., Sept. 28--A strong breeze which roughened up the Sound and pushed the scoters to the lee of the Shore "inside" the outer harbor lines, dashed the hopes of those who planned to get in the halfday opening on the tidal islands and breakwaters in this area.

Probing attacks by an enemy battalion in area north-northwest of Yonchon continues as of midnight Thursday). Aggressive attacks by enemy groups of platoon to regimental strength reported in area northwest of Chorwon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--Although the newsprint situation is still "critical," there should be adequate supplies available without Government regulation, executives of the National Production Authority told an industry advisory ...

UNION, N.J., Sept. 28--Industrial construction here during the first eight months of 1951 has shown an increase of nearly $2,000,000, Building Inspector Herbert F. Williams revealed today in a report to the Township Committee.

Acting to meet the growing shortage of coins, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and the New York State Bankers Association issued special appeals yesterday to banking institutions throughout this area. Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank, in a letter being sent to all banks in the Second Federal Reserve...

Indicating that the business of winning a pennant was "old hat" to them, the Yankees showed remarkable restraint yesterday at the Stadium, after they had clinched their eighteenth American League flag. A group of casual acquaintances, meeting by chance in the subway, would display more emotion than Casey Stengel's heroes did in the clubhouse after the twin bill.

Although former Generals Arturo Rawson and Benjamin Menendez, accused as leaders in the Argentine rising yesterday, hated the Peron regime, there was virtually no chance that a movement under their leadership could have overturned the Government. Curiously enough, the two men fought a sabre duel in 1940 in which both were wounded.

In the course of his exhortation to his party on the choice of political candidates Prime Minister Nehru has made clear some of the difficulties he is facing in trying to build a solid modern state. He is working earnestly to get a good Government. He is committed to the concept of a representative secular government. His road is not an easy one.
The alternating American hopes of victory or peace in Korea were dashed again last week, as the enemy build-up continued and sharp Communist attacks were launched along much of the front.

PREPARATIONS are already under way for the next long week-end, which starts Columbus Day, Oct. 12. A legal holiday in most states, the day falls on Friday this year, giving hundreds of workers an opportunity for short vacations.

THE peruked, brimming and licentious England of Hogarth was recreated amid the Byzantine splendor of Venice by way of opera this month and the results evoked more fanfare than any opera premi re since the days of Puccini and Mascagni.
POSTMASTER GENERAL JESSE M. DONALDSON has heeded philatelists' laments, which have become vociferous in recent weeks, that three months without a new commemorative stamp is too long a lapse.
Plans for meeting the demand for the popular three-bedroom dwelling in Queens were announced yesterday by various builders.

Rudolph Halley charged last night that unscrupulous landlords in the city were exploiting lowerincome tenants and that, official corruption and incompetence were contributing to a rise in injuries and disease.
An entire blockfront on the north side of Queens Boulevard, between Sixty-fifth Road and Sixty-sixth Avenue, in Forest Hills, is providing the site for three sixstory rental apartment buildings,...

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 29-- There were a few honest, upstanding racetrackers among the 54,000 persons at the football game in the Yale Bowl today. The racetrackers felt right at home. The game wound up in a dead-heat.

THE strong wave of optimism that is currently flooding the film industry after months--and even years-- of dark despairing and weeping into beer is beginning, thank goodness, to slop over and afford some flotation for the hopes of those simple sideline observers who had been led to fear that the movies were through.

WILTON, Conn., Sept. 29--In the Wilton Congregational Church this afternoon, Miss Sarah Diane Halsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Rittenhouse Halsey, formerly of Bronxville, N.Y., was married to Lieut. Joseph Sanford Stoutenburgh, U.S.N., son of Mrs. D. Ward Harrigan of Brooklyn, New York, and the late Guy Holden Stoutenburgh.

IN the brief compass of seventy-seven pages, Archibald Davison has written a refreshing treatment of the giant composers Bach and Handel, re garded as the consummation of the baroque in music. Mr. Davison is both a wise and witty writer.

Geographically, Italy occupies a key position in the North Atlantic Alliance, But its actual contribution in men and materials has been handicapped by the arms limitations of the 1947 treaty and its hard-scrabble, gnaw-bone economy.

As the result of an expansion program which has been marked by an increase in gross annual sales from $400,000,000 to more than $1,000,000,000 in the ten years since L.A. Van Bomel became president, National Dairy Products...
SYOSSET, L.I., Sept. 29--Jewelry valued at $100,000 was stolen from Mrs. Mellon Bruce's 121-acre estate here some time during her absence this week.
IN Walter Eucken's view, economic life expresses itself and can be discovered in everyday facts. Nobody can object to...

Some of the heroes of the breakthrough of the Hindenburg Line were together again yesterday on the thirty-third anniversary of that historic battle of World War I. By the end of last week most of the nation's 1,850 institutions of higher learning had completed their enrollment. Classrooms and campuses were active again as the 1951-52 academic year got under way.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29-- President Juan Peron's wife is very sick, it is believed. An official statement by the Subsecretariat of Information after her broaddcast last night said she was suffering from anemia, for which she was receiving blood transfusions. There is a private report that the President has told intimates it is pernicious anemia, for which there is no known cure.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29--Facing near-elimination from the National League pennant race, the Dodgers and big Don Newcombe rose magnificently to the challenge under the Shibe Park lights tonight by beating the Phils, 5--0, and moving back into a first-place tie with the Giants.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP)--With temperatures rising in the Midwest corn and soybean belts, prices of both those commodities sank on the Board of Trade today. Soybeans lost the most ground, being adversely influenced also by easing tendencies in crude soybean oil.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29--The United States center of population, continuing its unbroken westward movement, is now eight miles north-northwest of Olney, Ill.

TUCKED away on the second floor of a hangar at La Guardia Airport is a fantastic electronic gadget that commercial airline flight crews first approached with joking skepticism but now regard with unreserved respect. They know from experience that it works, and works well.

NOT all of the sculptors and painters whose works are included in the exhibition, Lehmbruck and His Con temporaries, at the Curt Valentin Gallery, are seen at their best, but justice, at least, is done the key figure, one of the greatest sculptors that this century has so far produced.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29--Integration of the economic war effort already under way with the nation's military requirements in the months to come is a major problem slated for consideration by banking leaders gathering here today for their annual convention.
Long Island builders announced plans yesterday for new housing developments on old estate land holdings in Nassau and Suffolk counties.

LONDON, Sept 29--Vast air maneuvers began here today as Air Secretary Arthur Henderson warned that in the event of war the Soviet Union and its satellites could put into the air 8,000 tactical aircraft--three times as many as Hitler had in 1940.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29-- Admiral Enrique Garcia, Argentine Navy Minister since 1948, resigned today in what was believed to be the direct aftermath of yesterday's abortive revolt against the Peron Government by small groups of Army, Air Force and Navy personnel.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday its endorsement of Rudolph Halley, Liberal-IndependentCity Fusion candidate for President of the City Council, on the ground that it would be "highly salutary to have an independent man" on the Board of Estimate.

THE herring has been many things to many men. Struggle for control of the herring fishery on the East Anglian coast caused wars between England and Holland. Wars, too, sprang up between some of the Hanseatic cities and the Baltic states over herring fishing grounds.

One out of every fifty in the United States over the age of 40 is a victim of glaucoma, a disease of the eye that can lead to blindness if not treated in time. Glaucoma is a leading cause of loss of sight, One of every eight blind people is a victim.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29--An increase in the November draft of 5,300 and a total draft call for November and December of 55,900 were announced by the Department of Defense today.

IF proof is needed that the pioneering spirit in the motion picture industry has not yet succumbed to the big-studio stencil, three brothers can offer it with a two-reel short subject which, working under grave handicaps and on a shoestring budget, they have produced right here in New York.

For month after month into years the issue of political "corruption" has been a persistent theme in Washington. "Probes" have followed one an other in the headlines almost without a break. Mostly the "corruption" charges have been directed against the Administration.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29--Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia, served notice today that he had sponsored his last tax increase bill "short of an all-out war or war crisis."

The New York University archaeological expedition to the island of Samothrace in the Aegean Sea has unearthed two ancient Greek structures, Dr. Karl Lehmann, director of the New York University Research Fund and head of the expedition, announced yesterday. He identified the structures as a hall for votive gifts of about the sixth century B.C. and a great altar court for public sacrificial rites.
Two Senate committees and an official Air Force pronouncement have called attention to the "substandard" condition of some of the housing around military bases in various parts of the country.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29--The Indonesian delegation to the United Nations said its reluctent good-bys this week to a young New York woman who walked into an Indonesian Information Office one day and stayed on to work for four years.

ATHENS, Sept. 29--Breaking the political deadlock that had drought Greece's national administration virtually to a standstill, King Paul put the Governmental mandate today in the hands of 68year-old Gen. Nicholas Plastiras.

VANGUARD has brought out a disk, played by the Vienna State Opera Orchestra under Felix Prohaska, which unblushingly has three key words printed on the album cover: Schubert's Gastein Symphony. What's this? The lost "Gastein" rediscovered? Who was responsible for this awesome musical scoop?

Macdonald of Walloston and North Eastham, Mass., in the Marble Collegiate Dutch Reformed Church.

Robert Marsh Sandoe, U.S. M.C.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nichol Main Sandoe of Pelham Manor, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles Atwater.
