The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Camille Bauer, daughter of Augustus W. Bauer of Needham Heights, Mass., and the late Mrs. Agnes White Bauer, to John Tristram Savage, son of Dr. Ross E. Savage of Gloucester, Mass., took place yesterday afternoon in the Little Church Around the Corner.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29--The first Washington Pilgrimage of American Churchmen honored two colleagues tonight for demonstrating in their daily lives that "belief in God and religious principles" was the capstone of democracy.

Perhaps the dullest radio broadcast that can be imagined is a list of stock quotations when the listener is not in the market and does not intend to be. But Radio Station WRUL (Radio Boston) has found that a daily report of 170 New York Stock and Curb Exchange and commodity futures prices has become one of its most popular features.

NO man, and especially no creative man, wants to be posthumous while he is still alive. The realization of his potentialities gives only puerile satisfaction if it leaves him isolated and remote instead of bringing him closer to other men. For the serious artist the problem of maintaining his integrity and still feeling a productive oneness with the world is crucial and delicate.

FREDERICK, Md., Sept. 29--A chapter of the history of the Civil War was closed in this historic town today when the final payment was made on a $200,000 ransom loan that saved Frederick from destruction on July 9, 1864.

LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP)--The Belton Warrierers returned to the top of the first division in English soccer today as they beat Charlton Athletic, 2 to 1, while Portsmouth downed Aston Villa, the erstwhile letter, 2 to 0.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)-- Most parcel post rates will go up an average 25 per cent Monday in a move designed to put that branch of the postal service on a pay-as-you-go basis.

PARIS. THE Paris stage this coming season--and many seasons to come--will be darker for the passing of its finest, purest light, Louis Jouvet, who died, like Moliere, in his own theatre.

LONDON, Sept. 29--A move to go into the elections as a united party was made late tonight by the Labor Government when Aneurin Bevan and party leaders agreed he would speak with them at a rally in Scarborough tomorrow on the eve of the party's conference.

London took on the aura of a hospital waiting room last week, but instead of merely an anxious family waiting the news from the surgery, it was a grieved and anxious population that waited for news from the bedside of George VI. Thousands stood silently about Buckingham Palace quietly hoping for a glimpse of the royal family or medical consultants coming in and out of the palace.
DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 29-- Voters in twelve Fairfield County towns will go to the polls Monday to elect municipal officers for twoyear terms.

IN the first hundred pages of this book, raconteur Harry Macfie finds himself treed by a love-starved bull moose, chased by a murderous band of Indians and a pack of twenty black wolves; and harassed by "a billowing sea of [forest] fire" which travels faster than a two-man canoe.

PELHAM, N.Y., Sept. 29--In St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church this afternoon, Miss Virginia Marie Warwick, daughter of Mrs. Robert Gerald Morgan of Pelham Heights and Bridgehampton, L.I., and John Marshall Warwick of Reno, was married to Dan Gordon Judge Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Judge of Pelham Manor and Scotland, Conn.

Hypnotism, when properly used by medical experts in the field, promises to serve as an important adjunct in the therapy for certain ills largely emotional in origin, according to reports presented yesterday at the second annual scientific meeting of the Society for Clinical and Experimental Hypnosis.

THE exodus to the big woods in search of bear, deer and moose is about to yet under way, but many of those who spend considerable time, effort and money on these trips will return home disappointed, primarily because they failed to make certain advance preparations that seemed insignificant or unnecessary.

With the railroads no longer a transportation monopoly, it is becoming increasingly evident to some in the industry that their regulation should be modernized to give management more latitude in making adjustment in rates and operations to combat subsidized competition and increasing costs of doing business.

After one whole week of debate on the floor of the Senate it appears that most of the new administrative provisions introduced by the Senate Finance Committee in the pending 1951 tax bill are likely to remain and to be adopted in the final version of the revenue bill. This refers to provisions not contamed in the bill as passed by the House of Representatives on June 22.

Marian Anderson has re-recorded some of the songs with which she made such a success in the past in Beloved Schubert Songs (Victor, ten-inch), and they are good. She floats lightly through the patterns of Love's Message, meditates with tenderness in Serenade and achieves mounting, dramatic suspense in The Erl King. The seven selections are sung to the accompaniment of Franz Rupp at the piano.

A formal warning that the Iranian oil dispute constituted a potential threat to peace was filed yesterday by Britain with the United Nations Security Council, scheduled to open debate on the question tomorrow.

The new V-loan terms available to machine tool builders must be backed up by prompt Government action to approve certificates of necessity for plant expansions in the machine tool industry which have been pending since last spring, machine tool builders revealed here last week.

Before returning to Rome by plane yesterday, Premier Alcide De Gasperi of Italy expressed great satisfaction with the results of his twenty-day visit to America.

The possibility of a tourist-class "price war" among scheduled airlines operating between the United States and Europe grew stronger yesterday. The ten-round heavyweight bout between Joe Louis and Rocky Marciano, scheduled for the Polo Grounds, Oct. 11, yesterday was transferred to Madison Square Garden and the date set back to Oct. 26.

LONDON, Oct. 1--Political uncertainty and the approaching end of the bookkeeping account kept business at a low ebb in the stock markets here today. Prices moved irregularly but small declines outnumbered the gains.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 1--Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz hailed the world's free press as the cornerstone of human liberty today and warned that totalitarian governments hated freedom of expression and were trying to stifle it. Whenever they succeed other liberties soon are lost, too he declared.
BOSTON, Oct. 1--President Truman expressed today the "fervent hope" that more persons would become interested in the present importance of recreation to the nation.

The Rhinelander Real Estate Company, owner of 48 West Fourteenth Street and 47-49 West Thirteenth Street, has increased its holding there through the purchase from Mrs. Geri Dorsey Chisolm of 50 West Fourteenth and 51-53 West Thirteenth Streets. The entire property is occupied under lease by the H.L. Green Company, Inc., as a 5 and 10 cent store.

Informal showings of coat and suit designs by Brigance will be given for the rest of this week on Lord Taylor's third floor between noon and 4 P.M. This collection encompasses both fitted and flared silhouettes in textured fabrics.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, Oct. 2-- Gen. Chu Teh, commander in chief of Communist China's armed forces, told the Chinese people today that the Peiping Government would have to go on fighting in Korea. He said this was necessary because of the "consistently hostile attitude" of the United States.

SARANAC, N.Y., Oct. 1--Representatives of the New York State Council of City and Village School Superintendents, which is holding its sixty-ninth annual convention here, received a preview today of what the school of the future might be like.

GENEVA, Oct. 1--Europe's surplus population problem could be completely solved in ten years at a cost within the capacity of the interested governments to bear, the International Refugee Organization stated in a report published here today.

BOSTON, Oct. 1--Thirty-five public health social workers from twenty states and the territories of Puerto Rico and Hawaii opened a two-week institute on the growth and development of children at the Harvard School of Public Health today.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 2--South Korean troops advancing in a driving rain yesterday won two high positions on the east-central front.

The current variety of fresh fruit on the market may delight the eye and appetite of the consumer, but to near-by apple growers it is one reason why their product is bringing them a price lower than their costs.

Plans to begin within a few weeks a $6,964,000 reconstruction of a part of the Queensboro Bridge and its principal approaches in both Manhattan and Queens were announced yesterday by Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 1-- Events of the last year have moved the free world measurably closer to the crisis that will bring war or the strength to avoid it, President John Sloan Dickey of Dartmouth College told a convocation audience today.

Jose Greco and his company, who have been having great success in Europe these last years, brought their program of Spanish dances to the Shubert Theatre last night to try the novel experiment of making a four-week run of it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--Cordell Hull, former Secretary of State and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize for 1945, called on his fellow Americans today to render all aid in their power to men and women struggling throughout the world to attain their freedom. The occasion was the eve of his eightieth birthday.

A funeral service was held yesterday in Washington for the Rev. Dr. James Stanley Durkee, former pastor of the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn, who died on Friday in the capital at the age of 84.

WASHINGTON, Oct: 1--The appearance of October on the calendar, with its reminder that a Presidential election year is close at hand, probably should serve as a caution against optimism that certain improvements in Congressional standards are assuming a permanent quality.

Two new products make is possible for the amateur carpenter with a minimum of equipment and experience to apply wood to walls and veneers to furniture, jobs that usually call for professional services.

Yesterday marked the beginning of National Newspaper Week and for the occasion the nation's newspapers received a message of tribute from President Truman.

Roger Clark has scheduled "Collector's Item," the comedy by Alfred Golden and Lillian Day, for production on Broadway this season. Mr. Clark, who was the sponsor last season of "Gramercy Ghost," is planning to cast his new offering and have it ready before the Christmas holidays.

The Polo Grounds Express, which started carrying the Giants from nowhere some six weeks ago, is still traveling at terrific speed. It shot right by the Flatbush Station yesterday to leave a bewildered Dodger contingent wondering however it got itself stalled on a local platform.
Local draft boards yesterday began an intensive review of 3-A classifications preparatory to transferring childless married men to a 1-A status.

TRENTON, Oct. 1--While smoke abatement officials of New York and health officers of northern New Jersey municipalities wage a war of words about the smoke blanket drifting willy-nilly over the metropolitan area, the New Jersey State Department of Health is applying a scientific approach to the air pollution problem.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--Back from a swing through Western states, Michael V. DiSalle, Director of Price Stabilization, said today that "there'll be no decontrol of beef, whiskey or cotton prices." and that his agency had no plans for any other major decontrol actions.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 1 --The Westchester Board of Su pervisors took a second look today at the piping of natural gas into the county. All comments about the Texas fuel were derogatory.

SCARBOROUGH, England, Oct. 1--British Labor party leaders sought vainly today to dispel the defeatism and gloom regarding the general election that has settled over the 1,500 delegates assembled here for their annual conference.

CANTERBURY, N.B., Oct. 1 --Shogomce Camp is the kind of hideaway hunting and fishing camp millions of urban sportsmen dream about having when that long-delayed ship comes in but until that ship docks they settle for a week or ten days as paying guests of Willard Way.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 1-- Three studios came up with announcements of story purchases today.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1--The meeting and exposition of the Industrial Packaging and Materials Handling Engineers got under way here a today with 100 exhibitors demonstrating the latest methods for wrapping and handling items from washing machines to airplane wings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--The Civil Aeronautics Board disclosed today that in the last fiscal year the nation's airlines had received subsidies totaling $34,565,000 as a part of their fees for carrying airmail. WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--The red velvet wall hangings parted and nine black-robed judges filed into the crowded courtroom.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ridgway Macy of Washington and New York of the engagement of their daughter, Sonja, to James Marshall McHugh Jr., son of Col. James M. McHugh, U.S.M.C., retired, of Washington.

New types of electronic equipment can revolutionize industrial and commercial accounting, Joseph B. It would be too much to say that the lines are now drawn for Britain's general elections of Oct. 25 between the Socialists and Tories. The real choice before the voters is not one of positive platforms but of personalities and hopes--or fears. This is natural enough and from the point of view of practical Politics it is hard to blame either side.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 8.5 per cent in September, compared with the same l950 month, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. An increase in resources over both the June quarter and the third quarter a year ago is shown in the statement of condition of the Manufacturers Trust Company on Sept. 30, released for publication today. WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)--The import tax on petroleum can be cut to 5 cents a barrel without seriously injuring domestic industries, witnesses told the United States Tariff Commission today. Present import taxes range from 10 cents to 21 cents a barrel. A cut to 5 cents would be the biggest permitted by law.

The football outlook at New York University has not taken any appreciable turn for the better in the year since Huge Devore came from St. Bonaventure and there is no prospect that it is going to improve very much in the immediate future.

Intensifying his efforts to half a union-inspired slowdown of garbage collections, Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain summoned ninety-five sanitation workers yesterday to departmental trials that might result in their dismissal.

Beginning the final week of its season at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Ballet Theatre last night presented its only scheduled presentation of Antony Tudor's "Romeo and Juliet." with Igor Youskevitch and Alicia Alonso in the title roles.
On the eve of the resumption of registration, political leaders urged the voters again yesterday to turn out in large numbers to protect their right to participate in the November election.

The Radio Corporation of America invited the public yesterday to witness a series of color television test programs to be presented here from Oct. 9 to 19 on color receivers installed in the Center Theatre in Radio City. SCARBOROUGH, England Oct. 2--By its deeds and its words today the Labor party conference showed that it had swung far to the left of its present moderate leadership.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 2 (AP)-- Fred W. Weiler, vice president and co-publisher of the Call-Chronicle Newspapers, Inc., died today in Allentown Hospital after a long illness. His age was 49. He had been a patient in the hospital since last July.

Licensed nurses must be freed from non-nursing duties, Miss Clara Quereau, secretary of the Board of Examiners of Nurses of the New York State Education Department, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)--The Government wound up the first quarter of this fiscal year $2,614,986,764 in the red. It was the biggest single quarter deficit in the country's history except in all-out war years.

The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A.F.L., and forty East and Gulf coast ship operators agreed last night on a new two-year contract. The accord came only five minutes before the expiration of the old pact.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--The Joint Chiefs of Staff have agreed to expand the Air Force from eighty-seven to about 140 groups, Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, told the Senate today. An increase for naval aviation also was indicated.

A syndicate headed by George Kraslow and Emmanuel Schultz has acquired Blossom Gardens, a garden apatrment development at Saul Street and Blossom. Avenue in Flushing, Queens. Alex S. Natanson was attorney for the seller.
WASHINGTON, Oct, 2--Key officials of the stabilization program have decided not to give ground in price enforcement, regardless of whether Congress strengthens the controls law.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--President Truman is considering plans to revive the inactive Commission on Internal Security and Individual Rights and other measures to tighten the Federal check on employes accused of being security risks.

Ellsworth B. Buck, former president of the New York City Board of Education and former Representative in Congress, was elected last night as Richmond County Republican Chairman to succeed Edward A. Ruppell, resigned.

Moshe Sharett Foreign Minister of Israel, said last night that his country was willing to enter negotiations with the United Nations to compensate Arab refugees from Palestine for their lost lands.

Baseball fever dominated the activities of New Yorkers--and Brooklynites--for the third successive day yesterday in a multitude of settings as the Brooklyn Dodgers racked up a soggy 10-0 Polo Grounds victory against the New York Giants.

Physicists at Columbia University are delving into the mysteries of the forces within the nucleus of the atom--source of atomic energy --with a powerful new tool--a beam of mesons--the sub-atomic particles believed to serve as the "cosmic cement" that holds the universe together.

In its first change of ownership in almost fifty years, the blockfront on the east side of Eighth Avenue from 147th to 148th Streets has been sold by the Wejjam Realty Corporation to an investor for cash over mortgages amounting to $110,000. DwightHelmsley, Inc., were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--President Truman said today that he was not sure whether Russia's explosion of a second atomic bomb had made another world war more imminent. He quickly added, however, that he hoped it had not done so.

The weekly newspaper Nordlyset (Northern Light), which sparked the spirit of Danes from Greenland to Cape Town against the Nazi occupation of Denmark during World War II, celebrated yesterday its sixtieth anniversary with an edition of eighteen pages instead of the usual four.

MOSCOW, Oct. 4--The Soviet press said today that atomic energy had been turned by "imperialists" into a weapon for the "mass extermination of populations" whereas properly used it could "liberate mankind from exhausting toil."

Advertisers and readers, loyal to La Prensa and never seeking to influence its policy, kept the Buenos Aires daily prosperous until the day the Peron Government took it over, Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz, former publisher of the paper, told the Third International Advertising Convention at the Plaza Hotel yesterday.

BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Oct. 4-- Carthage Hydrocol, Inc., headed by Guy Gabrielson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, which went into business with an $18,500,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, still is striving for full production of premium quality gasoline from natural gas.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 4--The last group of Anglo-Iranian Oil Company officials--Alec Mason, acting general manager, K.B. Ross, general refineries manager, and six others--left Iran today, going by road from Khorramshahr, near Adadan, to Basra, Iraq.
NEW ROCHELLE, Oct. 4-- Any twenty-fourth of June that the heirs or assigns of Sir John Pell want "one Fatt Calfe" from New Rochelle, they can have it, according to Mayor Stanley W. Church.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--Presidents of the United States, like baseball pitchers, have their off days, and this was just as much an off day for President Truman as it was for Allie Reynolds of the Yankees.

The Travelers Aid Society of New York opened its 1951 solicitation for $340,000 yesterday with ceremonies at the Roosevelt Hotel. The money will be used not only to maintain the agency's network of booths that help persons in need but to expand its services.

Nearly all of the residuary estate of Mrs. Annie Nathan Meyer, author, playwright and chief founder of Barnard College, will go eventually to organizations for educational, charitable or social work. Constitutional amendments involving a $500,000,000 increase in this city's borrowing power to finance new rapid transit lines and a $500,000,000 increase in state borrowing to finance the new Thruway will come before the voters for approval or rejection next month.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 4-- Dr. Robert Jay Cook, noted orthopedic surgeon who had been affiliated with Yale University for most of the last thirty years, died in his home today after a long illness. His age was 63.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 4 (AP)-- Undefeated Ford Hanover captured the rich Kentucky Futurity in straight heats and set a new season record today to strengthen his claim on the 3-year-old trotting title.

Three of tomorrow's outstanding Eastern football matches seem likely to hinge on the outcome of passing duels, which highlights the fact that there are some exceptionally fine aerial marksmen operating in this sector this season.

JERUSALEM, Tuesday, Oct. 9 --After eight months, Israel obtained a government with a stable majority tonight when Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion's new coalition obtained a 56 to 40 confidence vote with four abstentions.

The Office of Naval Research has signed a contract to assist for one year a research project at Yale University that may turn the curious navigational skills of animals, such as horseshoe crabs, bees and ants, to the advantage of men sailing ships or flying planes in polar regions.
PARIS, Oct. 8--Almost complete returns tonight appeared to confirm the victory of the French Moderates and Leftist losses on the first ballot of Sunday's cantonal election.
In 1952 the Soviet Union will substantially tighten the curtain screening its scientific progress from the outside world. It has banned the export of ten major scientific journals.

Harrington of the Illinois Circuit Court and Judge Joseph H. Drucker of the Chicago Municipal Court to be Federal district judges in northern Illinois.

Sales volume of New York and Brooklyn department stores for the week ended last Saturday fell 6 per cent below the comparable 1950 week, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Tenants in eight Manhattan apartment houses had to take to the stairs yesterday as service employes quit work in a series of strikes, called without prior warning. Owners of five buildings settled quickly, leaving three still on strike last evening.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 (AP)--The Post-Dispatch reported today that Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, was seeking by mail donations for a $1,000,000 Harry S. Truman Memorial Library from money which he said would go to higher-bracketed taxes anyway.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9--Michael V. DiSalle, Director of Price Stabilization, told the House Banking Committee today that all attempts to control retail meat prices might have to be abandoned unless Congress permitted allocation of slaughter quotas to meat packers.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 10-- The appearance yesterday of fresh Chinese troops for the first time since May in the mountainous territory of the east-central Korean front seemed to confirm the belief that the North Koreans defending that front had been beaten to the point of disintegration.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 9 --A new $250,000 water main that extends 2,000 feet under Long Island Sound to Fort Slocum was almost complete tonight. It was begun two months ago and now is urgently needed because the only old main in service was broken in Sunday's windstorm.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP)--W. Stuart Symington, administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Gorporation, said today that his loan talks with Guy George Gabrielson were "normal" business routine and that the Republican chairman defeated his own plea for easier repayment terms.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP)-- The Federal Trade Commission proposed today twenty-two rules to "eliminate and prevent" unfair trade practices among the nation's grocers. The rules would ban "loss leaders" aimed at attracting customers.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 9--Gus Hall, one of the four convicted leaders of the Communist party in the United States who jumped bail in New York to escape prison, was arrested by Mexican secret service agents last night as he entered this city and was swiftly deported to the United States early today.

Public Service Company of Indiana, Inc., is offering to holders of its common stock rights to subscribe, until Oct. 24, for 325,656 new shares of common stock at the rate of one share for each ten shares held of record on Oct. 8. Adolph Flashner, owner of the King of the Sea Restaurant at 879-885 Third Avenue, has rounded out an assemblage of adjoining parcels at the southeast corner of Fiftyfourth Street which gives him control of of practically the entire blockfront on the east side of the avenue between Fiftythird and Fifty-fourth Streets. NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10-- "The most dangerous scoring team in the Ivy League with the possible exception of Cornell," was the appraisal put upon Columbia by Coach Herman Hickman today as he prepared the Yale eleven for Saturday's meeting with the Lions at Baker Field in New York.

The Heyden Chemical Corporation informed stockholders yesterday that the Mathieson Chemical Corporation had bought all the 134,725 shares of the American Potash and Chemical Corporation owned by Heyden. The price was $5,389,000, or $40 a share.

General Electric Appliances, Inc., metropolitan area distiributor of General Electric Company's major appliances, has stopped accepting carload orders for refrigerators from dealers. This was disclosed yesterday by a spokesman for the distributing organization.

District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Brooklyn held a ninetyminute conference yesterday afternoon with Ellis Kopp, a special Bergen County prosecutor, on possible Brooklyn angles in the mysterious slaying of Willie Moretti, New Jersey racketeer. Moretti was shot dead at Cliffside, N.J., last Thursday.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 11-- With a drive that stunned the new Chinese troops on the east-central front, a United Nations task force carved its way eight miles into enemy territory yesterday. The Chinese forces hit were part of a corps that had been shifted from the western front a few days ago to bolster the mauled and fading North Koreans.

Richard G. Moser, who succeeded Rudolph Halley as chief counsel to the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, asked Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey yesterday to investigate charges placed against four Atlantic City policemen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--Higher income of farmers, together with increased Government wage and salary outlays, helped carry personal income in August to a new annual record rate of $254,400,000,000, the United States Department....

CHICAGO, Oct. 10--Corn futures registered sharp gains on the Board of Trade here today, but otherwise the grain markets were irregular and without any outstanding feature. Buying of corn was largely short-covering due to the expectation that recent frost...

The police rounded up seventythree persons early this morning in a West Forty-fifth Street garage in a raid on a floating dice game. The plainclothes men who made the raid said that $20,000 was involved in the biggest such game they had raided for some time.

New York--and the nation--will mark tomorrow the 458th anniversary of the discovery of America and honor its discoverer, Christopher Columbus, with parades, dinners, ceremonies and the other services appropriate to the holiday.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 10 (UP)-- Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati, former heavyweight champion, launched his comeback campaign tonight by flooring Rex Layne twice and winding a technical knockout over the clumsy Utah boxer at 2:32 of the eleventh round in frigid Forties Field. The fight was scheduled for twelve rounds.
Several trustees of Barnard College are of the opinion that it is a good deal livelier though somewhat tougher than when they were student. This discovery was made while attending classes yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10 (AP)-- An effort to impose censorship on news of a dog-training project had city officials and San Francisco newspapers puzzled today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--Army and National Guard officers have worked out in the last few days a new training program for guardsmen that is expected both to ease their transition from civilian life to active duty and also result in better trained organizations coming into Federal service.

A proposed 1952 capital budget of $527,283,767, the largest in the city's history, was made public yesterday by the City Planning Commission. Public hearings on the tentative allocations for various city departments and agencies will be held at City Hall next Thursday and Friday, beginning at 10 A. M.

The stock market was unable yesterday to resume the advance and modest attempts to rally failed. Losses of fractions predominated, although some of the independent steel issues reversed the trend to post gains well in excess of a point. Trading centered mainly in the low-price stocks, with only a few of the pivotal issues attracting sizable attention.

Moral lassitude is one of the gravest dangers this country faces, Dr. Robert J. McCracken, pastor of the Riverside Church, warned yesterday at the opening campaign luncheon to raise $300,000 for the Young Women's Christian Association.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina, who has criticized much of the evidence submitted by the Government to sustain its anti-trust charges against certain investment banking houses, made it clear yesterday that he would not dismiss the case after the Government ended its presentation.

CAIRO, Oct. 10--Popular demonstrations in Cairo took on a more actively belligerent character today. Centering in the business quarter, irresponsible mobs of students and the poor shifted from hailing Premier Mustafa Pasha Nahas and his decision to abrogate the Anglo-Egyptian Treaty to smashing windows and fighting with the guards of offices and stores.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I, Oct. 10 --The Women's Long Island Golf Association's final tournament and meeting was held at the Piping Rock Club today, with Mrs. J.B. Balding of the Creek re-elected president.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The House of Representatives approved tentatively today a $4,428,357,970 appropriation bill directed almost entirely at financing the greatest military construction program in peacetime or war.
Marta of the Woodvale Farm showed sufficient speed and stamina to win the Ladies Handicap over the distance of a mile and a half at Belmont Park yesterday.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 10 (AP)-- The United Church Women is starting a five-point program for world peace they hope women will discuss over their coffee cups as well as in official circles.

It is not generally known that, Leo Durocher was offered a bribe through the mails if he would "manage to lose the next three games." The letter, which was turned over to Commissioner Ford Frick a half hour before yesterday's game at the Stadium, also contained a threat.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The right and responsibility of the Government to stimulate the productioN of adequate housing for all the people was championed today by Representative Albert Rains, Democrat of Alabama, and Representative Frances P. Bolton, Republican of Ohio.
Designers of fashions for the young bear in mind girls whose tastes are for high fashions but whose budgets are in low figures. Junior winter coats now in the stores illustrate this point.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 11--Emperor Hirohito today inferentially called on the Japanese Parliament to ratify the San Francisco peace treaty but warned his people "many difficulties" would accompany the restoration of full sovereignty to Japan.

As 323 additional Sanitation Department employes reported ill yesterday and sixty-three more were suspended, Acting Mayor Joseph T. Sharkey urged speedy trials for those under charges and strong punishment, even dismissal, for those found guilty "of deliberately jeopardizing sanitation services."

The Treasury's decision to begin soon the sale of tax anticipation bills maturing on quarterly tax dates was held in financial circles yesterday to be a constructive move in debt management that should help the monetary authorities substantially in their efforts...
DETROIT, Oct. 10 (AP)--The Detroit Red Wings begin defense of their third consecutive National Hockey League championship against the Boston Bruins at Olympia Stadium tomorrow night.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 11 (AP)-- Union blacksmiths joined American Federation of Labor mutuel employes on strike at Laurel Park today, but all eight events went off as scheduled and there was little or no interruption of traffic that marred yesterday's opening day.

To the United States Navy, "fashion means functionability." This was demonstrated yesterday when Lieut. Philip Crosby, Research and Development Officer at the Clothing Supply Office of the Navy Depot, showed a new Navy collection in Brooklyn.

Wool futures and wool tops futures again dropped the daily trading limit on the New York Commodity Exchange yesterday, on news of continued weakness in Australia. Coffee rose on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange on news of Brazilian quota difficulties. Movements in other commodities were aimless and volume was slight.
Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres this morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today the arrest of 120 persons in two months, thirty in the last twenty-four hours, accused of stealing more than $1,000,000 in goods from the armed forces.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)-- The average householder's typical monthly electricity bill dropped 2 cents last year.

Despite the hue and cry raised by Richard W. Krakeur, producer of "Faithfully Yours," against Equity, Mr. Krakeur has capitulated. He had charged that the union took an arbitrary stand by, refusing to permit Philip Friend, a resident alien actor, to succeed Glenn Anders, an American performer.

With the smallest crowd of the season trying to peer at the proceedings through the downpour, William Ewing's Auditing carried the high weight to victory in the Gramercy Park Handcap at Belmont Park yesterday. Rigged at 120 pounds with Nick Wall in the saddle, Auditing registered a onelength victory over Easy Whirl of the Hampton Stable in the mile event.

DURING the nineteenth century, says Hardied in duels. From Richmond, Va., to San Francisco, where the tide of the gold rush washed up many a fire-breathing Southerner, angry men tried to kill each other "on principle." With rigid punctilio and precise attention to the niceties of ritualized murder ...

CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 11--The skies were gray and cheerless at St. Paul's today. It rained all afternoon, but the school's extensive intramural program went on as scheduled. Three football games and one soccer test made up the competitive program, with the Old Hundred sixth team turning in the biggest gridiron score as it beat the Isthmian sixth squad, 32--6.

VIENNA, Oct. 11--The Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions, which has been an unwelcome guest in Vienna since last May, was notified today by the Austrian Government that it had broken Austrian laws and that the police had been directed to treat it like any other lawbreaker.

MOSCOW, Oct. 11--The Soviet Union sent notes today to the United States, Britain and France agreeing to modify the Italian peace treaty if Italy quits the North Atlantic Pact and if the West agrees to similar easing of treaty restrictions on Bulgaria, Hungary, Finland and Rumania.

United Nations forces attacking in the area north and north-northwest of Yoachon continued to meet stubborn enemy resistance. Patrolling United Nations forces on the central front encountered light enemy resistance. Attacking United Nations forces north and northwest of Yanggu secured two hills.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--A Senate voice vote, participated in by fewer than a dozen of its ninety-six members, approved today the exchange, under rigid conditions, of nonweapon atomic information with friendly countries. The measure containing the program was then sent to the House for its action.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct. 11 (AP)--The Inter-American Press Association was advised today that seven Latin-American nations were taking steps to meet a newsprint shortage from their own resources. The association received two reports on the subject.

Simon H. Rifkind, former Federal judge and widely experienced trial lawyer, was appointed yesterday to try thirty-one policemen on departmental charges of "protecting" Harry Gross, Brooklyn bookmaker.
President Truman and Governor Dewey praised Premier Alcide De Gasperi of Italy in messages read last night before 2,000 guests at the Columbus Citizens Committee dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

FORT WORTH, Oct. 1 (UP)-- Miss Betsy Rawls, women's open champion and the veteran pro, Miss Betty Jameson, were eliminated from the women's Texas open golf tournament today as other favorites came through.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 11 (AP)--The nation's railroads are moving traffic almost equal to that of last fall, and the freight car shortage is only about half as severe as then, shippers were told today.

The Port of New York Authority voted yesterday to finish on a cost-plus basis construction of $4,000,000 of Lincoln Tunnel connections to the New Jersey Turnpike. The decision was taken to insure completion of the links in time for the opening of the turnpike in mid-January.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 11 (UP)--A special University of Virginia faculty committee recommended today that all aid to athletes be cut off and that the faculty exercise strict control of the school's intercollegiate sports program.

The reactivation and allocation of thirty-six Government-owned ships among as many steamship companies now serving as general agents of the National Shipping Authority was announced, yesterday by the Maritime Administration. The vessels are being taken out of reserve to meet Economic Cooperation Administration requirements, and they raise to 353 the number of vessels placed in service since the program began, last March 13.
CARDIFF, Wales, Oct. 11-- Anthony Eden added a new impetus to the Conservative campaign in Wales today with criticism of the Labor Government's handling of the Iranian crisis.
Fordham will meet Boston College tonight at Braves Field, Boston, in the Rams' fourth consecutive game on the road. Kick-off time is 8:30.

PARIS, Oct. 11--The French franc fell today to its lowest point since February 1949, with the price on black market quoted at 428 francs to the dollar. Large denomination dollar bills were quoted at even higher prices.

OTTAWA, Friday, Oct. 12-- Princess Elizabeth escaped last night from the long crinoline skirts and tiaras of state dinners and slipped into something comfortable. She put on a peasant blouse and dirndl skirt and the Duke of Edinburgh climbed into blue jeans and a wild shirt for an evening of square dancing at usually dignified Government House.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 11 (AP)--A former admiral took over as president of William and Mary College today amid open faculty resentment.

Springs Mills' reduction on sheets of 2 and 5 per cent, announced on Monday, will be rescinded in the next few days, it was learned yesterday. The reduction, in effect for only four days, was made to combat "inside trades," by some competitors which had jeopardized existing orders to Springs Mills.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--Retail price advances averaging about 2 per cent for more popular types of frozen vegetables and slightly more for frozen fruits, berries and minor vegetables were approved today by the Office of Price Stabilization. The adjustments take effect Oct. 25, or earlier if the packer desires.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--The possibility that new Federal controls might be devised to limit further the production of housing, and channel new construction so that defense needs received added priority, was acknowledged here today by Raymond M. Foley, Housing and Home Finance Administrator.

PARIS, Oct. 11--The Soviet Union is understood to be drafting a proposal for a new "European payments union," including countries of both the Communist bloc and of the Marshall Plan nations, according to reliable information received from Prague, Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--A majority of twenty-five outside experts called into a State Department round-table conference of October, 1949, either actively favored recognition of Communist China or accepted it as more or less necessary. Those favoring recognition included business men.

TRENTON, Oct. 11--Richard G. Moser, former counsel to the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, was invited today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to tell lawenforcement officials any facts he has about crime in New Jersey.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Oct. 11-- New Jersey contended today that the Western Union had taken on the role of "banker" for a big-time North Jersey bookie for a period of five months prior to his suspension of a gigantic wagers-by-wire operation in March, last year.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 11 (AP)-- Ridge Stable's Imamazed broke alertly and the 3-year-old son of War Relic--We Hail led the entire six furlongs to triumph by a nose over D.G. Neuman's Woodford Sir in the Executive Association feature race at Garden State Park today.

Clifford Orr, author and editorial associate of The New Yorker magazine, died on Wednesday in a Hanover (N.H.) nursing home, according to word received here yesterday. Mr. Orr, who resided in New York before he became ill in June, was 51 years old.

Representative Henry J. Latham, Republican candidate for President of the City Council, told members of the Junior Group of the Women's National Republican Club last night he felt certain that women generally would vote Republican in this city's election on Nov. 6.

Matched sets of pots and pans or vacuum bottles for keeping liquids warm, which many homemakers may believe to be twentieth century innovations, are only two pieces of kitchen equipment used by the cook of today as well as by the cook of a hundred years ago or more, judging from a display that will go on sale at Altman's today.
THE rain was pelting down furiously at game time yesterday for the seventh and deciding contest of the world series. Fortunately, though, there was no game. The Yankees had made it unnecessary.

The Marcu Oil Company has sold its waterfront barge terminal in Inwood, L.I., to Morton Spies of Newark, N.J., in a transaction negotiated by L.J. Phillips Co. as brokers. The property, held at $300,000, originally was owned by the Sinclair Oil Company. It has a storage capacity of more than 600,000 gallons.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--President Truman was asked a variety of questions on a wide range of problems at his news conference today, but his answers did not constitute big news.
TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 12--Communist resistance on the northernmost and last peak of "Heartbreak Ridge" crumbled and fell at 8 o'clock this morning before the might of United Nations armor and infantry.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP)-- The National Boxing Association today set up new enforcement machinery which automatically will dethrone boxing champions unless they defend their titles every six months.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 11--James P. Finnegan, former Collector of Internal Revenue here, was indicted on five counts today by a Federal grand jury. Mr. Finnegan, a close friend of President Truman, was charged in three counts with misconduct of office. The other counts alleged he had accepted bribes.
Along with the 33 1-3 rpm phongraph record and color television, the Columbia Broadcasting System has undertaken to do something with another manifestation of the electronic age: Frank Sinatra.

Omar Kiam's mastery in draping formal ball gowns was evident yesterday at De Pinna's luncheon-showing in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. Designing for Ben Reig, whose name has made fashion news for more than twentyfive years, Mr. Kiam presented a winter collection.
CHICAGO, Oct. 11--Robert W. Williams, a member of the Federal Marine Board, warned today that "more than ever before in our history, safety assumes a role of importance to this nation."

LONDON, Oct. 11--Appealing to the women of Britain to vote Conservative in the coming election, Miss Patricia HornsbySmith, glamour girl of the Conservative party and its champion of the white collar class, gave a sort of fireside chat today on all the domestic issues that have been bothering the housewives here, whatever their political affiliation.
Clifford C. Fischer, international theatrical producer, night-club impresario and booking agent, died yesterday in his home at Westwood, N.J., after a long illness. His age was 69.

Edward Mabley, who was coauthor of "Temper the Wind," is total author of "Glad Tidings," which opened at the Lyceum last evening. That shows progress in the right direction. For "Glad Tidings" has an impudent sense of ...
Walter Hoving, chairman of the Anti-Sales Tax Committee, raised the sales tax issue yesterday in the election campaign for President of the City Council.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 11--Dedicated to the proposition that religion is "intimately" related to the democratic traditions of personal dignity, individual responsibility and human freedom, the first assembly of the National Council of Catholic Youth opened a four-day session here tonight.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Oct. 11-- A new multi-million-dollar ColgatePalmolive Peet Company plant, designed to serve the vast trade territory of the Middle West, was dedicated here today in ceremonies presided over by thirteen members of the company's board of directors.
LONDON, Oct. 11--Troubles continued to pile up for Britain today. Everybody with a claim against this country seemed to be presenting it.
A merger of the Health Council of Greater New York and the Welfare Council of New York City is under consideration. Negotiations are well under way. This was confirmed by both sides yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 11 (AP)--The International Cooperative Petroleum Association plans to offer Iran its facilities to aid establishment of international management ...

Staten Island is approximately nineteen miles long, from St. George to Tottenville. It has a fine climate, the highest hill on a long stretch of the Eastern seaboard and many lakes, parks and piers in its fifty-seven square miles of territory.
In an introduction to his sixth annual report Secretary General Lie presents this morning a vigorous defense of the United Nations as an instrument for international peace and security.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 11 (AP)--The Browns today acquired Infileder Leo Thomas, who with Portland was one of the top batters in the Pacific Coast League this year. St. Louis picked up Thomas in a deal which involved some cash, Pitcher Fred Sanford and Infielder-Outfielder Jack Maguire.

ATHENS, Oct. 11--General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, Field Marshal Sir William Slim, chief of the British General Staff and Gen. CharlesFrancois Lecheres, chief of the ...
CAIRO, Oct. 11--The Egyptian police in Port Said beat off today a mob effort to storm the British Club, but otherwise the country was quiet with sizable but orderly demonstrations.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11--Iran said today that she was amenable to the arrangement by a "third party" of new talks with Britain over the British-Iranian oil dispute.
Albert H. Henderson, Surrogate of Bronx County since 1930, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital, Manhattan, of a heart ailment after a two-year illness. He waS 58 years old.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--President Truman said today that his recollection was rather hazy on whether he had ever asked Mr. Finnegan not to resign as collector of Internal Revenue at St. Louis.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 11-- The casting of James Cagney as Captain Flagg and Dan Dailey as Sergeant Quirt in "Charmaine," the musical version of the famous World War I comedy drama, "What Price Glory?", was confirmed today by Twentieth Century-Fox.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 11-- Torn between her approval in principle of Iran's nationalization of the oil industry and her urgent desire that the dispute between the Iranians and the British be settled on a practical basis, India has left it entirely to Sir Benegal N. Rau, her representative in the United Nations, how to cast his vote when the question of the Security Council's competence to deliberate on this matter comes up.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 11--Iraq has asked Britain to revise the treaty that allows the Royal Air Force to station units on Iraqi soil an official statement said tonight.
Brooklyn set out yesterday to raise $450,000 toward the United Hospital Fund's current campaign goal of $3,500,000 to aid eightytwo voluntary medical institutions in the city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--An appropriation of $7,482,527,790 in new funds to finance military and economic foreign aid was approved by the House of Representatives today by a vote of 221 to 99. The measure reappropriated unspent parts of previously approved funds that brought the total to $8,299,255,096.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 11-- The Milwaukee Journal said in a copyrighted story here today that General of the Army Douglas A. MacArthur had proposed that his Wisconsin supporters back Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, in the 1952 spring Presidential Primary.

The National Jewish Welfare Board, an association of 321 Jewish community centers, Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Associations, announced yesterday that it had undertaken a nation-wide campaign among its 250,000 adult members for blood donations to help meet needs of the armed services.

Increased difficulty being met by exporters in obtaining goods in heavy demand is spurring renewed efforts to obtain a "set-aside" which will assure them a fair share of products, key trade sources asserted yesterday.

HEADQUARTERS, United States Seventh Army, Germany, Oct. 11--A grim picture of delaying actions at high cost and counter-attacks against superior forces in the event of a Russian attack, was outlined to senior officers of the United States forces in Europe today.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 11--The Argentine Congress met today in the special session called by President Juan D. Peron Tuesday and passed a bill granting him a leave of absence during his campaign for re-election to a new six-year term.

Acting Mayor Joseph T. Sharkey, Democratic candidate for President of the City Council, said yesterday that he was employed by the General Builders Supply Corporation, 205 East Forty-second Street, as a salesman, at an annual salary of $7,500.

Department and union heads differed widely yesterday on the effect the sanitation workers' slowdown and wave of "sickness" was having on garbage collections, but were agreed that if the men continued to report sick a serious health menace might result.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--The Order of Railway Conductors rejected today the report of an emergency board on the union's dispute with the Pullman Company, and proposed a new committee to dispose of long-pending disputes with the railroad industry.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 (UP)--A longstanding front office feud of the Boston Bruins reached its climax today when control of the National Hockey League club was purchased for about $187,680 by the Boston Garden-Arena Corp. and Weston W. Adams stepped down as president.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today an amended plan for the recapitalization of the Portland (Ore.) Gas and Coke Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP)-- John S. Service, career diplomat, charged today that a Senate subcommittee used part of one of his 1944 dispatches "shorn of context to deduce a pro-Russian meaning." Actually, he said, the opposite was meant.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--During the week ended Oct. 10, member bank reserves decreased $65,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development extended today a loan equaling $28,000,000 to Yugoslavia and one of $10,000,000 to Italy in related moves to bolster the economies of those and other European Countries.

Reinvigorated by its late summer excursion to Scotland, the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night began its new season--its 110th, if you please-- with so much gusto and good cheer you would have thought it was just emerging out of its adolescence.

Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, wants steel, not "gobbledygook," when he requests an increased allotment of the precious metal from Thomas H. MacDonald, Commissioner of the Bureau of Public Roads in Washington, he said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)-- Uncle Sam's investment in surplus farm products under farm price support programs has been cut by nearly 60 per cent since it reached a record level last year.

A goodly number of new donors should appear at the local Red Cross blood bank if sixty-seven alleged dice players, arrested early yesterday in a raid on a floating dice game in a West Side garage, keep a promise made to Magistrate Harry G. Andrews.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP)-- The House Banking Committee today approved a change in the new controls law that would give the Administration greater power to hold down prices charged by manufacturers.

As sceneshifters went through their final chores yesterday in storing away the 1951 baseball campaign that ended with the Yankees' world series triumph over the Giants on Thursday, two items seemed to command most attention.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11--Breakfasts have been an important part of the Newspaper Food Editors Confer ence in session this week at the Hotel Drake. Tuesday, Swift Co. treated the group to a chuck wagon meal at which meat was featured. Yesterday the Florida Citrus Commission served hot griddle cakes topped with an orange syrup. Today Lever Brothers Company presented a variety of newly-devised, quick-tomake breads.

HUNTER RIVER, Prince Edward Island, Oct. 11--Wild fowling on this verdant island is one of the most uncomplicated forms of this normally involved shooting exercise we ever have encountered, and had the goose season been open we could have provided game dinners for the full complement of Highfield Cabins' hunters for the duration of our stay.

Personality development is not limited to the growth that takes place during childhood and adolescence but is a continuing process, frequently spurred by the adult responsibilities of marriage and family living, according to Dr. Lawrence K. Frank, a leader at the New York Ethical Culture Society.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 11-- With indignant denunciation of the Indian Government's treatment of "untouchables" despite abolition of the Hindu caste distinction by the Constitution, Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, Columbia-educated Minister of Law in the Nehru Cabinet who drafted that Constitution and is himself an untouchable, announced his resignation today and walked out of Parliament.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--A recent publication in this space of words and phrases employed in legislative and official circles to gloss over and otherwise obscure their true meaning has drawn from readers a number of new entries. These carry on the purpose of the original list, which was to bring up to date the Government jargon that ...

The 1904-style subway kiosk, which has loomed large on many street corners in the last four decades, would be eliminated under a resolution introduced in the City Council yesterday by Minority Leader Stanley M. Isaacs, Republican-Liberal, and Councilmen Samuel Davis and Earl Brown, Democrats, all from Manhattan.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 12--The United Nations Command announced today it was trying to get the Communists to resume the Korean truce talks "without delay," leaving procedural and security arrangements to the liaison officers.

William Lurye, organizer for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A.F.L., who was fatally stabbed on May 9, 1949, was "fingered by one or more of his union associates," it was charged yesterday as the first degree murder trial of Benedicto Macri began in General Sessions.
