WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--By a vote of 300 to 19, the House of Representatives today approved an appropriation bill for $4,428,357,970, devoted almost entirely to financing the nation's greatest military construction program. The measure now goes to the Senate, where ratification without much contest is predicted.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 11-- Edwin W. Hammer, a consulting engineer who was an expert on electrical and mechanical patents and had been an early associate of Thomas A. Edison, died here today of a heart attack in his home, 10 Crestmont Road. Mr. Hammer, who was 83 years old, was a founder and a former president of the Edison Pioneers, an organization of men who had worked with the inventor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--Conferees of the Senate and the House of Representatives reached final agreement today on a bill for general tax increases to produce an estimated $5,750,000,000 in new annual revenue.

Shopping at the dairy counter will require more cash this weekend than last Friday with butter up 2 cents a pound to 83 and both large and medium Grade A eggs more costly. The City Department of Markets reports a four-cent rise to 93 on the large eggs and a twocent rise on the medium to 75.

Plans for a two-story commercial building at 637-45 West Fifty-fifth Street, northeast corner of Twelfth Avenue, were disclosed yesterday in connection with the announcement of the purchase of the plot by Ossining Associates, Inc., from Thomas G. Patterson of Palm Beach, Fla. The sale, negotiated by John J. Reynolds, Inc., terminated an ownership of fiftysix years. Title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

"Heartbreak Ridge" in Korea was in allied hands after United States and French troops took the last hold-out peak from Communists, who had resisted for a month. Earlier, a helicopter airlift had moved a Marine battalion to the front. [1:8; map P. 2.]

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)-- Chester Bowles, former Governor of Connecticut and Price Administrator, was sworn in today as the new Ambassador to India. Mr. Bowles took the oath of office at the State Department. He said he would strive for "some real accomplishments" in his new post.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--The Wage Stabilization Board, voting 8 to 4, approved today a special pay increase for ship radiomen, but limited the retroactive effect to Sept. 1 instead of to the June dates when the agreements were reached by the ship operators and the American Radio Association, C.I.O.

The small private library of Franklin D. Roosevelt, housed in the late President's cottage retreat at Hyde Park and reflecting some of his interests--his love for the sea and his enthusiasm as a fisherman--has been sold to the Rosenbach Company of New York and Philadelphia by his son, Elliott.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--There is not too much perturbation among the farmers and dwellers in the smaller towns and cities in the Middle West about the domestic issues that perpetually agitate Congress.

Former Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., architect of many of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's economic policies, proposed to Trygve Lie, United Nations Secretary General yesterday that the United Nations create an authority to buy Britain's interest in the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company.

Business inventories began to level off in the third quarter after a sharp rise lasting almost a year, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday. It summed up business trends in the quarter on the basis of preliminary data, but said that a full statistical portrait would not be available until the year-end.

DETROIT, Oct. 11 (UP)--Glen Skov tipped in Ted Lindsay's shot in the first period tonight to give the Red Wings a 1-0 victory over the Boston Bruins in the National Hockey League season opener for both teams.

The Board of Estimate refused yesterday by a vote of 15 to 1 to allow a rent rise of $4 a month a room at Stuyvesant Town, the huge housing development of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company covering eighteen city blocks on the East Side between Fourteenth and Twentieth Streets.

Sluggishness of the two previous days in the stock market ended yesterday as a broad buying movement restored all of the losses sustained this week. Demand rotated from one section to another throughout the session with no particular favorites in evidence. On balance, the list rallied by 0.83 point, the best advance since Oct. 3, accompanied by the heaviest trading since Monday.
The Federal Civil Defense Administration will send a road show of exhibits of war destruction and home defense techniques across the nation to perk up civilian recruitment.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 12--The United Nations Command turned down yesterday a Communist proposal for resumption at 1 o'clock this afternoon of full-scale negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war, the Peiping radio asserted this morning.

For the first time in this part of the country, the Office of Price Stabilization moved yesterday to restrain a wholesale meat company from continuing in business until it complied with Government regulations. The agency also asked damages of $405,000 because the company allegedly was selling meat above ceiling prices.

DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 11 (AP)-- The Air Force today invoked a "security blackout" on information relative to the cancellation of contracts with firms involved in allegedly irregular procurement activities.

Production of raw steel by domestic mills in September, the third quarter and the first nine months of 1951 was larger than ever before in corresponding periods, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Mrs. Mirlam Shomer Zunser, author and playwright, wife of Charles Zunser, former head of the National Desertion Bureau, died yesterday in her home at 136 West Seventy-fifth Street, after a long illness. Her age was 68.

PARIS, Oct. 11--Having endorsed the agenda and accepted a compromise on the composition of its new executive bureau, the temporary committee of the North Atlantic Treaty Organibation, called here to solve the problem of Western defense production, ended its first series of meetings today and adjourned until Oct. 26.

Rudolph Halley, Liberal-Independent-City Fusion candidate for President of the City Council, attacked the present city administration yesterday on the ground that it had failed to attract civil servants with brains and idealism.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11--Secretary General Trygve Lie warned United Nations member states today against depending solely on regional alliances to foil future aggression. Such regional pacts, he insisted, must supplement but not supplant the United Nations' own system of collective security.
MALDEN-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 11--An uncharted deep in the Hudson River off this place at midstream has been discovered accidentally in a search for a sunken tugboat.

As it emerges from conference in Congress the new tax bill provides for the raising of revenue estimated at approximately $5,750 millions. This is a far cry from the $16.5 billions sought by the Administration last January and falls far short of the revised Treasury estimate of last June, which placed its needs at $10 billions.

The Communist command in Korea charged that United Nations planes had made strafing attacks near Panmunjom, where liaison officers have been meeting in an effort to arrange for the resumption of full-scale cease-fire negotiations. United Nations officers made two investigations at the scene, and the liaison sessions, halted a day, will now continue to plan for full-scale armistice talks. [1:8.]

VIENNA, Oct. 12--Walter J. Donnelly, United States High Commissioner in Austria, emphatically denied today in the Allied Council the Soviet charge made at the last meeting that the United States was remilitarizing its zone in Austria. He declared:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 12--The prohibition of coffee shipments from the Port of Rio de Janeiro was condemned today by Sen. Alencastro Guimaraes as a shameful effort to promote speculation. The order suspending shipments was issued by Horacio Lafer, Finance Minister.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 12 (AP)--War Token, a 3-year-old chestnut son of War Admiral, scored a hard-driving three-quarter-length victory over Adelantado in the Columbus Day Purse, mile feature of a racing double-header today at Rockingham Park.

Three important Beethoven compositions formed the nucleus of Eunice Podis' piano recital in Town Hall last night and, what is more, established the tonal and temperamental palette of the entire event. It was her fourth recital here in as many seasons, and was enjoyed by a large audience.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 12--A price of $310,000 has been set on a tract of more than forty acres the Singer Manufacturing Company is slated to buy from the Central Railroad of New Jersey.

ROME, Oct. 12--A vast plan is understood to have been adopted by the Communist party for creating a network of clandestine "factory commissions" within all Italian industrial establishments for the specific purpose of sabotaging defense production.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12 (UP)--James P. Finnegan, former Internal Revenue Collector here who has been charged with accepting bribes and violating a Federal tax law, will surrender at 10 A.M. tomorrow, the United States Marshal's office announced today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 12 (UP) --Military chiefs of the United States, Britain and France arrived by plane and immediately opened talks with high Turkish officials on the building of a powerful new defense network for the Near East.

Advancing United Nations ground forces in the east-central sector of the Korean battlefront yesterday (Friday) encountered stiff resistance from dug-in enemy groups employing heavy mortar fire. Leading elements of a United Nations unit in this area were forced to withdraw temporarily when counter-attacked by an estimated two enemy companies employing "Molotov cocktails," but immediately counter-attacked and secured their ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--President Truman's nomination of Ambassador at Large Philip C. Jessup to serve on this country's delegation to the United Nations may be considered dead, barring a series of wholly improbable events.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)-- Price Stabilizer Michael V. DiSalle assured cotton-state representatives in Congress today that any new order he might issue on textile prices would not lower existing ceilings on raw cotton.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 12--The first assembly of the National Council of Catholic Youth was hailed here today by the Most Rev. James A. McNulty, Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of Newark, as a new "united and powerful voice" destined to make itself heard above the "raucous noises of the youthful disciples of decadence."

Theatrical activities on Broadway and its fringes will be on the increase next week, when the professional producers will unfurl four new stage offerings, the Palace Theatre will bring back vaudeville on a two-a-day basis and two little theatre items will be presented.

WASHINGTON, Oct.12--United States Commissioner of Education Earl J. McGrath reported today a steel allocation of 96,296 tons for school construction in the first quarter of 1952, an increase over the tentative allocation of 81,000 tons that had been scheduled earlier.

Bronx House, community center at 1637 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, announced yesterday the opening of the Bronx House-Pelham Parkway Branch at 2280 Wallace Avenue, the Bronx. It is housed in facilities leased from the City Housing Authority at Pelham Parkway Houses, a middle-income housing project.

McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N.J., Oct. 12--The United States Air Force needs men. To get them, it started an experiment here to day by inviting seventeen students from Manhattan College to inspect its offerings and learn the advantages of becoming an aviation cadet.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 12 --Michigan State College, extending its own Point Four program of technical assistance to South America, is preparing to send an educational mission to Colombia this winter to help in the training of agricultural technicians.

ALBANY, Oct. 12 (AP)--Tax revenues are pouring in 9 per cent greater than Governor Dewey had estimated to balance the state's billion-dollar budget. Receipts for the first six months of the 1951-52 fiscal year totaled $561,123,367, an increase of $81,500,000 over a year ago.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12--A national Methodist conference on family life, aimed at evaluating the forces that are affecting the American home, began today. More than 3,000 persons, many of them young couples, attended the opening session at Medinah Temple. The conference concludes Sunday.

Franklin Simon opened its new "Tureen" yesterday. Aside from the fact that it seats only twentynine and is sure to keep feminine shoppers waiting in line, we have nothing but good to say for this little lunch counter on the department store's third floor.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 12--Discussing the current agitation over the Presidential order on classification of vital information, Turner Catledge, executive managing editor Of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared here today such regulations must be justified in the light of the larger purposes to be served.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Saturday, Oct. 13--Three United Nations divisions jumped off today in an attack on the central front, gaining up to a mile against feeble Chinese resistance, and violent fighting exploded across most of the Korean battle line. As the allies surged forward in the center, the Communists struck back in the east.

An investigation of "ten or twelve employes" of the Third District Internal Revenue Office, 110 East Forty-fifth Street, to ascertain the sources of their additional incomes, is under way, Monroe D. Dowling, Collector, said yesterday.

The engagement of Miss Suzanne Rohner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Alfred Rohner of 540 Park Avenue and Carmel, N.Y., to Pvt. Robert Walsh Godridge, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Primus E. Godridge of Carmel, has been announced by her parents.

Since July the Senate Internal Security Committee has been holding hearings apparently designed to show that the Institute of Pacific Relations, a private nonprofit research body, has exercised sinister or subversive influence on the direction of American policy toward the Far East.

Soviet Russia's company union known as the World Federation of Trade Unions has been an unwelcome guest in Vienna since last May when, without seeking permission of the Austrian Government or awaiting an invitation from the Austrian Trades Union Congress, it moved its headquarters there from Paris. The Federation had been ordered by the French Government to close its offices last January.

Agricultural Economics Bureau Predicts 'Moderate' if Any Early Price Increases WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)-- The Bureau of Agricultural Economics, in an appraisal of the economic outlook for the next few months, predicted today that price increases, if any, will be "moderate" in degree.

THE year 1942 had closed in Arctic waters with the spirited action by British de stroyers escorting a convoy to North Russia. Between January and March, in the remaining months of almost perpetual darkness, two more convoys, of forty-two ships and six ships sailing independently, set out on this hazardous voyage. Forty arrived. During the same period thirty-six ships were safely brought back from Russian ports and five were lost.

Mrs. Ogden Phipps' remarkable Oedipus, the 1950 winner of the steeplechaser-of-the-year title, completed the winning of the 1951 crown--and completed a sweep of Belmont Park's fall steeplechases --when he went three miles under 165 pounds to lead 'em to the wire in yesterday's $24,000 Grand National.
Major stores here reported yesterday that heavy holiday traffic brought them one of the best Columbus Day sales returns of recent years.
A letter has come from Beek, a modest mining community in the rolling green countryside of Limburg, a few miles from the ancient city of Maastricht, in the Netherlands.

PARIS, Oct. 12--W. Averell Harriman affirmed today his conviction that all of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's defense and rearmament objectives could be attained. He said that if the Western nations worked together they would have the power to deter the Soviet Union, since, in his opinion, Russia was the most backward of the European powers.

NEW HAVEN, Oct.12--Twentyfive years of helping students solve emotional aspects of life that might cause them to fall physically ill, fail classes, cheat on examinations or drink excessively were marked today by the Yale University Student Mental Hygiene Service.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 12-- Army and Dartmouth renew football relations at Michie Stadium tomorrow following a hiatus of fiftyone years. The cadets won both previous engagements, halting the Big Green, 6 to 0, in 1895 and 6 to 2 in 1899. The forecast of fair weather is expected to attract a crowd of 25,000.

The New York Antiques Fair, the big event among shows of the kind, is expected to get off to a better-than-usual start for its six-day run beginning Monday at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirtyfourth Street.
DETROIT, Oct. 12--The opening performance of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo here last night looked unhappily like a class of novice ice-skaters.

Dedicated to the theme "Americans All," one of the largest Columbus Day parades ever witnessed in New York brought the thud of marching feet and the shimmer of thousands of flags to Fifth Avenue yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 12 --The Yugoslav Government announced today a new tactical concession to the independent peasants to sustain the free sale of food, which was introduced in all cities in Yugoslavia several days ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP)-- Income earners will pay only about 2 per cent more in taxes for this year under the new tax bill agreed upon yesterday by a House-Senate conference committee. But next year they will feel the full force of the 11 per cent increase.

CHIPPENHAM, England, Oct.12 --The Liberals, by standing aside and letting Labor and the Conservatives fight it out alone in most of the constituencies of England, Scotland and Wales, are causing the major party leaders more anguish than they could ever have done by joining in the fray.

Henry and Jane Howard, in a purchase for occupancy, have acquired the three-story studio and office building at 206 East Twentieth Street from the Ozenfant School of Fine Arts. The sale was negotiated through Frances Spencer, Inc., as broker with Oliver Williams, Inc., acting as agent for the seller. The same brokers also negotiated the sale of the dwelling at 19 King Street for Ida Perrella to W. Koen for occupancy and investment.

Sales of leading mail order and chain stores in September showed a gain of 2.4 per cent over the like month of 1950, according to the compilation of forty-five companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Sales in August were 3.7 per cent above the comparable month of last year.
Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Steckler of 47 East Eighty-seventh Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Hope, to Roger Banning Steck, son of Mrs. Leah Steck of Bridgeport, Conn.
GENEVA, Oct. 12--Egypt attacked the United Nations plan for an independent Libya today as merely a screen for subjection of the former Italian colony to Britain.

For quick brush-ups in the kitchen, there is a new set of three brushes encased in a compact metal container. The brushes, designed for washing dishes or bottles and cleaning vegetables have durable nylon bristles. The white enamel container is made in a cylindrical shape, designed to stand in a corner on a shelf by the sink. Hammacher Schlemmer has the Nibco Kitchen Brush Set for $3.95.
Brooklyn Prep and Xavier High's football teams struggled to a scoreless tie last night under the lights of Ebbets Field before a crowd of 3,000.

The designation of this day as Council Day will serve to emphasize the importance of the part played by the 96,000 members of the National Council of Jewish Women in initiating and developing community services in health and welfare in their various villages, towns and cities throughout the nation.

Buck Rogers and Captain Video would have felt right at home yesterday with a group of fascinated scientists who listened to speculations on the future of interplanetary travel. They heard that the next likely step upward would be shooting out a rocket to be suspended in the earth's orbit, rotating with it as a satellite.
LONDON, Oct. 12--West Fulham, normally a quiet, dull and slightly shabby district of London, is the scene today of the start of one of the fiercest electoral tussles in the whole country.

TORONTO, Oct. 12 (Canadian Press)--Inflation is like a narcotic, William R. Biggs of New York said today in an address to the annual meeting of the American Life Convention, an organization of American and Canadian life insurance companies.

A third volume of the famous English potpurri of entertainment, "The Saturday Book," has been scheduled for publication here by Macmillan on Nov. 27. Edited by its founder, Leonard Russell, literary editor of The Sunday Times of London, the volume contains such items as Sacheverell ...
Football takes the center of the sports stage today with the exit, laughing, of the imperial Yankee Stengeleers and the unhappy end of the saga of the Giants, no less heroic in stature.
BOSTON, Oct. 12 (UP)--Fortytwo years ago a wise old doctor advised young Clarence De Mar to quit running in road races or he'd die of heart disease.

Lena Feingold has purchased the two-story store and loft building at 20-24 Meserole Street, Brooklyn, from Etta G. Burke. Saul Schwartz was attorney for the buyer, who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

We took note yesterday in a general way of preparations the city might be making to join in Columbia University's celebration of its 200th anniversary. We should like now to suggest specific physical improvements for which the 1954 bicentennial might be a target date.

All five candidates for President of the City Council, Acting Mayor Joseph T. Sharkey, Democrat; Representative Henry J. Latham, Republican; Rudolph Halley, LiberalIndependent-City Fusion, Clifford T. McAvoy, American Labor, and Michael Bartell, Socialist Workers, met last night on a television program for the first time during the campaign.
A.L. Simmons, president of the American Society of Travel Agents, sailed early today on the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth for France where he will attend the group's convention on Oct. 21.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--President Truman turned over to the Wage Stabilization Board today two strikes that had affected the output of jet engines and halted the assembly of big transport planes used to evacuate the wounded from Korea.

OTTAWA, Oct. 12 (Canadian Press)--The one-man MacQuarrie Committee on Combines has labeled the common practice of retail price-fixing "restrictive and monopolistic" and has recommended that the Government eliminate it.
Radio officers flocked back to their ships in large numbers yesterday and departure delays on all three coasts were "rapidly clearing up."
As the summer moved jerkily into the fall, a good many normally healthy people seemed to have colds.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 12 (AP)--Jack the Great, from the barn of Walter A. Edgar, won the Georgetown Purse today before a gathering of 9,022.

The largest one-day contribution by a single group to the New York regional Red Cross blood program bloodmobile was recorded yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital, where 502 Roman Catholic nuns responded to an appeal by Cardinal Spellman to priests, nuns and brothers in the Archdiocese. Each nun donated one pint of blood.

"NATURALLY, we all read a good many classics," Will Cuppy says in "How to Get From January to December," "be cause we were made to do so at school, but Adam Smith's 'Inquiry Into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations' is so classic that they don't even try to make you read it." That seems to suggest a prudent policy to follow in speaking of this quietly hilari ous new Cuppy book.

William R. Hearst Jr. announced yesterday the first major change in Hearst properties since the death of his father with a statement that on May 11 The American Weekly Magazine would appear in rotogravure on coated paper.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 (AP)-- Princeton and Pennsylvania will clash tomorrow in a football game that might well decide the Ivy League championship at this early date.

LONDON, Oct. 12--Iraq's demand yesterday for a revision of the treaty relations with Britain was taken very calmly in Whitehall today. The issue was thought to be less troublesome than those with Iran and Egypt.

Among its artist members the Ganso Gallery boasts three recent Fulbright fellowship recipients--Ethel Magafan, Edward Chavez and Howard Mandel, a trio of painters from Woodstock, N.Y. The current exhibition here honors them, as well as Jenne Magafan and Bruce Currie.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 12-- In St. Lawrence Roman Catholic Church this morning, Miss Mary Claire Buckley, daughter of Mrs. Anna J. Buckley of Chestnut Hill, was married to Ralph W. Whelan, son of Joseph B. Whelan of Needham, and the late Mrs. Whelan.

WASHINGTON, Oct.12--Thirtyseven per cent of the 339,000 college students who took the draft deferment tests last spring and summer failed to make the passing grade of 70, Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent over the week ended on Oct. 9, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index, which advanced for the fourth consecutive week, now stands at 177.3 per cent of the 1926 average, 5.2 per cent above the level of a year ago and 13 per cent above the May 24-June 25, 1950 (pre-Korea), average.

For a good many years when nutrition-minded mothers, camp cooks or school lunch program planners asked how many calories growing youngsters needed every day, no very exact answers were available. Plenty of research has been done on human energy expenditure for different activities, but the vast majority of the studies have dealt with adult subjects.

The election of Harry M. Addinsell, chairman of the board of the First Boston Corporation, as treasurer of the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church was announced yesterday. He succeeds Russell E. Dill, who died Sept. 27.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 12--John Bosley Jr. of Pimlico, Md., wellknown horse trainer and amateur rider, died in Nassau Hospital here today. His age was 56. He suffered a heart attack yesterday at Belmont Park racetrack.

PARIS, Oct. 12--While the French franc tumbled to a new low of 440 to the dollar today, Vice Premier Rene Mayer declared that his Ministry of Finance alone could not control the value of the franc. "It is up to the public," he told reporters. "If Frenchmen really want to defend the franc, it will be saved."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 12-- Royal Little, president of Textron, Inc., and Alfred C. Neal, first vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, urged communitywide cooperation here today to foster industrial economic development in New Eigland. Both executives spoke at sessions of the New England regional cost conference of the National Association of Cost Accountants, at the Sheraton-Biltmore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--The Senate completed Congressional action today on $56,939,568,030 of appropriations to run the armed forces through the present fiscal year and into the next.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 12 --Clayton Johnson and Les Bromlee of Wee Burn posted a gross best-ball score of 36, 34--70 today and took the medal in the Winged Foot Golf Club's second memberguest tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12--Iran today in effect rejected a new British proposal whereby the Security Council would ask both parties in the Anglo-Iranian oil dispute to negotiate their differences and avoid provocative actions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is virtually assured of re-election in 1952 unless there should develop within his own party between now and next April--when the Wisconsin Republican primaries will be held --an opposition movement sufficiently strong to deprive him of the nomination.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)-- A Senate subcommittee said today that there had been a substantial reduction in recent months in the war materials shipped from Western countries to Communists.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 12 (AP) --Villanova completely outplayed favored Alabama here tonight to win a smashing 41-to-18 victory in an intersectional football game.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 12--White autumn blossoms formed a background in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Redeemer here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Linell Chenault Nash, daughter of Ogden Nash, the poet, and Mrs. Nash of Baltimore, to John Marshall Smith, son of Mrs. Page Smith of Baltimore and William Ward Smith of New York.
Joe DiMaggio--the famed Yankee Clipper--left for San Francisco last night with the statement that he had played his last game of major league baseball.

TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 13--The Communist command charged yesterday that United Nations planes had raided the area near Panmunjom, where liaison officers have been meeting for the last three days to arrange a resumption of negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war. The Reds said the planes had killed one Korean child and wounded a second in strafing attacks.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 12-- Coming from opposite directions on a final beat to windward over a four-legged course of 8 miles, Corny Shields and Arthur Knapp had a real racing thrill today in the first contest of the wind-up series of three off the Larchmont Yacht Club.
BUFFALO, Oct. 12--Former City Court Judge George L. Hager died in General Hospital today at the age of 84.

Three cash prizes will be awarded to college and university students by the J.C. Nichols Foundation of the Urban Land Institute for the best essays on improvement and development of community life in the United States.

Henry Rosenfeld, one of New York's largest garment manufacturers, will cut prices of women's worsted suits for spring by $5 to the pre-Korean price of $24.75. The new retail price on suits, he said yesterday, will be down about $10.

MIAMI, Oct. 12 (AP)--Purdue gambled recklessly with a fourthdown line smash in the first three minutes tonight and lost the football game when Miami smothered the play and struck quickly for the touchdown that produced a 7-0 victory.

WINSLOE, Prince Edward Island, Oct. 12--After tramp ing hill and dale behind eight braces run in the annual Charlottetown hunt trials, we were left in no doubt as to the most popular breed in this area, for of the sixteen bird dogs run in shooting dog stake, all but three were Brittany spaniels.

CARDIFF, Wales, Oct. 12--The electors of Wales, where the radical tradition is strong, will cast nearly 2,000,000 votes in the general election and from present indications the overwhelming majority will again be solidly behind the Labor Government.
PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 12--William Moulton Ingraham, Assistant Secretary of War under President Wilson and a former Mayor of this city, died today at his home after a brief illness. He was 80 years old.

Verdi's "Rigoletto" returned to the City Center last night, though not altogether as anticipated. Last presented by the New York City Opera Company in the spring of 1948, "Rigoletto," in its current revival, has been newly staged by Jose Ruben, and last night's performance was to have introduced the recently acquired baritone, Theo Bayle, in the title role.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--An official Navy publication disclosed today that the "gigantic" atomic-powered submarines of the future, one of which is now being built, would attain underwater speeds as high as thirty-five knots. The best submerged speed expected of some of the latest type conventionally powered undersea craft, not yet tested, is about twenty-five knots at "all out."

Few persons realize the extent to which taxes affect the prices of homes, in the opinion of B.J. Bergton, real estate broker of Teaneck and Fair Lawn, N.J. He said that taxes account for more than 25 per cent, and in some cases as much as 40 per cent, of the cost of a dwelling.

Saying that juvenile delinquency had become New York City's number one problem, Rudolph Halley last night charged Mayor Impellitteri, Joseph T. Sharkey, Acting President of the City Council and his Democratic opponent, and the city's budget director with responsibility for failure to meet the problem.
It will be Columbia against Yale today in the first real test of the Lions' 1951 football team before a Homecoming Day crowd at Baker Field. The kick-off will be at 2 P.M.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 12 (AP)-- John H. Bosshart, New Jersey Commissioner of Education, reported today that hiring of school teachers without full legal qualification was on the rise in northeastern states.

Work on the superstructure of the $12,130,000 South Street elevated highway, the last link needed to complete the express traffic loop around lower Manhattan, will begin early next year, according to plans being developed in the office of Borough President Robert F. Wagner.

BOSTON, Oct. 12--Fordham's football machine rebounded from its crushing defeat at the hands of Holy Cross last week by sweeping to a 35-to-19 victory over Boston College tonight. A chilled crowd of 18,763 at Braves Field saw the visitors lead from beginning to end.

LONDON, Oct. 12--Leonard Keysor, who won the Victoria Cross, Britain's highest military decoration, for catching handthrown bombs and tossing them back into the Turkish trenches during the Gallipoli campaign in 1915, died here today at the age of 65.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12 (UP) --A smiling Leo Durocher and his wife, Laraine Day, returned home today and the manager of the National League champion Giants said he was "going to take it easy and get in a lot of golf."

The Vanadium-Alloys Steel Corporation more than doubled its net profit in the year ended on June 30, according to a report yesterday. Earnings were $1,896,823, or $4.57 for each of 414,492 shares, against $858,850, or $4.21 for each of 203,722 shares in the 1950 year.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 12-- In the home of her parents here this afternoon, Miss Frances Chambers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Chambers, was married to Gerald John Joswick, son of Mrs. Joseph Joswick of Chicago and the late Mr. Joswick, by the Rev. Dr. Andrew McCracken. There was a small reception later.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)-- President Truman said today that the United States would keep on trying to bring freedom to Russian satellite nations as long as he was President.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 12--The sincerity of the West German Government's offer to make suitable financial restitution for the wrongs committed against Jews during the Nazi regime is scheduled to get a speedy test.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 12 (AP) --Three of the four top favorites made it through the first two rounds of match play in the Willard memorial amateur golf tournament at Hardscrabble Country Club today, but former Champion Bob Cochran of St. Louis fell by the wayside.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 12--The enthusiasm and resolution evinced by the hundreds of thousands of ordinary fighting men in the recent series of maneuvers have emerged as the greatest strength of the Western World.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 12 (AP)-- Cornell will launch its Ivy League football campaign tomorrow against a weak and twice-beaten Harvard eleven.

Chico Vejar, 20-year-old Stamford, Conn., boxer, slugged his way to a unanimous decision over Lou (Sonny) Volpe of the West Side in a ten-round welterweight clash at the St. Nicholas arena last night. Vejar almost finished Volpe in the opening frame. He pounded away at the New Yorker's face midway through the round. Volpe went to the floor, but came up at the count of eight.

Rutgers is a strong favorite to defeat New York University at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island today. The Violets will seek to avenge the 42-0 trouncing they absorbed from the Scarlet eleven last year.

When Nahas Pasha proclaimed to a cheering Parliament that Egypt was abrogating her treaties with Britain governing the joint control of the Suez Canal and the Sudan it was well known in Cairo that the United States, Britain, France and Turkey were about to propose a defense agreement which would supersede the existing arrangement.

Representative Edwin Arthur Hall, Binghamton Republican, accused a Republican-controlled State Legislative Committee yesterday of planning a "heinous gerrymander" of New York's Congressional districts.

TOKYO, Oct. 12--Premier Shigeru Yoshida called on the Japanese Parliament today for quick approval of the San Francisco peace treaty and the security pact with the United States in order to restore to Japan "complete sovereignty and independence," withheld for six years since the surrender in 1945.
John M. Dumser has been named assistant to the general manager of the Wolverine Tube division of Calumet and Hecla Consolidated Copper Company, as of Oct. 15.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 12 (UP)--Leon Errol, the bald, "rubber-legged" star of short comedies, died today of a heart attack after a three-week illness. The 70-yearold actor had entered Good Samaritan Hospital last night for a check-up.

GRANVILLE, Ohio, Oct. 12 (AP)--Dr. Arthur Blair Knapp, who became Denison University's fourteenth president today in campus ceremonies, called for an integration between specialized and general education "or we shall in fact become irrelevant and our fate immaterial."

Adopting a stern attitude toward Sanitation Department employes accused of participating in slowdowns, Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain discharged two workers yesterday, one with more than twenty-three years service, and suspended five others for thirty days without pay. A thirty-day suspension is the maximum penalty short of dismissal.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)-- The railroad industry today asked for further time in which to complete a proposed uniform classification table of freight, to be applied to every segment of the country.

The four-story apartment house at 23-24 Thirty-first Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, accommodating thirteen families, has been sold by the Housing Realty Corporation to John Albert. The property also includes three garages. Simone Management Company was the broker.

Whereas a dispute has arisen between the Government of the United Kingdom and the Government of Iran regarding the oil installations in Iran, the continuance of which dispute is likely to threaten the maintenance of international peace and security and...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--The first six months of 1952 will be a "dismal" period for producers of civilian goods, defense mobilization officials agreed today. They added, however, that once that critical period was passed, more liberal supplies of steel and aluminum would permit easing of production restrictions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 12-- "The Scarlet Flame," a costume drama dealing with Brazil's struggle for independence, has been purchased by Fidelity Pictures for Yvonne de Carlo, who has a commitment with the company to make a second picture after she completes "San Francisco Story," with Joel McCrea.

MADRID, Oct. 12--Ambassador Stanton Griffis, taking part today in the Columbus Day ceremonies here, remarked that it gave him special pleasure to note that he was participating in an event that recalled "one of those many ties which link our two lands in common bond."

HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 12--At his inaugural as fourth president of 81-year-old Stevens Institute of Technology, Dr. Jess Harrison Davis called today for frequent, unbiased reappraisals of the entire program of engineering education as a necessary step in keeping engineering education "dynamic."

NEW KENSINGTON, Pa., Oct. 12 (AP)--The fifth banking scandal within a year broke in this industrial town of 25,000 today when the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested an assistant cashier of the First National Bank and said the total shortages in two banks would exceed a million dollars.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--The National Association of Housing Officials' 1,200 delegates closed their four-day eighteenth annual meeting here today with a morntill-night program that included attention to segregation, the drawbacks of "skyscraper" housing, and many technical problems of lowrent, subsidized dwellings.

Joseph T. Sharkey has two jobs. He is Acting President of the City Council; he is a $7,500-a-year salesman for the General Builders Supply Corporation, which sells supplies, some of them to individuals and concerns doing business with the city.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12 (AP)-- William Earl (Bill) Essick, West Coast baseball scout for the New York Yankees for twenty-five years, and the man who signed Joe DiMaggio, died in his sleep today at the age of 69. He had been ill since May, suffering from a heart ailment.

TORONTO, Oct. 12--Princess Elizabeth saw today the first Indians of her American tour as well as thousands of farm and small-town folk whose forefathers had fled the independence-minded American colonies to remain under the British crown.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12--The American Jewish Committee outlined here today a proposed eight-point program of action for West Germany that called for the establishment of a special agency by Bonn that would assure the protection of civil rights, and urged German officials to aid those Jews remaining in Germany to maintain their religious, social and cultural institutions.

A marked decline in demand for paperboard and corrugated containers is returning the dealer market to more normal competition and producing the first signs of weakening prices, trade sources reported yesterday.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 12-- Cpl. James Weston of Mattoon, Ill., sat in his three-quarter-ton truck late this morning and looked across white sands to a stone bridge, where two unarmed Chinese guards were staring down at him.

Two researchers offered statistical proof yesterday that overweight persons were far more vulnerable to diabetes and the degenerative diseases of the heart, liver and kidneys than persons of normal weight.
ATLANTIC, Iowa, Oct. 12 (AP)-- The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, New York minister and radio pastor whose appearance here had been protested, today addressed an overflow crowd at a teachers meeting.

The United States District Court has reserved judgment after a four-day trial of a salvage case inivolving an Italian tugboat company and its claim for more than $250,000 for assisting into port the mine-damaged Government-owned tanker Signal Hills.

LONDON, Oct. 12--The conditions laid down by the Soviet Union for agreeing to a revision of the Italian peace treaty were dismissed by British Foreign Office spokesman today as propaganda designed for exploitation by the Italian Communist party.

There were times during their home opener when the New York Football Giants attacked feebly, defended sloppily and floundered pitifully against the Chicago Cardinals at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Even when Steve Owen's men were in front early in the contest, they looked wabbly and when they fell behind, 17-14, in the second quarter, their outlook was far from bright.
Members of both the Police and Fire Departments who died in the last year were honored by their comrades in two memorial services yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 14 Monogram Pictures Corporation, with a consolidated net profit of $1,061,648 for the fiscal year ended last June 30, had the most profitable twelve months in its fifteenyear history, according to the annual financial statement to be released tomorrow.

The Port of New York will take on the role of capital of the maritime industry this week as leaders from various parts of the world converge on the three-day silver jubilee convention of the Propeller Club of the United States, to open at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Wednesday morning.

Preparations for protecting American workers, industrial plants and equipment of all kinds against atomic bomb air raids need differ only slightly from those utilized against conventional bombing, it was reported yesterday by a research team of the National Industrial Conference Board.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 14 (AP) The Cleveland Browns used a new script today, scoring five of their six touchdowns on ground plays in handing the Washington Redskins their third straight defeat, 45 0.

HEADQUARTERS, Far East Air Forces Bomber Command, Oct. 14-- Brig. Gen. Joe W. Kelly, commander of the Far East Air Forces Bomber Command, denied today that heavy losses of B-29 Superforts had taken place over Korea recently, and that complete figures had not been announced.

Edwin G. Booz of Glen View, Ill., founder and senior member of Booz, Allen Hamilton, management counselors, with offices in Chicago, New York, Washington, Los Angeles and other cities, died yesterday in Evanston (Ill.) Hospital, which he entered on Sept. 30, after two years of failing health. He was born in Reading, Pa., sixtyfour years ago.

Corliss Lamont, son of the late Morgan banking partner, Thomas W. Lamont, and former chairman of the National Council for American-Soviet Friendship, disclosed yesterday that the State Department had rejected his application for a passport to travel in Europe.

A number of manufacturers in the suburban areas of Long Island, New Jersey and upstate New York may not be aware that the ceiling price regulation on exports may affect their products even if they do not sell directly to a foreign buyer.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 14 Protests against the Indonesian Government's sweeping arrests last August of Communists and Commonist sympathizers have been conspicuously meager.

PARIS, Monday, Oct. 15 Complete returns in the second and decisive ballot in the French elections for the members of Departmental Councils, taken with the figures for last Sunday's vote, confirmed yesterday a shift in France's conservative provinces away from the Communists and the Left to parties of the Center and the Right.

President Truman declared yeaterday that "until the world accepts the principle of the brotherhood of man under the Fatherhood of God, it will be compelled to live under a day-in day-out alert with the dread of deadly explosions always imminent."

Everett Welles Frazar, a member of one of the oldest families engaged in business in the Far East,. died yesterday at his home at Daytona Beach, Fla., according to information received here by associates. He was 84 years old.
WASHINGTON Oct. 14 The field is wide open on a successor to William M. Boyle Jr, as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, with the final choice resting in the hands of President Truman.

PARIS, Oct. 14 (AP) A large number of people who see General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower believe he will become a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, and will say so in the spring.
PITTSBURGH, Oct.14 (UP)-- The San Francisco Forty-niners staved off a fourth-period Pittsburgh Steeler surge to score a 28-to-24 victory before 27,307 today at Forbes Field.

United Nations planes, despite "standing" instructions, strafed Panmunjom and Kaesong, General Ridgway said. Answering a Communist protest against violation of the neutral zone, in which one Korean boy was killed and his brother wounded, General Ridgway expressed his regrets and promised "prompt and appropriate disciplinary action." After thirty-two boards of play, the bridge team of Howard Schenken, Samuel M. Stayman, B.J. Becker and George Rapee, all of New York, with John R. Crawford of Philadelphia, led the team of Mrs. Helen Sobel and Myron Field of New York, with Charles H. Goren and Sidney Silodor of Philadelphia by 890 points last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 A sweeping investigation of Federal credit and debt management policies looking to a redefinition by Congress of the functions of the Treasury and Federal Reserve Board in each field was announced today by the Congressional Joint Committee on the Economic Report.

HAMILTON, Ont., Oct. 14 The peace of a small town church, a double rainbow in the mists of Niagara Falls and her biggest laugh since she came to Canada were Princess Elizabeth's rewards today after two crowded traffic-jamming days in Toronto.

CAMP KILMER, N.J., Oct. 14 The first contingent of alien soldiers now serving in the United States Army was greeted today at this camp by Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, sponsor of a law that will ultimately place 12,500 men from Iron Curtain countries in the military service of this country.

CAIRO, Oct. 14 Opposition to the four-power proposals to replace British forces in the Suez Canal zone and the British-Egyptian treaty with a Middle East command arrangement is boiling up. Leading newspapers commenting on the presentation yesterday of the proposals, made public tonight, definitely opposed the suggestions or were outright hostile.

LAS VEGAS, NEV., Oct. 14-- (U.P.)-- History's first atomic maneuvers will employ atomic weapons almost exclusively--no standard equipment such as tanks and machine guns will be employed, authorities said today.

Expanding activity in residential building in the Hicksville section of Long Island was noted yesterday with the purchase of three additional tracts there for development, and with earlier construction programs continuing at a brisk pace.

Spring prices of Gramercy Park clothes probably will be maintained until commitments are made but after that any change in quotations is likely to be an increase, Jerome I. Udell, president of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., told a sales convention held over the week-end at the Gramercy Park Hotel.

ALBANY, Oct. 14 The Dewey Administration is charting a new approach to the narcotics problem in New York City, one that will combine state financial aid with the available facilities of private hospitals and welfare groups.

NEW ROCHELLE, Oct. 14 Mayor Stanley W. Church, replying today to Governor Dewey's criticism of the city's civil defense activity, said the Governor's representatives had praised "our accomplishments as the best he had seen in the entire state."
TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 15 Rescue ships reached the grounded Kongo Maru, wrecked in a typhoon off southern Japan early today, and found several hundred United Nations troops safe.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) The Chicago Black Hawks won their second straight National Hockey League victory and went into a First-place tie with the Montreal Canadiens tonight when they defeated the New York Rangers before 11,782 by a score of 3 to 2.

Trade in the holiday season should be active and perhaps as much as 5 per cent above the 1950 period, Henry H. Heimann, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men, asserts in his monthly business review for publication today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 14 Miss Gail Fenbert and Ned Hancock, members of the Boulder Brook Club, captured the two top horsemanship awards today in the twenty-sixth annual Harrison amateur horse show, held in the outdoor ring of the Kentucky Riding Club. Miss Fenbert gained the championship in the saddle seat division while Hancock received the title rosette in the hunter seat section.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman of Christ Church (Methodist) of New York told delegates to the Methodist national conference on family life today that the family was "the spiritual atom of the atomic age."

Through his development of the theory of interpersonal relations, the late Harry Stack Sullivan, internationally known paychiatrist, opened a new approach to further research into the study of the human personality, Dr. Clara Thompson, executive director of the William Alanson White Institute of Psychiatry, declared yesterday.

An anonymous telephone call warning that a bomb had been planted in a locker in Grand Central Terminal precipitated a tedious three-hour search yesterday of 3,000 lockers in the terminal. When the search was finally called off at 1:40 P.M. no explosive had been found.

MANILA, Oct. 15 Off-year election politics are threatening to precipitate a clash over use of Defense Secretary Ramon Magsaysay's armed forces to prevent coercion of voters and insure clean elections next month. On Nov. 13, 4,000,000 registered Filipinos will elect nine Senators, fifty-two provincial Governors and several hundred town and city Mayors.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 15 Five thousand soldiers and 1,000 scientists, engineers and other personnel of the Atomic Energy Commission were poised today for the second series of test explosions at the commission's proving grounds seventy-five miles north of this resort.
Don Meade was denied reinstatement as a jockey by the New York State Racing Commission in a decision handed down by the board yesterday.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Oct. 15 President Truman renewed today an invitation to the Soviet Union to talk peace and disarmament, but warned the free world that it must continue to develop its own strength if it expected the Russians to keep their pledged word and avoid the carnage of atomic warfare.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct, 15 Hundreds of men and women in New York State have been sent to prison needlessly in the last decade because ten counties lack probation service, it was charged today by Joseph Shelly, deputy chief probation officer of the Kings County Court Probation Department, New York.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday and closed 8 to 25 points net higher.

Henry G. Harper has been appointed vice president in charge of sales for the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company of Canada, Ltd. He formerly was manager of associated merchandise for the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, Akron.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 15 Richard D. Steuart, veteran newspaper man and an authority on Baltimore and Maryland history, died today at the age of 73. He had been in poor health for several years.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 15 Dr. Harold W. Oppice of Chicago, president of the American Dental Association, cautioned the opening session of the group's 373-member House of Delegates today against a renewed move to have dentists included under the Old Age and Survivors Insurance Program.

United Nations patrols continued patrol actions on the western Korean battlefront. Attacks on the central front continued against light to heavy resistance, with gains up to 2,500 yards reported.
