PARIS, Oct. 16--The French are now taking measures to forestall in North Africa the menace of rising Arab nationalism that has beset the British in the Middle East.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Wednesday, Oct. 17-- United States troops caught Chinese forces today in a giant trap on the central Korean front where three Allied divisions have smashed within four miles of the big enemy base of Kumsong.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16--The Senate Appropriations Committee today cut $274,126,488 from foreign aid funds approved by the House of Representatives as the group recommended $7,208,401,302 in new money for the mutual security program to prevent Communist aggression and subversion.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16--The Defense Production Administration today planned limitations on the use of sulphur in certain industries in order to assure adequate supplies for essential users.
LONDON, Oct. 16--Whichever way the British general election comes out, Uncle Sam can hardly win so far as plans for the defense of the West are concerned.

The village of Poultney, Vt., where George Jones, one of the founders of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was born and was initiated into the printer's craft by Horace Greeley, conveyed its congratulations to THE TIMES yesterday on this newspaper's 100th anniversary.

MIAMI, Oct. 16--The American Legion held its thirty-third national convention parade today over a two-mile route through downtown Miami with General of the Army Douglas MacArthur formally reviewing the marchers.
CHICAGO, Oct. 16--Active buying was the response of the grain market to the pessimistic foreign political news and to the continuance of unfavorable weather in Canada.

LONDON, Oct. 16--Trouble in Egypt and the assassination of the Prime Minister of Pakistan accentuated a general decline in the stock markets here today. The weakest sections were those for foreign bonds, in which Japanese
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 16-- Prime Minister Liaquat Ali Khan of Pakistan was assassinated this afternoon by a Moslem while addressing a public meeting in Rawalpindi.
BIRMINGHAM, England, Oct. 16--The Conservatives expect to win the British general election on Oct. 25, but they are not counting on the West Midlands to turn the tide in their favor.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP)-- All except three of the country's thirty-nine largest cities spent more than their revenue in their fiscal years ending in 1950.

The fourteen-story apartment house at 1107 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Ninety-second Street, has been sold by the Marwise Corporation to Kokkins Lyras, architects and builders, who plan to alter it into smaller apartments. The sale was negotiated by ...

Not to be outdone by the United States Bureau of the Census, which recently named the center of population, the American Iron and Steel Institute set about determining the geographic center of the country's steelmaking capacity. It was found

Eighty-two professional variety companies are scheduled to go overseas to entertain members of the United States Armed Forces during the coming year, starting Nov. 1, it was announced yesterday by U.S.O.-Camp Shows.

SYRACUSE, Oct, 16--Fear that the Federal Government is moving to take over regulation of local natural resources from the states was expressed today at a public hearing of the New England-New York Inter-Agency Committee.
With many parts of the Moslem world in turmoil yesterday the oil dispute between Britain and Iran neared a showdown in the United Nations Security Council.

For the first time since the start of the Korean war, supplies of a wide range of heavy chemicals have improved, with shortages critical in only a few individual key items, it was revealed here yesterday by industrial chemical marketers.

OSLO, Norway, Oct, 16--The Norwegian Government will reject a note from the Soviet Union accusing Norway of violating the Paris treaty of 1920 by placing Spitsbergen and Bear Island under the "competence" of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Commodity futures markets generally rose yesterday, but in most of them volume was small. Coffee was an exception, declining moderately, and cottonseed oil was another, with volume about double that of a normal day.
Four members of the world champion Yankees were named on the United Press American League All-Star team last night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP)-- Leslie O'Connor, who for twentythree years was one of Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis' closest advisers, said today that farm systems were destroying organized baseball.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 16--Demand for steel products at present is mixed, with certain items in extreme demand while others are leveling off in demand.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16--Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio announced today his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination and expressed confidence that he would be nominated and elected.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 16-- The Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur best-ball tournament held over the Siwanoy Country Club course today resulted in victory for the home club talent.

The Philadelphia Orchestra opened its forty-sixth New York season last night at Carnegie Hall. Eugene Ormandy, who has conducted the last fifteen, again was at the helm. He and his 104 musicians were greeted by the audience with the cordiality of old friends whose return was welcome.

KEENE, N. H., Oct. 16 (AP)-- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, said here today he expected General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower either would declare himself a candidate for the Republican nomination for President or rule himself out as such by Jan. 1.

Under circumstances that would have done credit to a Hollywood thriller, three detectives at 2 P.M. yesterday arrested five men as suspects in a narcotics smuggling case in Huyler's Restaurant, 60 Broad Street.
The great unrest that is sweeping through the Moslem world has exploded in another assassination which has brought death to an outstanding personality--Prime Minister Liaquat Ali Khan of Pakistan.

PARIS, Oct. 16--Lanvin-Castillo inaugurates the Paris midseason by a well-designed collection in which a "fanlight" neckline is an attractive feature of slim frocks in black or light navy mat broadcloth.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 16 (UP)--Residents here watched the weather closely today for an indication when the nation's first atomic war games will open at the Frenchman Flat proving ground.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 16-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer admitted to the Bundestag tonight that 134 members of the Federal Ministry of Foreign Affairs were former members of the Nazi party and that 130 officials of the organization had served in the ministry's counterpart under the National Socialist regime.

Benedicto Macri, on trial in General Sessions for the fatal stabbing of William Lurye, union organizer, was linked by prosecution witnesses yesterday to owners of a nonunion dress manufacturing concern that was being picketed under Mr. Lurye's direction in the spring of 1949.

Eight Broadway producers have been engaged by the Columbia Broadcasting System to stage a series of full-hour color television programs on alternate Sunday afternoons at 1:30 o'clock, beginning Nov. 11.

Former Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind was sworn in yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan as Third Deputy Police Commissioner assigned to preside over the trial of thirty-one policemen on departmental charges resulting from the Brooklyn gambling investigation.

ROME, Oct. 16--A "temporary consultative council for European migrations" was established today by twenty-seven countries participating in a migration conference that has been sitting for the last two weeks in Naples. The conference concluded its work.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16--The United Nations received a partly encouraging report today on the prospects for settling the bitter Indian-Pakistani dispute over Kashmir, and a suggestion that negotiations be renewed at once.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct, 16 (AP) --Enforcement of a plan to complete liquidation of the Federal Water and Gas Corporation was directed today in a United States District Court order signed by Chief Judge Paul Leahy.

Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain announced yesterday that 321 men suspended since department employes began a slowdown Oct. 1 would be permitted to return to work tomorrow. He said those who had not yet received departmental hearings would be tried and would have to bear whatever penalties he imposed.

New issues of securities totaling more than $21,180,700 will be offered to investors today by underwriting syndicates. The flotations represent common and preferred stock issues of public utility and industrial enterprises and railroad financing equipment trust certificates. The offerings are as follows:

"We're certainly glad to get that world series off the sports pages so football can come into its own," was the greeting of Jack Mara, president of the Football Giants, to the gathering at the first pro football luncheon yesterday--a joint Giants-Yanks affair at the Polo Grounds press room.
LONDON, Oct. 16--Britain was preparing today to fight, if necessary, to keep possession of her military bases in Egypt.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan indicated yesterday he knew James J. Moran's successor as the principal collector of a $500,000-a-year shakedown racket in the Fire Department.
Charles A. Houston, a New York lawyer for nearly half a century, died yesterday at his home, 6 Vermont Avenue, White Plains, after a long illness.

In a grave and reverent mood, Christopher Fry has written a generally elusive drama. He composed "A Sleep of Prisoners" last spring for the Religious Drama Society in England, where it was acted in several churches.
Joseph Benintende, sought since midsummer as the leader of a ring of eight gamblers who bet $50,000 a game on rigged basketball contests, was held in $75,000 bail in General Sessions yesterday.
A "growing shortage" of radio officers delayed National Shipping Authority vessels from sailing on schedule in the last half of September, it was reported yesterday.

With each successive season, the raincoat becomes increasing less the garment it formerly was--a design with a purely utilitarian purpose. Now embellished and chic, its usefulness goes beyond rain and invites all-weather wear.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 (AP)-- Wayne Millner, former Notre Dame star and veteran professional player and coach, will replace Alvin (Bo) McMillin as head coach of the Philadelphia Eagles for the rest of the football season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16--Another key Democratic official resigned today as the Democratic National Committee was summoned to meet here Oct. 31 to elect a successor to William M. Boyle Jr., national chairman, who resigned last week.
Rudolph Halley, Liberal-City Fusion-Independent candidate for president of the City Council, asked Acting Mayor Joseph T. Sharkey, Democratic candidate, ...

Bob Ward, Maryland's great All-America guard who played thirty-seven minutes with a broken finger as the Terps downed Georgia, 43--7, last Saturday, was the overwhelming choice yesterday as lineman of the week.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday and closed at or near the best levels of the day, 20 to 45 points net higher on active months.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP)-- Senator Herbert Lehman, Democrat and Liberal of New York, denounced in the Senate today a "rider" to the proposed declaration of peace with Germany which would reopen claims of persons

ROGERS HORNSBY is back in the majorleagues--provided you're willing to concede that the St. Louis Browns are major league material. At least the Rajah has returned from exile even though the return isn't quite as triumphant as Napoleon's from Elba.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16--The Senate Democrats prepared today a major counter-attack on the Republicans on the issue of the policy toward China through what will amount to a senatorial white paper to be published before the 1952 campaign gets well under way.
The Association of the Bar of the City of New York adopted resolutions last night urging the Government to take all available means to bring about the release of William N. Oatis in Czechoslovakia.
Capitol Records, Inc., has leased 5,000 square feet of ground floor space in the new Mutual Life Building, 1750 Broadway, at Fiftysixth Street, for its New York offices.

The annual bridge and canasta party under the auspices of the New York Committee of the National Cathedral Association will be held on Dec. 3 at the Colony Club. Mrs. Cleveland F. Bacon is chairman of the organization.

The United States team-of-four contract bridge championship was won late last night by the team of Howard Schenken, B.J. Becker, Samuel M. Stayman and George Rapee, all of New York, and John R. Crawford of Philadelphia.

Twice a year the man of the house must fight for his rights, for the preservation of those few and small posses sions which, although of little or no value to anyone else, to him are important. Or promise, some day, to be

FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 17 (AP) Par eluded all competitors today in the qualifying round of the Hardscrabble Country Club women's open golf tournament, which, for the first time in its seven-year history, doesn't have a professional entered.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) Richard Hartshorne, a Republican, was nominated today by President Truman to be United States District Judge for New Jersey. He was named to succeed Guy L. Fake, also a Republican, who retired.

Something new in hospital hobbies was unfolded yesterday at the the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, Broadway and 168th Street. A 43-year-old grandmother, who busies herself days with slides and blood counts in the laboratory of the Institute of Opthalmology, occupies...

BOSTON, Oct. 17 No shortages of any materials used in volume and popular-price shoes are in prospect for spring footwear, it was reported today at the advance spring showing sponsored by the New England Shoe and Leather Association at various hotels and sales offices here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 A Senate subcommittee assigned last spring to look into the ethics and moral standards prevailing in the running of the National Government called on the executive...

The city's 8,000,000 residents will undergo a surprise atom bomb test one morning in the latter part of the week of Nov. 25, Civil Defense Director Arthur W. Wallander announced yesterday. No announcement of the day and hour is to be made.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L.I., Oct. 17 The job of provost marshal and commanding officer of this sprawling base's 238-man air police squadron was fitted for size here today on the shoulders of 1st Sgt. Esper E. Davis.

Parents who think that love for a child must be expressed in "conatant giving, giving, giving" have a confused idea of what love means because this practice can create tremendous anxiety and insecurity in their offspring, Dr. Exie E. Welsch, child psychiatrist, said last night.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 17 Relocation of U.S. Route 1 in Greenwich, which will divert an estimated 70 per cent of the Boston Post Road traffic, was announced tonight by G. Albert Hill, State Highway Commissioner.
MIAMI, Oct. 17 (AP) Following is the text of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's speech before the national convention of the American Legion here today:
Directors of Babson Reports, Inc., at a meeting yesterday at Astor Hotel heard relatively favorable forecasts of 1952 business activity and a somewhat gloomy prophecy about the stock market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, only avowed major candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1952, expressed hope today that President Truman would be the Democratic candidate next year so the issues would be crystal clear to the voters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The Securities and Exchange Commission today gave interested parties until Oct. 29 to request a hearing on the bond and common-stock stock financing proposal of the Central Maine Power Company, Augusta, Me.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 17 The alternate proposals for the relocation of U.S. Route 1 as it approaches the city line here were received hostilely at a public hearing tonight attended by 1,000 persons in Burdick Junior High School.

The tax bill that came out of conference last week was a better measure than either the House or Senate version, but it was thoroughly unsatisfactory in at least two basic respects. In the first place, it fell short by more...
GLASGOW, Scotland, Oct. 17 To a Scottish audience tonight Winston Churchill appealed for votes to make Britain great again.

Fred Lazarus Jr., who received last night the National Gold Award of the National Conference of Christians and Jews for distinguished service in the field of human relations, said it was a hopeful sign that "many who indulge in routine discriminations are now self-conscious where in the past they were self-righteous."

Only thirty-seven foreclosure actions to satisfy liens amounting to $949,380 were taken against Manhattan real estate during the first nine months of this year, according to the Real Estate Board of New York, which reported yesterday that this represented the lowest level for forced transfers since the group started compiling date on the subject.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 In a final defense of his loyalty and competence, Ambassador at Large Philip C. Jessup today accused his chief opponent, Harold E. Stassen, of making "subtle and light-footed" charges that had no basis in fact.

LONDON, Oct. 17 The start of the bookkeeping account covering the election on Oct. 25 helped the stock markets today to throw off some of the hesitancy caused by trouble in Egypt and the assassination of the Prime Minister of Pakistan. By the end of the day many early losses had been replaced by small net gains. However, the volume of business remained light. I

A "serious attempt" by Washington to improve relations with Russia and have her help break the Korean stalemate was made on Oct. 5, but has been rebuffed, the State Department said this morning. In a reply, Foreign Minister Vishinsky agreed to examine "all important and unsettled questions," but doubted Washington's desire for better relations. A Korean truce, he said, is up to the United States. [1:8.]

YONKERS, Oct. 17 Pronto Don, America's outstanding trotter is favored to win the $25,000 Gotham Trot tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway. The Hayes Fair Acres' star is the 2 to 5 morning line choice in the mile and a half fall feature.

For those who like the directness of understated modern, a new collection, made by Pine Baker of Cambridge, Mass., has just become available at We Moderns, 227 East Sixty-seventh Street. The designer is Joseph Carreiro, a teacher of design at Cornell University. His triangular nested tables received an honorable mention for design from the American Institute of Decorators last year.

Announcement has been made by Mrs, Lorenzo D. Armstrong of 1165 Fifth Avenue and Riverside, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Rose Armstrong, to Julio Palau, son of Mrs. Conrad de Palau of Bronxville , N. Y., and the late Mr. de Palau of Barcelona, Spain. The wedding will take place Nov. 17.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 17 In a letter to Queen Juliana delivered today President Truman expressed agreement with the necessity of finding a solution to the refugee problem but offered scant hope that the United States would take any early initiative for the new drive the Queen had proposed.

With the release of the prospectus for the 1951-52 season at the Metropolitan Opera House, officials of the association also had a few comments to make yesterday about the rejection by the House of Representatives of the conference version of the tax bill, in which a provision exempted cultural institutions from the admissions tax.

Judge Harold R. Medina denounced in Federal Court yesterday what he characterized as the designed "obscurity" in the presentation of the Government's antitrust suit against seventeen investment banking houses.
The United Nations Security Council last night postponed until tomorrow morning its vote on a resolution that would ask Britain and Iran to resume their stalemated oil talks.

Eighty-two voluntary, nonprofit hospitals in New York City, affiliated with the United... Hospital Fund, are now seeking $3,500,000. At least one of these hospitals is in your community. Today we salute:

The perjury case against Mrs. Anna Wentworth, Staten Island housewife, was adjourned yesterday until Nov. 13. She had been arrested by District Attorney Herman Methfessel of Richmond County on Sept. 20, a few hours after she had told the State Crime Commission that she had seen the prosecutor in a house used for gambling.

DETROIT, Oct. 17 More than 300 employes of Hammond, Standish Co., Detroit's oldest meat packing house, returned to work without pay today in a labor-management attempt to rehabilitate the company, which went into receivership five weeks ago.

MIAMI, Oct. 17 General of the Army Douglas MacArthur accused the national Administration today of wasting the country's human and material resources through timidity in prosecuting the Korean war and profligacy in rearming the free nations of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Senate and House conferees resumed meetings on the $5,732,000,000 taxincrease bill without immediate results today, but there were predictions on all sides that an agreement would be reached tomorrow.
Transactions in which syndicates participated as buyers featured realty activity reported in Manhattan yesterday.

Great Britain has paid off nearly five years ahead of time the $425,000,000 which it borrowed from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in 1941, it was learned yesterday. The debt was not due until July 1, 1956.

Winters are growing milder in this part of the world, and that is a fact that may have big, beneficial effects on habits and opportunities here and in Canada, Dr. George H.T. Kimble, director of the American Geographical Society, said yesterday.

Acting Mayor Joseph T. Sharkey declared yesterday that he would fight in the Board of Estimate for salary increases for members of the supervisory staff of the Health Department's bureau of maternal and child health.

A convicted bookmaker, awaiting sentence as a runner for Harry Gross, testified yesterday in General Sessions that he had seen Benedicto Macri outside the telephone booth where William Lurye, 40-year-old union organizer, was stabbed fatally on May 9, 1949.

KOF, Germany, Oct. 17 (AP) Ten Czechoslovaks, including women and children, shot their way to the free West on foot today after having failed to crash Czechoslovakia's Iron Curtain in a homemade armored truck.
Underwriting syndicates will make public offering today of new debentures and common stock of Celanese Corporation of America and Louisville Gas and Electric Company.

Commodity futures markets lost the domestic sugar contract on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange moved against the trend. It was influenced by the action of Washington in cutting the domestic sugar quota from 8,250,000 short tons to 7,900,000 tons and reallocating 190,000 tons of the deficits.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 17 A slight figure in a crimson coat appeared on the balcony of Casa Rosada (Government House) this afternoon to preside over her own show, Weak from almost a month's illness, Sefiora Eva Peron rallied strength to appear as scheduled and to speak for ten minutes to a crowd of more than 100,000 that filled the Plaza de Mayo to the last yard and spilled out into adjoining streets.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 17 The Netherlands, following Denmark's lead, is advising Washington of her objection to a statement of Brig. Gen. George S. Olmsted, director of the United States Defense Department's Military Assistance Program, that termed the defense efforts of several Western European countries, including the Netherlands, inadequate.

TORONTO, Oct. 17 (UP) The Toronto Maple Leafs scored twice in the final four minutes tonight to rout the Boston Bruins, 4 to 2, for their second victory of the season before a crowd of 12,627 at Maple Leaf Gardens.

Practically every factor of operations of wholesale grocers increased to some extent in 1950 over 1949, according to the third annual profit and loss survey of the United States Wholesale Grocers' Association, released yesterday.

IF all the conversation tossed carelessly around by baseball men during the world series had been placed end to end, it would have pro vided enough hot air to inflate the Graf Zeppelin. So here are just some fragments that have been remembered.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UP) Phil K. Wrigley, owner of the Chicago Cubs, came out today against giving organized baseball "blanket exemption" from the antitrust laws but said the game's status under present law should be spelled out.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Secretary of State Dean Acheson placed the United States Government today fully and irrevocably in support of Britain's efforts to maintain her troops and installations in Egypt under existing Anglo-Egyptian agreements.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 A group of newspaper editors urged President Truman today to issue clearer definitions of security information that Government agencies should withhold. They also called for the establishment of a better appeals machinery for...

The New Jersey Turnpike Authority completed yesterday the permanent financing of the 118mile toll expressway that is to open next month by selling at public bidding an issue of $35,000,000 of revenue bonds to an investment banking syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation, Blyth Co., Inc., Harriman Ripley. Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) Congress completed legislative action today on the bill appropriating $597,262,713 for Army Engineers' civil functions and sent it to President Truman. The bulk of the funds in the measure is for flood control and navigation projects.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 17 (AP) A gas industry official proposed a system of conversion plants today to fortify United States fuel supplies.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 17 (AP)-- Brookfield Farms' odds-on favorite Imacomin, charging to the lead shortly after the gates were sprung and never headed thereafter, scored by three-quarters of a length in the featured Skeeter Purse at Garden State Park before 14,928 spectators today.

On net sales of $153,371,814, the Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., realized a net income of $5,249,513, after taxes of $7,291,000, in the nine months ended on Aug. 31. In the same period of the previous year, the net income, after $3,727,000 tax charges was $4,748,230 on sales of $95,276,036.

Two Hollywood luminaries, Ann Sothern and Robert Cummings, are co-starred in tonight's Broadway stage opening of "Faithfully Yours" at the Coronet Theatre. A comedy in two acts by L. Bush-Fekete and Mary Helen Fay (Mrs. Bush-Fekete), it is based on a play by Jean Bernard-Luc, which opened on the Paris stage last winter and is still playing there. The opening night curtain will rise at 8 o'clock.

To give high school students a glimpse of the various steps pertaining to stage producing, the personnel attached to "Seventeen" will cover the subject at four consecutive Saturday morning symposiums to be held at the Straubenmuller Textile High School, starting Oct. 27. Offered by the School Art League, the forthcoming seminar will mark the fifth edition of a series labeled "Footlights in Your Eves."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 Sir James Chadwick, British physicist and Nobel prize winner, said tonight that development of atomic energy was delayed a year because of "failure to achieve full cooperation" between British and United States scientists.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17-- Henry A. Wallace strongly defended today his China mission in 1944 as Vice President, asserting that his recommendations clearly were not pro-Communist and, if followed promptly, held the best hope of saving the Nationalist Government.

TOKYO, Oct. 17 (UP) Baseballworshipping Japanese fans choked midtown Tokyo traffic for an hour and rocked the city with screams of "Banzai DiMaggio!" tonight in a tumulous welcome to the Yankee Clipper and other United States stars on tour.

The crippling wildcat strike by longshoremen here continued to gain momentum yesterday and appeared to be out of control as it spread to seven more piers. Despite an unsuccessful early morning attempt by Anthony Anastasia, notorious Brooklyn waterfront boss, to break the strike, no end of the walkout was in sight.

There was fighting from one end of the Korean battle line to the other yesterday (Wednesday) as ground troops of the United Nations command continued limited objective attacks against the enemy. Heaviest action of the day was once again centered on the western...
The constitutionality of the city's sewer rental charge was upheld yesterday in a decision by Supreme Court Justice Emil N. Baar in Brooklyn.

AT SEA, Aboard the United States Carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt off Corsica, Oct. 17 (UP) General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower said today "internal inspection" of Russia's atomic industries was the "minimum thing we must demand" for general disarmament.
TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 18-- United Nations forces drove yesterday within rifle shot of Kumsong, Communist supply center in central Korea, without meeting strong opposition.

A committee of 100 business, financial and labor leaders was organized yesterday to assume responsibility for the financial and business activities of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A.

Although Mme. Schiaparelli has made the word "shocking" famous in perfume, when she turns her de signing talents to lingerie, she uses taste and discretion in the couturier manner. The first New York showing of her lingerie collection was held yesterday at Lord Taylor, where it is available for sale.

Acting Mayor Joseph T. Sharkey, Democratic candidate for President of the City Council, announced last night he had resigned his $7,500-a-year job as salesman for the General Builders Supply Corporation.

SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass., Oct. 17 Bad luck has been dogging the trail of the St. Mark's School football team this year. The result is that the Blue and White finds itself without a victory after three games and with prospects for the future but little brighter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 General MacArthur sharpened an acute political issue by his statement to the American Legion convention at Miami today that his call of March 24 on the North Korean commander to meet him in the field "to arrange armistice terms unquestionably wrecked the secret plan" to obtain peace in...
TRENTON, Oct. 17 Samuel P. Allcorn Jr. of Montclair was named tonight as a special prosecutor to investigate crime conditions in Atlantic County.

BERLIN, Oct. 17 (UP) Gerhart Eisler, East German propaganda chief, admitted today that the Communist campaign for the unification of Germany was designed to sabotage the Western Allied plans to incorporate West Germany into a Western defense program.

A minimum salary of $3,200 to attract trained personnel for the nation's public schools was recommended yesterday by Dr. Willard E. Givens, executive secretary of the National Education Association, at the twentieth annual meeting of the Save the Children Federation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Administration supporters in the Senate were told by a member of the Appropriations Committee today that they would be wise to accept the 5 per cent cut in foreign aid funds recommended by the committee yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 17 The United Nations received today two new plans for settling the status of South-West Africa a problem that has been before the world organization for the last six years.

The New York City Anti-Crime Committee, a private organization headed by Spruille Braden, made public yesterday a letter to Presiding Justice Gerald Nolan of the Appellate Division, Second Department, asking him to consider "the prompt removal from the bench" of Magistrate J. Roland Sala.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 17 The annual convention of India's National Congress party began here today with moving references to Liaquat Ali Khan, Prime Min ister of Pakistan, who was assassinated yesterday.
Dr. Hugo Newman, former Assistant Superintendent of Schools and last principal of the former New York Training School for Teachers, died Tuesday in his home at 390 Riverside Drive at the age of 84.

LONDON, Oct. 17 If the voters return Winston Churchill as Prime Minister of Britain next week he plans to request the United States and France to join in the swift establishment of a three-power strategic committee that would supervise the interests of the democratic powers on a global basis.

Embarrassed by an invitation to send delegates to an international goodwill conference in Yugoslavia next week, the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations have decided that the kindest thing they can do from Marshal Tito's viewpoint is to stay home.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 17 Gen. J. Lawton Collins, United States Army Chief of Staff, has completed his mission to Yugoslavia and left this afternoon for Ljubljana, the capital of Slovenia, where he will spend the night before going to the Near East.

Overweight and what should be done about reducing were discussed with considerable controversy yesterday at the fall meeting of the Food and Nutrition Division of the Health Council of Greater New York.

The artistry of which Martial Singher is capable was shown to a Town Hall audience last night in the first of three concerts that the eminent French baritone is giving. Mr. Singher is devoting himself, so his prospectus reads, to "great cycles of song literature."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) The Treasury announced tonight it has accepted offers to buy $1,250,958,000 in its newest type of securities called tax anticipation bills.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined 703,000 barrels, according to the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 112,000,000 barrels, compared with 112,703,000 a week earlier and 103,807,000 a year ago.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 17--The extreme Left-Wing leaders of Indonesia have been dealt a severe blow by the recent wide-scale arrests of suspected subversive elements, Premier Dr. Sukiman Wirjosanpopo said in an interview today.

Many parties were given at the annual luncheon and fashion show in behalf of the American Women's Voluntary Services held yesterday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Ogden L. Mills, honorary president of the organi zation and chairman of the luncheon committee, and Mrs. C. Ruxton Love, active president, spoke briefly of the organization's program for the coming year.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Thursday, Oct. 18 (AP) Flame-throwing troopers of the United States First Cavalry Division today smashed the main Chinese Red resistance on the western Korean front.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today a volunteer program to curb flationary loans "has confounded the cynics and those who sneer at self-regulation."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and closed 24 to 37 points net lower on active months.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) Senator Thomas R. Underwood, Democrat of Kentucky, denounced in the Senate today the criticisms last week of Vice President Alben W. Barkley by Senator Harry P. Cain, Republican of Washington.

Two safe deposit boxes in a Wall Street bank were disclosed yesterday as the hiding place for $14,000 worth of opium, morphine, hashish and marijuana that had been left there for safekeeping by two seamen arrested for illegal possession of narcotics.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 17 (AP) A football game between Florida State University and Bradley University was canceled today because the Peoria, Ill., team had several Negro players on the squad.
DETROIT, Oct. 17 (AP) Herold (Muddy) Ruel took over today as farm director of the Detroit Baseball Club in the third Tiger front office shake-up in three months.
Not quite satisfied with some of their blocking against the Cardinals Sunday, Coach Steve Owen had the pads on his football Giants yesterday in a two-andone-half hour workout at the Polo Grounds.
HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 17 The average unit sale in the nation's retail drug stores throughout the year is about '50 cents, the National Wholesale Druggists Association was told here today.

LONDON, Oct. 17-- Counterattacking against complaints that the Labor Government had mishandled Britain's disputes with Iran and Egypt, Foreign Secretary Herbert Morrison told the nation tonight he dreaded to think what would happen to Britain's relations with Asia if Winston Churchill ever again were allowed to speak for this country.
Lack of buying power allowed the stock market to sink yesterday despite a fresh spurt in the oil division. Fractional losses ruled through most of the list and the composite rate fell 0.62 point.

A new method of producing wool-like characteristics in cotton fabric in the dye process was described yesterday by Dr. John D. Guthrie of the Southern Regional Research Laboratory, United States Department of Agriculture. Dr. Guthrie spoke at the opening of the thirtieth annual convention of the American Association of Textile Chemists and Colorists at the Statler Hotel.
LONDON, Oct. 17 Showing no signs of strain, Prime Minister Attlee returned here today after a nine-day whistle-stop election tour that has taken him around much of the country.

Steelmaking plants in Pennsylvania added nearly 2,400,000 tons to their annual capacity from 1948 to the start of this year and thereby retained for Pennsylvania its wide margin as the leading steel state, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. At the beginning of this year, the annual capacity of that state's steel plants totaled 30,000,000 tons of the nation's 104,200,000-ton capacity.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 17 George F. Mitchell, president of the People's Gas and Coke Company, Chicago, was elected president of the American Gas Association today. He succeeds D.A. Huley of Dallas, president of the Lone Star Gas Company. This organization's three-day annual convention, attended by 2,000 delegates, closed today.

The big game season is now open in North Carolina, and according to our marsh country correspondent, Axson Smith of Belhaven, the deer and bear are both plentiful and active, and should provide a mixed bag for those who will arrive later for the duck and goose shooting.

CAIRO, Oct. 17 British forces in the Suez Canal zone proceeded today to occupy various lines of communication, including the only bridge over the canal and bridges on the Port Tewfik-Suez road. Forces at Adabya, British military port south of the city of Suez, were strengthened.

The Iranian oil dispute has done something no other dispute in the history of the United Nations has been able to do. It has established the principle of total loss. It has proved what has heretofore been in doubt; namely; that it is possible to have an argument in the United Nations in which everybody loses, including the large powers, the small powers, and the United Nations itself.

"We are not disturbed by this wild story that the Polo Grounds will be sold and that the Giants will become tenants of the Yankee Stadium," said Edgar J. Feeley, treasurer and attorney for The National Exhibition Company (the Giants), yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 A move to permit wage increases based on "more efficient production" has been started in the Wage Stabilization Board by a labor member, Elmer Walker of the International Association of Machinists, A.F.L.
Sanitation workers suspended for engaging in a slowdown or "sick strike" spurned yesterday the offer by Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain permitting them to return this morning and voted to remain out.
REGINA, Sask., Oct. 17 Even the Canadian "Mounties," traditionally dauntless as they mush across trackless wastes, were so nearly frozen today that their teeth chattered from the cold.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, told a Senate subcommittee today he had new evidence showing that "a personal spy on Senator McCarthy's payroll" was an "admitted homosexual ex-Communist."

NORWALK, Conn., Oct 17 (AP) Frederick Bezner, 73 years old, who made a fortune in the automobile and aircraft industries, died today in Norwalk Hospital of the effects of exposure. He was found last night lyinng on a beach in near-by Darien after a search by the police with bloodhounds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17-- Delivery to Congress by Jan. 3 of a detailed program for a maximum expansion of the role of atomic energy in the defense of the United States was requested of the Atomic Energy Commission and the Department of Defense today.
"The Mob" moved into town yesterday. They're using the Paramount as a hangout. But they won't get far. Broderick Craw

EDNA ST. VINCENT MILLAY who was, as truly as Scott Fitzgerald, a laureate of an age of promise died a year ago to morrow at Austerlitz, in the Berkshires. Now Vincent Sheean, a man with a Celtic capacity for wonder and worship, has written a book about her, an elegy in blue, that is a tribute to her love of song and flight. It is a very personal

A resolution introduced in the City Council calls for the demolition of some seventy bulky structures that for nearly half a century have been looked upon as New York landmarks our subway kiosks. In general, these old structres mark the route of New...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17-- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 10, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 17 America's druggists urged today to "roll up their sleeves" and take the lead in getting an airtight Fair Trade Law back on the books. Three of the principal speakers at today's session of the convention of the National Association of Retail Druggists hammered away at the importance of this task.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17-- Witnesses from coast to coast protested in hearings before a House Education and Labor subcommittee against the National Production Authority's policy of refusing steel priorities to urgently needed school construction.

George Hamill Jr. has been appointed sales manager of the Magna-Crest Corporation, distributor for Thermo-Fax, the new one-step dry proces, instantaneous reproducing machine and paper, products of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 President Truman came to the aid of Senator Robert A. Taft today to remove a possibly embarrassing charge from the Ohioan's campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1952.
ALBANY, Oct. 17 (AP) Governor Dewey called today for "stern action by municipal authorities" to reduce the smoke nuisance in New York City and other areas.

John M. Schiff's Triomphe won the New York Turf Writers Cup, the hurdle race of about two miles that featured the opening day of the United Hunts Racing Association's two-day meeting at Belmont Park yesterday. A 4-year-old filly bred in France, Triomphe was guided to a two and a half-length triumph by Pat Smithwick over Mrs. G.H. Bostwick's Hyvania. James F. McHugh's Snob Tourist was third, a half-length behind Hyvania.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Oct. 18 The State Department disclosed this morning a new "serious attempt" by the United States to gain the Soviet Union's cooperation in breaking the deadlock in armistice negotiations in Korea as a prelude to relaxing the present tense situation between East and West.

The proposed $12,500,000 Morningside-Manhattanville slum clearance housing for Manhattan's upper West Side was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission at City Hall. The project originated with the city's Committee on Slum Clearance Plans, of which Robert Moses is chairman.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 18 The United Nations liaison officers attempted today to reach a compromise with the Communists on the disputed question of a neutral safety zone around the proposed new site at Panmunjom for resumed negotiations on an armistice in the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The State Department issued tonight the following statement and the texts of an exchange of messages between Ambassador Alan G. Kirk and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky:

Universal Military Training, if enacted by Congress, should be in tended as a temporary emergency measure rather than as a permanent program of conscription, delegates to the fifty-fourth annual convention of the New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 A house investigating subcommittee has subpoenaed a number of Internal Revenue agents of New it regards as their unsatisfactory response to requests for information about their income and for other financial data. Two or three of them already have tried to resign...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 A new policy covering future accelerated tax amortization certificates for projects directly connected with defense production will be announced today by Charles E. Wilson, head of the Office of Defense Mobilization. Mr. Wilson's statement is timed to coincide with the expiration of the sixty-day moratorium on tax grants which he ordered on Aug. 18.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Defense spokesmen in the Pentagon said today that the establishment of foolproof procedures to prevent violations of the truce zone in Korea by United Nations pilots was entirely the responsibility of the United Nations commander, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17-- Pennsylvania has lost its top tailback and best passer, Glenn (Bones) Adams, for the game with Columbia here Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Two charges that the State Department was "lacking in cooperation" in the enforcement of the McCarran Internal Security Act were made by Senators today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 17 Richard Widmark and Marilyn Monroe today were named by Twentieth Century-Fox to co-star in "Night Without Sleep," a suspense drama. It deals with the activities of a madman loose in a big hotel and the experiences of a baby sitter in protecting her charge against harm.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 The grain market turned reactionary today, although there was no special change in the news features which had prompted recent buying activities. Profit-taking was heavy, however, and shorts appear to have covered freely on recent upturns, ...
A richness of color and diversity of design distinguishes a new collection of thirty patterns for handscreened wallpapers and fabrics now on view at the Jackson Ellis Company, 538 Madison Avenue.

The Senate report on "Ethical Standards in Government" goes to the heart of one of the deep and vexing problems of our democracy, The greatest internal enemy of our form of government is a collapse of moral standards, a subversion of the public welfare in the interest of private gain, a disregard of the ordinary rules of justice and decency, a connivance (or even participation) in corruption.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UP)-- Representative Franck Havenner, Democrat of California, said today he had made "vigorous representations" to Federal agencies against delayed allocations of steel for five ships to be built in a San Francisco yard.

PARIS, Oct, 17 France's fundamental problem is her balance of payments rather than her need for military aid, according to Rene Mayer, Vice Premier, who also is in charge of financial and economic affairs. He declared today that France could make a more effective effort for defense if her economic machinery were kept working.

Three young men who refused to be inducted into the armed forces each received the maximum sentence of five years yesterday from Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman for violation of the Selective Service Act of 1948.

I COULD not admire the arrangements which had been made for my reception after landing in Teheran. The British Minister met me in his car, and we drove from the airfield to our Legation. As we approached the city the road was lined with Persian cavalrymen every fifty yards, for at least three miles.

After long consideration, the council of Actors Equity Association decided during a meeting held on Tuesday to turn down recommendations made to thwart employers and agents who utilize the loyalty blacklist against performers in various phases of the amusement industry.

LAS VEGAS, Nov., Oct. 17 A collision between conflicting Federal policies on information has turned security precautions on the coming Nevada atomic test explosions into a somewhat comic but prospectively serious muddle.
Leslie T. Harris has been made director of radio and television for the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company. He has been national program director for the radio network of National Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The first major gift of books for the projected Harry S. Truman Library at Grandview, Mo., about 240 volumes of the Scriptures in 120 languages and dialects, was presented to the President today by officers of the American Bible Society.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17(AP) The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption from Sept. 2 to 29 averaged 37,026 bales for each working day. This compared with an average of 39,574 bales for the corresponding period a year ago and with 37,706 for the August period this year.

The Cherry Malotte Handicap, a steeplechase of about two miles, was won by Mrs. C.M. Paterno's Errolford. Third choice in the field of five, Errolford raced evenly under a fine ride by Frank Adams, and defeated the favored Tellanrun by a length.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Manhattan Borough President, declaring that the city is not providing all necessary services and facilities, called yesterday for economy and the incorporation of the best management procedures in conducting the city's affairs.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 17 Manly Fleischmann, Defense Production Administrator, said here today that in the months ahead not enough copper and aluminum will be available to make more than a token delivery to the least essential producers of civilian goods.

The silver jubilee convention of the Propeller Club of the United States opened yesterday, dimmed somewhat by two adverse situations that arose earlier this week. The three-day convention, which runs in conjunction with the American Merchant Marine Conference under the club's sponsorship, is being held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
TODAY, 4 P.M.: "Ginger Pye" will be recorded as it is told at the Brooklyn Public Library's Brownsville Branch. Glenmore Avenue and Watkins Street.

With troubles rising for the West all along the southern periphery of the sprawling Soviet empire, from Suez to Korea, the Soviets are now seeking to create another trouble spot to the north. In a formal note they have charged Norway with violating the...

The special migration conference which has just ended a fortnight's deliberations in Naples under the aegis of the International Labor Office has proved disappointing. Instead of dealing boldly and imaginatively with the explosive problem of surplus population the meeting set up a "temporary consultative council" to advise Governments and help stimulate European migration by international action.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 17 Governor General Khwaja Nazimuddin assumed the leadership of this grief-stricken nation today as the capital paid final homage to the assassinated Prime...

Navy Gun, running in the colors of Lawrence W. Jennings, won the Temple Gwathmey, the steeplechase handicap event that served yesterday as the feature event on the closing day of the United Hunts Racing Association two-day meeting at Belmont Park.

Wolf-Ferrari's "I quattri rusteghi," or "The Four Ruffians," according to the English version of the Italian title of the opera, had its American premiere last night at the New York City Opera Company to the delight of everyone present.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (U.P.) Heartly (Hunk) Anderson said tonight he had been offered the job of head coach of the Washington Redskins pro football team and had accepted it, but that the Chicago Bears were blocking him from taking the job.
Spring fabrics will have a profile and a silhouette, according to a report and display arranged for the Fashion Group, Inc., at a luncheon meeting is the Astor Hotel yesterday.

ALTOONA, Pa., Oct 18 Benjamin A. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, attacked today the contentions of the "Calamity Johns" of the country who espouse the theory that "big business grows only by crushing small business."

Presiding Justice Gerald Nolan of the Appellate Division, Second Department, said yesterday that he would submit to the entire membership of his court the complaint filed with him on Wednesday by the New York City Anti-Crime Committee against the conduct on the bench of City Magistrate J. Roland Sala.

Ill with a virus infection that caused cancellation of his engagements until Monday, Rudolph Halley, Liberal-Independent-City Fusion candidate for President of the City Council, denounced yesterday the five questions asked him by Acting Mayor Joseph T. Sharkey,...

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 18 Anne Baxter and Dale Robertson today were cast by Twentieth Century-Fox in the starring roles of "The Outcasts of Poker Flat," which will be based on Bret Harte's short story of the same title.

THE formal conferences [at Teheran] were interspersed with what may be thought to be even more important talks between Roosevelt, Stalin, and myself at luncheons and dinners. Here there were very few things that could not be said and received in good-humour. On Sunday night the 28th [of November, 1943] Stalin was our host for dinner. We were a party of nine or ten, including the interpreters, and conversation soon became general and serious.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18 There will be three changes in the Yale defensive line Saturday when the Elis square off in the Bowl against a Cornell eleven that Herman Hickman says may be one of the great football teams of the country.
The Players, comfortable old Gramercy Park club of generations of actors and artists, was robbed of $800 yesterday morning by three well-dressed young men.

GROTON, Mass., Oct. 18 Last year the Groton School eleven swept through a seven-game schedule. The Red, White and Black not only emerged with an unbeaten and untied record, but also accounted for the most points made by a Groton team since varsity football was begun here in 1884.

With Joe Scott and Forrest Griffith, who had been hampered by minor leg injuries, running at full speed again, the New York Football Giants yesterday took measures to step up their attack for Sunday's contest with the Philadelphia Eagles at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 A regulation giving extra wage increases to workers whose pay is out of line with that of others in comparable jobs in an industry or area was issued today by the Wage Stabilization Board.

An enthusiastic audience that overflowed the ballroom of the Plaza Hotel yesterday viewed the sixth and final designer luncheon show given by Saks Fifth Avenue. Topping off its fall season, Saks selected forty-four designs from the New York collection of Christian Dior.

Four Dodgers, three Giants and one player each from the Phillies, Pirates and Cardinals make up the annual United Press National League All-Star Team, announced yesterday after its selection by twenty-four veteran baseball writers--three from each city.

Although not a exactly in the same news definition category as man bites dog, a Detroit report on what employes of a packing house are doing to help a financially embarrassed company was sufficiently important to merit Page 1 in this newspaper yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 18 Mrs. Roy F. Layton of Chevy Chase, Md., was elected today president of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America for a two-year term. She will succeed Mrs. C. Vaughan Ferguson of Schenectady, N.Y., who was elected honorary vice president.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today that "reckless and heedless" attacks on the State Department were destroying public confidence in "the whole structure of government."
Aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange as of the close of business on Oct. 15 last was 2,651,473 shares, a gain of only 13,287 shares over the Sept. 15 figure of 2,638,186 shares.

The Rockefeller Foundation announced yesterday it had made grants of $844,000 in the third quarter of 1951. The largest was $275,000 to the National Research Foundation at Washington for post-doctoral fellowships to be awarded over the three-year period beginning in 1952.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. The grain list developed great strength today, reversing its late trend of yesterday, and registered substantial gains for the day. Buying influences were the continued unfavorable weather in western Canada, where more snow fell in all...

Chickens and large turkeys are cheaper this week-end, with declines, of 2 cents a pound tagging fryers at 43, roasters 53 and large turkeys 59 cents. Heavy supplies, more than ample for current demand, brought the welcome markdown, reports the city Department of Markets.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18-- The finest of French art in an eightcentury span, from 1100 to 1900, was placed on display in the Carnegie Institute here tonight after the fifty-fifth annual Founder's Day program in Cargenie Music Hall.

NEW ROCHELLE, Oct. 18-- Detailed engineering plans for the first three mites of the New England Thruway, known as the Yankee Thruway, in this state are 75 per cent complete and the first contract will be awarded soon, Robert Wesley Briggs, designing engineer, reported this afternoon.
GLENDALE, Calif., Oct. 18 (U.P.) The boss of the Yankees' boss said today that Casey Stengel would be back on the job next season with her blessing.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 18 The United States would be willing to endorse a program toward the reunification of Germany it the Communist-controlled Government in East Germany accepted proposals for free elections made by Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor.

The maritime industry yesterday "took off the gloves" and, using the medium of the Propeller Club of the United States, challenged curtailment of steel allocations for shipbuilding, which has already resulted in the suspension of 40 per cent of the Government's major shipbuilding program.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed steady and 9 to 18 points net higher than on Wednesday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 18 One hundred and fifty persons from eighteen countries will attend the three-day anti-Cominform peace congress that will open in Zagreb, the capital of Croatia, on Oct. 23. The delegates represent every shade of political opinion, from anti-Cominform Marxism, to North African anti-colonial nationalism.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 18-- The Western Allies will announce officially soon their intention of liquidating the International Authority for the Ruhr, and the Coal and Steel Control Boards and of eliminating specific limitations on German industrial production.

The directors of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association have approved the poster and program submitted by the National Valentine's Day Council with a statement that it expects sales of all kinds of merchandise for Feb. 14...

Continued expansion of trade among free nations, particularly through consistent policy and leadership by this country, was urged at an international-trade panel held yesterday at the annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States.

The stock market continued yesterday to sink into lower territory. Prices wavered through most of the session although a stiffening in the tobacco and textile issues in the closing hour gave final quotations a better appearance than in the earlier trading.

In their ceaseless search for something new to be learned about, the embryo Ph. Dees may have overlooked a really good subject for a doctoral thesis: "The Cantaloupe and Its History: Does It Have One?" The answer, as accurate in one word as in a hundred thousand, is, Yes. Quite!
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 18 (AP) Thomas A. Sears' Ocean Breeze won by a length in the Fort Meade Purse here today.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 18 Establishment here of an advanced electronics center, believed to be the first of its kind in the country, was announced jointly today by the General Electric Company and Cornell University.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 18 (AP) The world series melon was cut today and, while the Yankees got the most money, it was the losing Giants who set a financial record in the 1951 classic.

UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., Oct. 18 A shift in Yugoslav policy on the British-Iranian oil dispute appeared tonight to have blocked the United Nations Security Council from taking any immediate action in the case.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 18 Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland, a Republican, today called "the smear technique," "the big lie" and "the sly innuendo" the greatest threats to personal freedom in the United States. His address opened the annual convention of the Maryland State Teachers Association.

Although no figures were released, "The Mob" played to the second biggest opening day of the year at the Paramount on Wednesday, it was reported by the management yesterday. The year's opening day attendance mark was set in July during the personal appearance stand of Dean Martin and...

In Washington this week the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy asked the Atomic Energy Commission and the Defense Department to furnish data for an expanded atomic program, including "the specific extent and type of new facilities estimated to be required."

Sheets of music, theatre programs, hunting horns, a miniature model house and cameras on tripods are some of the items, not usually associated with dining, used in a new group of table settings that went on display yesterday at Lord Taylor.

Miss Barbara Lewisohn, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Lewisohn of 1155 Park Avenue, was married yesterday afternoon to Sten Heyman, son of Prof. James Heyman of Stockholm, Sweden, and the late Mrs. Heyman, in Sherry's by Surrogate George Frankenthaler.

Garry Moore, who is the daytime delight of the housewives tuned to the Columbia Broadcasting System television network, began a new video series last night at 8 o'clock over Channel 2. It's the first time he's been out at night in quite some time; he has confined his recent TV activities to an early afternoon program, which still continues.

Consolidated earnings of United paramount Theatres, Inc., for the nine months ended with September are estimated at $9,537,000, compared with $7,963,000 for the 1950 period, Leonard H. Goldenson, president, reported in the statement for release today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The Senate passed the $7,208,401,400 foreign aid appropriation bill today and sent it to conference with the House of Representatives for negotiation of differences.

It's Vic Raschi's turn today, and Mickey Mantle's tomorrow, as members of the world champion Yankees continue to file to Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore for medical check-ups by Dr. George Bennett.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The date for the resignation of Eric Johnston, head of the Economic Stabilization Agency, was reported today to have been set for Nov.15.
There is one record in the Columbia football book that is not pleasing to Coach Lou Little. In the last eleven games against Pennsylvania, the Lions have been beaten.

Designed to focus attention on United Nations Day next Wednesday is the publication this week of "The World's Favorite Recipes" (Harper's, $1.) More than 100 recipes from member countries of the United Nations are included in the paper-bound book.

William C. McTarnahan of 530 Park Avenue, honorary chairman of the board of the Petroleum Heat and Power Company, died yesterday in Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He would have been 69 years old on Dec. 26.
Stevedore strike developments had some coffee roasters in difficulties yesterday, but reports from Brazil were considered hopeful by the futures market on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 Despite the Sovtet Union's rebuff to the United States appeal for cooperation in ending the Korean truce stalemate, hope was still alive here today for a possible Big Four session on East-West tensions some time during the United Nations General Assembly meeting in Paris beginning next month.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 18 Research and experiment have freed America from the specter of an oil shortage "for centuries to come," Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Department of the Interior, told representatives of the nation's druggists here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 President Truman signed today the biggest peacetime military money bill of record.

The Court of Appeals in Albany yesterday unanimously invalidated a criminal information filed by District Attorney Miles F. MCDonald of Brooklyn accusing, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh of neglect of duty while Commissioner of Investigation.
Apartment buildings were bought and sold by operators in the Bronx real estate transactions reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18-- Senate-House conferees agreed today on a slightly revised tax-increase bill that would produce an estimated $5,691,000,000 in new annual revenue, and the Senate promptly approved it by voice vote.

ROME, Oct. 18 An offer of Italian good offices to mediate a solution of the current AngloEgyptian controversy over the Suez Canal and the Sudan was made this afternoon in the Senate by Premier Alcide De Gasperi.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 President Truman asserted today that there was no basis in fact for General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's assertion before the American Legion convention yesterday that the general had "unquestionably wrecked" a secret plan to hand over Formosa and a seat in the United Nations to the Chinese Communists.

Taxes took a heavy toll of the earnings of the General Electric Company in the first nine months of this year, reducing the net profit 24 per cent to $85,936,435 from the $112,919,454 earned in the corresponding period of 1950.
MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 18 Albert Lawrence Rohrer, retired advisory engineer of the General Electric Company, died today in his home here at the age of 95.

In a draw-curtained dressing room beside the stage in a small basement auditorium at Goldwater Memorial Hospital yesterday, a very low voice was heard to say, "Damn it, I am about to cry. Some of those little kids..."
MUNSAN, Korea, Friday, Oct. 19 The Communists accepted today a United Nations compromise proposal for security zones of a radius three miles around Munsan and Kaesong. The Communist

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) The Senate adopted and sent to the White House late today a joint resolution ending the state of war with Germany. Passage was by voice vote. It had received House approval last July.

Joe Baksi of Kulpmont, Pa., once rated among the leading contenders for the world heavyweight title, will launch a comeback bid tonight. He will face Gino Buonvino of Bari, Italy, in the ten-round feature at St. Nicholas Arena.

ROME, Oct. 18 The North Atlantic pact forces in the Mediterranean have reached so high a degree of training and coordination that they are now in a position to cope with any naval and air threat from potentially hostile powers, according to Admiral Robert B. Carney, Commander in Chief of the Atlantic forces in the area.

Ground action on the Korean battlefront quieted down somewhat. United Nations Command elements conducted mopping up operations and clearing of enemy held bunkers after friendly airstrikes on the western front.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 18 Pudgy and jolly, and looking something like a genial medieval friar in his long black Moslem coat, Khwaja Nazimuddin brings a special personality to the Prime Ministership of Pakistan.

A rival American Federation of Labor union in the Sanitation Department attacked yesterday the organization sponsoring the slowdown and "sick strike" and advised the men to "join a real union one that has never let you down."
The Soviet standard of living has improved markedly in recent years but still remains very low, substantially behind that of Western Europe or the United States.

There was a fin-du-sicle tint to the music in Carnegie Hall last night when the Philharmonic-Symphony began the second week of its season. The selections were by Erik Satie, Karol Szymanowski and Gustav Mahler.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) President Truman nominated Richard Hartshorne, Republican, for a New Jersey Federal judgeship because Representative Edward J. Hart, Democrat of New Jersey, refused the post, an informed source said today.

The latest exchange of views between Moscow and Washington has produced a mixed reaction throughout the world. The State Department is, of course, right in regarding the new Soviet note primarily as another propaganda blast,

Negotiated financing affecting the Pacific Gas and Electric Company and the defendant investment banking concern of Blyth Co., Inc., figured in Government evidence submitted yesterday in the anti-trust suit in Federal Court here.

MIAMI, Oct. 18 A demand for the "immediate removal of the present corps of leaders" in the State Department on the ground that their actions had "reflected incompetency, indecision and defeatism" was overwhelmingly approved today by delegates to the American Legion's thirty-third annual convention.

RUSHVILLE, Ind., Oct. 18 (AP) Paul G. Hoffman, director of the Ford Foundation, warned tonight that America's birthright of freedom and justice was in "enormous danger" unless every man was free to speak his mind on every issue.

LONDON, Oct.18 It is unlikely that a Churchill Government would promote a foreign policy in Europe or the Western world differing in any essential way from that pursued by the Labor administration at the present moment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 Mrs. Nazli Tlabar, a member of the Parliament of Turkey who says that her main interest is "real politics," reported that she had been amazed to find herself the only woman at the luncheon for Senator Robert A. Taft earlier this Week at the National Press Club.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 18 (U.P.) Elpidio Gonzalez, former Vice President of Argentina, died today at the age of 76.

Defense counsel for Benedicto Macri yesterday gained admission from a prosecution witness in the William Lurye murder trial that while in police custody as a material witness two years ago he received a weekly salary as a bookmaking aide to Harry Gross.
The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, with neighboring chapters, fulfilled last year every request for whole blood for Korea, it was announced yesterday at the forty-fifth annual meeting.

Metal identification tags were distributed yesterday to 200,000 second and third grade pupils in the city's public, private and parochial schools. Designed as a civil defense measure in case of enemy attack, the disks are similar to the "dog tags" worn by members of the armed forces.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct.18 Richand L. White of Lander's, Frary and Clark, New Britain, Conn., was elected president of the American Hardware Manufacturers Association at the closing session of the 101st semi-annual convention here...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee refused by vote of 3 to 2 today to approve the nomination of Ambassador at Large Philip C. Jessup to serve on this country's delegation to the United Nations.
STOCKHOLM, Oct. 18 Dr. Max Theiler of the International Health Division of the Rookefeller Foundation of New York, was named tonight as this year's Nobel Prize winner for physiology and medicine.

YONKERS, Oct. 18 Pronto Don, to the surprise of no one, romped home first in the Gotham Trot, the $25,000 mile-and-a-half test at Yonkers Raceway tonight. Sent off flat 1 to 5, the consistent 6-year-old chestnut gelding from the Hayes Fair Acres Stable of DuQuoin, Ill., triumphed by half a length over J.J. Purcell's Darn Flashy in 3:12 1-5.

THIS is like stepping into a room after a long absence and finding everything untidy, the joint in a complete mess. Debris from shattered hopes and remnants from once bright dreams litter the football scene. LEEDS, England, Oct. 18 Both Laborites and Conservatives are watching Yorkshire with anxious concern hoping that before long there will be some indication of how its people will vote on election day, Oct. 25.

Senator Robert A. Taft urged yesterday a complete reappraisal of American foreign policy, which he said had cost the United States the peace after it had won the war. He suggested the revaluation be made by a new joint militarycivilian commission.
Expanding credit requirements of non-defense industries were the major influence in pushing business loan totals of New York City banks $92,000,000 higher last week.

ALBANY, Oct. 18-- The Court of Appeals upheld today the right of the State Board of Regents to ban showing of the Italian motion picture "The Miracle" on the ground that it was sacrilegious. The vote was 5 to 2.

PARIS, Oct. 18 The European Marshall Plan Council approved tonight the proposals of the managing board of the European Payments Union for dealing within the next three months with Belgian surplus in relation to the union. Such is the technical designation employed to describe a problem that might also be called that of the trade deficits of the British and French resulting from their rearmament emmort.

Admiral Alan G. Kirk, United States Ambassador to Moscow, warned last night this country must have "actual strength in being, not potential," to make its voice listened to by the Russians. "We cannot negotiate with the Soviets when we are weak," he told the seventh annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A collection of old maps of considerable historical as well as decoration value, one of which concerns plans for the Revolutionary Battle on the "Woody Heights of Long Island, Between Flatbush and Brooklyn, "will go on sale Monday at Altman's.
The Indonesian Merchant Marine has acquired its second large vessel for carrying passengers around the 3,000-mile islandstrewn chain that comprises the young republic.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 A tightening of rules under which tax amortization certificates will be granted for defense projects in the future was announced today by the Defense Production Administration.

In a broad program for eliminating smoke from all thirty-three of the city's municipal hospitals, the Department of Hospitals will soon begin drafting plans for installing new incinerators throughout its institutions, Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday.
Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan raked his department yesterday from the inspector to patrolman levels in the first big shake-up since he moved from the Fire to the Police Department last July.

ABADAN, Iran, Oct. 17 Travelers to southern Iran may on consecutive days visit two sites that stir emotions with almost equal force the ruins of monuments erected at Persepolis by the Achaemenid Kings of Persia long ago and the giant Abadan refinery lately abandoned by the British who built it.
The loss of specialized personnel in the Department of Health con tinued unchecked yesterday with the resignation of one of the agency's highest ranking officials.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 18 The prestige of the United Nations has suffered considerably because of its nonrecognition of Communist China, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today.

The question of the competence of the Security Council to take action in the Iranian oil dispute is an issue of considerable importance and it must be settled today. Warren Austin, the American delegate, was in a strong position on Wednesday when he upheld the Council's right to deal with the matter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The scarcity of scrap metal for use by the nation's defense program has reached the proportions of a national emergency, Manly Fleischmann, head of the Defense Production Administration, said today in announcing appointment of a special assistant to take charge of all salvage operations for defense production.

NEWARK, Oct. 18 Resolute purpose, unity in the face of peril and "decent respect for the opinions of mankind" made possible the realization of the Japanese peace treaty, and related Pacific security pacts, Ambassador at Large John Foster Dulles said tonight.

Formation of an industry-wide promotion council for man-made textile fibers was urged yesterday by Spencer Love, chairman of the board of Burlington Mills Corpo-ration. Such a body, which would include yarn producers, weavers,...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (U.P.) Chairman Emanuel Celler said today his House Subcommittee on Monoply, which is investigating baseball, had "no intention" of proposing Federal policing of the game, regardless of ousted Baseball Commissioner Albert B. (Happy) Chandler's views on the subject.

HONG KONG, Oct. 18 The twists and turns of the Chinese Communists in the protracted Korean truce talks are being studied here against the background of a blunt speech by Gen. Yeh Chien-ying, former Army Chief of Staff, who told a meeting of "people's representatives" in Canton last month that time was on the side of Peiping.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 The special grand jury investigating graft in Philadelphia reported today in an interim presentment that it had evidence of an illicit tie-up between racketeers and some public officials, police officers and politicians.

OLNEY, Ill., Oct. 18 Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, asserted today at the dedication of this area as the geographical center of this country's population that the center would always remain in Illinois.
India and Pakistan were appealed to yesterday to end their five-year-old dispute over control of Kashmir and thereby give the world a "desperately needed example of international cooperation."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 During, the week ended Oct. 17, member bank reserves increased $129,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
William B. Herlands, special prosecutor for crime and corruption on Staten Island, announced yesterday that his principal headquarters would be set up on Monday at 270 Broadway.
