"That's nothing." said John. "A lot of people in my business think just that." His business is advertising; but the satirical...

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 18-- A report has been made to the British Admiralty and Foreign Office of an allegation by Capt. Leonard Gow that his ship, the 3,500-ton Berylstone, was subjected to a bombing attack off the Soviet port of Archangel, in the White Sea.

WASHINGTON, Oct.18 Joseph Alsop, newspaper columnist, testified today that former Vice President Henry A. Wallace had struck the Communists "the heaviest blow possible" in 1944 when he recommended the removal of Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell as China commander.

The reaction in New Delhi to the assassination of the Pakistani Prime Minister is what would be expected from sensitive and thoughtful persons. Prime Minister Nehru, we are sure, voiced the sentiment of his whole people in his expressions of shock and sorrow.

The Centennial of THE NEW YORK TIMES was marked yesterday by the Overseas Press Club of America at a luncheon at Toots Shor's restaurant, 51 West Fiftyfirst Street. Meyer Berger, Pulitzer Prize-winning member of THE TIMES staff and author of "The Story of The New York Times," was the guest of honor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18-- Though Chester Bowles of Connecticut and Philip Jessup of New York have had trouble getting confirmed by the Senate in recent days, most observers here believe that confirmation can be achieved by paying attention to a few simple rules.
MONTREAL, Oct. 18 (U.P.) The Canadiens held off the determined New York Rangers tonight to gain a 3-2 National Hockey League victory before 14,233 fans at the Forum.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 18-- William H. Foster, chairman of the board of the General Fireproofing Company and a national industrial figure, died here today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. David B. Carson, wife of a Sharon Steel Company vice president. He had suffered a heart attack a few hours earlier. His age was 85.

The City Planning Commission's proposed 1952 capital budget of $527,283,767, largest in the city's history, was attacked yesterday as inflationary, unrealistic and based upon unsound estimates of construction costs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 John B. Dunlap, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, announced late today the suspension of Mordecai Miller, an Internal Revenue agent at New York, for refusing to disclose the extent of his wealth to investigators of the House of Representatives.

PLYMOUTH, England, Oct. 18 Side by side on the same platform in Plymouth tonight sat the "bogey man" and the "bogey boy" of British politics. That is what Jill Craigie called them and she added: "I love them I love them both."
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 Dr. Lawrence A. Kimpton was inducted as chancellor of the University of Chicago today. He is the sixth administration head of the sixtyyear-old university.

CAIRO, Oct. 18 British forces in the Suez Canal zone were withdrawing today from some of the installations they seized from the Egyptians yesterday and Tuesday, and were negotiating withdrawals from other occupied points.
Acting Mayor Joseph T. Sharkey sought yesterday to end the crippling four-day-old wildcat longshoremen's strike as it assumed a semi-official aspect.

An uncertain future faces the 23,626-ton Washington, one of this country's most popular passenger liners, after her arrival here today. from her last trans-Atlantic voyage under the house flag of the United States Lines.

CALGARY, Alberta, Oct. 18 This "cow town" in the foothills of the Rockies whooped it up in western style today for Princess Elizabeth. She lunched on chuckwagon beefstew and beans, rode with her Stetson-waving husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, in a stagecoach and sat in the open wrapped in a pink electric blanket to watch a miniature Calgary stampede in a driving snowstorm.

AT 9 o'clock this morning it is estimated that approximate ly a half-million New Yorkers will play hookey from their routines to beat the covers for rabbits, pheasants, grouse and woodcock over a large part of the state, although some may wait until noon, when the waterfowl season opens.

The Biltmore Theatre, an 1,100seat legitimate house at 261-65 West Forty-seventh Street, has been sold by the Warner Bros. Picture Company and George Abbott to Irving Maidman for investment, it was announced yesterday. John J. Reynolds was the broker in the sale for cash over a first mortgage of $275,000 for ten years.

When last heard in this sector in 1949, Fania Chapiro impressed this listener as a sensitive pianist who imparted no little charm to her playing. In the interim, Miss Chapiro must have meen reconsidering her pianistic philosophy, for the young woman who played in Town Hall last night had a different approach entirely.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 18 The Atomic Energy Commission acknowledged today that about 150 animals would be used in the atomic test explosions expected to start at the commission's proving grounds near here as soon as weather conditions are favorable.

PARIS, Oct. 18 The traveler of today in search of learning, business or just fun needs all the energy he can muster for entry into a large number of countries, a study by United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization shows.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 President Truman said today that he would announce whether he would seek reelection in 1952 at some politically expedient time after he had completed preparation of three major messages to the next session of Congress. These messages usually, are not finished before midJanuary.

Acting Mayor Joseph T. Sharkey, commenting upon a published report that he had been employed by a building supply company prior to his association with the General Building Supply Corporation, declared last night that his employment with the former concern had been a matter of public record.

PARIS, Oct. 19--Rene Mayer, French Vice Premier and chief of financial and economic affairs, presented to the Cabinet today a program of austerity and effort in the economic crisis that would be, for France, a veritable "new deal."

Brooklyn Tech scored a 26-6 upset triumph over Manual Training in the first game, and Madison defeated New Utrecht, 19-6, in the second half of a scholastic football double-header before 8,000 fans at Ebbets Field in Brooklyn last night.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 (AP)--A New York bank analyst said today the nation's banks are being squeezed between "penalizing taxation" and an "urgent need for capital" due to a growing demand for credit in an expanding defense economy.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18--Television broadcasters, striving to forestall action by Congress and the Federal Communications Commission, endorsed here today a code of ethics designed to eliminate obscenity, preoccupation with sex, horror dramas and other abuses in video programs. The code also seeks to curb excesses in television advertising.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (U.P.)-- A Congressional committee called on the Atomic Energy Commission today to show "greater boldness" and risk a few "failures" in order to speed up development of new atomic weapons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--Conferees for the Senate and House of Representatives agreed tonight on a compromise foreign-aid appropriation of $7,328,903,976 and arranged for its consideration and passage in both legislative bodies tomorrow.
Federal, state and city mediators stepped into stalemated negotiations between major milk distributors and five local unions yesterday in an effort to head off a possible strike next Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19--Irregular price moves marked the trade in grains today, and many cross currents were manifested.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Oct. 19-- The New Jersey professional-woman golf championship for the Frank J. Cloran Trophy got under way over the Forest Hill Field Club course today. Two teams tied for the medal.

LONDON, Oct. 19--Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery--a lifelong apostle of austerity--warned the British people tonight that they must work much harder or cut their living standards to secure themselves against aggression.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19--Extension of Government controls to include all phases of the oil business on permanent basis should be "the beginning of the end" of the industry, P.C. Spencer, president of Sinclair Oil Company, said today. He spoke at a luncheon of the Executives Club of Chicago.

BOSTON, Oct. 19--Boston University accounted for one of the biggest intercollegiate football surprises seen here in a decade tonight by beating a highly rated College of Pacific eleven, 27--12. The visitors entered the game with a record of four victories in a row.

The annual observance of United Nations Week will begin tomorrow in the United States and continue through Oct. 28, with communicants affiliated with the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A. attending regular and special Sunday services. Many of them will be conducted by laymen.
Police Commissioner Monaghan is doing some needed housecleaning in his department. It cannot be said that he has acted precipitately.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The Administration is aroused over the meat industry's challenges to its ability to enforce price controls on meat and is ready to use whatever emergency powers it needs rather than abandon the program.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 19 (AP)-- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, today called for "drastic" decisions to revise the United States budget system and cut out non-essential Federal services.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 19-- Yale University, proud "mother of colleges," celebrated her 250th anniversary today.
A.J. McCarthy of South Orange, N.J., retired senior vice president and director of the United States Lines Company, died of a heart ailment Thursday in Orange Memorial Hospital.

The Yonkers Savings and Loan Association Building, a two-story structure at 28 North Broadway in Yonkers, N.Y., has been purchased by Knepper Levin, New York, operators. THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Oct. 19--The last reservations in some European countries regarding the inclusion of Greece and Turkey in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are crumbling under the impact of recent events in the Near East.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)-- The railroads today asked for a new freight rate increase estimated at about 7.2 per cent. The carriers told the Interstate Commerce Commission that they needed the rise to offset rising costs.

The violin recital that Fredell Lack gave last night in Town Hall was a heartening instance of progress and maturity. Miss Lack played with considerably more control than in her last concert appearance here.

Kings County District Attorney Miles F. McDonald announced yesterday that he would meet next week with District Attorney Frank S. Hogan to plan a course of action on the Brooklyn prosecutor's charge of neglect of duty against Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 19 (AP) --Three jockeys and three other men were indicted by a grand jury today charged with attempting to fix races at Lincoln Downs and Narragansett race tracks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--Faced with what it termed "a serious shortage" of aviation gasoline, the Petroleum Administration for Defense issued two orders today designed to step up the output.

Teachers must have the courage to think about and discuss controversial issues despite efforts that have been made in various parts of the country to impose conformity of thought, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday at a section meeting of the New York State Teachers Association at Hunter College.

Joe Baksi, heavyweight threat several years ago, launched his comeback in spectacular fashion last night at St. Nicholas Arena. The Kulpmont, Pa., veteran needed only fifty-four seconds to knock out Gino Buonvino, Italian boxer, in what was scheduled as the tenround feature.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 19 --Suits brought by Joseph Lewis of Purdys, president of the Freethinkers of America, to exclude religious organizations from occasional use of public firehouses in Mamaroneck and Brewster were dismissed here today by Supreme Court Justice Frederick G. Schmidt.

The United Nations made its final departure from Flushing Meadow yesterday, leaving the site where nine nations had been welcomed into the world organization.
Save for wool, which was strong, commodities generally moved lower in yesterday's futures markets.
LONDON, Oct. 19--There is greater excitement in the United States over an election more than a year away than there is in England in the last days of a momentous political campaign.

The passenger liner Washington will be idle only for a few weeks and will re-enter trans-Atlantic service as a displaced persons carrier, it was announced here yesterday by the Maritime Administration.
Richard C. Fowler has been appointed associate medical director in the medical division of E.R. Squibb Sons. He formerly was a practicing dentist.

A 30-year-old war veteran, now a furniture company executive, prevented two Federal Bureau of Investigation agents yesterday from arresting his father-in-law, a fugitive, by threatening them with a revolver in the presence of his wife and two small children.

Probably as many as 50,000,000 persons have been vaccinated with 17-D. Between 1940 and 1947 the Rockefeller Foundation prepared and distributed free more than 28,000,000 doses of it to protect Allied troops and others who took part in the Second World War from yellow fever.

BOSTON, Oct. 19--Roger Livingston Scaife, a book publisher for half a century, died here today, after a long illness, at the age of 76. He was the father of the Right Rev. Lauriston L. Scaife, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Western New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 18 (UPI)--The Washington Redskins fired Coach Herman Ball today, but were forced to replace him with Backfield Coach Dick Todd when the league commissioner ruled that Heartley (Hunk) Anderson was not eligible for the job,

A collection of paintings by Navy artists who documented and interpreted World War II battles on the sea and in the air, will be a feature of the National Business Show which opens at Grand Central Palace on Monday.

YONKERS, Oct. 19-Good Times, record money-winning pacer, scored his ninth straight victory and set a new Yonkers Raceway mile record of 2:02 2/5 tonight by posting a five-length victory in the $10,000 New Jersey free-for-all pace before 19,976 fans. This was the night's feature of the Grand Circuit program.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--James J. Strebig of Silver Spring, Md., aviation editor of The Associated Press since 1943, died today of cancer at his home after an illness of several months. His age was 44.

Another large housing development is planned for Suffolk County, where a fifty-five-acre tract has been acquired for improvement with 300 dwellings and a shopping center. The property, formerly the Williams farm, is on the west side of Jackson Avenue, about three blocks south of the railroad station.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)-- The Congressional Committee on Defense Production said today that a period of civilian shortages and a rising number of bankruptcies lay ahead.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--Average primary market prices advanced 0.2 per cent over the week ended on Oct. 16, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index, 177.7 per cent of the 1926 average, was 13.3 per cent above the pre-Korean average and 5.2 per cent above the level of a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The first session of the Eighty-second Congress was on the verge of adjournment tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company of San Francisco applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to sell $93,327,400 worth of securities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--Nine of President Truman's choices to serve on this country's delegation to the United Nations were approved tonight by the Senate but the Democrats surrendered on the tenth, Ambassador at Large Philip C. Jessup.
It's Columbia against Penn at Franklin Field and Cornell against Yale in the Bowl in today's two big Ivy League football attractions.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 19-- The Women's Cross-County Golf, Association brought its season to an end at the Nassau Country Club today with a meeting and a tournament.

Mrs. Ralph Cramer Coxhead of 10 Gracie Square has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Kathleen, to Geoffrey Alan Hotham, son of Mrs. William Montagu Hotham of Vancouver, B.C., and the late Mr. Hotham.

Fordham's fifth football game of the season and its first before a home-town crowd will take place today when the Rams take on the Dons of San Francisco at Randalls Island. The kick-off is set for 2 P.M.
Collections of blood by the Red Cross in metropolitan New York have continued in "gratifying" volume since the renewed national drive began Sept. 10, it was announced yesterday.
The following is a round-up of new products that might be of help to the homemaker.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 19-- Labor control in Indonesia by Communists and party-line organizers has diminished in recent months.
Canvas and plastic wall coverings, noted for their practicality in being washable, durable and easy to put up on walls, again demonstrate, in five new collections, their decorative qualities.

VIENNA, Oct. 19--The office of the United States High Commissioner protested today against the seizure two days ago by the Soviet occupation authorities here of a half million copies of a map showing the location of slave labor camps in the Soviet Union.
With morale undermined by disclosures of widespread police grafting from bookmakers, the New York Police Department experienced yesterday the most complete reorganization of its modern history.

Toy volume for 1951 is estimated at $30,000,000 more than last year, with a manufacturers' value of $330,000,000 already shipped or on their way to retail outlets, it was announced yesterday by William A. Wenner, president of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A., Inc.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 19-- Yale University, which celebrated its 250th anniversary today, was born one September day in 1701 in the home of the Rev. Samuel Russell, a Congregational minister, at Branford, Conn.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP)-- The Senate approved a bill today providing $4,019,198,266 in supplemental appropriations, mainly for military bases throughout the world.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 19--The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith reported here today that in the last five years there had been not only a sharp decline in the anti-Semitic attitudes over the country but also in racial and religious prejudices toward other minority groups.
HOLLYWOOD, Callf., Oct. 19-- The high cost of movie-making, which already is a Hollywood headache, is going still higher.

TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 20-- United Nations and Communist liaison officers held their tenth meeting today at Panmunjom, with two basic issues still outstanding in the negotiations over conditions for resumption of armistice talks in the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The Wage Stabilization Board settled its first dispute case today by proposing pay increases averaging 18 cents an hour at the American Smelting, and Refining Company's smelter in Garfield, Utah.

Preliminary experiments on mice in which the birth rate was controlled by a synthetic chemical introduced in their diet were outlined yesterday at a conference on world population problems and birth controt under the auspices of the New York Academy of Sciences. The two-day conference is being held at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.
LONDON, Oct. 19--In a technical sense next week's British elections will turn on the contest between the Conservatives and Labor for the legacy of a corpse--that of the Liberal party.

The horses--and 17,494 horseplayers--started on the last roundup of the New York racing season at the Jamaica track yesterday. The Empire City Racing Association opened its four-week meeting, which will run through Nov. 15. That will be the final day of the campaign.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28--Los Angeles' art war, which flared up last week, is somewhat abated today.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 29-- United Nations forces moved ahead slowly yesterday along the (forty-mile stretch of the Korean (front involved most by the disparate stands of the Allies and Communists on a cease-fire line.
Rudolph Halley, Liberal-Independent-City Fusion candidate for President of the City Council, denied yesterday with considerable force and indignation that he favored a city income tax.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 28--The anti-Cominform peace congress at Zagreb adjourned in the early hours of the morning after voting a set of resolutions recommending steps to be taken to preserve and strengthen the peace.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Oct. 28--The marriage of Miss Anne Mary Slattery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Slattery of Malverne, formerly of Rockville Centre, to George Edwin Seeba, son of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Seeba, took place here this afternoon in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church.

Running the City Government in the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1952 may cost $150,000,000 to $200,000,000 more than the $1,322,181,423 provided in the record-breaking expense budget for the current fiscal period.

Cotton prices moved upward last week, reaching new season's highs on most active deliveries toward the end of the week's trading on the New York Cotton Exchange. The advances ranged between 42 and 76 points.

HONG KONG, Oct. 28--The average Chinese is being required to contribute to the meeting of new big military expenditures resulting from the Korean War. Aside from increased rates for ordinary taxes, the Chinese Communists regime
BONN, Germany, Oct. 28--The progress of Federal Germany toward sovereignty has been accompanied by renewed activity by the extreme right or Fascist wing of German political life.

Representative Jacob K. Javits, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, urged the State Department last night to encourage Turkey "as the country to carry the major responsibility in the new Middle East Command:"

Saying that several newspapers had indicated belief of insufficient discussion of issues by candidates for President of the City Council, Representative Henry J. Latham, the Republican nominee, reviewed yesterday the issues he had discussed in statements and speeches.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced here yesterday that a restaurant worker, his wife and another woman had been arrested in California for conspiracy to defraud the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York in a swindle involving forged checks.

PARIS, Oct. 28--Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, said today that Britain should form part of a "united and organized Europe:" He added that Britain, could count on the good will and comprehension of France "in the

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 28-- Israel was informed today in notes from the Western Powers that the views of Middle Eastern countries on the proposed Middle Eastern command would be welcomed at a later stage after further steps had been taken to establish the command.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28--The three armed services would make maximum use of the six-month training period under the proposed Universal Military Training program to turn out qualified basic soldiers, sailors and airmen, according to the report of the National Security Training Commission.

LONDON, Oct. 28--The two foremost housewives of Britain, Mrs. Winston Churchill, wife of the newly elected Prime Minister, and Mrs. Clement R. Attlee, wife of the outgoing Socialist leader, are going to have their hands full the next week or so moving house.

MORRISVILLE, Pa., Oct. 28-- The growing pains of a new industrial life are being felt more keenly day by day in lower Bucks County communities within the big bend of the Delaware River. The area runs from Yardley, just north of here, to Bristol, eleven miles south.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UP)The Government put the blame today on strikes and high import prices for drastically cutting supplies of copper, lead, zinc and aluminums and said copper supplies are "almost dangerously low."
DETROIT, Oct. 28 (UP)--An alert Chicago Bears team came from behind today and blocked a fourth-period punt for a touchdown and a 28-to-23 victory over the Detroit Lions before 36,950, fans.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 28--A dazzling sheet of light and a great orange fireball that fleetingly outshone the early morning Nevada desert sun today signalized the advent of yet another of the nation's frightful atomic "weapons of tomorrow."

CAIRO, Oct. 28--The Egyptian State Council approved today the general mobilization of manpower and the drafting of all Egyptians between 18 and 50 "in case of war or threat of war." The council has the status of a supreme court.

The Jewish Labor Committee in annual assembly yesterday presented to the American Federation of Labor a bronze bust of William Green, federation president. Speakers praised him for his support of adequate displaced-persons legislation and services to oppressed minorities here and abroad.

Gen. Zenon Noricga, Minister of War of Peru, with four Peruvian Army aides, and six veterans of fighting in Korea from five nations attended solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. The fiftieth anniversary of St. Paul's Guild was commemorated.

One would never have guessed from the tenor of the election campaign just concluded in Britain that it was being conducted under rapidly gathering economic storm clouds--under skies whose darkness could conceivably forebode for the country its third major economic crisis since the war.

Every time broadcasting gets in trouble it tries to avoid the issue by adopting a code of good behavior. Some years ago, when radio was criticized for being too commercial, the broadcasters came up with a set of standards about which nothing has been heard since.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28--Observers at the Chicago stockyards said this week-end that cattle feed lots, the corn belt's "beef factories," were getting into heavy production after months of inactivity attributed to Federal price controls.

The true importance of a religion is not found in its age but in the way its adherents follow the word of God, the Rev. Alfred R. Bernadt declared yesterday in a Reformation Sunday sermon at the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, Madison Avenue and Thirty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28--Following is the text of the Summary of the first report to Congress today by the National Security Training Commission, impaneled last June to draft an outline for a Universal Military Training program and eventually to supervise the program adopted. The full report is entitled "Universal Military Training--Foundation of Enduring National Strength."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)-- The Bureau of Agricultural Economics predicted today that 1952 would bring more jobs, higher consumer incomes and perhaps some additional price increases.

Philip Murray and other leaders of the United Steelworkers of America, C.I.O., told the union membership yesterday to be ready for a "struggle" with the steel industry over higher wages and other contract improvements.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28--A master plan for six months' compulsory military training for all able-bodied youths as they become 18 years old was sent to Capitol Hill today for action by the next session of Congress. The program is designed to assure the nation "enduring strength" through a constant citizens' reserve.

MT. POCONO, Pa., Oct. 28 (AP)-- The chairman of Incodel, the Interstate Commission on the Delaware River basin, today urged New York and New Jersey to defer taking independent action on developing the Delaware River and asked them to give Pennsylvania more time to appraise the water conservation measure.
Protestants across the country took the occasion of the observance of Reformation Sunday yesterday to protest the appointment by President Truman of a United States Ambassador to the Vatican.
MOSCOW, Oct. 28--There were signs on the Moscow horizon today that perhaps at least some small rift in the international storm clouds may lie just ahead.

An improvement in orders for women's apparel was reflected in demand for woolens, it was learned last week from fabric suppliers. Reorders for fleece coats, worsted suits, and other apparel items made of wool cloth, were received by garment manufacturers who have utilized the last of stocks bought many months ago.
TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 29--Communist negotiators conceded yesterday the United Nations contention that an armistice line for the Korean war must be "related to current battle positions."
ROME, Oct. 28 (UP)--Food and crop conditions are better in the Communist countries than in most other parts of the world, the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization reported today.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 28--Donald R. Wilson, national commander of the American Legion, tonight commended the National Security Training Commission for the promptness with which it made its report to the Eighty-second Congress. He also outlined a legislative proposal for the speedy implementation of universal military training.

Hartman Levine, builders, have sold the five-and-a-half-story apartment house for thirty-five families on plot 100 by 66 feet at 345 East 205th Street, northwest corner of Decatur Avenue, in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx, to Morris J. Wissman for investment. Armstrong Brothers, brokers, negotiated the sale for cash over mortgages amounting to $73,500. The property consists of apartments of three, four and five rooms and rents for more than $19,000 annually.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 28--The National Negro Labor Council formed a permanent organization here this afternoon and voted to lead "a national march on Washington around May 1, 1952."

The desirability of continuing redevelopment of the Lower East Side by public and private capital was stressed by Government officials and business representatives last night at the silver jubilee dinner of the East Side Chamber of Commerce in the Commodore Hotel.
Approval of revisions in the Election Law, as recently proposed by Assemblyman John R. Brook, Manhattan Republican, was voiced yesterday by the Citizeas Union and Americans for Democratic Action.

Unhappily, the economic report for the third quarter of this year just released by the Soviet Government continues and even increases the pattern of tight secrecy inaugurated with the first quarter report, issued last May.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 28-- Mady Christians, distinguished actress of the American and European theatre, died here tonight of a cerebral hemorrhage in Norwalk Hospital. The 51-year-old star of stage and screen was taken ill this afternoon at her home in New Canaan.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28--The grain markets had a reactionary trend much of last week, feeling the effect of profit taking which came on sharp upturns.
Joseph Szigeti gave his only local violin recital of the season Saturday evening at Hunter College.

Calling for another Protestant Reformation, the Rev. Dr. Albert J. Penner declared in a Reformation Sunday sermon yesterday at the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church at Fifty-sixth Street that "we need a revival, a reformation in our knowledge of the meaning of Christianity and in a mature Christian faith."
Renewed violence along the city's waterfront was threatened last night as the fourteen-day-old stoke of dissident longshoremen continued unabated.

The new Holland-America "economy" liner Ryndam, which departed Friday afternoon for Southampton, Le Havre and Rotterdam, was under the command of Capt. Coenraad Bouman as substitute for the ship's regular commander, Capt. Folkert H. Dobbinga, who is on leave.
President Truman yesterday called upon all adherents of "the great religions of our day" to join hands in seeking a return to religious principles.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 28-- The leaders of Communist China have voluntarily accepted a "selfdenying ordinance" to postpone doctrinaire communism until certain essential conditions have been fulfilled, Sardar K.M. Panikkar, India's Ambassador to Peiping, declared today.

PARIS, Oct. 28--French foreign trade difficulties are becoming a major problem of the Government. While the deficit with the dollar zone had been reduced in the last quarter of 1950 to 4,500,000,000 francs it rose to 10,700,000,000 in July and 12,900,000,000 in September, which is the last month to be reported in the official figures.
LONDON, Oct. 28--Prime Minister Winston Churchill offered Clement Davies a post in his new Cabinet today but the leader of Britain's Liberal party declined.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28--A House of Representatives subcommittee praised the Consumers Price Index today as "the most important single statistic issued by the Government."
This newspaper supports without exception the eight proposed state constitutional amendments and urges a "yes" vote on Nov. 6.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 28 --Mrs. Mary Bain of Miami, Fla., Southern chess champion, strengthened her lead in the tournament for the United States women's championship today by winning her sixth-round game from Mrs. Lena Grumette of Brooklyn after twenty-three moves at the Log Cabin Chess Club.

THE literary mind has its full share of mysteries and people blessed or cursed with it do not necessarily have more in common than the itch to write. But there is one peculiarity--we might call it the old-oaken-bucket complex--which nearly all writers share.
A full day of New York's hospitality yesterday proved only slightly less exhausting than an overnight hike in the mountains of Korea for fifty United Nations service men, representing nineteen

Bob Dixon, an authority on life in the Far West, will present the "Bob Dixon Show," Monday through Friday, over the DuMont Television Network, beginning next Monday, under the sponsorship of the Coca Cola Company.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 28-- Completing the last two sessions today of the opening winter sailing dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club, the first skipper to enter the winning column was Arthur Knapp with his craft Agony.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28--The American Association for the United Nations warned today against allowing the Soviet Union to gain the initiative at the forthcoming Paris meetings of the General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28--Judge Brice Clagett of the Municipal Court of Appeals died of a heart attack Friday night at his residence here. He was 82 years old.
Two contract bridge teams finished in a tie last night in the 1951 Metropolitan Match Point Teamof-Four Championship in the McAlpin Hotel.
Cardinal Hayes High turned back the Archbishop Stepinac eleven of White Plains, 13 to 0, before 4,000 fans at Randalls Island yesterday.

The National, a 2,000-seat theatre at Second Avenue and Houston Street, has been leased by the Raynes Realty Corporation, representing Jules Raynes, to a corporation headed by Hyman Jacobson, producer, composer and actor, who is rehabilitating the playhouse for stage shows and pictures. Berk Krumgold, brokers, negotiated the lease.

THE reader must now be asked to hark back nearly a year in order that a summary may be presented to him of the war against Japan in the Pacific, which was at this time the main effort of the United States and of the Commonwealth of Australia.

Two young men were well-received yesterday afternoon when the New York City Opera presented its third "Madama Butterfly" of the season at the City Center. They were Wesley Dalton, 22-year-old Detroit tenor, who sang Pinkerton, and Lee Shaynen, 26-year-old conductor, who led the work.
"Turn West, Turn East: Mark Twain and Henry James," a new book by Henry Seidel Canby, will be published by Houghton Mifflin on Nov. 6. In the parallel biog

LONDON, Oct. 28--The stock markets ended the week with reactionary tendencies as a result of the general election. Despite the confidence felt by the public that the end of the Socialist Government was in sight, it backed its convictions with only limited support of the markets.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 28--Recovery of the Dutch monetary position continues. During the last three months foreign exchange and gold reserves have increased about 370,000,000 guilders, of which last week accounted for 25,000,000. In addition the nation is developing a creditor position with the European Payment Union.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 28 (UP)-- Senator Robert A. Taft said today the United Nations had proved an "utter failure as a means of preventing aggression" in the world.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 28 (AP)-- Frank Stranahan of Toledo won his third Mexican amateur golf championship today, defeating the United States titleholder, Billy Maxwell of Odessa, Tex., 3 and 2.

The ten top college football teams of the country, as ranked in The Associated Press and United Press polls, kept their banners flying Saturday without a deviation, the first week that has happened in a long, long time.
DENPASAR, Bali, Oct. 28--For the first time in its history, Broadway soon may see performances of a full-strength gamelang orchestra and a ballet troupe from Bali.

Alterations costing $1,300,000 to convert the New York Orthopedic Hospital at Fifty-eighth Street and Sutton Place into a residence for 372 elderly persons have been started and are expected to be completed in time for full occupancy next May. Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday.

Harvard, Yale and Princeton Universities took official notice yesterday of recent collegiate athletic scandals and reaffirmed a joint policy of denying scholarships or special subsidies of any sort to athletes.

Add to good things that come in small packages the new Versailles Patisserie just opened at 782 Lexington Avenue, corner of Sixtyfirst Street. Its floor space measures a mere 10 x 30 feet but this little shop is abundantly stocked with baked goods interesting in variety, excellent in quality.

One thousand United Jewish Appeal campaign leaders, representing forty-four states, presented checks amounting to $19,981,000 to the appeal as it closed its special two-day report conference at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 28--A slight but perceptible quickening of the pulse beat is the first result of the election. The British people did not vote for decisive change and they are not going to get it, but despite the disappointment of both parties in the result of the election it is quite evident that the public at large welcomes a new administration.

GUATEMALA, Out. 28--Officials of the United Fruit Company are still waiting today for a reply from President Jacobo Arbenz for a meeting to discuss questions that are expected to lead to a decision as to whether the United Stated-owned company will continue operations in Guatemala.

With none of the candiadtes for President of the City, Council favoring an increase in the subway fare, the League of Women Voters made public yesterday replies to a questionnaire asking the candidates how they proposed to finance efficient operation of the subway system and whether they favored taking over all transportation lines by the city.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 28--The New York Football Giants discovered in the huge stadium on the lakefront today that the old script they have been using is out of date. It's the script that they borrowed from the baseball Giants, the one featuring the implausible finish. They tried it out on the hard-bitten Cleveland Browns this chill afternoon and it just didn't work. Ray Poole's 42-yard field goal attempt just

The word United Nations has come to mean different things to different people. Some say it's a skyscraper in New York overlooking the East River; some may think of it as a vehicle for ideological invective; others still, mainly in the Soviet orbit, are apt to refer to it as a propaganda platform of imperialism. It all depends, apparently, on the point of view.
Rex Harrison and his wife, Lilli Palmer, have signed to co-star in the Theatre Guild presentation of Christopher Fry's comedy, "Venus Observed," due at the Century Theatre the week of Feb. 11.

A number of exhibitions of special interest are scheduled for this week. A set of portrait drawings by the German Renaissance master, Cranach, belonging to the Museum of Rheims, is to be shown at Knoedler's for the benefit of the museum. The preview, for which

Fred Cone's 16-yard field goal eleven seconds before the final gun capped a 23-point fourth-quarter rally that gave the Green Bay Packers a 29-27 decision over the New York Yanks at Yankee Stadium yesterday, spoiling the home debut of Ted Collins' winless National Football League entry.

PORT ARTHUR, Ont., Oct. 28-- To the startled residents of Peers, Alberta, who saw Princess Elizabeth pull into the station yesterday at the throttle of her train, the business of moving a royal party across Canada might have looked deceptively casual.

The typical business girl customer of Manhattan stores is in her twenties, earns $2,000 to $3,000 a year and wants the stores to stay open until 9 o'clock more evenings and provide more salespersons and better services.

While making a strong appeal for support of Jewish needs throughout tha world at a special session of the United Jewish Appeal yesterday at the Commodore Hotel, William Keyserling, 82-yearold father of Leon H. Keyserling, chairman of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, collapsed and died of a heart attack.

Acting Council President Joseph T. Sharkey, Democratic candidate for that office, sent telegrams yesterday to twenty-two supporters of Rudolph Halley, demanding that they withdraw their support from the Liberal-Independent-City Fusion candidate for President of the City Council in view of the disclosure that Mr. Halley had received a fee of more than $100,000 for representing the late George A. Richards, owner of several radio stations.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28--Steel mill operating men here believe that the month that ends this week may well set an all-time record for steel production. If it should fall short, and there are a few who feel it will, the cause will be work stoppages.
We heartily welcome Controller Lazarus Joseph's public recognition of the fact that the city has not met the primary obligation of seeing that its employes are decently paid.
NORTH READING, Mass., Oct. 28--A funeral service was held today for Dr. Albert H. Covner of Nahant, Mass., heart specialist whose body was found in the woods here yesterday. Dr. Covner

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 28 (AP)--Communist correspondents here for the Korean truce talks said today that Kimm Kiu Sic, middle-of-the-road former political leader in South Korea, died "sometime this year" in Communist North Korea.

Mario Jazzetti, a pianist with the tone and temperament of a virtuoso, played in Town Hall last night. It was the first appearance in this country for the Italian performer, who brought with him a history of musical honors.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Oct. 28-- A record representation of 106 clubs approved 125 competitions for the 1951-52 winter season as the thirtieth annual convention of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association ended today.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 28--That the foot is still an important part of football was the costly lesson the Giants learned today at Municipal Stadium, where Ray Poole's failure to boot an extra point and his inability to succeed with a last-gasp field goal enabled the Cleveland Browns to beat Steve Owen's club, 14-13. The season's first setback
The victory of the Conservatives in the British elections last Thursday was well discounted judging by the action of sterling forwards in the markets which preceded the actual event.

BERLIN, OCt. 28--Following an indication that Moscow considered the German unity campaign a matter of prime importance, the Soviet zone Foreign Minister, Georg Dertinger, declared today that his government was ready to make concessions to achieve this purpose.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UP)-- The Federal Bureau of Investigation is checking into Reconstruction Finance Corporation dealings with a Mobile, Ala., paper mill whose former president contends he was "squeezed out" by a group including relatives of Representative Frank W. Boykin, Democrat of Alabama.

The stock market yesterday pulled out of its dump of late last week but only alter prices reached new low marks for the October recession. Early losses renging as high as a point were transformed into gains well in excess of 2 points in some instances while the composite rate showed a recovery of 0.71 point.
To anyone who has suffered from rheumatic diseases, or seen a loved one suffer, it should hardly be necessary to urge support of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation.
BOSTON, Oct. 29 (AP)--The National Pest Control Association heard bad news for rats today.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29--California resort and early spring fashions for every hour and occasion will be shown this week to fashion editors from all parts of the country assembled here for National Press Week, sponsored by California Fashion Creators.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 29--Last night Dallas witnessed perhaps the largest concerted event of its vital fashion center, a showing of the Dallas Fashion Center's spring styles, held in Fair Park auditorium.

The New York City Anti-Crime Committee asked Governor Dewey yesterday to call a conference of New York and New Jersey officials to take action against "inefficiency, crime and political corruption" on the metropolitan waterfront.

A new practice of signing on civil service crews aboard vessels of the Military Sea Transportation Service of the United States Navy for a period of twelve months, rather than on a single-voyage basis, has been instituted by the service's Atlantic division, it was announced yesterday by Rear Admiral John M. Will.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)-- The Subversive Activities Control Board today rejected a demand by the Communist party that it start all over again on the hearings into whether the party must register as a Russian-directed group.

ROME, Oct. 29--Alarmed by the spread of birth control and also by licentiousness in modern society, Pope Pius XII urged midwives and doctors today to oppose abortion, artificial insemination, sterilization and any other practice that would violate the fundamental Roman Catholic principles of the sacrament of marriage: procreation and the education of children.

DANVILLE, Ky., Oct. 29 (UP)-- The thirtieth anniversary of football's greatest upset went almost unnoticed today in this sleepy little town on the Perryville Pike because Centre College fans were too excited about this year's unbeaten team to think about the 6-to-0 victory over Harvard back in 1921.

Word that Colombia was ending its exchange rate discrimination against the "coffee dollar" reached Beaver Street after the close of New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange trading yesterday and failed to affect the market. Coffee futures rose 2 to 8 points in a dull session, with, a volume of 12,250 bags.
Persons prominent in society finance, public service, business and the armed forces are expected to attend the opening of the sixtythird National Horse Show tonight in Madison Square Garden.
The city extended a heroes' welcome yesterday to fifty soldiers, sailors, marines and airmen of nineteen nations fighting in Korea under the banner of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)--A retired Navy captain and an Air Force major received today the National Air Council's annual awards for outstanding aviation research and experimentation in year ending last June 30.
BOMBER Command played an ever-growing part in all our war plane, and eventually made a decisive contribution to victory.

Representative Henry J. Latham, Republican candidate for President of the City Council, calling his two major opponents "the Tammany tax twins" and wishing "a plague on both their houses," declared last night that the responsibility for the lack of a LiberalRepublican coalition candidate for the Council presidency rested solely with the Liberal party.

Parents are likely to think of toys merely as objects useful in keeping youngsters occupied and out of mischief, but they have other more important and subtle values, Mrs. Emma Dickson Sheehy, Associate Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--The House Ways and Means subcommittee investigating scandals in the Internal Revenue Bureau plans to have a showdown Wednesday with John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, and John B. Dunlap, Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

HARTFORD, Oct. 29--The first support for the Presidential candidacy of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio from a Republican party leader in Connecticut came today from Robert E. Parsons of Farmington, former Lieutenant Governor and now a member of the Republican State Central Committee.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 29-- The first Chinese cultural mission to be sent out officially by the Chinese Communist Govermnent arrived here today for a six weeks' tour of the country. It received a rousing reception at the local airport by representatives of many Indian organizations and of the Government.

Proposed Amendment No. 3, on which voters will act Nov. 6, recognizes the social obligation of the governmental employer to provide a decent old age for faithful employes, now retired, whose pensions are based on the extremely low salaries of days gone by.
ALBANY, Oct. 29 (AP)--The first snow of the season in central New York fell early today and was believed the cause of the probable drowning of a tugboat captain in the State Barge Canal.

FAYID, Suez Canal Zone, Oct. 29 (UP)--Egyptian lighthouse keepers brought all night traffic through the Suez Canal to a halt tonight by refusing to man their beacons after renewed outbreaks of violence and gunfire had left one dead and two injured in the area.

MONTREAL, Oct. 29 (UP)-- Floyd Curry scored three goals in the second period tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 6-to-1 triumph over the New York Rangers before a crowd of 14,408 that included Britain's touring royal couple, Princess Elizabeth and Prince Philip.
MONTREAL, Oct. 29--Seventy thousand Montrealers massed in Dominion Square roared their "welcome" and "bienvenue" tonight as Princess Elizabeth made the only balcony appearance of her Canadian tour.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29--About 15,000 representatives of the shoe industry gathered here today with high hopes for the future at the eighteenth national shoe fair which opened today.

Making their first trip from Rheims since the reign of Louis XV, an important group of portrait drawings by such famous sixteenth-century German masters as Lucas Cranach the Elder, Cranach the Younger and Amerberger will be shown to the public beginning today at the Knoedler Galleries.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 29-- Dr. Robert G. Aitken, director emeritus of Lick Observatory and astronomer emeritus of the University of California, died today in a rest home at the age of 86.

Prominent figures in boxing made a fine showing on behalf of the family of the late George Flores last night. Among these were sixteen former and present champions of the world, who appeared at the St. Nicholas Arena, where a charity boxing program was held.
The Office of Price Stabilization authorized higher milk prices yesterday for the five boroughs, Long Island and Westchester County.

WHILE the far horizon appeals, it does not always provide, and after a fruitless morning spent cruoched in a rock blind on Lake Champlain, we had to return to Long Island to gather in the major ingredients for a duck dinner.

JAMES MICHENER'S "Return to Paradise," was published only last April. His new work, "The Voice of Asia," was published yester day. Both books are the fruit of Mr. Michener's jaunty journeys over much of the world. Together they mark two significant stages in the transformation of a writer of fiction into a reporter.

A tanker, only partly completed by her builders in this country and then towed across, the Atlantic to Germany for completion, now lies at anchor at a Jersey City shipyard for final repairs before entering into regular service.

The United Public Workers of America, left-wing labor group that says it represents substantial groups of employes in many different city departments, was denied membership yesterday by the newly-formed fifteen-member advisory committee on city labor relations.

A representative group of wholesalers, retailers and manufacturers surveyed by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., anticipated continuation of high sales volume through the first quarter of 1952, Roy A. Foulke, vice president of the credit agency, said yesterday.

A subcommittee of the House Committee on Education and Labor, which held extensive public hearings last spring in order to inform itself on how the Consumers Price Index, or so-called cost-of-living yardstick, is prepared, has now issued its report.

The Spencer Steel Company has leased the industrial property at 34-46 Vernon Boulevard in Long Island City, Queens, from Colonna Co., and will use it for manufacturing purposes. The property consists of about 10,000 square feet of building space together with 20,000 square feet of waterfront and crane facilities. The C. Grant Keck Organization and Queens Industrials were the brokers in the transaction.

The scheduled announcement by Joe Louis as to his retirement plans was not forthcoming yesterday. Listed to talk about what he intended doing in the future at a tentative session arranged after last Friday's bout with Rocky Marciano, the ex-heavyweight champion failed to make an appearance.

SIMSBURY, Conn., Oct. 29-- This year's Westminster school football team, a senior outfit, is "playing up to expectations, if not better." That's how the affable Ron Michelini, in his twenty-third year as head coach, described his outfit today.

PARIS, Oct. 29--Czechoslovakia's Five-Year Plan has fallen apart under the stress of Soviet demands for increased deliveries of heavy industrial equipment and under the strain of huge industrial expansion beyond the strength of the country's economy, according to reports reaching Paris.

PRINCETON received a million-dollar legacy from a non-Princetonian the other day but it is doubtful if the Sons of Old Nassau appreciate it a fraction as much as another unexpected gift they had dumped into their collective lap a few years ago. This one can't be measured in dollars and cents. It isn't impressive if measured in avoirdupois, but it's a gift beyond valuation, the 171 pounds which adds up into Dick Kazmaier.
Indications of a possible break in the city's costly waterfront tieup appeared yesterday as the stoppage entered its third week with the major portion of shipping still strikebound.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 29--More high school courses should be offered to acquaint the nation's young people with the other countries of this hemisphere, six high school students recommended tonight in The New York Times Youth Forum.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 30--Although the Korean fighting was still limited mostly to patrol activities yesterday, there were indications that the Communists were building up strength along the central front, where some recent engagements have been of battalion size.

PARIS, Oct. 29--Adm. William M. Fechteler, United States Chief of Naval Operations, declared today that Western naval defenses were operating under "a decided handicap" because no agreement had been reached on a supreme commander of the Atlantic under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

George C. Sherman Jr. of New York was unanimously re-elected president of the Indoor Polo Association of America at the annual meeting held at the Racquet and Tennis Club. Delegates attending the meeting represented leading clubs in Chicago, Detroit, Ohio, New England and the metropolitan area.

A proposed judgment for final settlement of Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan's decision that Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and Remington Arms Company, Inc., were operating in violation of the anti-trust laws was filed yesterday by the Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--Two Marine heroes who helped to break a trap set by the Chinese Communists in the Changjin Reservoir area in Korea last winter received Medals of Honor from President Truman today.

William H. Draper Jr. is seeking to resign his $30,000-a-year position as trustee of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road to devote all of his time to the unsalaried post as chairman of the Long Island Transit Authority.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday subpoenaed the books and records of the Broadway Maintenance Corporation, which has a contract to service and maintain lighting facilities on New York streets.

CAIRO, Oct. 29--The Arab governments are consulting on the attitude to be taken toward the decision of the Western powers to go ahead with formation of a Middle Eastern command organization that would include Britain, the United States, France, Turkey, New Zealand, Australia and the Union of South Africa.

Very advisedly, and to the marked advantage of the musical community, the Schneider Quartet gave last night in the Lexington Avenue Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association the first of a series of sixteen concerts to be devoted to the string quartets of Franz Joseph Haydn. These programs are given under the auspices of the Haydn Society, which later will issue the complete series on records.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 (UP)-- The National Football League today asked the Federal court to dismiss the Government's television anti-trust suit against it on the ground that the Federal charges were vague and ambiguous.

Three years of the Marshall Plan in Europe have accomplished even more than was originally expected. Every Marshall Plan country is now producing more than it did in 1938. For the first quarter of this year the rate for all Marshall Plan countries was 139 per cent of 1938's production.

TORONTO, Oct. 29 (Canadian Press)--The movement of Canadian provinces, municipalities and corporations into the private capital market of the United States is a development of the last twelve months, Louis Rasminsky of the Foreign Exchange Control Board said today.
The cotton futures market closed yesterday at virtually the best levels of the day as late trading increased on the New York Cotton Exchange. Final prices were 49 to 59 points net higher.

Consolidated net income of the Packard Motor Car Company for the first nine months of 1951 amounted to $4,922,876, equal to 32 cents a share on 15,000,000 common shares, according to the report released yesterday by Hugh J. Ferry, president. Net income was computed after an estimated tax charge of $5,335,000.

General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein reserved decision yesterday on whether to cite for contempt First Deputy Fire Commissioner Nathan C. Horwitz for failure to answer questions in connection with the Fire Department inquiry.

LONDON, Oct. 29--Prime Minister Winston Churchill continued the task of forming his new Conservative Government today at his Kentish country home as complete returns from Thursday's election held his over-all majority in the House of Commons to eighteen.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Oct. 29 --Guayaquil chauffeurs and gangs started overturning trucks and cars and looting and burning early today. The city is now guarded by troops to maintain public services. Banks, businesses and most industries closed.

The Allied High Commissioners and Chancellor Adenauer of Germany are scheduled to initial tomorrow the draft of a "peace contract" designed to end the occupation regime, broaden German sovereignty and pave the way for a German contribution to Western defense.
The trustees of Ohio State University are in danger of damaging the reputation of that great center of learning as severely as the regents managed to do in the case of the University of California.
Surgical operations have been suspended at the city's Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn since Oct. 19 except in cases of emergency, it was learned yesterday.
Railroads Authorized by I.C.C. to Drop Service in West

ATHENS, Oct. 22 (By Airmail) --The United States Air Force, in expanding its operations in the Mediterranean region, finds that it must prove itself a good tenant of foreign governments. Its relations as a tenant of France, Libya and Greece have been considered good, and it is determined to keep them so.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29--Grain prices were weak early today, but they gained momentum on the buying side gradually to close generally strong. Late buying by export houses in a substantial way gave wheat a strong close.

Benedicto Macri, 39 years old, was found not guilty at 10:19 o'clock last night of second-degree manslaughter in the fatal stabbing of William Lurye, organizer for the International Ladies Garment Workers Uinon, on May 9, 1949.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--Inflation, the demands of the defense production program, world unrest, labor shortages and a scarcity of machines and materials essential to high productivity are problems with which the American farmer will have to wrestle for the next couple of years, according to speakers at the Department of Agriculture's twenty-ninth annual Agricultural Outlook Conference today.

Since 1939 participation in hospital insurance plans has increased thirteen times until today half the nation's populace is enrolled in one or more such plans, the Hospital Council of Greater New York reported yesterday.

Guerrilla and underground war, sabotage and ambush, and economic boycott--the type of constant harassment that took place in Palestine and is now taking place in Malaya--is the potential danger to Britain and the Allies in the Middle East and Moslem countries.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 29--The Netherlands Government announced tonight the exposure of a Communist espionage plot organized by the Czechoslovak Government and operating in this country and Belgium for more than two years.

Twenty-six prominent Protestant clergymen of the metropolitan area called on President Truman yesterday to withdraw "immediately" his appointment of Gen. Mark W. Clark as United States Ambassador to the Vatican. They characterized the President's action as "a needless and tragic blunder" that would "issue in deplorable dissension among our people."

Two teen-age girls who had spent an adventurous night in a drifting rowboat in Jamaica Bay got ashore safely yesterday morning but only after one of the girls had narrowly escaped drowning in the capsizing of a police helicopter.
Tennessee and Michigan State clung to the No. 1 and No. 2 positions in The Associated Press football poll yesterday, but the rest of the top ten underwent a minor shakeup.
The Bronx holds no charm for a baseball-loving monkey when the last batter is out, the season is over and cold winds blow across the outfields at the Polo Grounds and Yankee Stadium.

Enactment of a new, comprehensive national fair trade act and increased attention on the part of advertising and marketing people to any proposed legislation that may affect them were urged yesterday at a meeting of the American Marketing Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Oct. 29-- Miss Caroline Townsend Nason, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. P. Nason of Twin Lanes Farm, Fairfield, has completed plans for her marriage on Nov. 21 to James Hollyday, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Hollyday of Bedford Hills, N.Y.

Although net sales of the Armco Steel Corporation and subsidiaries for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 increased 26 per cent to a record of $399,053,788, a tax rise of 82 per cent caused net profit to drop 42 per cent below the results attained in the same period of 1950.

BERLIN, Oct. 29--The systematic building of the East German Communist army on the Soviet model and under tight Soviet supervision will reach a new stage next month when more than 5,000 officer candidates, having completed a nine-month course, are to be examined for commissions.

"The Number," a first play by Arthur Carter, will be unfolded this evening at 8 o'clock at the Biltmore Theatre under the sponsorship of Paul Vroom and Irving Cooper, who have teamed up for the first time in a managerial capacity.

As an incentive to recapture 1,000,000 tons of high-grade steel from abandoned trolley car tracks throughout the country, the Office of Price Stabilization has authorized a premium of $25 a ton for the scrap.

Supporters of Rudolph Halley, Liberal-Independent-City Fusion party nominee for President of the City Council, produced yesterday a score of statements reiterating confidence in him despite a demand made on Sunday by Joseph T. Sharkey, the Democratic nominee, that Mr. Halley's backers withdraw.

Increased trade among Western Hemisphere nations has been made more essential by division of the world by the Iron Curtain, Dr. Luis Machado, Cuban Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday at the thirty-eighth National Foreign Trade Convention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--In the forthcoming attempt to get President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill together on foreign policy questions, the key man here is likely to he W. Averell Harriman, White House foreign affairs adviser and Mutual Security Administrator.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Oct. 29-- A constituent assembly will meet here Wednesday to draw up a constitution for the bitterly contested state of Jammu and Kashmir.

Armstead Brown of Tallahassee, Fla., a former Supreme Court Justice in that state, died of a heart attack yesterday in his suite at the Plaza Hotel. His age was 76. He had twice been Chief Justice of the court.

Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, told 500 persons at a dinner of the American-Turkish Society last night that he hoped that Turkey soon would become a full member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--Formidable plans to block President Truman's nomination of Gen. Mark W. Clark to be Ambassador to the Vatican have now been prepared for the Senate, where such appointments must be confirmed by majority vote.

LONDON, Oct. 29--As one of his first acts after becoming Britain's Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden today asked Sir Francis Shepherd, British Ambassador to Teheran, to come home for consultations about the unresolved oil dispute with Iran.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UP)-- The armed forces have spent or awarded contracts for $62,900,000,000 for weapons and military supplies since the start of the Korean war, the Department of Defense reported today.
The departmental trial of thirtytwo policemen, postponed yesterday until next Monday, will be moved to Brooklyn Borough Hall.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 29--The United States, Britain and France retain four key powers in the treaty establishing the political sovereignty of the Federal Republic of Germany.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--Speculation about a possible conference between Prime Minister Winston Churchill and President Truman, possibly during the President's protracted trip to Key West, Fla., mounted today despite a studied White House policy of "no comment."

Judge Harold R. Medina said in Federal Court here yesterday that the Government's conspiracy-monopoly suit against certain investment bankers may come down to whether bankers should be required to submit competitive price bids for all issues of securities up for public sale.
MILAN, Italy, Oct. 29 (AP)--Evidence of a world-wide renaissance in operatic composition, namely 130 manuscripts for three-act classic operas, is in the possession of the renowned La Scala of Milan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--Members of the National Security Training Commission expressed hope today that Congress, the President and the Department of Defense would combine to get a limited universal military training program, calling up 60,000 youths of 18, going by midsummer of next year.
The Government obtained yesterday an additional $15,000 in forfeited bail posted for three convicted Communist leaders now listed as fugitives.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 29 (AP) --Willie Mays, Negro center-fielder for the Giants, probably won't be going into the Army after all. His draft board meets tomorrow to consider the result of his preinduction examination here last week. An authoritative source, whose name may not be used, said Willie probably would be classified 4-F.

White autumn blossoms formed a background in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Mimi Foss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Perkins Foss of 155 East Seventy-second Street, to Howell Hoffman Howard, son of Mrs. Howell Hoffman Howard of 895 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Howard.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, October 29-- Two more attacks upon Ohio State University's rule requiring advance screening of campus speakers were made here today by statewide organizations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--Dr. Karl von Lewinski, former German Government official, who for many years was German General Consul in New York, died here today of a heart ailment at the age of 78.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--William M. Boyle Jr. placed President Truman on record tonight as approving Frank E. McKinney, Indianapolis banker, for the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee. Mr. Boyle, who resigned as party chairman recently, said he had reached his decision to place Mr. McKinney's name in nomination "after consulting with the President and Democratic party leaders."

Offering to the public of about $9,000,000 of new convertible preferred stock of the Shellmar Products Corporation, packaging manufacturer, and of Goodall-Sanford, Inc., manufacturer of textiles and lightweight clothing for men, will be made by underwriting syndicates today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--One day in February, 1947, the British Ambassador informed the Secretary of State that his Government, after March 31, would be unable to give any further assistance to Greece and Turkey, the strategic Mediterranean bulwarks against Bolshevism.

New York will have a look this week at one of the college football powerhouses with the coming of Southern California to the Yankee Stadium Saturday to play Army. At the same time Notre Dame makes its only appearance of the year in the East at Baltimore for its annual game with Navy.

The need for homecraft or home basement machine shops in national defense production has returned in the toolmaking field for the first time since World War II, it was reported here yesterday by Carl Kertesz, vice president of the Design Tool Corporation, 80 Washington Street.

A Texan with a good "bankground" and a pretty girl in tow sat down, so a story goes, in the restaurant that enjoys being known as "the most expensive in New York." Annoyed by the long menu in French and the lofty head waiter, also French, the plain but prosperous guest said he wanted "the juiciest hamburger in the house."

Frequent references to the late Fiorello H. La Guardia and the type of government he gave New York occur in the "off-the-cuff" speeches being made all over New York by Rudolph Halley, running for President of the City Council as the candidate of the Liberal, City Fusion and Independent parties.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--A much bewildered Republican, who chooses to remain anonymous, wants to know who runs the mailing room at the Republican National Committee.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 29--The National Association of Home Builders today set up a defense housing committee composed of fifty members whose task it will be to expedite the building of housing in critical areas of the country next year.
ZURICH, Oct. 29--The upward movement of the dollar rate of exchange, which began some weeks ago, at Zurich last week finally reached what is loosely called "parity."

The eleven-story Jensen Building at 665-671 Fifth Avenue has been sold by the estate of David A. Schulte to District Theatres of Washington, D.C., headed by Harry Freedman, realty investor. In connection with this transaction, Georg Jensen, Inc., dealer in silver, gifts and other merchandise, signed a new lease for the ground floor, basement, mezzanine and second and third floors.

The State Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had ordered an investigation of the safety of operations and the equipment used by the Children's Bus Service, Inc., which transports 35,000 public school pupils each day. The company operates 240 buses under a $1,305,908 contract with the city.

Asserting that the greatest problem this country faces was the breakdown of government, Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, said yesterday that the cause of this collapse was the failure of the people to accept their civic responsibilities.
WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 29-- Winterthur, the 185-room home of Henry Francis du Pont in the gently rolling countryside about six miles from here, will be established formally as a museum tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--New information indicating "serious irregularities" at the Rossford Ordnance Depot near Toledo, Ohio, has been turned over to the Army, has been checked by the Army and apparently found correct, an investigating subcommittee of the House of Representatives reported today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UP)-- Industrial production, rose in September, but not as much as had been expected, the Federal Reserve Board said today. The new level was 219 per cent of the 1935-39 average, up two points from August, but still below the record of 223 set last April.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29-- Twentieth Century-Fox today announced two new screen projects, one of them based on Jack London's 1912 novel, "Smoke Bellew," the other on a current book, "The Form Divine," by Hildegarde Dolson.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations joined today in denouncing the record of the Eighty-second Congress so far, pinning responsibility on the Republican-Southern Democrat coalition that was accused of shaping it.

MOUNT POCONO, Pa., Oct. 29 (AP)--The Attorney General of New York declared tonight that his state would go before the United States Supreme Court to seek permission to tap the Delaware River for urgently needed water.

LONDON, Oct. 29--Francis Lister, the actor, died in a hospital here yesterday at the age of 52. He was taken ill in June while appearing with Jessie Royce Landis in "Come Live With Me" at the Vaudeville Theatre in London.

With Acting Council President Joseph T. Sharkey forced to cancel his speaking engagements yesterday because of a throat ailment, his campaign for election to the Council Presidency was carried on by Emil K. Ellis. Mr. Ellis, speaking ...

Underwriting houses were required to go in for some secondguessing again yesterday to develop a going price in the present uncertain market for a new issue of the A-rated bonds of the Utah Power and Light Company.

Ground action in Korea yesterday was largely composed of patrol activities on the part of United Nations command troops. Friendly patrols operated all along the battle line, with only minor contacts established with the enemy.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 29--A routine court journal entry today marked the end in Probate Court of the Vaness Company, liquidating agent for Van Sweringen creditors.

Lambent of the Double M Farm reeled off a fast mile and a furlong in taking the main race on the Empire City Racing Association at Jamaica program yesterday. Engaging seven others in the contest, which was called the Hartsdale Classified Handicap, Lambent stepped the distance in 1:51 to defeat Clarence Buxton's favored Ted M. by a length.

In his violin recitals Max Pollikoff always has been generous to modern composers; he continued the practice last night when he played at Carnegie Hall. Sarasate's Habanera was the only work on the second half of his program that wasn't contemporary.
Two distinguished coaches yesterday rose to the defense of spring practice, which recently has been subjected to heavy fire from some quarters as contributing to the overemphasis of college football.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 30-- United Nations and Communist negotiators meeting yesterday at Panmunjom to discuss an armistice in the Korean war debated the value and defensibility of the Ongjin and Yonan Peninsulas, which thrust out into the Yellow Sea south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel.

Police barricades at City Hall were overrun at 5:30 o'clock last night by 2,000 members of the Building Service Employer International, A.F.L. The breakthrough, made in an effort to gain entrance to the building occurred after the men had picketed peacefully for about an hour in City Hall Park.

Anyone may be pardoned who thinks of Winston Churchill as a Government by himself. He gives that impression, to begin with, and, as the memoirs now running in this newspaper remind us, when he is Prime Minister he is a Big Boss, with an eye to all things large and small and a mind that is very much his own.

America's aluminum industry, important in peacetime and strategic for war purposes, has widened further this year its marlin of world leadership through a 17.5 pet cent production increase and a strong start on a $500,000,000 expansion.

Red-faced city officials conceded yesterday that several pay checks --the exact number was in dispute last night--issued on Oct. 15 to rookie patrolmen almost "bounced." But the city aides said it was all a clerical or mechanical error and not an indication that the city was in trouble with the banks.

There were times yesterday on Forty-ninth Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues when passersby had to look sharp to avoid horses being led along the north sidewalk. They were being unloaded from vans and taken into Madison Square Garden for the National Horse Show that begins an eight-day run today.

These are days of big and bad news, woe piled upon woe like Pelion on Ossa. So when a little piece of good news creeps timidly into the newspapers we ought not to let it go unnoticed but greet it with pleasure and gratitude. One such item was tucked away in a corner of a recent issue--just a paragraph out of Rome.
