TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 31-- United Nations forces continued to make slight advances yesterday at strategic points along the Korean front, while throwing back Com- ...
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 30--Official reports published in the Yugoslav provincial press indicate that peasant resistance to land collectivization and the compulsory delivery of bread ...

In resigning his $30,000-a-year job as trustee of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road to devote full time to his unsalaried chairmanship of the Long Island Transit Authority William H. Draper Jr. is demonstrating the fine qualities of character that the public has come to expect of him.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--Net working capital of American corporations reached a new high level of $79,000,000,000 at the end of June, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--Vice Admiral Ross T. McIntire, retired. has resigned as chairman on Medical Policies and Procedures of the Red Cross National Blood program. No successor has been named.

PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 30 (AP) --Captain Sam Snead today announced three-fourths of his lineup for the Ryder Cup Scotch foursome matches and said national open champion Ben Hogan would see double duty against the British golfers this week-end.

William H. Draper Jr. formally resigned as trustee of the Long Island Rail Road and recommended William Wyer of Rumson, N.J., a consulting engineer, as his successor at a hearing yesterday before Judge Harold M. Kennedy in Brooklyn Federal Court.

The second-day story yesterday on Monday's capture of an 18year-old robbery suspect by a 60year-old Municipal Court Justice in Brooklyn showed that the press had played up the capture a bit, but that the jurist was nonetheless an agile and courageous citizen.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--Soviet atomic explosions should spur United States atomic research and production, Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, asserted today.

Nearly 100,000,000 man hours of productive labor were lost in this country last year because of arthritis and rheumatism, Gen. George C. Kenney, commander of the Allied Air Force in the Southwest Pacific in World War II, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)--A price official said today liquor dealers will get Government permission to raise prices by a good bit more than the amount of new taxes going into effect Thursday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 30--In defiance of a categorical police prohibition 2,000 left-wing university and high school students and sympathizers marched in Teheran's streets today to demonstrate their sympathy for Egypt in her fight against "Anglo-American imperialist warmongers."

ROSELLE, N.J., Oct. 30--Lewis D. Rights of 410 Wheatsheaf Road, retired bridge and rail lines engineer, whose father was a Moravian missionary working among the Cherokee Indians in what is now Oklahoma, died today at the Roselle Park Nursing Home after a long illness. His age was 80.

Representative Henry J. Latham, Republican candidate for President of the City Council, was counted out of the race by some political observers shortly after it began, but he has been campaigning like a man who intended to win.

The Department of Hospitals disclosed yesterday that Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson had consented to ask the Board of Estimate at its next meeting to vote $300 increases for nurse anesthetists to keep them from quitting their jobs.
There is a fine moral lesson to be derived from "The Number," which was acted at the Biltmore last evening. But the excitement in Arthur Carter's new melodrama is pretty hollow.

BOSTON, Oct. 30--World War III is being fought out "bloodlessly" on the atomic testing grounds in Nevada, William L. Laurence, Pulitzer Prize winning science reporter of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said here today.
TRENTON, Oct. 30--Another rail tube under the Hudson River linking northern New Jersey transit facilities with Manhattan was proposed today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

George M. Weiss, general manager and vice president of the Yankees yesterday signed a new contract to continue in both jobs with the world champions. Weiss' former agreement, for five years, still had a year to run, but President Dan Topping tore up that one in favor of a new one.
Frank Costello and Rudolph Halley had an apparently accidental encounter a month ago as a result of lunching at the same time in an East Side restaurant, it was disclosed yesterday.

Aided by donations to four bloodmobile units, the New York regional program of the Red Cross collected 1,222 pints of blood Monday. Employes of the long lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company gave 310 pints to one of the units and have pledged 2,000 more.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30--On the site of what seventeen months ago was a blighted residential district, Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation started production of steel today from the first of eleven open hearths that will increase the nation's annual productive capacity by 1,200,000 ingot tons.
The vast development of the Port of New York Authority properties was described by Austin J. Tobin, executive director of that department, at the eastern regional ...

Foreign traders soon will be called upon to take an increasingly important part in procurement of needed raw materials from abroad, Jess Larson, administrator of the Defense Materials Procurement Agency, said yesterday at the National Foreign Trade Convention.

ON Monday, May 15, [1944] three weeks before D-Day, we held a final conference in London at Montgomery's headquar ters in St. Paul's School. The King, FieldMarshal Smuts, the British Chiefs of Staff, the commanders of the expedition, and many of their principal staff officers were present. On the stage was a map of the Normandy ...
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 30 (AP)--A Swedish Navy engineer, Ernst Hilding Andersson, 42, pleaded guilty today to charges of spying against Sweden and Britain for the Soviet Union.
Insurgent dock strikers tightened their control of the port yesterday as pickets dispersed back to-work movements in separated harbor areas.

Fred Allen continues to be television's foremost problem child. For the last year or so, the comedian has floundered around in one format after another and has failed to achieve results satisfactory ...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, announced today that he planned to introduce a bill to bring all Collectors of Internal Revenue under Civil Service.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)--V. A. Hubbard of Chaffee, Mo., whose nomination to be Collector of Customs in St. Louis has gone to the Senate three times without action, received another recess appointment today from President Truman.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30--General of the Army George C. Marshall urged tonight "an enduring system" of universal military training as the nation's only means of maintaining an effective force at a reasonable cost.

Shore Park Cooperative Apartments, Inc, Morton Goldberg, president, has obtained a building loan of $1,000,000 on the 108-family cooperative apartment house to be built at the southeast corner of Shore Road and Sixty-eighth Street in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.
CAIRO, Oct. 30--The Egyptian Ministry of the Interior issued tonight a list of Egyptians killed and injured in incidents in the Suez Canal zone since Egypt declared her treaty with Britain abrogated.
Federated Department Stores, Inc., one of the country's largest retailing groups, will embark this week on a program to build and operate new department stores in medium-size and smaller cities ...

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 30 (AP)--The "frightening spectacle of the increased use of narcotic drugs by teen-agers" is possibly the most urgent of all problems confronting law-enforcement agencies, Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan of New York said today.

The present era in medicine may well be called the "renaissance of the general practitioner," it was asserted here yesterday at the third annual scientific assembly of the New York State Academy of General Practice at the Statler Hotel.

LONDON, Oct. 31--Prime Minister Winston Churchill, who began his wartime leadership of Britain with a promise of nothing more than blood, toil, tears and sweat, started his peacetime administration at the head of a Conservative Government today with a pay cut for all Cabinet officers, including, himself.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Oct. 30 --Jean de Raymond, French Commissioner for Cambodia, was stabbed and bludgeoned to death in his bedroom at Pnompenh yesterday by a Vietminh assassin who had got employment as a servant, it was announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 (AP)-- Eddie Sawyer, who managed the Phillies to their first and only National League pennant since 1915, signed a new three-year contract today. He announced that, except for two stars, his players are "available for a profitable deal."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 30 (AP)-- Dave Sands, British Empire middleweight champion, scored the fifty-eighth knockout of his professional career tonight by stopping Henry Brimm of Buffalo in fifty seconds of the tenth round of a scheduled ten-rounder.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)-- The present tight world supply situation for wool will encourage further expansion next year in the production of synthetic fibers such as rayon, nylon, Orlon and others, the Department of Agriculture predicted today.
CAIRO, Oct. 30--Messages were sent to all Arab state capitals today proposing an immediate meeting of foreign minister's to discuss a common policy toward the Middle East Command proposals.
The pleasure that Americans will express over the Washington visit of Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh today will be genuine.
Joviality reigned at the luncheon table of the Polo Grounds yesterday as the rival coaches swapped tales about bygone days and relived old football experiences.

The television-radio workshop established by the Ford Foundation will produce as its first television series a weekly film report of the Sixth General Assembly activities of the United Nations, which convenes in Paris next Tuesday.

The redistricting of Manhattan for representation in Congress, to conform to the 1950 census figures and the lowered Congressional allotment for New York State, has been completed. It has been sent to Albany for inclusion in the reapportionment legislation to be ...

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 30-- High Government officials connected with the housing field agreed here today that in their opinion there will be ample funds available next year for private industry to do the essential housing job for the nation.
State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman announced yesterday the tentative allocation of $70,000,000 of state loan funds to New York for a two-year project ...
Freedom of the mind is the underlying theme of Maxwell Anderson's twenty-eighth play, "Barefoot in Athens," opening at 8 o'clock this evening at the Martin Beck.

Doorstep delivery of milk has become increasingly expensive since the war, and the fact that milk prices will rise again tomorrow may prompt some women to ask themselves whether home delivery is worth the extra cost.
National advertising expenditures in September declined 2 per cent from the record established in August, according to the latest issue of Printers' Ink, out Friday.
The $50 window at the Federal tax offices got almost no play at all from the bookmakers yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 30--Bishop Otto Dibelius of Berlin, head of the East German Evangelical Church appealed today for EastWest German talks on unity and declared that his church found the division of the country "unbearable."

PANAMA, Oct. 30--Col. Jose Antonio Remon, Panama's strong man, resigned today as Chief of the National Police, this country's only armed force. President Alcibiades Arosemena immediately promoted Col. Bolivar Vallarino to the post.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--Democrats from across the nation assembled here tonight to ratify tomorrow President Truman's selection of Frank E. McKinney, Indianapolis banker, as National Chairman, succeeding William M. Boyle Jr.

Coach Hugh Devore and his New York University football squad probably were happier yesterday than they've been since they opened their season by taking a shellacking from mighty Princeton.

A $6,000,000 treble damage suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court by the Sunbeam Corporation of Chicago, makers of household appliances, against R.H. Macy Co. and four Macy officers as a result of the price war last May.

PIMLICO, Md., Oct. 30 (AP)-- Senator Joe, who has been a consistent winner for owner-trainer Alan T. Clarke all season, registered his seventh triumph in fifteen starts when he accounted for the six-furlong Towson Purse, feature of today's program.

The nation is still basically in a buyer's market, despite the vast size of the defense production program, several speakers asserted yesterday at the Eastern Annual Conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies at the Roosevelt Hotel.

AN imposing number of new angling records were added to the final summary of world record marine game fishes during 1951, according to the latest list of the International Game Fish Association, which has its headquarters at the American Museum of Natural History.
A routine action in a Cleveland probate court this week marked the end of the legal technicalities left behind by one of the most spectacular series of financial exploits of our time.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 30 (AP) --India will face a famine threat next year worse than in 1951, a Food Ministry spokesman said today.

CANTON, N.Y., Oct. 30--The special grand jury investigation of charges of gambling and official corruption in St. Lawrence County began today with the selection of twelve grand jurors.

Unfamiliarity with the course failed to prevent Regal, a 4-yearold filly, from capturing the main race at Jamaica yesterday. Established the outsider at odds of 22 to 1, Regal wrapped up the mile and a sixteenth Ciencia Classified Handicap under a sound ride by Hedley Woodhouse.

Those who like the look of metal furniture indoors but prefer soft traditional designs to the sharp linear appearance of most contemporary wrought iron should be interested in a new collection of pieces by Richard L. Sandfort.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation reported yesterday for the nine months ending Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $58,431,456 after charges and taxes, equal to E4.83 a share on the outstanding stock. This compares with $46,902,416, or $3.88 a share, in the similar period of 1950.
RAPID CITY, S.D., Oct. 30 (UP) --Former Gov. Tom Berry collapsed and died in the offices of a law firm here this afternoon. He was 72 years old.

Contempt sentences imposed on four trustees of the Civil Rights Congress bail fund were upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals. The four had refused to cooperate in the investigation into the disappearance of four convicted Communist leaders, three of whom are still fugitives.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 31-- Negotiations for a cease-fire in Korea again reached a deadlock yesterday. Subcommittees of two officers for each side argued for three hours in their roadside tent at Panmunjom. At the close of the session each side still insisted on its own version of a line across the peninsula where a truce should be declared.

William W. Remington, former Government economist, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court to a new perjury indictment charging he lied five times while under cross examination at his earlier perjury trial.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., originally elected to Congress on the Liberal party ticket, and subsequently as a Democrat and Liberal nominee, came out yesterday for the election of Joseph T. Sharkey, the Democratic candidate for City Council President.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 30--A public reception was held today for members of the Chinese cultural mission on the lawn of New Delhi's Constitution Club. Not since India became independent has any foreign delegation received such an enthusiastic welcome.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 30 (AP)--A court-martial heard Col. Shirley W. McIlwain testify today he saw nothing wrong in accepting large discounts in eight personal automobile "deals" he made while commanding the near-by Rossford Ordnance Depot.
ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 30--A well-known 825acre Hudson River estate here has been given to Bard College by Christian A. Zabriskie of New York, it was announced today.

PARIS, Oct. 30--Tariff reduction and freer competition were urged as measures against inflation by both Premier Rene Pleven and Finance Minister Rene Mayer in discussing the budget today before the Finance Committee of the National Assembly.

Drivers of buses in operation when the city-wide air-raid drill is held during the week of Nov. 25 will be required to pull up at curbs so that their passengers can disembark and go to the nearest shelters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP)-- President Truman signed today a measure to permit the Government to share certain atomic information with friendly countries. None of the information will involve atomic weapons secrets and the actual exchange will be made under strict security safeguards.

Grateful for the assistance given her by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, the mother of a local high school athlete who was the fatal victim of the disease has devoted herself to an effort to make the forthcoming Mothers' March on Polio a success.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)-- There was a definite trend of Negro population away from the South to industrial areas of the country during the 1940-1950 decade, Census Bureau figures showed today.

When women take over control of election districts, their power will sweep corruption out of Government on all levels, Miss Mary Donlon, chairman of the New York State Workmen's Compensation Board, predicted yesterday.

Return to work by insurgent longshoremen at Army base piers on the sixteenth day of their costly strike yesterday was a good, if belated, beginning, but the strike-bound condition of nearly all the commercial piers still confronts the port with a grave crisis.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP)--The Illinois Athletic Commission said today it would bar Joe Louis from Illinois rings if he decides to continue fighting.

Nadia, Koutzen, an attractive young lady of 21, made what was described as her official New York debut as a violinist at Town Hall last night. While 21 is not a ripe old age for a debut, Miss Koutzen has been playing the fiddle since she was three and a half.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--The 134-year-old Monroe centerpiece and matching gold flatware were taken from storage today for the first time since the White House was closed in 1948. It will be used at the state dinner tomorrow night for Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh.

LONDON, Oct. 30--One of the two fully organized regular Army divisions left in Britain, representing nearly half of the country's strategic reserve, has been ordered to the Near East to reinforce British strength in that restless area.

Witches and ghosts made an early appearance this year for the special benefit of youngsters who began attending yesterday the story-telling hours of the 1951-52 season in New York Public Library branches.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30--Adequate Federal, state and local laws for the protection of the youth of the country were advocated today by Dr. A.B. Price, director of the Federal Security Agency, at the closing meeting of the National Midcentury Committee for Children and Youth.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 30 (AP)-- Franchot Tone, film actor, was in court today on a charge of assault and battery against a woman columnist.
An all-male jury awarded yesterday $140,000 to a widow and three children of a 45-year-old Department of Correction guard who was shot and killed accidentally by a city policeman five years ago.
LONDON, Oct. 30--Prices continued to fall on the stock market today.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 30-- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio called on the South's electorate tonight to vote for a Republican Presidential nominee next year as part of an "all-out campaign against crookedness in governments and influence peddling."

The first evening performance of the sixty-third National Horse Show last night at Madison Square Garden brought ou a distinguished gathering not only of society, but ranking officers of the armed forces and many persons prominent in civic and business circles.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 30--A suit to enjoin Rye Township from interfering with the construction of a $1,000,000 natural gas compressor station in a residential neighborhood was begun today with service of the complaint on town officials. The plaintiff is the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation.

DENPASAR, Bali, Indonesia, Oct. 30--The biggest problem for the young Republic of Indonesia in this part of its territory has been the establishment of peace and order. On Bali, sporadic violence continues but the pacification problem now appears to be virtually solved.

The Atlantic Coast's already trouble-ridden shipping industry faced yesterday the prospect of further tie-up as representatives of upwards of 5,000 deck officers threatened to strike Saturday morning.

Fourteen Girl Scouts, campaigning for Civil Defense volunteers, bivouacked during the noon hour yesterday on the sidewalk in front of City Hall, where they cooked a stew on tin can stoves for the Mayor's wife and a half-dozen city officials while 200 curious and hun gry persons watched.

Top leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations drafted yesterday an official recommendation that Allan S. Haywood, national director of organization, be advanced to a new post that would make him second in command of the C.I.O.

The State of Michigan plans to sell $80,000,000 of its expressway revenue bonds on Nov. 20, it was announced yesterday. The rate will not exceed 2 per cent, but no due rate was named in the announcement. The issue has been approved by the Voluntary Credit Restraint Committee.
BERLIN, Oct. 31 Effective steps must be taken now to reunite Germany, otherwise peace cannot be considered secure, Deputy Premier Walter Ulbricht told the East German People's Chamber today.

The general practitioner holds a key position in the increasing problem of rehabilitating the aged crippled, the third annual scientific assembly of the New York State Academy of General Practice was told yesterday afternoon at the Statler Hotel.

The stock market refused to give ground yesterday and, in the strongest rally in two months, wiped out some of the losses of recent sessions. The reversal of trend was accomplished on only modest bidding. Measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES index, the market rose 1.41 points, although much wider gains were made by some of the high-price issues.
The right of a school district to erect educational facilities in an area zoned exclusively for residences was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department.

Four major points of progress have been made in obtaining European machine tools to ease shortages here, it was reported yesterday. The report was made by John Stokvis, president, Stokvis, Edera Co., Inc., 21 East Twenty-sixth Street, who has just returned from France, Belgium and Austria.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 31 (AP) Don Williams and Johnny Greco fought to a ten-round draw tonight in the Baltimore Coliseum. The judges and the referee all disagreed on the outcome.

The Baseball Writers' Association of America yesterday voted Roy Campanella. Dodger catcher, the most valuable player for 1951 in the National League. With the award goes the Kenesaw Mountain Landis plaque.

The 1854 Park Avenue Corporation, of which Ben Cohen is president, has purchased two business buildings on a plot about 40 by 200 feet at 280 Fourth-Avenue, Brooklyn, from Emanuel and Sabina Gallo. The Inland Steel Company reported yesterday a new high level of sales and operations for both the third quarter and the first nine months of 1951, but said that "heavy taxes and rising costs" had prevented earnings from equaling the records achieved in the respective periods of last year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 The Bureau of Labor Statistics estimated today that retail food prices rose 0.7 per cent between Sept. 26 and Oct. 15, increasing the retail food price index to a record.
A lunch-time recruiting rally for civil defense in Harlem yesterday won 102 volunteers.

LOU BOUDREAU asked for his first managerial job. He was a 24-year-old stripling when he bluntly told Owner Alva Bradley that he should be considered for the post of skipper of the Cleveland Indians. Bradley had never even thought of him. But the more he toyed with the idea the better he liked it. Boudreau was born to command. So he got the job.

The F.M.H. Realty Company has sold a long-term lease on the entire blockfront on the west side of Third Avenue between Twenty-ninth and Thirtieth Streets, opposite the Psychopathic Hospital in the Bellevue group, to an investor. LONDON, Oct. 31 Prices fell more heavily on the stock markets here today with the start of a new bookkeeping account, and closed at the lows of the day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 Princess Elizabeth flew today across a border that she could not see to be greeted with a cordial welcome from President Truman and half a million Americans along the streets of the nation's capital.

The prospects of averting further trouble for the shipping industry on the Atlantic Coast brightened yesterday as Federal mediators won assurances that American Federation of Labor deck officers would take no precipitate action until the issue in dispute had been explored further.

PARIS, Oct. 31 The last meeting of the 1950 session of the United Nations General Assembly, which will be held here Monday in the Palais de Chaillot, is expected to bring still another proposal by the Soviet Union for the immediate admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

The second evening performance of the sixty-third National Horse Show last night at Madison Square Garden attracted a large gathering of prominent persons. As on the opening night, the boxes and arena seats were filled. Many dinner parties preceded the performance.

Acting on a direct order from Mayor Impellitteri, the Mayor's Committee on Unity called yesterday on Sherman Billingsley, owner of the Stork Club, "to issue a public statement, clearly enunciating what the Stork Club's policy is in regard to serving all people without reference to race, creed or color."

Much progress has been made in American Association of Advertising Agencies' four-point program aimed at making advertising more effective, according to Frederic R. Gamble, president of the organization.

Gibson Cowan, English actor, theatrical producer and author of "The Voyage of the Evelyn Hope," has a new book of sea adventures scheduled by Norton for Nov. 9 publication. "The Odyssey of Mister Man" is an account of the cruise of the yacht "Pelican" and...

Former Representative Ellsworth B. Buck, who recently was elected Republican leader of Richmond County, joined three of his fellow county leaders yesterday in predicting that Representative Henry J. Latham, the party's candidate for President of the City...

PARIS, Oct. 31--Gen. Augustin Guillaume, France's Resident General in Morocco, urged the United States today to instruct its representatives abroad to work in "close and understanding liaison" with the French in Morocco.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 (UP) A group of the country's leading scientists, physicians and teachers was named today to a committee to stimulate interest in the United Nations World Health Organization as one means of helping to prevent another war.

New securities offered publicly in the local market in October showed a sharp increase over recent months and a year ago. Large offerings of Housing Authority and Federal Home Loan bonds lifted the total of new bonds to the highest level since March, 1948. Stock emissions were the biggest for any month since March and the largest for an October since 1945.

WINDSOR, Ont., Oct. 31 This border city on the Detroit River was shocked and bewildered today when the Ford Motor Company of Canada, Windsor's largest employee, announced plans to move its assembly operations to Oakville, near Toronto.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 31 (UP) Because Outfielder Willie Mays of the Giants finished in the upper half of his high school graduation class, Selective Service officials today ordered him to be reexamined by his draft board.

BOSTON, Oct. 31 Housewives were urged today to call on the services of pest control operators for advice on how to keep their homes free from disease-bearing insects rather than rely on hit or miss practices. This view was voiced by several speakers at ses-...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) A Congressional eyewitness said today the latest atomic bomb blast over the Nevada desert "looked big enough to destroy an enemy division" on the battlefield.
Commodity futures markets turned downward yesterday. Sugar was a minor exception, closing slightly higher on small volume.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 Following is a table comparing the new withholding taxes that are effective tomorrow with the present levies for persons paid on a weekly basis. "A" designates a single person with no dependents; "B" a married persons with no children, and "C" a married person with two children.
Security issues in an aggregate amount of more than $32,800,000 will be offered to investors today.

Maxwell Anderson's new drama has all the virtues except brilliance and vitality. He calls it "Barefoot in Athens"; it opened at the Martin Beck last evening. In terms of the career of Socrates it speaks a good word for freedom in the life of political societies.
One bright spot in the otherwise bleak picture presented by the current waterfront strike became apparent yesterday.

ATHENS, Oct. 31 The Cyprus question flared up at the first meeting of the new Greek Parliament tonight when a Progressive Deputy, Lukis Akritas, of Cypriot origin, asked Premier Nicholas Plastiras why no mention of Greece's claims to the island had ...

EASTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 31 The outlook appears to be improving in football at Williston Academy. Defeated in its first three games of the campaign, the Blue and Gold last Saturday conquered Vermont Academy, 34 14, for its first victory. The triumph came on the heels of a 13-12 setback by Loomis the preceding week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--Increases in excise and individual income taxes take effect tomorrow under terms of the $5,691,000,000 Revenue Act of 1951.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 24:
Plump spooks and gaudy goblins jumped the broomstick on Halloween yesterday afternoon to haunt each other in Police Athletic League youth centers throughout the city.
An old-fashioned country store or, more a appropriately, a country store as it might look after the ministrations of a modern Manhattan designer opens today at 16 East Forty-ninth Street.

MADRID, Oct. 31 The United States military survey team that has been working here since August under Maj. Gen. James W. Spry of the Air Force will leave Madrid tomorrow, completing one more step in the development of mutual defense relations between Spain and the United States.

The city's revenue from the 3 per cent sales tax in the current fiscal year ending June 30, 1952, will fall short of the $208,000,000 estimate of last June if the present trend of retail sales continues.
The automobile is almost five time as safe as the home, according to accident data presented yesterday at the second annual Safety Institute for Parents and Teachers at the Hotel Statler.

The loudest cheers heard at the National Horse Show thus far came from a crowd of 10,000 last night when Maj. John Russell of the United States equestrian team rode Blue Devil to victory in Madison Square Garden.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 31 The Middle Eastern oil revolt spread here today against United States and British pipeline companies.

MOUNT IDA, Ark., Oct. 31 A leopard, one of several circus animals that escaped in this wild mountain area of western Arkansas, was shot and killed this afternoon. Another leopard, two black bears, one polar bear and six rhesus monkeys still are at ...

All along the main line from New York to Philadelphia yesterday afternoon the sweeping arm wave of railroad men in the signal towers, at the grade-crossing gates, on the station platforms, in the maintenance gangs and aboard oncoming trains sent a hearty farewell toward the locomotive cab of the westbound 1 o'clock express.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31 The State Department has denied passports to a number of United States citizens assigned by the United Nations to go to Paris for the General Assembly meetings and they have thereby been barred from leaving the country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 Frank E. McKinney, Indianapolis banker, assumed the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee today with a firm pledge that he would tolerate no influence peddlers in the organization and a promise to revamp party machinery to make it more responsive to the wishes of Democrats everywhere.

Steve Owen, whose Giants meet the non-winning Yanks on Sunday at the Polo Grounds, scanned his scouting reports yesterday and then took the team on the field to concentrate on pass defense for a great part of the workout.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 243,000 barrels, last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, they amounted to 111,120,000 barrels, compared with 111,363,000 a week earlier and 105,062,000 a year ago.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 31--Criticism of the projected European army, an idea that pleased Germans last summer, is mounting as the leaves and illusions fall.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 1 (AP) General Headquarters communique 1,054, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A.M., Thursday (4 P.M., Wednesday, Eastern standard time):

Plans were filed yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority for two Federally subsidized projects costing $31,168,000 and $20,389,000, respectively, to be built on the upper East Side of Manhattan.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned reactionary yesterday, and prices of active months closed 3 to 50 points net lower than on Tuesday.

In a far-reaching move to wipe out jurisdictional fights within the Congress of Industrial Organizations, unions representing all of the C.I.O.'s 5,000,000 members voted support last night for a contract outlawing inter-union conflict among the organization's affiliates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 Another in the long line of Indiana bankers whom politics has attracted, Frank E. McKinney, was accepted here today by the Democratic National Committee as President Truman's choice for its chairman and commissioned to develop the "new ideas" he is reported to have brought to his task.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad gave an itemized report yesterday of the accomplishments of the late F.C. Dumaine during the three years that he was chairman and president of the road. The report stated that in that period, the cash resources of the New Haven were increased by about $5,000,000, despite capital and other unusual...
Mrs. E. Roland Harriman, a vice chairman of the New York Red Cross, appealed yesterday for hundreds of women to assist with local blood collections.

The third member of the quartet charged with conspiring to steal from $800,000 to $1,000,000 out of the payroll safe at Mitchel Field Air Force Base, L.I., was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court before Commissioner Martin C. Epstein.

THE most conspicuous target among the new books is now the foreign policy of the United States of America. This seems to be a main trend of the year. There is general agreement that the three-speed Soviet terror seeping, creeping and leaping must be stopped. There are many differences of vehement opinion on what's to be done and who's to be blamed for not doing...

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 31 (UP)--Fleeting Moment, a 28-to-1 shot ridden by Arthur Breasley, came from behind in the final strides today to win the 110th running of the Cambridgeshire Stakes, one of Britain's most heavily played horse races.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP) Following is the text of President Truman's welcome to Princess Elizabeth:

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 21 Five-year power contracts between Bonneville Power Administration and major Pacific Northwest private utilities were approved today by Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, and hailed by private power spokesmen as a great step forward in fair working arrangements between the Government and electric companies of the region.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 The major railroads operating in the East and the South today protested to the Interstate Commerce Commission against any grant of temporary authority to Seatrain Lines, Inc., to operate its special type of service between New York City and Savannah, Ga.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 31 Premier Marshal Tito described today the precise limits within which his Government was prepared to cooperate with the United States and other Western powers and the areas in which it could not cooperate with them.

CAIRO, Oct. 31 Three unions of workers for the Suez Canal Company centered in Port Said, Ismailia and Port Tewfik were reported today in the press and from labor sources to have informed company officials they would go on a general strike in a week if the Company did not cease "cooperating with the British."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 W. Averell Harriman became Director of the Mutual Security Agency today after having received a tribute from President Truman. He planned to leave tomorrow for London and talks with Prime Minister Winston Churchill, Foreign Minister Anthony Eden and the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Richard A. Butler.

MOSCOW, Oct. 31 An excoriating attack upon the United States Ambassador to Moscow, Admiral Alan G. Kirk, was published today by the magazine New Times, which characterized Admiral Kirk's address in New York on Oct. 18 as a violation of ...
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 "Jumping Jacks," a story about two night-club comedians who joined the Army's paratroops, will be Dean Martin's and Jerry Lewis' next picture for Hal Wallis and Paramount.

The identification signs were removed yesterday from the outdoor enclosure at the Bronx Zoo where Susie, an 11-year-old giant panda, had spent the last ten years. She was found dead at 10:40 A.M., shortly after she had eaten her customary breakfast of gruel compound. The cause of death is not known.

ROME, Oct. 31 A bill denying to Government employes the right to strike and forbidding all strikes arising from controversies over the interpretation of collective labor contracts was approved by the Cabinet today, and it will be submitted to Parliament soon.

PARIS, Oct. 31 After hearing Premier Ren Pleven report on his talks with French political leaders the Cabinet was virtually unanimous today in approving that every effort should be made to avert a fall of the French Government at this time.

Those who contemplate the political and economic situation in France today must do so with anxiety. The origins of today's difficulties are complex, but they are clear enough. France has never really been strong since the defeat of Napoleon.

The granddaughter of Robert G. Ingersoll, the agnostic who died in, 1899, appeared yesterday in Felony Court to accuse a 36-year-old gypsy woman of stealing $15,507 from her through "the handkerchief switch game."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The Ways and Means subcommittee of the House of Representatives investigating the Bureau of Internal Revenue announced today that it intended to find out why a "very high percentage" of tax fraud cases, recommended for prosecution by special agents, had been "dropped at higher levels."

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 Pinks from delicate cloud to cyclamen, yellows from mimosa to clear calisun, and blues from palest through turquoise to night sky navy these were the color highlights of the Wool Bureau's "Wool in California Colors" fashion show...

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Oct. 31--The Constituent Assembly of the states of Jammu and Kashmir and Ladakh opened here today. The temporary chairman of the body which claims to represent the will of the people of much disputed Kashmir immediately asserted ...

The general board of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A. adopted a statement yesterday asking President Truman to withdraw or Congress reject the nomination of an ambassador to the Vatican.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 31 Caramoor, the palatial Italian renaissance estate at Katonah of the late Walter Tower Rosen, was endowed as a permanent museum and concert center for the public by Mr. Rosen's will, filed for probate here today in Westchester County Surrogates Court.

ALTHOUGH few "outsiders" think of it as an important woodcock area, possibly because those who know good covers keep them a deep, dark secret, the reports on the timberdoodle from New Jersey are excellent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) The award of a contract for 250,000 woolen blankets to Federal Prison Industries, Inc., aroused protests today against the Quartermaster Corps.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 31 (AP) William P. Atkinson, president of the National Association of Home Builders, today pegged housing needs for 1952 at 1,000,000 homes.

In what looks like the most promising development in the Korean armistice negotiations thus far the Communists have at last accepted the United Nations demand that the truce line must run along the current battle line and have proposed a two-and-a-half-mile demilitarized buffer zone based on their version of where the battle line lies.

"Top Banana," a new musical comedy starring Phil Silvers, will make its local bow this evening at 8 o'clock at the Winter Garden. Paula Stone and Mike Sloane, represented in the past by such productions as "The Red Mill" and "Sweethearts," are sponsors of the entertainment.
A pretty collection of daytime and cocktail fashions by Leonard Arkin was shown yesterday in the Empire Room of the Waldorf Astoria.
Prices of coffee futures ran against the trend yesterday as most commodities moved downward.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1--Dr. William P. Shepard, outgoing president of the American Public Health Association, charged here tonight that some factions of organized medicine were trying to impede and limit the activities of public health officers, to the detriment of public health in this country, because they "tend to confuse public health programs with what they call 'socialized medicine.'"

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--General Eisenhower is coming from France to spend two days in Washington next week, and the American people may as well brace themselves for the heaviest deluge yet of dope stories about his political intentions and future.
Both painters and graphic artists are included among those who are exhibiting new work this week.

Addressing a Queens rally in Lost Battalion Hall, 93-29 Queens Boulevard, Acting Council President Joseph T. Sharkey, Democratic candidate for that office, promised last night to work for improved transit facilities for Queens, which he said are badly needed.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 1--When a doorbell rings in this suburban city of 65,000 it may mean that one of the candidates for Mayor has arrived for a personal visit, as the campaigns in Westchester County's liveliest election are being carried to the people in the manner of door-to-door peddling.

LONDON, Nov. 1--For Mary Martin this was "Some Enchanted Evening" and a triumphal one as well. The distinguished audience, glittering with diamonds and swathed in mink, that gathered at the Drury Lane Theatre to see the long-awaited opening of "South Pacific" seemed determined to "Never let her go."
A citizens panel of fact-finders to act in the record waterfront strike in the Port of New York will be named by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner.
WALDRON, Ark., Nov. 1 (UP)-- Arkansas' big polar bear and leopard hunt was called off today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 1--Today's session of the Majlis or Lower House of Parliament was thrown into confusion by a bitter attack on the Government for its alleged failure to take any effective steps to curb the activities of the illegal Tudeh (Communist) party.

CHERRYFIELD, Me., Nov. 1 --Every deer hunter is con vinced that there is nothing so conducive to successful hunting as two inches of fresh snow, but those who roamed the Washington County hills today are unanimous in their opinion that the snow came at the wrong time, for it did not start until 10 A.M. and did not change to sleet until 3 P.M.

Robert K. Christenberry, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, yesterday ordered each licensed boxing club in the state to install a safety pad on its ring. The clubs received thirty days to comply with this directive, aimed to reduce the number of head injuries suffered by boxers who hit the canvas hard.

Summarizing his approach to problems that affect New York's future, Rudolph Halley, LiberalIndependent-City Fusion candidate for President of the City Council, declared last night that the cost of living in the city could be cut down by cutting "racket-laden costs" at the port, its gateway, and reduction and ultimate elimination of the city sales tax.

SELMA, Ala., Nov. 1--Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, called today for a Southwide political action program to defeat President Truman and his Fair Deal followers, but cautioned that "it would be unrealistic at this time for any of us to chart precisely our 1952 course."

One of the most intricate courses ever devised for a National Horse Show jumping event provided no particular problems to the leader of the Mexican Army team, Col. Humberto Mariles, in Madison Square Garden last night.

FOOTBALL moves into the final half of its season this week-end, which is about the only logical move it has made. Perhaps nothing demonstrates how daffy it has been than the result of the Princeton-Cornell game last Saturday. This was a pick-'em toss-up. Princeton won, 53--15. When you get a sport where inspiration counts as much as perspiration, selectors should beware. Since this picker hasn't learned his lesson, here he goes for another whirl.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--The White House announced today that President Truman would urge Congress in January to enact a law that would place Collectors of Internal Revenue under the ... Civil Service System. The President's decision, immediately acclaimed by Democrats on Capitol Hill, was made public shortly after Frank E. McKinney, newly installed as Democratic National Chairman, had recommended the step in a midmorning visit at the White House.

Queens, third largest of the city's boroughs,is witnessing a far brisker political campaign than any of the others. Six well known and popular candidates are vying, three for each post, for Borough President and District Attorney, in addition to the city-wide campaign for the Presidency of the City Council.
Mrs. Caryl H. Sayre of The Creek Club was re-elected president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the annual meeting held yesterday at the Hotel Shelton.

The prospect for a new office building in the Grand Central area was disclosed yesterday when the easterly blockfront parcel on Park Avenue between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets was sold at auction by the city for $1,610,000. The successful bidder was the Tishman Realty and Construction Company of 445 Park Avenue, long active in office anal apartment construction in New York and other area.
The Columbia football team left by train last night for tomorrow's game against Cornell at Ithaca with two of the starting offensive unit in doubtful shape.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--The Temporary Council Committee of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is considering a shift of emphasis in European defense planning that would subordinate longrange objectives to the task of equipping fighting divisions already on hand in the shortest possible time.

Action by the States of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to authorize a tri-state survey of all mass transportation serving the New York metropolitan area was urged yesterday by City Planning Commissioners Francis J. Bloustein and Goodhue Livingston Jr.

MOSCOW, Nov. 1--Moscow's English-language magazine, News, in a leading editorial today called for "great power" negotiations and particularly for Soviet-American negotiations to settle world problems of peace and war.

The unpredictable Mitropoulos opened the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall with the most sensitive and dramatic reading of the "Symphonic Piece" from Franck's "Redemption" that it has been our fortune to hear. It was one of those performances when the interpreter, sensing the composer's innermost intention, realizes it in a degree that the music itself does not always attain.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1-- Benjamin Slade, an attorney here for the last fifty-six years, who was one of the most successful trial lawyers in the state, died of a heart attack today after an illness of several months. His age was 78.

ALBANY, Nov. 1--The state's "Little Hoover Commission" anpounced today that it would sponsor legislation at the 1952 session aimed at an extensive reorganization of the State Board of Regents and the State Education Department.

Halloween is over now, for this year at least, if not, to be sure, forever. The front gate has been restored as a decorative feature of the entrance walk, whereas with the dawn of All Saints' Day it had been discovered high in a tree.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 (AP)-- Peace returned to the San Francisco waterfront today as the issues in a knotty labor dispute were taken under study by the California Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--A revised form intended to shorten and improve the prospectus required for the registration of securities under Form S-1 was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The revised form, the Agency said, will not sacrifice material information but should facilitate its distribution and make it more useful to investors generally.
Alcoholic beverage retailers and their suppliers were in a whirl yesterday and it was not from sampling their products. It was just that nobody knew what hard liquor prices should be.

Increased productivity, especially by other democratic countries, together with enlargement of United States imports, were listed yesterday among needs for strengthening this nation's economic potential and position of world leadership.

MIDDLETOWN, R.I., Nov. 1-- Rain and a forty-mile-per-hour northeast gale drove the St. George's School football squad indoors today. Huge waves and swirling whitecaps were agitating the Atlantic Ocean surrounding the Red and White campus, and Coach Peter Rothermell required only one quick look at them to cancel outdoor practice.
TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 2 (AP)--General headquarters communique 1,055 for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A.M., Friday (4 P.M., Thursday, Eastern standard time):

PARIS, Nov. 1--Although the normal military maneuver season is drawing to a close and the Soviet and satellite divisions should soon be moving to their winter quarters, the Cominform appears to be stepping up its nerve war in the Balkans, a traditionally hysterical area.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 2--The lull along the Korean battlefront became more marked yesterday. With snow covering parts of eastern and east-central sectors, United Nations and Communist forces made very little effort to advance.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 2--United Nations and Communist negotiators reached tentative agreement yesterday on a line for an armistice in the Korean war in the eastern section of the peninsula, from the right flank of the enemy's former "Iron Triangle" of defense to the Sea of Japan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--The Department of Justice said today that a recommendation by the Board of Immigration Appeals that Mrs. Ellen Knauff, German "war bride," be admitted to the United States was before J. Howard McGrath, the Attorney General, for his final decision. There was no indication when Mr. McGrath might announce his ruling.
The variety of objects included in an exhibit now on view at Bonniers, 605 Madison Avenue, gives some indication as to why ceramics have found such wide acceptance for use in contemporary rooms.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 1--Congress passed the third reading of the oil prospecting contract with the Union Oil Company of California last night by 43 votes to 2.

Although many expect that a cease fire in Korea would slow down defense spending, production of weapons at this stage is the lesser part of the defense program, the National City Bank of New York points out in its monthly letter, published today.

The N.B.C. Television Opera Theatre, which has to its credit some fine jobs of mounting opera specifically for telecast, put on Offenbach's "Monsieur Choufleuri" last night. In the new version adapted and translated by Dino Yannapoulos, who also staged the piece, it was called "R.S.V.P."
The deadlock between East and Gulf Coast shipowners and the American Federation of Labor deck officers' union over welfare fund payments continued yesterday as mediation efforts proved fruitless.

Dr. Christian Gauss, dean emeritus of Princeton University and one of the foremost exponents of academic freedom, collapsed and died shortly before 7 P.M. yesterday in Pennsylvania Station. The 73-year-old educator fell to the floor of the concourse and was dead before medical aid could reach him.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1--Long liquidation was heavy and general in the grain markets today, with overbought pit conditions, coincident with uneasiness over the fact a truce agreement may be reached in Korea, tending to unsettle the markets. The lack of any export business of importance also cooled buying enthusiasm in wheat and ...

Plans for the erection of a new business building near the Port Authority Bus Terminal were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by the 317 West Forty-first Street Corporation of the structures at 315-17 West Forty-first Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, from A.C. Stiansen. Razing of the present ...

Phil Silvers will have to look after his health this winter. He is king-pin in a very funny musical show that ought to last as long as he can. In honor of the top clowns in burlesque theatre, it is called "Top Banana"; and it opened with a bang at the Winter Garden last evening.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 2--Tooling centers throughout the country are facing an acute shortage of skilled labor, with more than 5,000 skilled workers badly needed by contract shops alone, it was reported today at the annual meeting of the National Tool and Die Manufacturers Association.

Thirty-three dollars and thirtyfour cents gets you a $50 gambling tax stamp at any Internal Revenue office, but even those odds failed to lure one bookmaker or policy operator when the new tax law became effective yesterday.

Election day will be a holiday for the New York Stock Exchange, the New York Curb Exchange and all New York commidity markets except the New York Produce Exchange. The New Orleans Cotton Exchange also will close. But many states have no elections on next Tuesday and will not observe the holiday. The Chicago Board of

SURABAYA, Indonesia, Oct. 30 --Conditions have steadily improved in most directions during the last year in the productive and populous East Java province of the new Indonesian Republic. In this area the Indonesian administration has shown a growing capacity to cope with the problems of a Government-established basis for social and economic progress.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (UP)--Doug Bentley, veteran center, broke his season scoring drought with two goals in less than one minute in the second period tonight to pace the Chicago Black Hawks to a 4-2 triumph over the New York Rangers before 4,994 fans.

Consumers will find more liberal supplies of pork and slightly more lamb and veal at the butcher shops this week-end, the city Department of Markets reported yesterday. Retail meat prices, however, are unchanged except for smoked ham (regular), which is 2 cents cheaper at 63 cents a pound.

The continuing increases in seamen's wages threatens the extinction of all unsubsidized Americanflag shipping, the Association of American Ship Owners said yesterday in releasing a study of ship operating costs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--An order to show cause why New England Air Express, Inc., an irregular air passenger and freight carrier, should not be forced to suspend its letter of registration immediately was issued today by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

The thirteenth annual convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, opening here Monday, will adopt a resolution criticizing Federal wage controls and making it plain that the C.I.O. will not agree to a no-strike pledge at this time.

PARIS, Nov. 1--The replies to a questionnaire on rearmament, now being prepared by North Atlantic Treaty members, are expected to show that the key to the financial problems involved is to be found in the balance of payments. This applies to the two major European countries, France and Britain, and also to the Netherlands and Denmark.

For voters in different parts of this city there are twenty-four judicial offices to be filled on Election Day. Following our usual practice we present as a trustworthy guide to the merits of candidates for these twentyfour offices a list based on the recommendations made by the city's leading bar associations.

Sol Levy, a referee for the National Basketball Association, was, accused by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan early this morning of taking $3,000 in bribes in connection with three games in which he officiated.

In attendance at the Empire City-at-Jamaica races yesterday were 12,306 persons. Perhaps it is not inappropriate to refer to them as the hard, nutty core of New York racegoing. The day was raw, gray, and windy; the track was sloppy, and the racing was of the type guaranteed to provide nary an item for anyone's memory book.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 1--The crimson blast of another big atomic test explosion on the Nevada desert this morning ushered in a new American military epoch. The bomb was exploded in the first "atomic warfare maneuver" in the nation's history.

Heretofore F. Hugh Herbert, author of the hit comedy, "The Moon Is Blue," has preferred to write plays. Now he is eager to enter the musical comedy field. With the successful firm of Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin, producers of the enjoyable "Guys and Dolls," Mr. Herbert is discussing the potentialities of a show employing the Parisian atmosphere related to the peripd of ToulouseLautrec, noted French painter.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 1--Details of the fatal violence at Parana last night, when a Peronista was killed and Rodolfo Ghioldi, Communist candidate for President, was seriously wounded by gunfire during a Communist rally, were available today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP)--A new set-aside order intended to assure the armed services of enough tasty beef cuts, but without upsetting the civilian supply, was announced today by the Office of Price Stabilization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1(AP)--The Government today proposed a reshuffle of materials quotas for the auto industry so as to increase slightly the supply for some small producers and reduce bigger companies accordingly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--Princess Elizabeth and her husband shook hands today with 1,500 guests described by the British Embassy, which gave the huge party, as "a cross-section of ... American public life." Midway in the two-hour receiving line the couple took five minutes for a cup of tea.

Recovery of the stock market gained considerable momentum yesterday under the lead of the oils and metals. It marked the second consecutive rally of importance after last week's sharp setback and produced a rise of 1.39 points in the composite rate with much larger gains in some selected issues.
LONDON, Nov. 1--Sir Mohammed Zafrullah Khan, Pakistan's Foreign Minister, informally offered his country's services today to help settle the treaty dispute between Britain and Egypt.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 1-- Members of the United States and British Ryder Cup teams completed practice today for the opening of the international golf series tomorrow over the Pinehurst Country Club's No. 2 course.

Central Air Terminal, Inc., presenting six major airlines, including American Airlines, Eastern Air Lines, National Airlines, Pan American Work Airways, Trans World Airlines and United Air Lines, yesterday signed a new lease for most of the space in the Airlines Terminal Building at Park Avenue and Forty-second Street.
Two Long Island bus lines were hit by separate strikes yesterday and their 35,000 passengers, including 4,200 school children, had to look elsewhere for transportation.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Nov. 1-- Nine hundred commuters on the 7:57 A.M. Long Island Rail Road train from here today obligingly sat as a "captive audience" while Democratic candidates for re-election to the Long Beach Council campaigned briefly but thoroughly through ten of the twelve passenger cars.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--The chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, Representative Clarence Cannon, Democrat of Missouri, charged today that the abandonment of the consolidated funds bill system in January had resulted in record waste, confusion and delay at a time when savings, clear thinking and prompt action were most essential.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1-- Gary Cooper, who recently was named by Carl Foreman, so-called uncooperative witness at the latest Congressional inquiry into Hollywood communism, as a stockholder in a new independent film producing company Foreman has been organizing, today issued a statement through his lawyer, I.H. Prinzmetal, saying that he had decided not to become associated with the project.

Indians used to put cranberries in sacks, then hang them outside their tepees to freeze at winter temperatures. Today, more than 300 years later, the freezing of the fresh fruit remains essentially the same. The berries are washed, placed in containers and frozen. They keep excellently that way for some months without either the sugar or sugar syrup usual in processing fruits.

Jurisdictional disputes have been the bane of the labor movement since its inception. They have been costly to employers and employes, have dragged on interminably and have spawned bitter enmities within union ranks. By a bold, imaginative stroke the Congress of Industrial Organizations has agreed upon a plan which aims to end these interunion fights peaceably.

It was probably with the discovery of a sentimental Victorian novel for children called "Castle Blair," found among some books that my mother and aunts had read when they were children. Who was its author I cannot recall, but he created the first heroine I ever loved.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Nov. 1 --The story that developed in the showings yesterday of the California National Press Week swung around fabric and fabric designs. Beauty of materials brought character to the clothes. Styles followed the trends already set in the fashion centers of the East and the South.

Eisenhower's forthcoming trip to the United States, the first the general has made since he arrived here last February, was unexpected--a circumstance that gave rise to much speculation--it was emphasized that no military emergency was involved.

Textile suppliers are maintaining a steady flow of sales by pricing several finished products at cost or below, Worth Street merchants said yesterday. An example, they said, is corduroy, which is selling from 15 to 20 per cent under mid-year prices.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 1--Aggressive diplomatic activity is developing among the refugee groups in Western Germany. This contrasts with past programs aimed chiefly at feeding and housing the victims of the regimes behind the Iron Curtain.

John J. McHugh of 196 St. John's Place, Brooklyn, chief starter of major track meets for more than forty years, died here yesterday after a brief illness. His age was 75.

New York bank loans to business have resumed their upward movement, advancing $10,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. The gain followed a decline of $24,000,000 in the previous week, the first reduction in eight successive reporting periods.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--President Truman has called General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower back from Paris for a series of high-level policy conferences Monday and Tuesday dealing with the North Atlantic Treaty and General Eisenhower's assignment to the Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Powers in Europe.

PARIS, Nov. 1--The United States, Britain and France have encountered rough going in their new effort to bring about the admission of Italy to the United Nations.
