DETROIT, Nov. 4 (UP)--The Detroit Red Wings lengthened their National Hockey League lead over idle Toronto tonight by defeating the New York Rangers in a hard-fought contest, 4 to 2, before 10,026 fans at Olympia Stadium.
MOSCOW, Monday, Nov. 5 (AP)-- Pravda branded today as "absurd" the position taken by the Allied cease-fire delegation in Korea.
The unequal treatment of pension fund contributions in connection with tax deductions is causing concern now that personal incomes have been seriously affected by the new higher taxes.

The New Friends of Music's first concert of the season yesterday was planned primarily as a memorial tribute to Artur Schnabel, but, as it turned out, the dominant impression of the program was that of the triumph of a new ensemble, the Quartetto Italiano.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4 (UP) --Fleet-footed fullback Ollie Matson led the University of San Francisco Dons to their seventh straight victory of the season today, a 26-7 decision over Santa Clara.

Rudolph Halley will wind up his campaign for the Presidency of the City Council tonight with a combined radio and television program starting over WOR at 10:15 o'clock and picking up on WJZ-TV at 10:35 o'clock.
Domestic Relations Court Justice Hubert T. Delany has accused the city Department of Welfare of "usurping" the functions of his court in cases of neglected children, it was learned yesterday.

It is impossible to make reasonably accurate predictions of business and employment cycles. This conclusion is reached in "Conference on Business Cycles," a volume reviewing a recent gathering of thirty economic experts, to be published today by the National Bureau of Economic Research, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4--The Defense Advisory Committee on Women in the Armed Services today advanced plans for the Armistice Week drive for more women in the armed services despite a complete denial of recruitment advertising funds by Congress. The campaign will get under way next Sunday with a radio appeal by President Truman.
Forty years ago today a lot of people in Alameda, Calif., had stiff necks.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP)--The Cleveland Browns synchronized Otto Graham's passing and a smooth running attack for a 34--17 National Football League victory over the Chicago Cardinals before 19,742 shivering fans at Comiskey Park today.

CANTON, N.Y., Nov. 4 (AP)-- The Rev. Dr. John Murray Atwood, dean emeritus of the theological school at St. Lawrence University and former national head of the Universalist Church, died of a heart attack today. He was 82 years old.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 4--Evidence is accumulating that the Social Democratic, party is preparing a legislative proposal to nationalize the basic industries of Western Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4--Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, rejected today the suggestion that his government was pursuing a "neutralist" policy in the struggle between freedom and totalitarianism.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 4-- Opening a foreign policy debate in the Knesset (Parliament), Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett said today that the question of Israel's participation in the West's proposed Near East security organization had not arisen "yet." He implied that the Israeli Government would be happier without an invitation to join.

Mrs. Mary Bain of Miami, Fla., defeated Miss Adele S. Raettig of Hoboken in forty-five moves in the ninth round to win the United States women's chess championship at the Marshall C.C. yesterday. She finished the tournament with a score of 8 -- .

Que., Nov, 4--Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh ended a two-day vacation in the snow-covered Laurentian Mountains, today and returned to their ten-car train to complete their 10,000-mile Canadian tour.
Miss Anneke Lucy Ebert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Ebert of Montreal, formerly of The Hague, the Netherlands, was married yesterday noon to Pvt. Martin Shulman, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs.

Winter seemed to be arriving well ahead of the calendar as the temperature here yesterday dipped to a new low for the date, 28.3, at 3:55 A.M. The previous low of 29 degrees had stood as a record for Nov. 4 since 1908.

It has been a political truism for many years that a light registration in New York City means that any Democratic organization candidate for a city-wide office is virtually sure of election. This year's city registration, 1,909,016, is the lowest since 1943.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Nov. 4-- Edwin Merrick Dodd Jr., Fessenden Professor of Law at Harvard Law School, and Mrs. Dodd were killed late last night when their automobile skidded on ice on the Shapleigh Island bridge and crashed through a guard rail into the Piscatauqua River.

At last, after years of demand for modernizing New York's Topsy-grown patchwork classification of city civil service jobs, and after several abortive attempts to get started, the Mayor's Management Survey has received the Griffenhagen report.

The characteristics of Solomon's playing are these: extreme finish and polish, lovely tonal characteristic, a relaxed and genial keyboard approach, perfect taste in most--but not all--segments of the repertory, a flexible enough mechanism to enable him to make his points without undue stress, a liking for pedal undercoatings and a rare ability to vary weights of tone.

A group of forty-five Vermonters, who are pursuing an "aggressive goodwill" project in furthering inter-racial understanding and harmony, was welcomed yesterday at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street.

LONDON, Nov. 4 (Reuters)-- Alexei Goodovich Badayev, a member of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party and a veteran Bolshevik, died in Moscow yesterday after a long illness, the Soviet official news agency Tass reported in a message received here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4--W. Stuart Symington, Administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and former Air Force Secretary, emphasized today that Russia's aggression could be stemmed by providing the free nations with food and the necessities of life.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 4-- The United States team of golf professionals retained the Ryder Cup as the two-day competition of the international series with the British ended at the Pinehurst Country Club today.

Eight proposed amendments to the State Constitution are being submitted to voters in tomorrow's election. In all districts, both within this city and upstate, they will appear on voting machines above the lines listing the several offices to be filled.
With only one city-wide office at stake, fewer than 1,750,000 persons are expected to go to the polls here tomorrow to register their choice for President of the City Council.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UP)-- Both Republicans and Democrats will keep a close eye on a number of scattered elections Tuesday in the hope of spotting a trend that might carry through to the 1952 Presidential and Congressional elections.

PARIS, Nov. 4--Gen. Charles de Gaulle in an address to the national council of his party, the Reunion of the French People, took the opportunity tonight on the eve of the resumption of the National...

There is still a need for new "rules of the road" with respect to merchant shipping despite Congressional authorization for implementing that portion of the International Safety of Life at Sea Convention of 1948, the American Merchant Marine Institute said yesterday.

A proposed plan for reclassifying the jobs of 86,000 city employes and adjusting their compensation to conform to the principle of "equal pay for equal work" was made public yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, headed by Controller Lazarus Joseph.

ALBANY, Nov. 4--Governor Dewey set up today a nine-member medical advisory board of the State Athletic Commission, headed by former Yale football coach Dr. Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens, in a move to reduce the number of fatal or serious injuries in New York boxing rings.

YONKERS, Nov. 4--William F. C. Ewing, president of the Alexander Smith Company, rug manufacturer, appealed today to members of Local 122, Textile Workers Union, C.I.O., to work closely with the concern to improve its competitive position in the industry.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4--The grain markets had the weakest trend last week that they have had in several weeks, with free selling early this week on brighter prospects for a Korean truce, coincident with a lull in the export trade, and weakness in the stock market, all of which stimulated heavy profit-taking.
Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved to new seasonal highs last week and closed the period with net gains of 118 to 174 points.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 4--The West German Government did not answer today the latest and most challenging Communist proposal on unity, the issue that has become the most important to face the German people since the end of the war.

CAIRO, Nov. 4--The Egyptian Ministry of Social Affairs has sent a protest to the International Labor Organization in Geneva, charging violation of basic human rights by British forces in the Suez Canal zone. The British were accused of keeping Egyptian labor at work by use of force. The protest stated:
First steps have been taken in the New York Stock Exchange national census of the shareholder population, designed to show that Main Street, not Wall Street, owns this country.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 4--The two big topics of discussion in the steel industry last week were: How soon will steel supplies get easier and what is the wage price outlook? Plenty of opinions were being voiced among the trade most of which would have to be taken with a grain of salt.
APART YET NOT AFAR, by Evelyn Benton Seeley (Vantage, $2.50). An account of the author's experience with extrasensory perception.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4--Found --an Army colonel whose assigned duty is to break military secrets and thrust them into the public domain.

A New York detective, for whom a thirteen-state alarm had been sent out, was apprehended last night. He was questioned into the early morning hours today about a series of drug store robberies in which narcotics were stolen.

LONDON, Nov. 4--In its first week in office Britain's new Conservative Government has shown no disposition to rush into negotiations with Iran about the future of the Iranian oil industry, once British-owned.

An aviation weather forecast by short-wave radio has been started by the Weather Bureau here to assist private flyers. The forecast, reportedly the first of its kind, will cover the area bounded by Boston, Albany, Harrisburg and Washington.
DES MOINES, Nov. 5 (UP) Johnny Bright, leading collegiate football ground gainer, reluctantly agreed tonight to follow a doctor's suggestion and play no more college football.

The hospital report filed yesterday by Dr. Francis J. Sweeny indicates that their 37-31 triumph over the Yanks on Sunday was a costly victory for the New York Football Giants. Three regularsBill Stribling, Al DeRogatis and Fritz Barzilauskas suffered injuries that will sideline them for some while, the team physician informed Coach Steve Owen.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 Exports of petroleum products from the United States to help offset the deficit resulting from shutdown of the Abadan Refinery in Iran totaled 144,000 barrels a day in July, August and September, C.L. Burrill, director of the program division of the Petroleum Administration for Defense, said today.

THE gross earnings of Joe Louis from the prize fight industry have been in excess of $4,000,000, a figure which would impress anyone except a Washington bureaucrat. That doesn't mean that he's kept four million. He hasn't, because the net earnings first had to be split down the middle with his managers and then the Collector of Internal Revenue has been gobbling something like 90 per cent of the remainder.

Acquisition of 271,900 shares of common stock of Universal Pictures Company, Inc., was announced yesterday by Milton R. Rackmil, president of Decca Records, Inc. Mr. Rackmil said that his company also would acquire 32,500 warrants to purchase additional stock. The purchase price was not disclosed.

Recent declines in outstanding letters of credit and new drafts drawn in the Latin American trade may indicate at least a temporary dimunution in the volume of new orders for United States exports, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower found out today he could not indicate even passing interest in an historic picture without setting in motion a chain reaction of political speculation.

An attorney of Miami Beach, sought since Thursday after nine persons, including four physicians, were indicted in this city for dealing in black-market babies, has been picked up in Florida, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 Dr. Paul R. Hawley, director of the American College of Surgeons, declared here today at the opening of the annual clinical congress of the college that the proposal for compulsory national health insurance, favored by the Truman Administration and bitterly opposed

Able-bodied young men witn knowledge of and interest in football can put themselves in line for pleasant and reasonably profitable employment on autumn. Saturdays as football officials by communicating with Asa Bushnell.

Ground action In Korea yesterday was focused in the western sector of the battlefront, where United Nations forces continued to encounter heavy enemy resistance. Forward elements of advancing friendly units were nearing their objectives, but heavy fighting was still in progress at the close of the period.

Joseph T. Sharkey, acting president of the City Council, asserted yesterday that the Hunts Point pollution control plant in the Bronx showed a "civic mindedness that is part of the make-up of every person in this administration" and that it stood as "a stinging rebuke to those who seek to defame New York City."

The National Production Authority may eliminate in the second quarter of next year special preferences on critical materials now granted to manufacturers who have orders directly from the armed forces and the Atomic Energy Commission, This was made known yesterday by Manly Fleischmann, administrator of the agency.

Net profit of Coca-Cola Company and consolidated subsidiaries for the nine months ended Sept 30 amounted to $20,988,997, equal to $4.91 a common share, according to the report released yesterday. This compared with $25,339,111 or $5.89 a share for the nine months ended Sept. 30, 1950.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 5 Following are the items proprosed for inclusion on the regular and suppplementary agenda of the sixth regular session of the United Nations General Assembly, which will convene in Paris tomorrow. Explanatory material within parentheses was compiled by the United Nations Department of Public Information.

Four former staff members of the Marguery Hotel's dining room have withdratvn to pool their wit, wisdom and dollars in a new establishment, the Restaurant Laurent, which they have just opened in the Lombardy Hotel, 111 East Fifty-sixth Street. It occupies a site formerly held by the Brussels.

DETROIT, Nov. 5 Joe Louis, dethroned heavyweight champion, was honored by his home town today in a City Hall ceremony denounced by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People as a "political gesture."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 5 Time is growing short for the inhabitants of Indonesia to decide which country they desire to call their own. Involved are roughly 2,000,000 Indonesian residents of Chinese origin, 120,000 persons of mixed Dutch and Indonesian blood.

George Killoran, the now suspended detective who is accused of having robbed Manhattan and Queens druggists of narcotics, was sent to Bellevue Hospital yesterday for psychiatric observation after he had been described in Felony Court as the victim of narcotic addition brought on by the tragic death of his 3 -year-old son.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 The Supreme, Court admonished today against this country's adopting "principles of totalitarianism" and opened the way for a possible reduction of the $50,000 bonds set for twelve persons accused in California of engaging in an alleged Communist conspiracy.

The American Locomotive Company reported today that earnings for the first nine months of this year totaled $4,286,000, an increase of $18,000 over the comparable 1950 period. The company said the increase was achieved despite strikes in the first quarter of the year and substantial increases in taxes.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 6 United Nations and Communist troops engaged yesterday in hard fighting between Yonchon and Kaesong as enemy attacks in that area continued for the second day. Still using tanks, the Reds threw into action elements of one division.

C. D. Howe, Canadian Minister of Trade and Commerce as well as of Defense Production, replied last night to "anyone living outside of Canada [who] has any doubts about the determination of the Canadian people to play their full part in the defense of the free world."

The Union News Company, already beset with a strike at 150 I.R.T. and B.M.T. subway newsstands, had additional labor trouble yesterday when a sister local of the newsstand union sought to picket company-operated drugstores in Pennsylvania Station.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 (AP) Professional football's travelling quarterback, George Ratterman, was returned to the good graces of the National Football League today althouh it cost him $2,000 to become a New York Yank in good standing.

For the second time this year, forty-one Bronx families were made temporarily homeless yesterday as a result of the deterioration of a rock retaining wall between two apartment houses at 2108 Ryer Avenue and 2119 Valentine Avenue. On the order of Edward T. Crinnion, Bronx superintendent, of the Department of Housing and Buildings, the two six-story buildings were evacuated yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 5. --Establishment of a comprehensive Westchester Museum to present "dynamically" the past and present cultures of the county and provide educational and recreational facilities for all members of the family was advocated to the Board of Supervisors today by the Westchester County Association.
Joseph F. Mann, general counsel and a director of the Union Pacific Railroad Company, died on Sunday in his home, 52 Gramercy Park North. He would have been 61 years old on Dec. 2.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 5 (UP) Gregorio Simonovich, the Russian leader of an alien smuggling ring for years, has been "shanghaied" mysteriously out of Cuba and dropped into the arms of United States immigration officers here.
Acute cold kept its grip on the nation yesterday from the northern Rockies to the Atlantic. The Associated Press reported.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 5 The good health of this country apparently lies in factors other than native resistance to disease, possibly in nutritional or sanitary, standards, it was reported here today at the opening of the autumn meeting of the National Academy of Sciences at Yale University.
Schoolboy football moves into the spotlight today, with-a heavy program, caused by last week's postponements, slated for the metropolitan and suburban areas.

The National Manpower Council, in its first policy statement since its founding last spring, announced yesterday that it had initiated a study into the problems of student deferment and would make public its recommendations early next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UP)? The Supreme Court today left standing a lower court ruling that persons who "maliciously" give false information to the Federal Bureau of Investigation may be sued for libel. It refused to review the ruling despite a warning by J. Edgar Hoover, director of the F. B. I. that it might keep people from turning in information bearing of subversive and criminal activities.

Arthur W. Wallander, the city's Civil Defense Director, appealed yesterday for 14,500 volunteers for the fire emergency division of civil defense as he announced that the facilities of the Navy fire-fighting school at Fort Schuyler in the Bronx would be used for the advanced training of the 5,500 already enrolled.
WASHINGTON. Nov, 5 Revenue receipts and expenditures, close of business Nov, 1:

LAS VEGAS, Nov. 5 (AP) The fifth and biggest atomic blast in the current series of tests gave a Nevada town a realistic disaster drill today. In Caliente, the 2,500 residents had an experience such as they might have in a real atomic war.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) The National Petroleum Council estimated today that it would take 3,231,000 tons of steel and cost more than $965,000,000 to increase the availability of petroleum products in the Western Hemisphere by 1,000,000 barrels daily.
Prices for commodities in the New York market, unless otherwise noted, were:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 The spread to the Bureau of Internal Revenue and the Department of Justice of charges or proofs of official corruption in the Truman Administration, and at a time when the Government is beginning to collect additional taxes, has had an instant political effect that earlier disclosures did not.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 5 (UP) A B-29 bomber dropped a new, compact atomic bomb on the Yucca Flat proving ground this morning, rocking the Nevada countryside with one of the nation's mightiest nuclear explosions.
Oscar Natzka, operatic basso who collapsed during a performance by the New York City Opera in the City Center on Oct. 23, died yesterday morning in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 46 years old.

PINEHURST, N.C, Nov. 5 (AP) Gene Sarazen, who has played in more Ryder Cup matches and won more points than any player, said today the British would never retrieve the international golf trophy until they become realistic and field an empire team.

The Little Orchestra Society's second concert of the season last night in Town Hall programmed, among other things, New York premieres of two concertos, each for two violins, in the concerto grosso manner of scoring, works two centuries apart in point of time, and each of them a beauty.
LONDON, Nov. 5 Led by a minor improvement in British Government securities, some of the leading equities reversed last week's trend here today and finished with modest price improvements.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower held a series of conferences with President Truman and the nation's top defense officials today on the arming of Western Europe and insisted to reporters that domestic politics had not been discussed at any time.

PARIS, Nov. 5 Mohamed Saleh el-Din Pasha, Egyptian Foreign Minister, indicated today that his country would not reopen negotiations with the British on the Suez dispute until British troops quit the Suez Canal zone and the Sudan.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 5 Foreign exchange and gold reserves showed a further rise last week of 47,000,000 guilders to 1,313,000,000, making the total gain for the last three months about 420,000,000. During the same period note circulation rose by only 96,000,000.

No papers have been signed, but Chuck Dressen will return as manager of the Dodgers, in clarifying Dressen's status yesterday, President Walter O'Malley revealed that assurances had beeng given Chuck a month ago, on the very day, in fact, that the Dodgers blew the pennant to the Giants.

Henry J. Latham, Republican nominee for President of the City Council, wound up his campaign last night with the charge that he alone of the three major candidates had discussed the issues of city government in the campaign. He predicted that it would bring victory to him in the election today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--A "thick file" of new leads to alleged irregularities in the intelligence unit of the Bureau of Internal Revenue at Detroit was delivered today to the subcommittee of the House of Representatives investigating fraud and favoritism in income tax collections.

A three-man state fact-finding panel, with which now rests the primary hope for a solution of the crippling twenty-two-day-old longshoremen's strike, was sworn in at noon yesterday, and four hours later it opened its inquiry.
Voters of the city, state and nation go to the polls today, probably in smaller numbers than in any other post-war year, to settle a series of isolated off-year contests for public office.

Ted M., capitalizing on an objection lodged by Eddie Arcaro, was adjudicated the winner of the Gramatan Classified Handicap, the mile and a sixteenth race that occupied the feature spot on the Empire City Racing Association's card at Jamaica yesterday.
NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Nov. 5 A policeman and a bystander were killed and a hold-up man wounded critically in a gun battle in a garage during a payroll robbery here today.

With all levels of government assuming the basic financial responsibility for the nation's needy, the voluntary family and children's agencies, for the most part, now focus on other needs of troubled persons.
PARIS, Nov. 5 Lion Jouhaux said tonight that the award to him of a Nobel Peace Prize was "confirmation of the value accorded to the action of the working class in favor of the organization of peace."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UP) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, lit a fresh fuse under the civic rights issue today by announcing Senate hearings in January on a fair employment practices bill.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 In the Supreme Court of the United States today, Alexandre de Baillet-Latour, Arthur D. Wingebach, John D. Calamari, and Canton A. Walls, of New York City, among others, were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 The heaviest early November selling of cattle in ten years broke steer prices 50 to 75 cents a 100 pounds today. Hog prices also tumbled. Owners of Corn Belt feed lots, including most of the principal exhibitors of prime steers at livestock shows, unloaded large numbers of high quality slaughter stock.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 5 Although off to a poor start, Peekskill Military Academy's light and undermanned football squad is geared to make a strong finish this season.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 Uncertainty regarding developments in disarmament took the edge off the demand for gains after all cereals had displayed much early strength. Choppy fluctuations are expected by most traders until after the President outlines his aims later this week. Initial strength was attributed to the unfavorable news reports from Argentina and from Canada.

The provision in the Revenue Act of 1951 making mutual savings banks subject to the corporation income tax had little to commend it, even in theory. In practice, it would appear, it may be about to backfire. And in backfiring it could have repercussions that would be felt even by the Treasury itself in its own savings bond campaign.
The stock market made a halfhearted attempt yesterday to pull out of the depressed area of last week, but efforts proved too mild.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 5 Federal and state legislation regulating the televising of football games was predicted here today if the National Collegiate Athletic Association holds to its present policy.

A parcel of twenty-five lots fronting on 163d and 164th Streets, Thirty-third Avenue and Bayside Lane in Flushing, Queens, have been sold by the Chase National Bank of New York, as executor of the Williams estate, to the Bowne Park Homes Company. The Halleran Agency was the broker. The new owner will improve the property with ranch style dwellings to be offered for sale within the next thirty days.

PARIS, Nov. 5 The United Nations General Assembly put a formal end today to its fifth seslion its longest and most critical by voting down another routine Soviet effort to push the case for representation of Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 Lieut. Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd Jr., commanding the Pacific Fleet Marine Force, was nominated today by President Truman as commandant of the Marine Corps to succeed Gen. Clifton B. Cates. General Gates' four-year term as commandant expires at the end of the year.
James J. Parker of Paterson knocked out George Tsaldaris, heavyweight champion of Greece, in 0:51 of the second round of the scheduled eight-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 Only the continued presence here of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh of Iran and his informal discussions with Assistant Secretary of State George C. McGhee kept alive today the official hope of reaching a basis for settlement of the British-Iranian oil dispute.

The Council of Actors and Chorus Equity Associations went on record yesterday as being opposed to an amalgamation of the Television Authority with any one branch of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, parent body of all entertainment unions, although it favored a merger of all branches of the 4 A's.

PARIS, Nov. 5 The United States, Britain and France called on the United Nations General Assembly today to setup an international commission to investigate the possibilities of holding free elections throughout Germany.
Cotton trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat erratic yester day and final prices were 1 point higher to 12 points lower than last Saturday's close.

ROME, Nov. 5 Forty of Italy's top-flight industrialists on the management-owner level will depart for the United States shortly to attend the first International Conference of Manufacturers in New York Dec. 3-5. They are part of a group of 226 leading Western European manufacturers who will

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) The Navy announced today the appointment of Rear Admiral Roy T. Cowdrey, two-time winner of the Legion of Merit medal for outstanding work in World War II, as commander of the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn.

General Eisenhower returns to Europe today after a series of conferences with President Truman and other topranking officials which are described as having dealt with critical developments in the European rearmament program and presumably with the new armament control plan being considered by Mr. Truman as the crux of a new Western peace offensive.

With the winter setting in and TV, as reported in a recent survey, keeping more and more persons at home, leisure fashions have come into their own. They've moved into the living room, leaving behind any hint of the boudoir.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) American Power and Light Company told the Securities and Exchange Commission today it plans to distribute its common stock in Washington Water Power Company to American's stockholders on a share-for-share basis if it doesn't sell the Washington company to public power districts.

PARIS, Nov. 5 On the eve of the opening of the sixth session of the United Nations General Assembly, usually reliable sources said today that the United States would propose that the Assembly call on all nations to report the number and amount of their armament stockpiles, including atomic weapons, to a United Nations com

Announcing that the city would have to furnish 6,240 selectees in January, Col. Candler Cobb, Selective Service Director here, said yesterday that local boards would have to adopt immediately a "much stiffer" attitude on postponements and deferments.

Surrounded by Mayor Impellitteri and other members of the Board of Estimate, Acting Council President Joseph T. Sharkey appealed last night for election to that office on the basis of his eighteen-year record of "constructive service in your city government."

The National Steel Corporation reported yesterday net earnings of $34,479,198, equal to $4.68 a capital share, for the first nine months of 1951, compared with $43,091,331, or $5.85 a share, in the similar period of last year.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 5 A workshop for training public school teachers in new methods of promoting pupil appreciation of American democracy was opened here today as part of a $1,500,000 nation-wide program financed by the Carnegie Corporation.

No horse ever had won five individual events in international competition at the National Horse Show until Mexico's 13-year-old Arete turned the trick last night. The contest was for the International Individual Championship Challenge Trophy and Arete won it with the redoubtable Mexican team leader, Col. Humberto Mariles, riding before 10,000 in Madison Square Garden.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 5 Under the influence of new and more radical leadership, the West German labor movement is preparing to seek extension in the field of key industries, in which it enjoys by law a 50 per cent share in management and operation.

Millions of Americans will study today's election returns with keen interest. In many communities, including our own great city, the voting will be extremely significant. Yet the outstanding and astounding fact of these elections is that so few people are sufficiently interested to register and vote in them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Assistant Secretary of Defense, who just returned from an inspection trip to the battle lines in Korea, disclosed today that the Army planned to send its first detachment of the Women's Army Corps to that country.

With Election Day promotions featuring prices of men's and women's apparel as low or lower than, a year ago, New York department and leading specialty stores looked forward yesterday to today's selling as a test of consumer buying power.

Irregular price movements characterized commodity futures trading on the exchanges here yesterday, with declines predomimating. Traders generally were hesitant, partly because most of the major markets would be closed today for Election Day.

Sixteen years of labor disunity show no signs of yielding to any healing influences at this time. Indeed, the longstanding dispute between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations not only reveals elements of shadow-boxing for tactical advantage but, even more important, now appears to have reverted to its original status-namely, a strug

The long-awaited account of how Harry Gross, the bookmaker, disbursed $1,000,000 a year as police graft began to unfold yesterday in public, with names mentioned, as thirty policemen went on departmental trial in Brooklyn Borough Hall.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 5 The Yugoslav Government was reported today to be considering making a fundamental change in its economic planning by cutting back its annual rate of capital investment from 28 per cent of the national income to 20 per cent.

THE third and last day of the search for the buck was suc cessful. But carrying the deer through blow-downs and thick growths of popple, as well as over the crest of a mountain, made us wish we had never pulled the trigger.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 6 The United Nations proposed yesterday a new plan for negotiation of an armistice in the Korean war.

PARIS, Nov. 5 Schiaparelli's extensive mid-season collection is stimulating because of gorgeous coloring and interesting detail on slim lines that draw attention to the midriff and emphasize the bust.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 5 Following an exceptionally favorable advance build-up in the Indian press Chester W. Bowles has made an auspicious beginning as United States Ambassador to New Delhi.

The Danish motorship Jeppesen Maersk, the latest addition to the fleet of cargo ships in the Far East service of the A.P. Moller Company, arrived Sunday at Hampton Roads, Va., on her transatlantic maiden voyage.

LONDON, Nov. 5--The whole question of the appointment of a supreme Allied naval commander for the Atlantic has been revived by the visit here of Admiral William M. Fechteler, United States Naval Chief of Staff. The matter was discussed today when Prime Minister Churchill entertained the admiral at luncheon.

The Hoover Commission proposals for reorganizing the executive branch of the Government received little more than lip service this year from Congress and the Administration. In contrast to the real progress made during the life of the Eighty-first Congress, when some 50 per cent of the entire program was enacted, the Eighty-second Congress has definitively accomplished next to nothing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 The Department of Commerce today made its contribution toward a "workable" definition of small business in the manufacturing field. Completing a two-year study, the agency said that a definition of small business must vary with different industries but could be applied to establishments employing 100 persons or less in some industries and to those employing 2,500 or less in others.

Boys' wear sales at retail have shown marked improvement in the last month, enabling merchants to reduce their inventories, buyers at the show of the Boys' Apparel and Accessories Manufacturers Association in the New Yorker Hotel say.

The thirty-sixth annual National Hotel Exposition opened yesterday at Grand Central Palace with large crowds virtually duplicating the 1950 record of attendance. More than 5,000 hotel executives were present, according to estimates by officials. The exposition is sponsored jointly by the New York State Hotel Association and the Hotel Association of New York City.
LONDON, Nov. 5 The legacy of economic ills inherited by Prime Minister Churchill appears to be more threatening than was expected when the British voters passed it on to the Conservatives.

The Automobile Club of New York in an expansion move, has purchased the four-story business building at 1881 Broadway, northwest corner of Sixty-second Street, from the Drosemor Corporation. The Cross Brown Company was the broker.

The reds and golds of autumn leaves in the Adirondacks have been brilliant beyond description this season, but not in all parts of the country has the landscape received such generous daubs from nature's palette.

The Long Island Lighting Company made it known yesterday that it was "postponing negotiations" for the sale of $10,000,000 of new preferred stock, reflecting a possible shift in plans in effectuating a current financing program.

TRENTON, Nov. 5 The end of the caucus rule in the Senate of the New Jersey Legislature is expected to be one of the most significant results of the off-year election tomorrow. The rule has been a chief campaign issue for the Democrats for several years and has been brought to light again in the current campaign.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 5 A House of Representatives subcommittee investigating reported union control of hiring on the billiondollar Savannah River hydrogen bomb project was told by an Atomic Energy Commission official today that the job could not be done without resort to the unions "as a primary source of labor supply."

Dr. Eugenie Clark, research associate of the American Museum of Natural History, has just returned from ten months' study of poisonous fish in the Red Sea. Her findings will be used by the Navy to protect service men stationed in the Pacific.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 5 Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion tonight justified the swing westward in Israel's political orientation when he told the Knesset (Parliament) why relations with the United States had to brought closer.

Under the auspices of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, a Christmas sale will be held all day tomorrow and Thursday afternoon and evening at 209 Madison Avenue. LONDON, Nov. 5 Prime Minister Churchill virtually completed his Government today, naming fifteen additional Ministers and junior Ministers and four members of the royal household. As of tonight sixty-nine posts in the Administration had been filled.

OSLO, Norway, Nov. 5 L on Jouhaux of France, 72-year-old anti-Communist labor campaigner, has won the Nobel Peace Prize for 1951. The announcement was made tonight.

CAIRO, Nov. 5--Fuad Serag el Din Pasha, Egyptian Minister of the Interior, stated today at a press conference that the tension in Egypt that started when she abrogated her treaties with Britain on control of the Suez Canal zone and joint rule of the Sudan was being aggravated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 President Truman accepted today the resignation of Nelson A. Rockefeller as chairman of the International Development Advisory Board, effective at once. Two hundred and fifty political refugees who were brought here from Lisbon in 1941 with the help of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society finally attained citizenship this year and yesterday cast their first votes after decades of wandering across the face of Europe.

JUST as some semblance of sanity starts creeping in stealthily on the Great Autumnal Madness, the weatherman has to perform in completely addle-pated fashion and make it daffier than ever.
