Assuming that he will stop making with the jokes and act normally, this bewildered guesser will try again.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8-- Seventeen Republican leaders of California, including both Senators and seven members of the House delegation, directed a letter today to Gov. Earl Warren urging him to declare his intention to seek the Republican nomination for President in 1952.

An organization of 151 armed guards operating on an aroundthe-clock basis in twenty-four new jeep station wagons will begin today protecting the city's water supply. The new force, equipped with two-way mobile radios, will range over the 1,000-square-mile area of the Catskill and Croton reservoirs.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 8 (AP) --Three major opponents were dropped today from Harvard's 1952, football schedule.

An instance of commercial television gone berserk is, to be found in the program called "Strike It Rich," presented at 9 P.M. Wednesdays on C.B.S. Here is a show that callously exploits human anxiety to sell the products of a soap manufacturer and does it with a saccharine solicitude than hits the jackpot in bad taste.

The flowers on display at the forty-fourth annual autumrn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York reflect all the rich coloring of the season. Yet greenhouses are the source of most of the exhibits for this three-day show in the Colonnades Ballroom of the Essex House.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--The effort of Democrats to induce General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to become the Presidential nominee of their party in 1952 instead of confining his availability to a "draft" by the Republican National Convention has been a much more active and organized campaign than has been generally known.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 8 (UP) --Cary Middlecoff, Memphis, Tenn., professional who six years ago became the only amateur to win the event in its forty-nine-year-history, today posted his second one-underpar 71 to take a stroke lead at the halfway mark of the $7,500 North and South open golf tournament.

A suit has been filed in the Brooklyn Supreme Court to test the action of State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman in using relative income as a basis for preference in subsidized or taxexempt housing projects.

There was a horse race at a mile and a half at Jamaica yesterday. Races at that distance at the Jamaica track have to be started on the big turn, and they're such a rarity that John B. Campbell, a man with a prodigious memory, couldn't recall when the last one had been run.
Municipal hospitals always "get the bottom of the barrel of the civil service lists," Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, City Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday.

Sales of industrial supply and machinery distributors throughout the country are expected to exceed four billion dollars this year. An informal estimate of an increase of more than $700,000,000 over last year's business was made yesterday at joint sessions of the American Supply and Machinery Manufacturers ...

Even at the close of the last century a medical college consisted of a comparatively small building in which a few professors lectured on what was then known of medicine and surgery. The present century was scarcely twenty-five years old when it became evident that many laboratories, schools and special hospitals would have to be coordinated into what we now call a medical center if medicine was to be taught competently.

NORTH ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 8--This year, Coach Leo Cronan has been working With the smallest football group since he came to Brooks School six years ago. Only twenty-two players make up the squad. The result is there have been times when finding eleven boys to scrimmage against has presented quite a task.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8----The United States would play right into the hands of Russia if it halted production of automobiles and other peacetime products, a National Production Authority official said today. If such steps were taken Russia would send out peace feelers to disrupt the American production program, and results would be "chaotic,' he said.

In its first change of ownership in fifty-five years, the five-story apartment house for nine families on lot 20 by 102 feet at 47 East Seventy-second Street has been sold by the estate of Louis Marshall to Frederick Brown.
The Fashion Panorama, a presentation offered last night at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of Interfaith in Action, transported its audience to worlds of furs, fabries and color.

The Norwegian America liner Oslofjord arrived here yesterday with a group of twenty youngsters who will be assigned to various Norwegian ships touching this port in keeping with a program of training future personnel for the country's vital merchant marine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--The Truman administration was trying to do three things with its new disarmament proposal: first, placate its allies, who have been urging us to pipe down a bit; second encourage the Russians to end the "cold war," and, third, give they Allies a better propaganda theme throughout the world.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 8 (AP)--A risk of cancer in flying at 90,000 feet altitude was reported today to the United States Air Force symposium on physics and medicine of the upper atmosphere.

The probability of a permanent radar installation for ships in the New Jersey-New York harbor was indicated yesterday when the Port of New York Authority authorized continuation of the experimental harbor radar installation centered at Fort Wadsworth, S.I., overlooking the Narrows.

Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius S. Lee Jr. of New York and Weston, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Lee's daughter, Miss Barbara S. Davis, to David P. H. Watson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin P. Watson of 50 East Seventy-seventh Street. The wedding will take place early in January.

Scallops are especially recommended now by the Fishery Council because of the good supply and, even more important, the comparatively reasonable price. A glance at City Department of Markets' records shows that sea scallops average 80 cents a waste-free pound.

A young common tern that was hatched on a gas stove in Massachusetts and later featured on a Boston television program was placed on exhibition at the Bronx Zoo yesterday after it had been picked up in a starving condition in the Bronx.

LONDON, Nov. 8--Business slowed again today as investors began cautiously to assess the implications of yesterday's statement by Chancellor of the Exchequer Richard Austen Butler. Prices responded only slightly to his plan to slash imports and to raise the bank rate.

Seasonal influences continue to push business borrowings higher and commercial loans by New York banks rose $8,000,000 last week, registering the ninth advance in ten weeks. Such loans outstanding, according to data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, now make a total of $7,521,000,000--$6,000,000 below the peak reached three weeks ago.
CAIRO, Nov. 8--British forces in the Suez Canal zone will bring in labor to operate the big canal zone base in view of wholesale withdrawal of Egyptian labor, a British spokesman disclosed today.

The National Maritime Union, C.I.O., will press for the prosecution of murder charges against Capt. Frederick D. Weaver in connection with the slaying of William Harvey in Kobe, Japan, on Oct. 25, union spokesmen said yesterday.

Most commodity futures on the local exchanges moved sharply forward yesterday, reflecting the soaring market in cotton following publication of the Government's crop report forecasting a much lower yield this year than had been expected.
TORONTO, Nov. 8 (AP)--Max Mackenzie, Canada's Deputy Minister of Defense Production, announced today that the United States was planning a big expansion in Canadian arms purchases.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 1,607,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 109,513,000 barrels, compared with 111,120,000 a week earlier and 104,350,000 a year ago.

Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, assailed Republican leaders of New York State yesterday for "working behind closed doors" on a "purely political gerrymander" of the state's Congressional districts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP)-- The Government today accused a big Ohio aluminum company of illegally using more than 3,000,000 pounds of aluminum in the first nine months of this year and the National Production Authority immediately started action to force the firm out of business for the duration of the defense emergency.

A 77-year-old woman with snowwhite hair and twinkling blue eyes called on Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, yesterday and said she wanted to pay a "debt." She asked him to accept the crisp $100 note she held in her hand, explaining it was for ...

As Paris is a symbol of European culture and beauty, so the United Nations is the world's symbol of peace. This city has seen its wars, its strife, and its sorrows as well as its triumphs. Since we last met in this General Assembly, there have been tensions and crises and armed conflict in the world, but the cause of peace has prospered in tangible ways.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 8 (AP) --Tar Heel, who shares the world 3-year-old pacing championship, was sold today to the Hanover shoe Farm, Hanover, Pa., for $125,000, highest price ever paid for a harness horse at an auction.
Willoughby F. Brazeau, formerly president of Intsel Metals Corporation and International Selling Corporation, has joined the ore and metal department of W.R. Grace Co.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 8--The three Allied High Commissioners have been forced to refer some of the issues connected with West German sovereignty back to their Governments.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)-- The Navy today announced the award of contracts to seven private ship yards for the construction of thirty mine sweepers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)-- President Truman said today "there's not a word of truth" in a published report that he had offered to step aside and support General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1952.

The Iranian oil negotiations seem to be going in circles, which is a good way to get nowhere. Premier Mossadegh is still in Washington and is naturally reluctant to go home empty-handed. The State Department seems to believe that a dilemma of Mossadegh or the Communist Tudeh party is being presented. The British disagree.

LONDON, Nov. 8--Britain's new Conservative Government is determined to rescue the iron and steel industry from public ownership but apparently will be content to leave coal mining under state control. This was the inevitable conclusion to be drawn from today's debate in the House of Commons on government policy.
Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Ford Foundation, warned last night that disarmament proposals were not enough to counter the Soviet propaganda that the United States was bent on war.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture today estimated this year's cotton crop at 15,771,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight
The streets of Londontown will see quite a parade today, as they have seen it on this day for the past five cen turies. It is the Lord Mayor's day.
PHILADELPHIA. Nov. 8--The Pennsylvania football team left early this evening for Madison, Wis., and one of its most rugged ordeals of the year against the Badgers on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--The Government today took actions to permit price increases for about one-fourth of the country's manufactured goods, veal and lamb and to prohibit automobile manufacturers from producing new model lines.

Although Joel Wyman's "Dinosaur Wharf" first was presented on the rustic trail last summer, Mr. Wyman seems to have been something of a clairvoyant. There is in his play, which had its premiere at the National Theatre last night, a quality of newspaper freshness which should be one of its virtues.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--The appointment of Justin Miller, chairman of the board and general counsel of the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters, as chairman of the Salary Stabilization Board was announced today by Eric Johnston, head of the Economic Stabilization Agency.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 8--An official of the Bricklayers' Union, A.F.L., denied today there was any agreement with the primary contractor on the hydrogen bomb project near here to hire union bricklayers only. But, he said, there was a limit to the number of nonunion workers his members would tolerate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)-- Robert J. Barrett, Superintendent of Police in the nation's capital, argued today that Senate investigators had no right to ask him intimate questions about his financial affairs, including his lodge dues and grocery bills, as well as the finances of his family.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8--The United States must obtain substantially more air power this year to meet the threat of aggression, General of the Army Omar N. Bradley declared here today. "The air battle must be won if the war.

Senator McCarran's success in destroying the nonpartisan Nimitz Commission before it had even begun to work has left his own highly partisan Internal Security subcommittee as the principal operator in the field. This is an unsatisfactory state of affairs.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP)--Eugene Holman, president of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), said today that new oil fields and new technological developments hold the greatest promise of meeting the constantly glowing demand for more oil.

WITH UNITED STATES FIRST MARINES, in Korea, Nov. 6--A large force of marine veterans of the Korean war, most of them here since the Inchon landing fourteen months ago, massed today on the shores of the Sea of Japan in an exuberant welcome to their replacements. Then, in a swift one day shuttle operation, they took off in the same transports for the long voyage home.

Following a Government crop estimate much lower than had been expected, the cotton futures market here advanced the permitted limit yesterday and closed at net gains of 184 to 200 points, or $9.20 to $10 a bale.

President Truman's proposal to send an Ambassador to the Vatican does not "mean a surrender to the Roman Catholic Church" nor does it "jeopardize the American doctrine of separation of church and state," The Living Church, national Protestant Episcopal Weekly, declared in a lead editorial in its Nov. 4 issue.

The Lincoln Lubricating Systems, Inc., of New York, supplier of lubricating equipment, has leased the new one-story building at 48-14 Thirty-sixth Street, Long Island City, Queens, from the 36th Street Lincoln Company, Inc. The James H. Burns Company was the broker.

PARIS, Nov. 8--Egypt said today she was not averse to participation in a Near East defense arrangement but that it must be limited to the Arab states. A spokesman of the Egyptian delegation to the United Nations General Assembly session said his Government hoped that by tomorrow the other Arab states would line up with Egypt in opposing Western participation in such an arrangement.
ALBANY, Nov. 8--The Public Service Commission approved today the merger of three bus companies in New York City into a single operating company with total assets of $28,000,000.

Vito Romano, a suspended patrolman, denied yesterday in Kings County Court that he had propositioned two members of the Kings County District Attorney's staff to obtain data from the prosecutor's files on two policemen involved in the borough's gambling inquiry.

Large industry product inventories should assure adequate supplies of petroleum through the winter months, Rawleigh Warner, board chairman, and L.S. Wescoat, president of the Pure Oil Company declared yesterday in reporting consolidated net earnings of $24,375,000 for the first nine months this year.

Sixty Marines, fifty-four of them veterans of the Korean War and all of them patients at the St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens, gave a pint of blood each yesterday for their buddies in the First Marine Division, fighting in the Heartbreak Ridge sector.
The end of the longshoremen's wildcat strike that had tied up the Port of New York since Oct. 15 was announced shortly before 2 A.M. today by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner.

Shoppers will find most vegetables, as well as several species of fish, more costly this week-end. Heavy rains and winds cut receipts of both. Hit especially hard were locally grown tender crop vegetables, such as spinach, lettuce, peppers and cabbage, which froze in the fields. Prices increased from 2 to 6 cents a pound on the vegetables and from 5 to 10 cents on fish, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

GENEVA, Nov. 8--Denmark Sweden and Norway are the only Western European countries doing more business with Eastern Europe than before World War II, according to figures published here by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.
Lawrence Peter (Yogi) Berra, durable and hard-hitting catcher of the world champion Yankees, yesterday was named the American League's most valuable player of 1951.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8--The prompt Russian rejection of the disarmament proposals together with an unexpectedly bullish cotton report turned all grains strong and caused a near stampede of shorts in soybeans.

The stock market made a wavering rebound yesterday and closed with a gain of a small fraction. Price changes in major divisions were highly mixed and the trading was so slow that it could give no real indication of any major change in the trend.

Yesterday in Korea, United Nations ground forces continued to maintain positions and patrol. In the west-central and east-central sectors, several small enemy probing attacks were repulsed by friendly elements. United Nations tank and tank-infantry reconnaissance forces continued to seek out enemy defenses, encountering scattered resistance from small hostile groups and destroying bunkers and inflicting numerous casualties on the enemy.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8--Overspending by Government and private organizations and individuals is putting a dangerous--strain on the country's economy, C. Francis Cocke, president of the American Bankers Association, said today. He spoke at the opening session of the association's Midcontinental trust conference.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 8--President Truman flew into Key West today for the tenth time, planning to work and play here for at least five weeks, his longest absence from Washington since he assumed the Presidency in 1945.
HALIFAX, N.S., Nov. 8--The Duke of Edinburgh, in what amounted to a "farewell address" to the people of Canada, took notice today of persistent criticism of the royal tour.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 8-- John and Roy Boulting, England's twin brother film-making team, have come to an agreement in New York with Dore Schary, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's production chief, on their first picture for the studio under their writer-director-producer contract.

Grafting policemen had such a stake in keeping Harry Gross in the bookmaking business that they lent large sums of money to the racketeer when he was strapped for cash, according to testimony given yesterday at the departmental trial of thirty suspended members of the Police Department. Two alleged loans totaling $23,000 were cited.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 8--The anti-United States issue was revived today as a major issue for the last three days of the peronista campaign before Sunday's general elections. The anti-Yankee drive is getting top billing on the radio, in newspapers and in posters with the illness of Senora Eva Peron, who is recuperating in a hospital from a major operation undergone last Tuesday.

The 18,000-ton liner La Guardia, the only American ship providing regularly scheduled passenger service between here and Israel, will be returned to the Government at the end of her last voyage on Dec. 12, it was announced here yesterday by American Export Lines, operators of the vessel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)--Sitat-home football fans put up a rising howl today against a scheduled "blackout" of major college football television affecting twelve cities in the Midwest, South and East this week-end.
Thinking that women who make their own clothes must have a certain amount of creative imagination, B. Altman's is holding a series of demonstrations to show the weaving processes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--Seven American Jewish leaders presented to the State Department today a declaration demanding that Germany make "practical amends for the staggering material losses inflicted upon Jewry by the Hitler regime."

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 9--The United Nations Command formally rejected yesterday the latest Communist proposal for an armistice line in the Korean war and again pressed for acceptance of its own program, presented to a military subcommittee at Panmunjom last Monday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP)--A poll of 2,188 weekly newspaper editors disclosed today that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was their first choice for President in 1952 but that most of them believed President Truman would be re-elected.

Plans are going forward for the Winter's Eve dance, to be held on the night of Nov. 30 at Sherry's for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association. Mrs. C. Frank Reavis is president of the beneficiary, which is aiding the campaign against air pollution and striving to maintain clean streets throughout the city.

New issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling $24,070,000 will be offered to investors today by banking syndicates. Two of the issues were sold to the bankers at competitive bidding yesterday.
Within twelve hours after the Western Powers had presented their new armament reduction plan as an alternative to a continuing race in armaments, the Soviets in effect rejected it sight unseen.

Although New York's longshoremen will return to work in full force today, the effects of the long waterfront strike probably will be felt in American homes for some time to come, observers predicted after the back-to-work agreement was announced.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 8--Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, said today that he would conduct a public hearing in the controversy over proposals to control lawyers who represent Indian tribes. A special committee of the American Bar Association, meanwhile, assailed the majority of the proposals.

The American Fair Trade Council pledged an all-out fight yesterday to persuade Congress to enact legislation making so-called "fair trade" laws enforceable. The organization, which represents thousands of manufacturers who fix retail prices of their products in forty-four states, failed to indicate, however, what specific measure or measures it advocates.
Mrs. Louis Guerineau Myers of 755 Park Avenue, former national vice president of the Girl Scouts of America, died here yesterday after a brief illness.

Putting aside their helmets, firemen in Queens donned aprons yesterday to learn how to diaper and bathe babies. The occasion was the third session of an American Red Cross home nursing course in "mother" and baby care.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 8--One of the least publicized economic problems in West Germany is what would happen to the present prosperity of the Federal Republic should unity somehow be achieved.

While the issuance of traffic summonses in Yonkers zoomed to a record 458 on Wednesday, a former mayor of that city noted yesterday that police diligence could have been inspired by "vindictiveness" over defeat of a referendum in Tuesday's election that would have raised the salaries of policemen by $500 a year.

IN the ruins of Budapest and the rubble of Warsaw Alexandra Orme watched the deaththroes of a civilization and the birthpangs of a new and frightening society. That was in 1945 and 1946, shortly after her adventures coping with the amorous inclinations and innocent vandalism of Russian soldiers which Mrs. Orme described so wittily and well in her "Comes...
Petitions for higher bus fares were filed yesterday by two Public Service transportation compa nies in New Jersey and by the Third Avenue Transit Corporation in Westchester County.

Rudolph Halley will lose no time in taking office as President of the City Council, a post that he won at last Tuesday's election by a plurality of 163,492 over Joseph T. Sharkey, the Democratic candidate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--When a reporter for a journal of high standards and a politician or some other variety of public person become principals in a dispute involving the credibility of the source of a news story the basic difference between their professional canons is strikingly revealed.

The case of Cpl. Irving Wiener of the Air Force, 21 years old, who was accused by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation of being one of four involved in planning a $1,000,000 payroll robbery at Mitchel Field Air Base, was dismissed yesterday when he was arraigned before United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn Federal Court.

VIENNA, Nov. 8--Austria, which had applied for $190,000,000 of Marshall Plan aid during the 19511952 fiscal year and had been cut to $106,000,000, is to get an additional $25,000,000 or $30,000,000 from Washington, but on a new basis of "good behavior."

WASHINGTON, Nov.8(AP)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a, reorganization of the capital structure of the American Foreign Power Co., a subsidiary of Electric Bond and Share Co. The proposed change still must get Federal court approval.
EUSTIS, Fla., Nov. 8 (AP)--Walter Irvin, a 23-year-old Negro, said tonight that a deputy sheriff had fired a bullet into him while he lay wounded from two shots fired by Sheriff Willis McCall.

THE New Jersey waterfowl season will open at noon to day and reports from Port Monmouth Bay on the north to Great Egg Harbor Bay on the south, as well as the marshes along Delaware Bay, indicate that this should be one of the most interesting seasons in years for the wildfowler.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 8 --The exorbitant prices of foodstuffs after the first week of operation of a relatively free market in Yugoslavia indicate that the peasants so far have not responded to the Government's policy of deflation.

The Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind, which is seeking $425,000 to meet its operating costs for the current year, opened its fund-raising campaign last night with a dinner in the Lighthouse auditorium, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street. The campaign will continue through Dec. 31.

Ten radio stations specializing in serious music have set up a joint sales organization to be known as the "Good Music Broadcasters." Its purpose will be to make available to advertisers programs of good music on a national basis, although the stations will not be linked by land-line in the sense of a network.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8--An experimental technique in which oxygen has been introduced directly into the blood stream of animals, while their lungs were breathing in pure nitrogen, was described here today at the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 (AP)--An upset was provided in Pimlico's Mount Royal Purse today when Cary C. Boshamer's King Clover came on with a late rally to win the six-furlong test by a head over Brazen Brat.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 9--In four jet battles over Northwest Korea yesterday United Nations fliers destroyed one MIG, damaged two others and apparently damaged two more as the Communists used what was believed to a record number of their MIG-15's in one day's fighting.
Governor Dewey expressed dismay last night over recent trends in this country that discourage both earnings and savings necessary to create new capital.

Headed for the Broadhurst is the revival of a melodious show, "Pal Joey," the combined product of Richard Rodgers, Lorenz Hart and John O'Hara. Last scheduled for early January, the opening has been moved up to Dec. 27 by Jule Styne, sponsor of the production, in association with Anthony B. Farrell.

Sixty million steel drums are being reconditioned and reutrned for use each year, Morris Hershson, president of the National Barrel and Drum Association, declared yesterday at the opening sessions of the trade organization's threeday annual convention, held at the Statler Hotel.

With children in many places attending school in shifts, recreation workers must reconsider what is meant by an "after school" program, Mrs. Adele S. Mossler, director of the Play Schools Association, said yesterday. For some youngsters "before school" now means all morning; for others "after school" means the entire afternoon, instead of the hours from 3 o'clock on.

Amid the generally pallid and listless company that inhabit City Hall Mr. Halley certainly has a major opportunity to stand out by contrast. He has little competition for leadership in any field of city government to which he applies his talents, in investigation, legislation, defects of administration or the search for economy and efficiency.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8--The International Amphitheater on Chicago's South Side was picked today as the site for both national political conventions here next July in a closed session of Republican and Democratic leaders. The decision will give this city its first big air-conditioned convention hall.

Student, teacher, sports and religious groups, their members numbering up to 50,000 persons, have already inquired about the tourist class air service to be instituted across the Atlantic next spring, Willis G. Lipscomb, Pan American World Airways vice president in charge of traffic and sales, said yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 8--Despite strong Arab protests, the Western powers tried today to get an indefinite postponement of Arab League charges that the French were guilty of violating freedoms and human rights in their Moroccan protectorate.

OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 8 (UP)-- The United States' touring baseball All-Stars were held to an eleven-inning 2-2 tie by the Pacific Professional League All-Stars today before a surprised crowd of 25,000. The game was halted because of darkness.
Six defense motions attacking the indictment of seventeen Communists arrested last June were argued for five hours yesterday before Federal Judge Edward A. Conger, who reserved decision.

Credit losses by the fur industry in 1951 will be greater than in any year since 1932, it was predicted last night by Alexander Macleod, executive director of the American Fur Merchants' Association, Inc. For the period between Dec. 1, 1950, and Oct. 23, 1951, he reported, insolvencies in New York and other parts of the country amounted to $7,540,542, compared with $8,390,836 in the twelve-month period ended on Nov. 30, 1850.

An American newspaper, The Trenton Times, in cooperation with Latin-American publishers, has bought a Michigan paper mill for the express purpose of sending its estimated 25,000 ton a year output to Latin America to relieve the newsprint shortage there, it was announced yesterday.
Two exhibitions of sculpture and a group show of paintings are among the interesting attractions of this crowded week in metropolitan art galleries.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 8--A major operation has been performed on some of the back yards of this city's blighted business district to revitalize the area and to correct an acute dangerous traffic and parking problem.

Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Toxin told they Congress of Industrial Organizations convention yesterday that the wages of nearly half of the nation's workers had lagged behind the rise in living costs in the first year and a half of the base period for fixing Federal wage controls.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)-- The Government halted the stockpiling of tin today so that all available supplies can go to industry. It also announced further cuts will be made in civilian use of the metal.

The urge to cross the Atlantic in a small boat seems to crop up among adventurous men every few years. Within the past twelve months three such tiny vessels have reached New York, and the resourceful and daring seamen who manned them have had their day of newspaper acclaim and slight monetary reward.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 8--A motorist was about to park in Capitol Plaza today when a Capitol policeman stepped up and asked him to take down the Confederate battle flag that flew from the radio antenna of his car.

With total revenues reaching $78,245,329, highest for any ninemonths period in its history, the Burroughs Adding Machine Company and its United States operating subsidiaries increased earnings by $1,869,580 over the first three quarters of 1950.
Sixty-three-year-old Irving (Waxey Gordon) Wexler showed no desire yesterday to admit he was a fourth offender and subject to life imprisonment.

LONDON, Nov. 9--Britain, which has not had any United States monetary aid for nearly a year, has made a bid for a share in the funds that the United States is to allocate soon to its partners in the Western defense alliance.

Edward P. Mauder, manager of the New York branch of the Cadillac Motor Car Division of General Motors, died Thursday night of a heart attack, in his home at 523 Stellar Avenue, Pelham Manor, N.Y. His age was 63.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 9-- Clarence Mitchell, director of the Washington headquarters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, speaking in this "white supremacy" stronghold tonight, warned ...

Administrative officials of professional schools in this state expressed opposition yesterday to "accelerating" college courses of study from four to three years as was done widely during World War II.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 9 (AP) --Tommy Bolt, 33-year-old native Oklahoman who registers out of Durham, N.C., today added a oneunder-par 71 to previous rounds of 71 and 72 and moved into a onestroke lead after fifty-four holes of the $7,500 North and South open golf tournament with a total of 214.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 9-- India's Communists have come out of hiding to contest the first national elections this winter, but they have been unable to convince a skeptical Government of their peaceful intentions.

A basketball double-header, presenting four of last year's leading professional clubs, takes over at Madison Square Garden tonight, with the Knickerbockers opening their home National Association season.

Opening today at the Stanley is "Miners of the Don," a Sovietmade drama in color directed by Leonid Lukov, with Boris Chirkov featured. Dialogue of the Artkino Pictures release is Russian and there are English subtitles.
Vito Romano, 47-year-old suspended patrolman, was found guilty yesterday in Kings County Court of perjury in the first degree.
Reflecting the decline in demand that has persisted in recent months, prices of paper-container and related materials were reported by trade sources yesterday to be taking another drop.

Arthur W. Wallander, Civil Defense Director, began yesterday the distribution of 2,000,000 posters setting forth the rules for the public to follow in both an actual air raid and the public drill in the week of Nov. 25.

Governor Dewey has agreed tentatively to call a special session of the State Legislature for Monday, Nov. 26, to act on Congressional reapportionment if a special committee studying the subject is ready to report by then.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 (AP)-- All-America Jim Thorpe, flat broke, underwent successful surgery today for removal of a cancerous growth on his lower lip.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)-- The National Production Administration has under consideration, for probable early action, a request that it extend indefinitely a permit to the New England Steel Development Corporation, to build a $228,000,000 ...

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 9-- The economic outlook for Indonesia is a source of concern for officials here despite the high money value of this year's foreign trade and the relatively satisfactory budgetary position.

A college-girl ballot cast on current fashions yesterday at Abraham Straus gave acceptance to the short formal dress even for important occasions. The vote was 27 to 8 in favor of the dress that shows the ankles and does not hang below coats.

IN November, one hundred years ago, Herman Melville was cheerfully minding his own business at his country house in the Berkshires. "For some days past busy engaged in the woods with axe, wedge and beetle," he wrote his friend, Evert Duyckinck, "the Whale had almost completely slipped me for a time ( I was the merrier for it) when Crash! comes Moby Dick himself ...

Representatives from more than 300 member organizations of the United Parents Associations raised questions and suggested answers, argued points and discussed theories on some causes of family dissension Thursday night at their headquarters, 115 East Seventyseventh Street.
Coley Wallace finished strong to earn the decision over Aaron Wilson of Birmingham in the star bout of ten round's at Madison Square Garden last night.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 10-- United Nations and Communist negotiators met for the seventeenth time today in their roadside tent at Panmunjom to discuss the deadlocked question of an armistice line for the Korean war.
The development of synthetic resins and new types of pigments have enabled paint manufacturers to overcome serious problems in reconditioning used drums and barrels.

Philip Murray was re-elected yesterday to his twelfth term as president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations a short time after convention delegates had cheered an attack on General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as a Presidential candidate.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9--Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, indicated today that he might oppose Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio for the Republican Presidential nomination if General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower did not seek the nomination.

LONDON, Nov. 9--Likening Britain's present food situaion to that which existed during the grimmest period of the war, in 1941, Maj. Gwilyrn Lloyd George, the new Food Minister, had nothing but gloom to offer housewives today.

PARIS, Nov. 9--The French Government intends soon to make cuts in imports, more drastic proportionately than those made by Britain, to meet a crisis that is considered the most serious that France has faced since 1947, when the United States granted emergency aid.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 9-- There are many big football games scheduled for the East tomorrow but, as far as the students at Andover and Exeter are concerned, the most important will be at Exeter, N.H., where the two Phillips academies will continue the nation's oldest schoolboy rivalry.
Harry Gross, convicted Brooklyn bookmaker, yesterday handed the Police Department its sharpest setback to date in the departmental trial of thirty policemen on charges of collusion with gamblers.
Pressure on the stock market was relaxed yesterday and prices responded with the best gains in more than three months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--Regulations designed to prevent influence and favoritism from entering into contracts for $25,000,000,000 to $30,000,000,000 of defense materiel and supplies are under preparation and due for strict enforcement.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9--With Industry turning more and more to universities for skilled personnel, Dr. Lawrence A. Kimpton, chancellor of the University of Chicago, said today that industry should increasingly aid in independent education ...

Soviet industrial production has made substantial strides in 1951, but its rate of increase is lower than last year's. This is revealed by analysis of the speech made by Lavrenti P. Beria, Politburo member, in Moscow last Tuesday, a full copy of which has just reached this country.

PARIS, Nov, 9--Yugoslavia formally brought her troubles with the Cominform countries before the United Nations today by accusing the Soviet Union and six of its Eastern European backers of creating a dangerous situation by conspiring to overthrow Premier Marshal Tito's Government.
LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP)--A member of Parliament demanded an official inquiry today into the removal of a baby from this country by Jane Russell, film actress.

PARIS, Nov. 9--Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States Ambassador at Large, asserted today that the United Nations General Assembly itself constituted a disarmament conference and chal lenged the Soviet Union to start talks here now rather than insist on a special disarmament conference next year.
Four of the current exhibitions of work by contemporary painters again demonstrate the differences between individual approaches to somewhat similar subject matter.
Unlike today, the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries produced card tables that were works of art. Card and gaming tables occupied important places in a room's deoor.

Industry has an important interest in basic research and should not leave to the Government the entire burden of acquiring "new" knowledge, according to Alan T. Waterman, the first director of the newly created National Science Foundation.

Warning against any surrender of our shipping industry to that of other nations, Vice Admiral E.L. Cochrane, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, declared yesterday that "a great nation which depends solely upon foreign flag ships for its essential imports and exports is in a precarious situation."

PARIS, Nov. 9--Yesterday's verbal duel between Mr. Acheson and Mr. Vishinsky continues to echo in the big bare lounge where delegates exchange comments as they pass in and out of the strangely quiet and highly charged meetings of the United Nations General Assembly.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9--The Board of Regents of the American College of Surgeons today adopted a report condemning five prevalent forms of fee-splitting, including what is known as "ghost surgery." The board warned that greater efforts were being planned to eliminate the evil.

Prayers for world peace and better understanding among all peoples will be said by members of 431 Young Women's Christian Associations in this country and those in sixty-five other nations during World Fellowship Week, which starts tomorrow.

PORT ANGELES, Wash., Nov. 9 (UP)--Thirty survivors of the grainship George Walton arrived here today and described their "nightmarish struggle" to survive in lifeboats whipped about by twenty-foot waves after they had abandoned ship.

ALBANY, Nov. 9--State Administration leaders predicted today that high tax returns, coupled with strong legislative resistance to spending demands, would enable the state to avoid new or increased taxes in 1952.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9--Production of military items has reached a rate of $1,500,000,000 a month but this is not enough, Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, said today at a luncheon meeting of the Executives Club of Chicago.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association, bowing to heavy pressure, changed its mind again yesterday and decided to let the Michigan State-Notre Dame football game be telecast in the Washington area.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent for the week ended Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)-- The Government pared its estimate of the year's crop slightly today as the result of damaging drought, freezes and other bad weather in October.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 10-- Ground fighting along the Korean battlefront subsided yesterday to the point where the Eighth Army did not have to withstand a single heavy attack. Eighth Army headquarters indicated that even behind the Communist lines there were no apparent signs of a build-up.

The four-story apartment house at 930-32 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, accommodating twenty-three famililes, has been sold by George Sekuler to William Pollinger in a transaction negotiated by Harry Miloff as broker.
Adolescence, sometimes called "the forgotten years" in mental health, received new recognition yesterday.
Offense was stressed by the New York Football Giants yesterday in their final hard drill preparatory to tomorrow's contest with the Washington Redskins at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)-- The Defense Department identified today 546 more casualties in Korea, including 102 killed, 403 wounded, 24 missing in action and 17 injured in combat accidents. The following were from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut).

Traffic summonses continued to fall like confetti yesterday on hapless motorists in Yonkers and in Bridgeport, Conn., in a renewal of a crackdown that has been attributed to "vindictiveness" over defeat of police salary rise referendums in Tuesday's elections.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 9--As revealed by administrative plans, the Office of the United States High Commissioner for Germany should be succeeded by a formal embassy by next spring. The final reduction in the strength of the present force and the reorganization to conform with ordinary embassy requirements have been initiated.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced the 200-point limit on all active months again yesterday.

The commodity futures markets generally were lower yesterday. Reflecting prospects of a much lower cotton yield, cottonseed oil futures again recovered and soybean oil contracts sold higher. Both wool tops and wool futures moved irregularly.
Domestic steel mills produced more raw steel in October than in any other month in the industry's history.

LONDON, Nov. 9--Britain's destiny is inevitably bound to that of the United States, Prime Minister Churchill said tonight at the Lord Mayor's dinner at the Guildhall, traditionally a place where Prime Ministers make major statements of policy outside Parliament.

Magazine billings in October totaled $56,600,000 for all general and farm magazines included in the Publishers Information Bureau Service, it was reported yesterday by the Magazine Advertising Bureau.

When literally translated from French, demi-tasse means half-cup, as most Americans know. The Snow Crop division of Clinton Foods, Inc., signed yesterday in Tampa with the Florida Citrus Exchange, Inc., the largest contract on record for the processing and marketing of a quarter of Florida's bumper crop of oranges and other fruits.

THE Vermont whitetail season will open on Wednesday the 14th for its annual two-week run, and according to the reports flowing down from the rolling hills the deer herd is larger than usual and hunting conditions excellent.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--The Salary Stabilization Board made public today its policy on Christmas bonuses this year, liberalizing somewhat existing interpretations.

PARIS, Nov. 9--France won her first major political test of the current United Nations General Assembly today when the fourteen-member General Committee recommended an indefinite postponement of hearing the Arab charges against French rule in Morocco.

Last of the local season's big stakes, the $50,000 added Butler Handicap highlights today's Empire-at-Jamaica program at the Baisley Boulevard course, where the New York campaign will end on Thursday.
In February, 1950, New York City retained Dr. Wallace E. Howell, Harvard meteorologist, to bring down rain and thus replenish the more than half empty Catskill reservoirs.

While Southern California and Stanford and Notre Dame and Michigan State are squaring off in the games commanding paramount attention today, the best scrap of the local college season is offered to New York football clients in the meeting between Dartmouth and Columbia at Baker Field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--The United States Government, steadfastly silent so far, is expected by some of its officials to make its first formal statement next week on the status of efforts here to mediate the prolonged BritishIranian oil dispute.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--Federal Judge James R. Kirkland refused today to enjoin the District of Columbia Commissioners from enforcing their order requiring about 350 policemen to answer a questionnaire issued by a Senate subcommittee investigating crime here.

PARIS, Nov. 5 (By Airmail)-- A Paris white collar worker recently made an observation regarded as increasingly typical of thinking within a wide section of the French people.

CLAREMONT, Calif., Nov. 9 (AP) --Dr. George Albert Coe, nationally known authority on religious education, died today at the age of 89.

PARIS, Nov. 9--The Western Big Three foreign ministers agreed today to postpone the meeting of the North Atlantic Council in Rome scheduled for Nov. 24 and to hold an interim session in Paris on that date instead.

Two men taken into custody Thursday in connection with the theft of $1,500 worth of marine equipment from a Brooklyn pier were named yesterday as suspects in the disappearance of more than a half-million dollars' worth of merchandise from the Brooklyn waterfront during the last twoand-a-half years.

A property in the Chelsea section of Manhattan passed to new control with the sale by the estate of Francis McCabe of the threestory rooming house at 450 West Twenty-fifth Street which had been in the hands of the sellers for seventy-three years.

A brazen thief stole a truck containing an estimated $35,000 worth of furs in midafternoon yesterday outside the St. Regis Hotel as shoppers hurried by unaware.

James M. Trenary of the Riverside (Conn.) Yacht Club was elected president of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound at the annual meeting in the New York Yacht Club last night.
DENVER, Nov. 9 (AP)--A committee of industry advisers to the Navy has concluded that exploration for oil in Naval Reserve No. 4 in Alaska should continue.
Army made a clean sweep of the top honors in the thirteenth annual Heptagonal cross-country championships yesterday.

The hopes of fund raisers for educational and charitable institutions were buoyed last night when Beardsley Ruml, New York economist, said that American business could contribute more than $2,000,000,000 for such purposes, or else pay it in taxes.

NEWARK, Nov. 9--One hundred policemen, equipped with flood lights, were believed tonight to have cornered two gunmen who wrecked their blue convertible after staging five holdups here, killing a special policeman and making off with at least $11,000.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 9--Charles Phelps Taft, a son of former President William Howard Taft and a brother of Senator Robert A. Taft, formally announced his candidacy here today for the Republican nomination for governor of Ohio. Senator Taft is seeking the Republican nomination for the Presidency.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Nov. 10-- "That's the Army for you," is a lament not unknown to any military camp, but for 1,400 veterans of the Korean war it carried more than its usual icy meaning today.

Retailers throughout the country are confident of sales gains in the holiday season ahead. Christmas decorations are about to go up and impersonators of Santa Claus are making their costumes ready. Most important, large-scale promotional events are being planned.
KIMPO AIRPORT, Korea, Nov. 10 (AP)--Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, United States Air Forces Chief of Staff, said today that improved jet fighter planes were on tap for use against the Communists in Korea.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 10 --Miss Susan Starr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Starr, was married here this evening to First Lieut. John Jackson Burchenal 2d, U.S.M.C.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Burchenal of Glendale, Ohio.

For the inquiring mind of Dr. Abraham Flexner there is no such thing as retirement. On the eve of his eighty-fifth birthday the educational reformer has enrolled in a Columbia University course in "Russian Institutions" and has added a new book to the list of his publications.

PAPEETE, Tahiti--A return visit to one of the loveliest vacation spots in the world after an absence of eighteen years indicates that this island in the heart of the South Pacific now has more appeal to the visiting American than ever before.

THE children will be happy to see another story about Johnny and his funny uncles and his attractive teacher, Miss Day. Johnny is spending two weeks with his uncle on the farm. He can hardly wait to see his friend Brick. To get to Brick's house he has to pass many neighbors' houses.

THE extent of the inroads motels are making in the resort field is revealed by the announcement by the Sheraton Corporation of America, operator of the Sheraton hotel chain, that it is opening a twentyunit motel adjacent to, and as an annex of, the Sheraton Plaza Hotel in Daytona Beach, Fla.

AN author who knows the beautiful, rugged coast of Alaska has made it the setting for a warm story of a fine family--and particularly of Spence Baird, a young man of vision and drive. Spence's father, Jeff, was a great, rough-hewn man who needed space.

WASHINGTON. CONGRESS quit for the year late last month, but its place of business, the United States Capitol, seems even busier than ever today. The legislators wore out more than the welkin with their golden-throated oratory during the session.

The latest United States peace proposal may have been put forward at the Paris meeting of the United Nations Assembly last week without any belief that Russia would accept it. Russia has not been acting as though she would accept any plan whatever that might bring peace to this anxious world.

Photographs of some of the thousands of blue geese, snow geese and various species of waterfowl that have been sheltered during the winter seasons near Abbeville, La., were shown for the first time yesterday at the opening of the forty-seventh annual convention of the National Audubon Society at 1000 Fifth Avenue.

About 1,500 items that belonged to Franklin Delano Roosevelt will be available to souvenir hunters and admirers of the late President at a sale at the Hammer Galleries, 51 East Fifty-seventh Street, beginning tomorrow evening and lasting for three weeks.

A young man with ideas and the energy to carry them out has taken over an unusual and lively course at Barnard College--the English Conference. Barry Ulanov calls it "one of the most enlightened series ever heard of."
Dr. DeWitt Stetten, long a prominent surgeon here and active in the Fed Cross blood program, died yesterday at, his home, 850 Park Avenue. His age was 70.
John R. Bevilacqua, a hairdresser who apparently was involved in a stolen automobile ring, was shot dead early yesterday in the hallway of a West Side tenement.

Ground was broken yesterday for the Knolls, a cooperative apartment development on the site of the old Johnson foundry in the Spuyten Duyvil section of the Bronx. Ferman Builders, the sponsors, described it as one of the first reinforced cooperatives of its kind in New York to win a goahead signal from the Federal Housing Administration.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 10-- The Republican party retained or gained control of seventeen of Fairfield County's twenty-three municipal administrations in Tuesday's elections. The Democratic party's fortunes are at the lowest ebb in a quarter of a century.

TRITELEIAS have not been appreciated or used freely enough, partly because of the confusion in their cata logue listings. Yet, their starry flowers of blue, appearing toward the end of April, make them one of the choice bulbs of the lily family. They are attractive in either a garden of limited space or in a larger area where the bulbs can be used in masses.

PARIS, Nov. 10--The United States has advised Yugoslavia that it is prepared to sign a bilateral military assistance pact with that country and the accord will probably he formalized next week.

THE Post Office Department will place approximately $1,000,000 worth of mint blocks and sheets of postal paper on display at the Third National Postage Stamp Show to be held on Friday through Sunday in the Seventy-first Infantry Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. The event will climax National Stamp Collecting Week, which begins tomorrow.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Nov. 10--This historic city, midway between Washington and Richmond, is making plans to commemorate next year two events of its early annals that are expected to attract attention from all parts of the country.

Totton P. Heffelfinger of Minneapolis, Yale hurdier in his college days, has been nominated to be president of the United States golf Association in 1952, according to the organization's nominating committee.

NEWARK, Nov. 10--Thugs who staged five hold-ups in this city between 8 P.M. and last midnight, fatally shooting a special policeman, were still at large tonight after one of the most intensive man-hunts in local police history.

HANOI, Indo-China, Nov. 10-- French forces lashed out from their Hanoi perimeter today and announced that they had driven Communist-led Vietminh forces from nearly 400-square miles of territory and sixty to eighty villages in a surprise one-day offensive.

"Energy Unlimited" is a description often applied to Stanley Charles Allyn who, as president, guides the destinies of the National Cash Register Company.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 10--The new $4,500,000 Methodist Hospital, incorporating many advances in hospital construction was dedicated here this afternoon. The eight-story 315-bed building is in the fast-growing Texas Medical Center.

The off-year elections last week produced a number of surprises and some important political conclusions. The most important conclusion was that corruption is a potent political issue. Others were that the era of clubhouse political dictation to the electorate is about over; that big city machines win if and when they have a popular candidate; that this is especially true in New York City.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska--The next open season for bagging the colossal Kenai Peninsula moose of Alaska runs from Dec. 1 to 10, and it promises to be one of the best moose seasons ever. So officials of the Alaska Railroad say, and they base the estimate on their worst "moose problem" to date.

Convinced that selling will remain an important factor in the country's economy despite the defense program, National Sales Executives has adopted a program designed to keep the profession at a high level. As the productivity of Japanese labor rises, the gap between prices for Japanese and American products is gradually closing, according to compilations by the Toyo Spinning Company of Osaka.

AN unexpected material is currently invading every nook, corner and cranny of the contemporary home. It appears in a surprising number of sizes, shapes and guises.

On the simple issue of honesty in politics and government, reform candidates scored important municipal electoral victories last week in New York, Philadelphia, Boston and several other cities. Only in a few places where corruption and misrule were issues were the "ins" able to withstand the tide.

Department stores chalked up gains last week over the 1950 period, with promotions bringing excellent responses and nearly all types of goods reporting increases. The colder weather was a major help in bringing in the customers, and only one day of heavy rain marred the week's trade. Trade observers estimated the advance for the week at 8 per cent.

Guiomar Novaes, the eminent Brazilian pianist, made a triumphant return yesterday afternoon at Town Hall after a season's absence from the local concert field. The artist attracted a capacity audience with the overflow seated on stage, and in every way her recital proved a gala event.

EAST LANSING, Nov. 10--On its first play from scrimmage, Michigan State sprang Dick Panin through the middle of Notre Dame's line for aw 88-yard touchdown run. From there, Biggy Munn's slick and resourceful Spartans went on to hand the Irish their worst defeat since the 48--0 rout by' Army in 1945. Today's final count was 35--0.

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 10 (AP)-- Twice-beaten Wake Forest struck for three quick second-period touchdowns and fought off a stirring Duke rally to defect the Blue Devils, 19--13, in a Southern Conference football thriller today.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (Reuters)-- Portsmouth scored the biggest success of today's English League soccer, reaching second place in the first division by beating Stoke City 14--1.

THESE first ten titles in the Regal Books series are a fine addition to our supply of informational books for boys and girls of 9 to 12. We have long needed just such a series of introductions to those subjects which children of that age are beginning to explore with, all the enthusiasm of young Balboas.

HEWLETT, L.I., Nov. 10--Miss Mathilde Marie Kingsland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold N. Kingsland, was married here this afternoon to Charles Lowell Burnett, son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis Lowell Burnett of Manchester, Mass., in Trinity Protestant Episconal Church.

SOUTHBORO, Mass., Nov. 10-- A crowd of 1,000 watched St. Mark's School rout Groton, a traditional rival, 41-13, today. The winners started passing early and held a 20-6 margin at the intermission.

It was a day of maintaining positions and patrol activity for ground forces of the United Nations command in Korea yesterday (Saturday). Friendly patrols operating along the front engaged in several brief firefights as they encountered only light to moderate enemy resistance. Artillery supported friendly patrols in the east-central sector.

HAD it been possible to foresee the recently decreed remission of the 20 per cent entertainment tax on its performances, the 1951-52 season of the Metropolitan Opera Association, which opens Tuesday night, would no doubt have been differently arranged than it is.

PARIS, Nov.10--It is axiomatic that in a democratic system no single man is indispensable. Nevertheless, it would be hard to reckon what would have occurred in Britain eleven years ago without the leadership of Winston Churchill. It is equally difficult to imagine just how far along its arduous progression toward reality European defense would be today were it not for the leadership of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

GARDEN fixtures and equipment which have been exposed to the outdoors dur ing an entire season deteriorate rapidly if neglected. Both metal and wood need a protective coat of paint. And the clear, bright days of autumn are close to ideal for most painting chores about the garden.

HEINLEIN'S science fiction always seems so real you almost catch yourself thinking you may as well take the next bus down to the space port. His latest is a tightly constructed tale of revolution in the sky.

THE Haders have added a merry quirk to the old game of hide-and-seek in their new book. Small John Henry takes an unpremeditated stroll through the zoo in pursuit of pigeons and sister Karen starts anxiously to look for him. Readers who follow John and Karen will be rewarded by a fine view of the zoo animals, realistically portrayed in color and in tone.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 10-- By the scant margin of a point after touchdown, Bucknell preserved its undefeated status and gained its twelfth-straight victory today, 21--20. WASHINGTON, Nov. 12--The "cruel, derisive" laughter of an Andrei Vishinsky will never succeed in shouting down the hopes of men of goodwill for world-wide peace, Eric Johnston, Economic Stabilization Administrator, said here today.
Their victory over the Washington Redskins cost the New York Football Giants the services of Travis Tidwell for Sunday's showdown battle with the Cleveland Browns at the Polo Grounds.

MANILA, Tuesday, Nov. 13 (AP) --A City Hall worker was killed here early today in the first reported flare-up of Election Day violence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12--James E. Webb, Acting Secretary of State, announced today that Austria and the United States had agreed to exchange Ambassadors. The respective diplomatic missions in Vienna and Washington are now headed by ministers. Britain and France took similar action.

The National Orchestral Association gave the first concert of its twenty-second season last night in Carnegie Hall. Leon Barzin led the young musicians in a program which both displayed their abilities and introduced some music that needed to be played here.

LONDON, Nov. 12--A talk between the Spanish Ambassador in London and an official of the Foreign Office last week apparently has raised expectations in Madrid of friendlier treatment from Britain's new Conservative Government than from, the late Labor Government.

Reports that Winston Churchill, once more at Britain's helm in a time of world crisis, would meet with President Truman at an early date have now been confirmed. The talks will take place, it is revealed, "in the early days of January."

The answer to the high cost of modern medical service lies in the development of voluntary medical and hospital insurance plans and in the group practice of medicine, Dr. Henry E. Meleney, Professor of Preventive Medicine at the New York University College of Medicine, declared yesterday.

Food-handling mechanization in large hospitals and industrial cafeterias is now the most active sector of demand for new equipment, it was reported here yesterday by A.P. Anderson, sales engineer here of the Samuel Olson Manufacturing Company, Hoboken.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 12 --William Woodhouse Peake, retired New York stock broker and former secretary of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, 24 Broad Street, New York, died here today in United Hospital at the age of 73. He resided at the Westchester Country Club, Rye.

Peter P. Spinelli, for thirty-one years secretary of the Richmond County Republican Committee and since 1942 an assistant district attorney under Democratic prosecutors, resigned as an assistant rather than "embarrass" his chief, District Attorney Herman Methfessel, he announced yesterday.

Seven-year-old Joseph Yull, who is in the third grade at Public School 33 and lives at 426 West Twenty-seventh Street, does not yet rank with Picasso, Matisse and Grandma Moses.
A mystery developed yesterday over Central Park's three gone geese.

CAIRO, Nov. 12--Pressure on the Egyptian Government to give extremists their way is increasing. A Moslem Brotherhood committee held a public meeting today to appeal for the release of 482 persons detained on political charges mostly concerned with terrorism or inciting to terrorism.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 12 (U.P.)--Joe DiMaggio cut short his tour of Japan as a member of Lefty O'Doul's traveling American baseball team and returned here today determined "not to let anyone run my mind or make my decisions about my future in baseball."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP)-- The Defense Department today identified 423 more battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 69 killed, 326 wounded, 14 missing in action and 14 injured in combat accidents. The following were listed from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:...
Rugged tests await most of the few remaining undefeated football powers this week in all sections of the country and the end of the season comes for some of the smaller college teams.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP)-- The Philippine Islands have put enough money into the United States Treasury to pay off all Philippine Government bonds issued before May 1, 1934, Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder announced today.

The United Nations draft Covenant on Human Rights impinges on the basic freedoms made explicit in the Bill of Rights, including freedom of the press, Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, said last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12--The research division of the National Education Association estimated today that elementary and secondary school enrollment in October, 1951, totaled 26,567,374, an increase of 800,000 over a year ago.

AS a result of a signal lack of cooperative spirit on the part of the weather man, New Jersey wild-fowlers had a somewhat unexciting opening for the duck season, although fair bags of broadbill and a scattering of brunt made life bearable for those who tried Barnegat Bay.

Dr. Charles Mallory Williams, a dermatologist who served as president of the medical board of the New York Skin arid Cancer Hospital from 1928 to 1934, died yesterday after a brief illness in his home in Stonington, Conn. His age was 79.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12--The late Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes told a biographer that President Franklin D. Roosevelt's attempt to enlarge the Supreme Court "had not the slightest effect" in changing the court's mind on New Deal cases.
PORTUGAL COVE, Nfld, Nov. l2--Princess Elizabeth ended her five-week tour of Canada at this rocky, storm-beaten fishing village today and sailed for home and England on the liner Empress of Scotland.
Michigan State nudged Tennessee out of the No. 1 spot in the weekly Associated Press football poll yesterday with 55 of 158 firstplace votes from sports writers and broadcasters.

PARIS, Nov. 12--Australia's chief delegate charged today that the policy speech of Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky before the General Assembly last week had reduced the future effectiveness of the United Nations as a machinery for maintaining peace.
Johnny (Red) De Fazio, 142 pounds, Bayonne, N.J., won a split decision over Tony Allegro, 138, the Bronx, in the eight-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

LONDON, Nov. 12--Prime Minister Churchill's Conservative Government won the first skirmish in the House of Commons tonight of what is certain to be a long and bitter fight to restore Britain's steel industry to private ownership.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP)-- Eight examples of superior accomplishments by Federal workers were cited by the Civil Service Commission today in a report on annual awards.

BRISTOL, Pa., Nov. 12--Mrs. George La Rue of Spring Brook Farm, Bristol, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Yardley, of Princeton, N.J., to Lieut, Robert Gedney Leonard, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Leonard of Bloomfield, N.J.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 12 --The Eastern States Antiques Fair opened in the Westchester County Center today with a wellup-to-standard collection of merchandise for its thirty-third semiannual edition.

PARIS, Nov. 12--Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden appealed to the Soviet Union today in the United Nations General Assembly to agree to "a truce to name-calling and angry words" and to cooperate with the Western powers in making "a fresh start" on the "real road to peace."

WILLIAM BRADFORD, says his direct descendant, Bradford Smith, was "the first American, the pattern of the self-made man." John Alan Haughton, a senior editor of Musical America magazine, died Sunday in University Hospital. He was 71 years old.

Merces Silva-Telles, Brazilian pianist who gave her second local recital last night, is a slim young woman who looks as if a breath of wind might blow her away. But, judging from her program and from her manner of playing, she has virtuoso ambitions.
LONDON, Nov. 12--Soviet submarine strength of 380 vessels, with at least 120 more under construction, is reported in Brassey's, the Armed Forces Year Book, out tomorrow.
ROME, Nov. 12--A truck and a sailing vessel collided on a main highway outside Chioggia on the Adriatic Coast.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 12--In contrast to restrictive measures being undertaken in France and Britain, the West German Government will reveal shortly new liberalized trade import lists that would open the way to larger dollar purchases.

President Truman declared yesterday that his recent order standardizing Government procedures for safeguarding security information was not designed to impede the flow of news, but to give the American people more information.

Wilfred H. Gillian, as executor and trustee of the estate of Clara L. DeVoe, has sold the five-story building accommodating fifteen families at 153 East Twenty-ninth Street to the Joedhal Realty Corporation, which plans to hold it for investment.
OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 12 (AP)-- Dr. Wilbur A. Sawyer, medical scientist who developed the first successful vaccine against yellow fever, died of a heart ailment today. His age was 72.

One of the nation's largest operating utilities, the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, reported yesterday a net income of $36,225,832, after all expenses and charges, for the twelve months to Sept. 30, 1951. This compares with a net of $35,717,394 in the corresponding period a year ago. Gross revenues increased to $266,860,820, from $230,301,819 last year.

The impressions gathered by two American designers on a visit to Milan's Triennale exhibition of home furnishings last summer were discussed at a luncheon-meeting of the Home Fashions League here yesterday.

Schenley Industries, Inc., and its subsidiaries had consolidated net earnings of $22,252,772 for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31 last, Lewis S. Rosenstiel, chairman and president, reported yesterday. Sales during the period totaled $450,576,264.

Compulsory motor vehicle inspection in this state would prevent 800 fatalities and save 40,000 from injury annually on the highways, State Senator Seymour Halpern of Queens declared yesterday. "About 40 per cent of the vehicles operating on the New York roads are potential murder weapons because of typical defects' such as bad brakes and steering systems," he said.
Norris P. Ballou, retired assistant to the president of the Railway Express Agency, died Tuesday, following a stroke, in the University Club, where he resided His age was 72.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 14--An extradition convention by which swindlers in Canada who have been taking an estimated $1,000,000 weekly from American stock buyers can be brought to book in this country has been signed by the United States and Canada, the State Department said today.

The mechanism to put into operation the $160,000,000 American program of economic and technical aid to the Near East has now been started. The credit was previously assigned under the new Mutual Security Act. Now the problem is to spend it in such a way as to benefit the abjectly wretched people of the Middle East and thus reduce the pressure of violent nationalism and the ultimate threat of communism.

In behalf of the philanthropic work of the Women's Association of the Brick Presbyterian Church, a fashion show and tea will be given this afternoon in the parish house of the church at 62 East Ninety-second Street. Mrs. Henry Steeger is chairman of the committee in charge of the arrangements for the event.
Rudolph Halley took office yesterday morning as President of the City Council, pledging himself as a political independent to fight for "clean, decent municipal government."

PARIS, Nov. 14--At least 80,000 miners of a total of 160,000 were on strike tonight in the coal fields of northern France. The walkout, ordered last night by the Communist mining locals, was followed by similar orders from the Socialist Workers Force locals this afternoon.

OTTUMWA, Iowa, Nov. 15 (AP) --Thomas Henry Foster, chairman of the board of John Morrell Co., One of the country's Oldest meat-packing companies, died of a heart ailment at his home here today. He was 76 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio explained his foreign policy at a literary press conference today, and while the melody sounded familiar, the words were very different from his campaign themes of 1940, 1944 and 1948.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14--Dr Nahum Goldmann of New York co-chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, said tonight that tendencies toward a revived American Jewish isolationism in respect to Israel had developed since the World Zionist Congress last August.

LYON, France, Nov. 14 (UP)-- Searchers found today a partly burned military document bearing the name of one of the thirty-six United States service men missing aboard a United States Air Force plane that was feared to have fallen in the rugged mountains of central France.

Roger Franz was back at quarterback yesterday as Fordham ran through a dummy scrimmage for its game with Temple on Saturday. Franz had been sidelined for three weeks with pulled tendons in his right leg.

EVANSTON, Wyo., Nov. 14 (UP) --The death toll in Monday's train wreck near here stood at sixteen known dead and one person missing today as workmen finished a preliminary search of the wreckage of the two crack Union Pacific passenger trains.

Former Representative W. Kingsland Macy asserted yesterday that Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio had tremendous rank-and-file support in this state. And he added that many outstanding men and women were anxious to enter the Republican primary next April as candidates for election as Taftpledged delegates.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Nov. 14 --Echoes of the Kefauver crime investigation resounded in the second day of the gambing trial of Leonard Costa today when a convicted gambler challenged the state's right to produce income tax records linking him with Joe Adonis and other underworld kingpins.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 14 (AP)--Evy Trostyle, 17-year-old high wire performer, dropped sixty feet today before 7,500 circus spectators at the Fifth Regiment Armory today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14-- Herschel D. Newsom of Columbus, Ind., Master of the National Grange, proposed today a threepoint approach to the problem of developing a national farm program that would provide consumers with abundant supplies of foods and fibers, and at the same time safeguard the ability of farmers to continue high-level production.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh of Iran coupled a request for a $120,000,000 United States loan today with a warning that continued support of "imperialist" policies in the East would intensify the threat of communism there.

Charles Munch opened the first New York concert of the season by the Boston Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall with the performance of Mozart's Masonic Funeral Music played in memory of Serge Koussevitzky, for a quarter of a century the leader of the organization upon which he left so indelible an impression.

Tom Landry and Bosh Pritchard were the focal points of Coach Steve Owen's attention yesterday as he sent the New York Football Giants through a two-hour drill in preparation for Sunday's big battle with the Cleveland Browns at the Polo Grounds.
TORONTO, Nov. 14 (Canadian Press)--Mexico retained its lead tonight in the international jumping team competition at the Royal Winter Fair horse show.

The strategy of taking out the goalie worked for the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game against the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night. Trailing by a goal with less than two minutes to play, the home sextet benched netminder Charley Rayner and replaced him with a skater.

Manufacturers of medium-price blouses have virtually withdrawn lines for holiday selling because of the large volume of orders, according to Louis Brecher, president of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers, Inc. WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--An emergency board appointed by President Truman to head off a railroad strike last week is so unacceptable to the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen that union officials are considering calling on the board to disqualify itself.

Within a week the New York City Theatre Company expects to have lined up its drama program for the City Center winter season, scheduled to get under way on Dec. 26. Three revivals, each to run two weeks, will be given over a period of six weeks.

District Attorney Herman Meth fessel, who has been superseded in the state's investigation of official corruption on Staten Island, was a witness before the special grand jury in the Richmond County Courthouse at St. George for two and a half hours yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--The Interstate Commerce Commission granted Seatrain Lines, Inc., of New York temporary authority today to transport commodities generally between New York and Savannah, Ga., for 180 days, or until next May 11. The carrier has pending an application for permanent authority.
