The need for protecting existing water supply systems is being emphasized by the growing shortage of metal pipe for civilian use, Henry L. Shuldener, president of Water Service Laboratories, Inc., declared yesterday at ceremonies marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of the chemical engineering company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--Shipments of United States arms, including aircraft and heavy equipment such as tanks and artillery, are arriving in Western Europe ahead of the schedule set by defense leaders, the Defense Department announced today.

Commenting on the charge by Elmer Rice that "Celanese Theatre," the television show, was barring actors for political beliefs, the president of the advertising agency representing the sponsor said yesterday that "no artist engaged by the producer has ever been disapproved" by his company.

As far as recent emergency extension of special export licenses is concerned, the New York dock strike will be considered officially ended today, it was announced yesterday by the New York regional office of the Department of Commerce.

The stock market resumed the advance yesterday but the average gain was so meager as to be meaningless. Interest shifted among a variety of groups, but in the main the coppers, televisions and airlines were favored. Most of the heavy industrial stocks operated within a narrow range and attracted little interest.

The world of storybooks came alive for 16,000 school children yesterday when the heroes of fact and fiction, the authors who conjure them up, the artists who draw them, put on the Boys and Girls Book Fair at the American Museum of Natural History.

"SPLENDOR," Scott Fitzgerald said, "is something in the heart." That quality of splendor, sometimes strained, always somehow thinly golden, runs through all his books--particularly "Tender Is the Night," Which has now been published in a new, chronological arrangement* that he devised in the grim days of the Nineteen Thirties and did not live-to See floated on the ambiguous tides of the current Fitzgerald revival.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- About 400 men and women will receive from the National Science Foundation graduate fellowships in various scientific fields for the academic year 1952-53. The foundation announced today that the fellowships would be granted in mathematical, physical, medical, engineering and biological sciences.
Gerard J. Carney, formerly sales manager in Cincinnati for Farm and Garden Associates, Inc., has been appointed general sales manager of the Dayton Pump and Machinery. Company, Dayton, Ohio.

A customers council board will be set up by Mays Department Store of Brooklyn and Glen Oaks, Queens, to determine customer preferences in store service and fashions, Joseph Weinstein, president, announced yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 (AP)-- The Pirates released Pete Reiser unconditionally today.

The Stats Roads Commission Of Maryland borrowed $25,000,000 yesterday on highway construction bonds maturing serially from 1952 to 1966 at an interest cost of 1.7305 per cent. The Fashion Institute of Technology, operated jointly for the last seven year by the Board of Education and the Educational Foundation for the Apparel Industry, was dedicated last night as a college of the State University.
FORT JACKSON, S.C., Nov. 14 (AP)--Art Wall Jr. of Honesdale, Pa., fired a 6-under-par 66 on his final eighteen holes today to win the second annual Fort Jackson open golf tournament with a 134 total.

Watchers along the banks of the East River were startled yesterday to see a flotilla of twenty ferryboats, barges, tugboats and other harbor craft parade upstream in a stately row. From time to time they tooted whistles.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14-- Richard O. Hooper of the R.C.A. Victor division of the Radio Corporation of America said, at the opening session of the American Public Relations Association here today, that television was the one propaganda weapon the United States has and its enemies do not have.

The latest deadlock in Korea involves the question whether the fighting shall cease immediately on land, on the sea and in the air, along a truce line on which both sides are close to agreement, or whether the fighting shall continue until all points of the armistice have been agreed upon.

CAIRO, Nov. 14--Fuad Serag elDin Pasha, Minister of the Interior, said tonight that the Egyptian Government would take over the training of the so-called anti-British "liberation groups" within a few days. These groups had been organized to drive the British out of the Suez Canal zone.
The first part of a broad traffic "package" intended to convert the West Side from Fourteenth Street to 110th Street into a network of one-way avenues will go into operation early next month.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Nov. 14 (U.P.)--The New York textile concern of Safie Brothers Co., Inc., found itself today with a new $5,000,000 plant that it was unable to operate because imports of raw cotton were prohibited.

Directors of the Mathieson Chemical Corporation voted to increase the dividend on the common stock with the declaration yesterday of a 50-cent quarterly for payment on Dec. 22. Previously shareholders received 40 cents quarterly.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14-- Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Pamela Wilson Chappell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Benjamin Chappell, to Robert Lowe Kunzig, deputy attorney general of Pennsylvania, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Weiss Kunzig of Philadelphia.

SACRAMENTO, Nov. 14--Gov. Earl Warren of California declared himself a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination today. In a statement read to a special press conference, the Governor said: "With all humility, I have concluded to become a candidate."
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14-- Princeton's football coach, Charlie Caldwell, today found himself in complete disagreement with some of the recent dispatches emanating from New Haven, Conn.

LONDON, Nov. 14--The new bookkeeping account opened on the stock markets today with prices showing more resistance. Although a slight improvement showed signs of petering out and the best prices were not held, most markets closed firm.

Rains such as those which descended upon and around the city yesterday can be regarded as little less than unreasonable. They were a burden and they will be a burden again should further such torrents fall before evening of today, tomorrow or immediately beyond.

PARIS, Nov. 14--A triangular race is developing for the place on the United Nations Security Council now held by Yugoslavia, and there were indications today that the United States delegation, which holds the key position, might reconsider its earlier stand in favor of Greece and support the Philippines instead.
A dirty and somewhat dilapidated painting, picked up for $3 at a rummage sale last year, has been attributed within the last few days to the Italian sixteenth century master, Luca Longhi.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)-- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 99,226 today, an increase of 1,712 since lastweek.

Since holiday time is virtually here, bringing more and more entertaining at home, a nest of tables may be a godsend to the busy hostess. These tables, while occupying little space when not in use, are invaluable for informal entertaining.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 14 --Business conditions in the nation should continue strong in 1952 with price levels holding fairly steady, Roger F. Murray, vice president of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, told delegates attending the twenty-third annual conference of the New Jersey Bankers Association here today.
A fashion show of clothes designed and made in Israel was presented yesterday to the Central Chapter of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, at a luncheon in the Plaza Hotel.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 14--There are nearly half as many vending machines as retail sales personnel in America today and the time is approaching when the machines may outnumber live sales people.
BOB GAUDIO sounded very wistful the night he phoned Tony Adamle, the captain of the Cleveland Browns. The Browns were at their pre-season training camp in Bowling Green and the time was last August.

John E. (Jack) McInerney, advertising and publicity director of the Paramount Theatre in New York and director of press relations for United Paramount Theatres, Inc., died yesterday morning at Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He had suffered with a heart ailment for many years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)-- New York ranks first among the states in total urban population and Pennsylvania has the most rural residents, the Census Bureau announced today. But, percentagewise, New Jersey is the most urban state and North Dakota the most rural.

A program of construction and modernization of schools in Manhattan "essential to minimum requirements" was asked yesterday by Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, in a letter to the Board of Estimate.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14--A reactionary tendency developed in the grain market after new highs had been registered for wheat, corn and oats for the crop year. Profit-taking was heavy and there was a gradual easing of prices in all the grain pits.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Nov. 14-- Henry A. Alker, president of the Port Washington-Manhasset National Bank, with headquarters in Port Washington, died today in his home here, after a long illness, at the age of 65. He also had a home at 930 Park Avenue, New York.

PARIS, Nov. 14--The Belgian Government has invited the United States and other interested Governments to meet in Brussels Nov. 26 to take definitive action in aid of migration from Europe's overpopulated and politically strategic areas.

BERLIN, Nov. 14--The opening in-East Berlin tomorrow of a six day conference by the General Council of the Communist World Federation of Trade Unions was considered by Western sources today to be the occasion for a high powered appeal to the workers for the Soviet conception of German unity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14-- The Chinese Nationalist Government filed a suit in Federal District Court here today, demanding the return of more than $7,000,000 and an accounting of many millions more from its two air force procurement officers who were denounced and ordered to return to Formosa last Aug. 21.

Stressing his opposition to a higher transit fare, Council President Rudolph Halley announced yesterday that he was seeking an alternative solution for the financial difficulties of the municipal subway system.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 14-- Production of low-budget pictures will be sharply reduced, if not entirely eliminated, by R. K. O. Radio Pictures, according to plans now being mapped out for the company's 1952 filming program.

ARLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 14-- Only the more determined hunters put in a full opening day in the Buck Hill-Spruce Mountain woods section of Vermont today, for a strong wind and intermittent rain made for uncomfortable, as well as unsuccessful, hunting conditions.

Air France, the French national airline, is negotiating with the de Havilland Aircraft Company, Ltd., for the purchase of jet-powered passenger planes and "probably will order three by the end of this week," according to Max Hymans, chairman of the airline.

One kind of exhibition that museums in general might profitably put on more frequently is opening to the public today at the Brooklyn Museum in the special exhibition galleries. John I. H. Baur, curator of paintings, has brought together 150 paintings in six groups in an effort to relate the principal nineteenth-century tendencies in American art to the work of our contemporaries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--The House Ways and Means subcommittee digging into tax scandals announced today it had received President Truman's assurance that it could have access to all Department of Justice files needed to check the thoroughness of tax fraud prosecutions.

Mike Mahoney, 17-year-old senior from Bishop Loughlin High School, led all the way to win individual honors in the twenty-ninth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools, Class I, cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

ALBANY, Nov. 14--The Appellate Division, Third Department, of the State Supreme Court declined today to undertake an investigation of the Columbia County Surrogate's Court, which is alleged to have been involved, in eighty-nine "fake" adoptions of black market babies.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Nov. 14--Delegates to the fifty-seventh annual convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs voted today to urge the United States Senate not to make any "further treaties which would tend to give our national sovereignty into other hands than those of our own

The familiar preparation of public opinion to expect a large increase in the city budget in the coming year is under way. City officials and others in a position to know are talking about a "desperate" financial situation. A budget increase anywhere from $100,000,000 to $200,000,000 is mentioned. Bad news is thick on the horizon. A transit deficit of $20,000,000 to $25,000,000 is in the making, for the current year.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced yesterday the names of 101 artists whose work had been chosen in the museum's national competition, "American Sculpture 1951," for exhibition beginning Dec. 7.
Mrs. Eddie Duchin, who bought the four-story private home at 229 East Sixty-second Street last May, has resold it to a buyer for occupancy in a cash deal negotiated by Douglas L. Elliman Co. brokers.

TOKYO, Nov. 14--Charges that Chinese and North Korean Communists have ignored the Geneva Convention by killing more than 2,500 United States prisoners of war in the last year were contained in a report made public today by the Judge Advocate General of the Eighth Army.

PARIS, Nov. 14--The Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly plunged into the touchy question of SouthWest Africa today. Even before it had adopted its agenda, the committee came close to inviting to its session Hosea Kutako, senior chief of the Herrero tribes of that region

PARIS, Nov. 14--Reflecting a growing French anxiety over the Allies' plans for integrating West Germany into the West's defense, the Foreign Affairs Committee of the French National Assembly adopted 30 to 2 today a motion asking its chairman to demand debate on the proported European army in the Assembly Council Conference in Rome Nov. 24.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture reported today that recent developments point to a high level of beef cattle feeding this season.

For home cooks whose culinary background is Italian, a macaroni manufacturer has devised an abbreviated method for making that Neopolitan favorite, stuffed rigatoni. But the simplified and savory dish should have an appeal, too, to other than ItalianAmerican cooks. Most anyone

A new state court to review Workmen's Compensation Board decisions was proposed yesterday by Associated Industries, Inc., an organization of large industrial employers. Joseph R. Shaw, assistant to the association's president, contended that opportunity for review was needed because the board had been overly liberal in interpreting the law.

Sales of leading mail order and chain stores in October showed a gain of 12.8 per cent over the corresponding month of 1950, according to a compilation of forty-four companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. This was the largest gain for any month since March, when the increase was 19 per cent. Sales in September were 2.4 per cent above the comparable month of last year.

More than 2,500 United States prisoners of war have been murdered by the Communists in Korea, the Eighth Army announced. "In a record of killing and barbarism unique even in the Communist world," the announcement said, more than 250,000 Korean civilians have also been slain.

Commissioner Ford C. Frick yesterday outlined a proposal for the creation of a new "open" classification in baseball, through which the higher-ranking minor leagues might eventually advance to major league status. The plan will be voted on at the minor and major league meetings next month, with only a simple majority needed for acceptance as part of baseball law.

CALGARY, Nov. 14 (Canadian Press)--Northwest Natural Gas Company and Canadian Gulf Oil Company have concluded an agreement for disposal of southern Alberta's big Pincher Creek Gas Reserve over a twenty-five-year period, Details are given in an agreement filed with the Alberta Petroleum and Natural Gas Conservation Board.
Underwriting syndicates placed on the market yesterday blocks of common stock of New York Air Brake and Canadian Atlantic Oil Company, Ltd., of Canada, having a market value of more than $11,600,000.

The fates have not been kind to Nathan Kaplan, 49-year-old salesman. He was convicted and served seven and a half years for a crime committed by another. He is on home relief, owes the Government a $2,000 fine and his life is regimented under a five-year probation.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 15-- Fighting was light along the entire Korean front yesterday. Air Force activities were curtailed also, because of bad weather over northwestern Korea.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 14--George V. Allen, United States Ambassador, and Premier Marshal Tito signed today an agreement under which the United States Government will supply military equipment, materials and services to the Yugoslav armed forces within the framework of the amended 1949 Mutual Defense Assistance Act and the Mutual Security Act of 1951.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 14 (AP)-- While the favorite was being carried wide in the stretch run, Cobbles Stable's Abstract saved ground and won Pimlico's Catonsville Purse today by three-quarters of a length over Mully S.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14--Two major forces, diversion of income through excessive taxation and monopolistic practices of labor unions, are leading this country down the same path to socialism that contributed to England's present sorry plight, Louis Ruthenburg of Evansville, Ind., chairman of Servel, Inc., warned today.

Cargo congestion along the waterfront continued unabated yesterday and in some instances was intensified as thousands of tons of exports were disgorged on piers and in terminals already jammed with imports.

The Small Manufacturers Emergency Committee has protested award of an order for 93,500 winter undershirts and an equal quantity of winter drawers by the United States Marine Corps to E-Z Mills of Cartersville, Ga., and Bennington, Vt. In an exchange of telegrams with Col. Ion Bethel, ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, declared today that keeping the Suez Canal open to the Western world must be "a vital part of American world policy."

DETROIT, Nov. 14--The impact on United States foreign policy of such race relations incidents as the Cicero, Ill., outbreak was analyzed today at the opening session of the fifth National Conference on Intergroup Relations.

Walter F. Ring Sr., 79 years old, a retired real estate man, was killed last night in Flushing, Queens, in an accident in which he was knocked down by an automobile and run Over by two other cars. One of the drivers involved was reported to have been a clergyman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--The Salary Stabilization Board laid down the rules today under which employes may receive options to buy stock in their company. No approval is required if the option price is at least 95 per cent of the market value and certain other conditions are met.
LONDON, Nov. 14--Prince Charles, the oldest child of Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh, celebrated his third birthday today by playing host to a party at Buckingham Palace.

ALBANY, Nov. 14--The Democratic minority in the Legislature has prepared a plan for reapportioning the state's Congressional districts that is designed to split upstate Republican support for the Dewey Administration reapportionment proposals and block their approval.

Harry Stuart, head of the Chicago investment banking business of Halsey, Stuart Co., will testify early next month in the antitrust trial of seventeen underwriting houses now under way in Federal Court here, it was announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Nov. 14 (AP)--More than a hundred United States service men volunteered to serve as spar mates for Joe Louis on his exhibition tour of Japan as he arrived by plane today to a tumultuous welcome.
PARIS, Nov. 14--India called today for another round of Big Four negotiations and urged the major powers to sign a joint nowar declaration. Sir Benegal N. Rau of India, one of a dozen...

Negotiations between East and Gulf Coast ship operators and the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A.F.L., will be resumed next Tuesday under the auspices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, Bernard J. Forman, mediation commissioner, said yesterday.

SEATTLE, Wash., Nov. 14-- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur welcomed home today a shipload of Korean war veterans and assured them that whatever criticism had been aimed at the conduct of the war it nowise referred to the fighting forces themselves.

Mobilizing on a large scale for the first time since World War II, thousands of civil defense workers demonstrated last night how they would swing into action if enemy planes should drop atomic and high-explosive bombs on the city.

MANILA, Thursday, Nov. 15 (AP) --Administration Liberals trimmed the early lead of the opposition Nacionalista party last night as the count reached the one-third mark in Tuesday's senatorial election.

The six-story apartment house at 745 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, accommodating fifty families has been sold by Jacob Glass Sons to Fairbanks Estates, Inc., represented by Bernard Friedman, attorney. Farber-Wittman, Inc., was the broker and. Samuel Rothstein was attorney for the seller.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 7:

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 (U.P.)-- Jimmy Carter successfully defended his world lightweight championship for the first time by battering Art Aragon into helplessness tonight to win a unanimous fifteenround decision.

Eight years have gone by since the Hot Springs Conference, when the idea of a Food and Agriculture Organization was first worked out. This week, at an F.A.O. meeting in Rome, Director General N.E. Dodd introduced his annual report with the remark: "Grim is still the word for the world food situation." If all the food in the world

DETROIT, Nov. 14--Local 600 of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., filed a suit in Federal District Court here today asking for an order restraining the Ford Motor Company from moving any operations from its River Rouge plant in Dearborn.
Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts has been named manager of the campaign to make General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower the Republican Presidential nominee.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 14-- L. Walter Lissberger, manufacturer, inventor and promotor who gained wide publicity in the Twenties, died in Norwalk Hospital last night after a long illness at the age of 75. He lived at Liberty Farms, his estate, on New
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and prices fell 12 to 55 points, with near months showing relatively, more strength than distant months.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)-- No Presidential Cup football game will be played this year.

Gov. Earl Warren's announcement that he is a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination will quicken interest in a campaign that already has American voters sitting on the edge of their chairs. The Chief Executive of California now joins the senior Senator from Ohio in the field, and at this stage we agree with Mr.
Stockholders of the Royal Typewriter Company, at a meeting here yesterday, approved an increase in the authorized common stock of $1 par to 2,000,000 shares from 1,078,816.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14--J.O. McClintock, executive vice president of the Chicago Board of Trade, has notified directors of the big grain Exchange that he will not seek renewal of his present fiveyear contract, expiring Dec. 31, 1952, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--The history of politics has a strong repetitious quality, as a comparison between the present and the years 1847-48 strikingly demonstrates. Then, too, there was a victorious General whom leaders in each of the major parties sought to make their candidate for President and whose attitude for some time toward these efforts offers a near-parallel to that of General Eisenhower thus far.

Commodity futures in the New York markets were generally lower yesterday. Cocoa recovered most of its decline of Tuesday, but coffee and vegetable oils lost ground. Sugar and wool contracts were mixed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (U.P.)-- The Treasury Department announced today that large taxpayers would have a second chance to pay their 1952 taxes in advance and at a discount.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--The Government today authorized substantial increases in price ceilings on new homes, factories, highways and scores of other construction projects to guarantee the building industry its pre-Korean profits.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP)-- council of the National Collegiate Athletic Association will meet here next Monday and Tuesday to formulate a definite program for control of athletics and elimination of pressures which have produced overemphasis.

The Graham-Paige Corporation, a closed-end investment company, reported yesterday that the net equity for stockholders aggregated $7,161,318 on Sept. 30, an increase of $2,903,649 since last Dec. 31. The figures are based on market values for securities having market ...
Many boxes have been taken and tables reserved for the tea dance and fashion show for the benefit of the Judson Health Center to be held tomorrow afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

Edwin T. Gibson, executive vice president of the General Foods Corporation, called on the United States yesterday to share its sulphur and molybdenum with its Western European allies. He spoke at a meeting of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce in the Plaza Hotel.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 15--The Bundestag was thrown into an uproar today when Dr. Franz Richter of the neo-Nazi Socialist Reich party declared that Germany was still at war with Israel and anyone sending money there should be denounced as a collaborator with an enemy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP)-- John Foster Duller believes the Soviet Union has absolutely no claim to the Kuriles, South Sakhalin or any other former Japanese islands under the Japanese peace treaty.
TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 16--The Korean front was in general inactive yesterday and a cold rain drenched the troops in most sectors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--Command of the Military Air Transport Service passed today from Lieut. Gen Laurence S. Kuter to Maj. Gen. Joseph Smith. General Kuter has been assigned as Deputy Chief of Staff for personnel at Air Force headquarters.

Franz Schoenberner, author who was editor of the famous German satirical weekly Simplicissimus until the Gestapo drove him into exile, is in Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital in a serious condition from injuries received under mysterious circumstances.

The band played Auld Lang Syne at 3:53 P.M., the tote board went dark an hour or so later, the men behind the $100 windows presumably brushed away furtive tears, and the New York horseracing season ended at Jamaica yesterday. What do the horseplayers, poor things, do now?
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, and prices rose 20 to 40 points.
TORONTO, Nov. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Canada jumped from fourth to first place tonight in the international low-score competition at the Royal Winter Fair horse show.

Rocky Compitello, 151 pounds, of Brooklyn, was booked last night at the Eighty-first Precinct police station on a charge of felonious assault after having punched and kicked Referee Jack Appel at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn. The referee had disqualified him in 1:35 of the third round of the scheduled eight-round semi-final bout with Tommy Reece, 154, Niagara Falls, Ont.

The National Council of American-Soviet Friendship held a rally last night at the Riverside Plaza Hotel, Seventy-third Street near Broadway, to celebrate the thirtyfourth anniversary of the founding of the Soviet Union and the eighteenth anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the United States and the Soviet Union.

For the second novelty of the season at the City Center, the New York City Ballet last night presented its long-planned revival of George Balanchine's "Apollo, Leader of the Muses" to the music of Stravinsky, with Andre Eglevsky, Maria Tallchief, Tanaquil LeClercq and Diana Adams in the chief roles.

The natural evolution of a bathing suit designer's turning her anatomical knowledge to corsetry has taken place. Frances Sider, well-known for swim suits and active sports clothes, has introduced the "Body" at Saks Fifth Avenue.
In no other country in the world could there be such a scene as is now visible from time to time on a treeshaded lawn in Florida, near Key West, when President Truman meets the press.

The trade concept of "historical position," regarded by the Department of Justice as a tool for monopolizing the securities underwriting business, was described by defence counsel in Federal Court here yesterday, in the anti-trust suit against certain banking houses, as a "grade A brushoff" used by ...

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov, 15 --A proposed 1952 budget for Westchester County, calling for a tax levy of $15,822,294 and a tax rate of $7.76 for each $1,000 of assessed valuation, was submitted by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach this afternoon to the Board of Supervisors.

A Broadway clothier and a key lieutenant in the bookmaking hierarchy of Harry Gross identified three suspended patrolmen yesterday as recipients of clothing and cash gifts provided by the bookmaker. One of the three was said to have accepted $1,000 for permitting the use overnight of seized "work sheets."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15-- Because of the continued drought, Rio de Janeiro may soon be in near darkness, its electric railways may reduce their schedules, factories are likely to be working fewer hours daily and office building elevators may be put on a schedule of runs. Unless heavy rains fall within seventy-two hours, city officials may be forced to take these actions.
WASHINGTON, Nov, 15--During the week ended Nov. 14, member bank reserves increased $183,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Five designers were represented in a small collection of new furniture and accessories, assembled at Mamo Siedentop, Inc., 403 East Sixty-second Street, for the opening of its new showrooms yesterday.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 15 (AP)--A faculty committee's demand that the University of Virginia de-emphasize football ran head-on today into opposition from two sources.

The Bank of Canada, which has been a marginal market buyer of Canadian Government internal bonds most of the year at prices slightly below 100, lowered its buying price yesterday, with the result that major issues declined to 1 points.

Mrs. Jorge R. Andre of 277 Park Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Alice Alexandra, to William Floyd-Jones of New York and East Norwich, L.I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Floyd-Jones.

Marion B. Folsom, chairman of the Committee for Economic Development, announced yesterday a grant of $85,000 from the Fund for Adult Education to establish eight college community economic research centers to study local or regional economic problems.

In the forthcoming Brussels conference on migration the United States has a special responsibility and a special interest. The termination of the International Refugee Organization's activities early in 1952 does not, ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15-- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, in a letter made public today, comended Vice Admiral E.L. Cochrane, Maritime Administrator, for "vigilance and alertness" in connection with the filing of a Government libel against the tanker Meacham at Norfolk.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Nov. 10 totaled 791,403 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

CHAMBON-SUR-LAC, France, Nov. 15 (AP)--A United States Air Force Flying Boxcar, lost two days ago in swirling snow, rain and fog, was found crashed and burned today on the snowmantled Mont Dore range. All the thirty-six Americans aboard were killed.
Up in New England at this season--or at least it used to be so-- home cooks would turn talents, previously directed to grape jelly and mustard pickle, to mincemeat.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15--The bull market in grains gained momentum on the Board of Trade here today, with corn leading and soaring to another set of crop highs on general buying.
A $15,000,000 alkali plant will open next January near Bogota, Colombia, marking another step in the industrialization of Latin America.

Cotton mills and other textile interests voted yesterday to add $100,000 to the $100,000 previously appropriated by the Textile Bag Manufacturers Association to promote the use of cotton bags for packaging feed, flour and other commodities.
A new record for blood received in the New York Regional Blood Program of the Red Cross on a single day was established Wednesday when 1,847 pints were donated.

Arthur M. Taylor of 248 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, a veteran newspaper man, known as a oneman boys-work institution, because he devoted most of his leisure unofficially to improving the condition of underprivileged youths, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Carson C. Peck Memorial Hospital, Brooklyn. His age was 76.

As a site for eventual improvement with a nineteen-story store and apartment building, the blockfront at 995 to 1009 Madison Avenue, between Seventy-seventh and Seventy-eighth Streets, has been sold by the Manhattan Financial Corporation and the Barkey Importing Company in a deal negotiated by Douglas L. Elliman Co.
Two of the current group shows do good work in encouraging lesser-known talents. On exhibition at the Village Art Center is an exhibition of work by four contemporary artists.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 15-- President Truman rejected today a proposal by President Vincent Auriol of France that he go to Paris during the current meeting of the United Nations General Assembly for a world peace parley with Premier Stalin of the Soviet Union, Prime Minister Churchill of Britain and Premier Rene Pleven of France.
TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 16 -- United Nations delegates at Panmunjom took up yesterday a Communist challenge to fix a ceasefire line in the Korean war immediately or abandon the armistice conferences.

Declaration of a year-end dividend of 75 cents, payable on Dec. 14, to stock held of record of Nov. 30 was announced yesterday by the Republic Aviation Corporation. This brings this year's dividend declarations to $1 a share, for 25 cents was distributed in April.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP)-- Lagging production and Western Europe's need for new planes have forced the Air Force to push back its target date for building up to ninety-five groups from late 1952 to some time in 1953.
TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 16 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 1,069, covering Thursday's operations:

IT was with considerable excitement that many thousands of readers discovered Willard Motley's "Knock on Any Door" four years ago. That raw and brutal book about crime in the slums of Chicago was overlong and sometimes crude in its denunciation of the sins of society and the perils of an evil environment.
MANILA, Nov. 15 (AP)--Majorities piled up by Nacionalistas in the cities may be big enough to defeat Administration candidates in nine Philippine Senatorial races, late returns indicated today.
Sharply higher earnings for the first nine months of this year were reported yesterday by the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, the nation's largest copper producer.
DETROIT, Nov, 15 (AP)--The Detroit Red Wings scored their twelfth consecutive victory in a two-year span over the Chicago Black Hawks, 3--1, before 10,411 fans tonight.

A prolonged legal battle over the $100,000,000 estate of Mrs. H. Sylvia Ann Howland Green Wilks, daughter of the the late Hetty Green, noted woman financier, was averted yesterday when two leading contestants withdrew.

The city Department of Commerce is opening a branch office in Washington to act as a liaison between local businesses and all Federal agencies in an effort to get a fair share of defense contracts here and to obtain materials allocations for local industry.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the National Broadcasting Company was observed yesterday at a luncheon of the Radio Executives Club in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Among the special guests were some of radio's old-time personalities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--Republican members of the House of Representatives, polled on their preference for a Presidential nominee, rated Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio ahead of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, 71 to 54.

The Public Housing Administration announced yesterday that issues of temporary loan notes totaling $44,963,000 to finance lowrent public housing for five municipal authorities were sold yesterday at interest costs ranging from 1.10 per cent to 1.19 per cent.

Despite an increase of defense spending of between $25,000,000,000 to $30,000,000,000 in 1952, there will be only a moderate increase in over-all business activity, according to Martin R. Gainsbrugh, chief economist, National Industrial Conference Board.
Ninety-six of the 120 parcels in Brooklyn offered at auction yesterday by the city were bid in for a total of $399,950. This was 22 per cent above the combined upset price of $329,200.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--Producers of consumer goods requiring scarce metals will share in available supplies of steel, copper and aluminum in the first quarter of next year, but the quantity allotted each manufacturer will depend upon the essentiality of his product, the National Production Authority announced today.

Columbia's ability to pass may be a deciding factor in the game against Navy at Baker Field tomorrow, according to the analysis of Paul Governali, scout and member of Lou Little's football coach ing staff.
ALBANY, Nov. 15 (AP)--The State Council of Churches said today that New York State should bring its blue laws "up to date."
The names of the Nobel Prizewinning scientists announced yesterday--Cockcroft and Walton, McMillan and Seaborg--stand out in the annals of science among the top architects of the atomic age.
An inept holdup man fumbled a stickup in Greentwich Village yesterday afternoon and then brought the episode to a climax by leaping into the arms of a policeman.

PARIS, Nov. 15--If the Cominform succeeds in provoking a prolonged coal strike in France, which it is now attempting to do, it would constitute a really serious blow to the North Atlantic defense program.

All sizes of eggs are up 2 cents a dozen since last week. Limited receipts, hardly sufficient to meet current consumer demand, along with heavy Army buying, are responsible for the increases, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

Dr. Marcus D, Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, outlined yesterday a departmental program for staffing Riverside. Hospital on North Brother Island as a municipal treatment and educational center for teen-age narcotics addicts.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 15 --The marriage of Miss Patricia Joanne Hagerty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Xavier Hagerty, to Charles Stone Gregg, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Burr Gregg of Hackensack and Brussels, Belgium, took place here this morning in Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 15-- Fogbound over the Portland Airport for two and a half hours today, General of the Army Douglas MacArthur landed here this afternoon, took a twenty-five mile drive through crowds that received him with enthusiasm and left for New York at 6:11 P.M., Eastern standard time.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 15--Declaring his eagerness to cooperate with Congressional committees seeking to expose and punish Federal employes guilty of malfeasance in office, President Truman asked the public today to remember that more than 95 per cent of all Government workers were honorable men and women who were doing a good job.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--The storage of food and feed stuffs to meet foreseeable domestic, military and foreign aid needs instead of to support prices was advocated today by the National Planning Association, a nonprofit organization seeking to solve national problems in the public interest.

The heat, which came yesterday within three degrees of melting a seventy-two-year record for midNovember, brought a rash of forsythia and other spring blooms to Brooklyn, job shirkers to the Battery sea wall, and song to a Bear Mountain cricket that had somehow survived after the first frost weeks ago.

FOR those who prefer technical perfection in their football, the college games each Saturday provide a pleasant enough way of marking time while awaiting the real game on Sunday, the professional one.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 15-- James Mason, who has a onepicture-a-year agreement with Twentieth Century-Fox for seven years but is otherwise free to work when and where he pleases, has made a deal with Paramount to co-star with Alan Ladd in "Botany Bay."

PARIS, Nov. 15--Representatives of non-Communist coal miners late tonight accepted a settlement calling for a return to work in the northern French mines, but the strike, jeopardizing two-thirds of the nation's coal production, is still being maintained by the Communist-dominated majority.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 15--The Netherlands turned down today an Indonesian demand for a special conference on Western New Guinea and an Indonesian ...

Gil McDougald of the Yankees and Willie Mays of the Giants yesterday were officially named the rookies of the year in their respective leagues. Their selection completed a clean sweep for the three local teams of the honors annually distributed by the voting committees of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

New York's racing season ended yesterday--and apparently not too soon for 50-year-old Joseph P. Friscia, a Bronx druggist. Indicted on a grand larceny charge in Bronx County Court, he was accused of defrauding thirty customers of $35,000 with a prosecutionproof, post-dated check scheme.

GENEVA, N.Y., Nov. 15--Dr. Ulysses Prentiss Hedrick, former director of the New York State agricultural experiment station here and author of several books on horticulture, died last night in a sanitarium at near-by Clifton Springs. He was 81 years old.
Although defense loans showed no net change last week, business borrowings from New York banks rose $39,000,000.

MOSCOW, Nov. 15--Moscow's English-language publication, News, declared today that the present United States foreign policy "leads straight to the brink of another world war" and that "only Soviet-American friendship can guarantee mankind peace and security."

The ninety-fifth birthday anniversary of the late Supreme Court Justice Louis D. Brandeis was commemorated last night at a dinner held at the Roosevelt Hotel by the Friends of Brandeis University of Greater New York.

Arnold Schoenberg wrote "Erwartung," a short opera or cantata or, as he called it, a "monodrama," in 1909. At long last, forty-two years later, the piece received its first performance in this country last night, with Dimitri Mitropoulos, an ardent advocate of Schoenberg, conducting the Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall.
The Army Engineers' hopper dredge Essayons has completed a seizes of trials after a $95,000 overhauling in a Brooklyn shipyard and will be shifted tomorrow to the corps' Norfolk district for a month.

DETROIT, Nov. 15--A Chicago industrialist told officials of the fifth National Conference of Intergroup Relations today that business men were becoming convinced they must promote fair employment practices in shops and offices.

A hundred or more controllers or their representatives from members of the National Association of Food Chains, meeting yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel, made tentative plans to seek relief from price limitations by the Office of Price ...
Grim warnings of financial trouble for the city in the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1952, were sounded yesterday at City Hall, with Controller Lazarus Joseph as the chief prophet of doom.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 15--Official reports of Communist party meetings in various parts of the country indicate that Yugoslavia leaders have begun a determined campaign to insulate the rank-and-file membership and the civil services against Western political ideas and standards of social morality, which have made serious inroads into the party and state machinery.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 15 (UP)--Capt. Frank Shields and his five United States Davis Cup players scored first-round victories against Australian entrants today as the New South Wales tennis championships got under way.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 15--The director general of the Israel Ministry of Trade and Industry said here today that that country's position would be greatly improved in 1952 and its new Government would be in a position to work toward the solution of the nation's economic problems.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 15 (UP) --Juan Mats, 27 years old, a Shrine circus acrobat, fell twentyfive feet from a horizontal bar late today and was taken unconscious to a hospital.
Commodity futures on the local exchanges were generally lower in yesterday's trading. Wool contracts were in heavy supply reflecting in part further weakness in the Australia market.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP)-- Price control officials said today that ceilings might have to be placed on white potatoes if prices continue to rise as they had in the last few months.
With a non-title shot at James Carter, and a possible later try at the lightweight champion's crown, promised to the winner, Paddy De Marco of Brooklyn and Eddie ...
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--The United States is giving "sympathetic consideration" to the Iranian Government's request for a loan, a State Department spokesman said today.

Through the purchase of stock of the Macrid Corporation, the Hecuba Corporation, headed by Abraham Pollack, has acquired Cambridge Court, a six-story garden apartment building at 36-40 Bowne Street in Flushing, Queens. Louis Carreau, Inc., and Murray O. Handel were the broker's.
In recent years a studied attempt has been made in Washington to create and develop a new type of class-consciousness in this country.

Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch, one of the city's pioneer settlementhouse workers, died yesterday at the age of 84 after an illness of three months at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, the settlement she founded in 1902.

Ill winds blew across the faces of commuters from all points of the compass yesterday morning. Struggle and fume as they might in that critical period between 7:30 and 9:30 o'clock, many thousands of them were late for work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--The unauthorized publication of a report that the Communists have killed more than 2,500 United States prisoners of war in Korea during the last year caused more trouble and confusion in official quarters here today than any development since the dismissal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

Satisfied with the preliminary reports on Wednesday night's drill for defense workers, civil defense authorities began yesterday intensive preparations for the city-wide public participation exercise to be held during the week of Nov. 25.
New York University runners placed one, two, three to defeat Fordham, 22--34, yesterday in a cross-country meet at Van Cortlandt Park.

The Western Maryland Railway and the Pittsburgh and Lake Erie Railroad borrowed $21,385,000 in the public market yesterday on general-mortgage and equipmenttrust obligations sold at competitive bidding.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15--Leon R. Ludwig, a research engineer at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, who had aided the nation's defense work in the second World War and the present emergency, died in his home in suburban Mount Lebanon last night after six weeks' illness. He was 47 years old.

Tex Coulter, handyman of the line, will be back at offensive left tackle for the New York Football Giants Sunday in their showdown battle with the Cleveland Browns at the Polo Grounds. Coach Steve Owen reached this decision yesterday after sending his charges through a two-and-a-half hour field drill.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--The Reconstruction Finance Corporation approved today a loan of $57,185,000 to reopen the white Pine copper deposits in the Upper Michigan Peninsula area, Representstive John B. Bennett, Republican of Michigan, announced.

LONDON, Nov. 15--The stock markets today maintained the improvement shown yesterday, with prices reasonably steady. As exceptions, rubber and tin shares fell sharply in view of reports of increased activity by Communist guerrillas in Malaya.
SALEM, Mass., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Frank W. Benson, noted artist who painted seven panels in the Library of Congress, died last night after a long illness at the age of 89.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 15 (UP)--A sandlot-bred scoring system for testing the character of football players and fans alike will be used Saturday at the HaverfordSwarthmore game for the first time on a college gridiron.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 15-- Earl Blaik, Army football coach, came strongly to the defense of spring practice and the two-platoon system today, declaring that it would be a deplorable mistake to do away with the former.
Cannon Mills will reopen its books for orders for sheets and pillowcases to all customers who have not had the opportunity to buy for January white sales, it was learned yesterday.

Except for the formality of signing contracts, everything is set for Cole Porter and F. Hugh Herbert to write the songs and book, respectively, of a new musical. Steeped in a Parisian atmosphere, it will be called "Can-Can."
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 15 (AP) --If you're shopping, around for a grain storage bin--here's the bargain of the day.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 15 -- President Truman said today the first recommendation of Fred M. Vinson for nomination as Chief Justice of the United States was made by the late Charles Evans Hughes, then retired Chief Justice, and was supported subsequently by Owen J. Roberts, a retired Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.

Despite the considerable increase in the size of the American Merchant Marine in the last year it remains unbalanced, and has too many slow ships that cannot meet present-day requirements, especially for national security, J.H. King, president of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, asserted yesterday.
KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 15 (U.P.)-- President Truman today set up an emergency fact-finding board in an effort to settle the union shop dispute of seventeen nonoperating railroad brotherhoods.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15 (UP)-- A jubilant Jimmy Carter picked up an estimated $32,000 purse today for his first defense of the world lightweight crown, a fifteen-round brawl in which he received an eye cut his trainer said might keep him out of action for "maybe a year."

The expanding waistline of the television addict and the automobile enthusiasts has given nutrition experts a new research problem, Dr. Charles G. King, scientific director of the Nutrition Foundation, Inc., declared yesterday.

Distance apparently lends an added enchantment to the United Nations for television. Now that the General Assembly of the world organization is meeting in Paris, its proceedings are receiving more coverage than when the U.N. was convening within sight of the Empire State tower.
State regulation of union welfare funds was proposed yesterday at a meeting of the Joint Legislative Committee on Labor and Industry, and immediately obtained bi-partisan support.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined 58,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 109,455,000 barrels, compared with 109,513,000 a week earlier and 105,465,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--The Legion of Decency, in its annual report to the Catholic Bishops of the United States, noted with approval today an increase in wholesome and moral themes in Hollywood-produced motion pictures, but viewed with concern objectionable foreign films.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--A demand from local units of the League of Women Voters that the national organization work for more efficiency and economy in the Federal Government was under consideration today by the national board in a policy session here.
LONDON, Nov.15--Progress toward self-government and selfdetermination for the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan has been accelerated as a result of the current dispute between Britain and Egypt.

PARIS, Nov. 15--Dr. Edvard Kardelj, Foreign Minister of Yugoslavia, presented to the United Nations General Assembly today a proposal for action by that body to end the tension between his country and the Soviet bloc states.

A charming daintiness marked the collection of Hannah Troy resort and spring designs shown yesterday by De Pinna at the Plaza Hotel. Divided between pretty prints, crisp taffetas, a few linens and woofs, the presentation highlighted a youthful slim-waisted, full-skirted silhouette, although in a few instances the slender line was seen.

YONKERS, Nov. 15--Yonkers Raceway closed its second season tonight with numerous records shattered. Most significant was the handle of $1,524,597, which eclipsed the former world record of $1,191,615 for a harness racing card, set here Oct. 6.

In Paris, Sir Benegal Rau, the Indian delegate to the United Nations, has renewed the proposal for another "private" meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers. This suggestion may be a token of the free nations' desire for peace, but it may be questioned whether it is realistic at this time, or even serves the end it seeks.
WASHINGTON, Nov.15--There have bean differences on strategy among Republican leaders who seek to nominate General Eisenhower for President at their National Convention in 1952, ...

The reconstructed Sandy Hook pilot boat New York, now practically a new ship, has had a thorough four-month trial period on station at the approaches to New York Harbor and has been pronounced satisfactory, officials of the pilot association said yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 15--The Government of Israel is ready and willing to enter into a Middle East defense alliance with the Western Big Three powers and Turkey--but only on certain definite conditions --according to information in the hands of responsible Western statesmen here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--An order rolling back used-car ceiling prices to levels 6 per cent below those prevailing at the first of this year was issued today by the Office of Price Stabilization.

SANDGATE, Vt., Nov. 15 -- There is no secret to bring ing down a buck if you look where you shoot and point where you look, as we discovered this morning. But the buck in question was weaving and bouncing through a birch grove, which made it difficult to coordinate the looking and the pointing.

The stock market held in a narrow range again yesterday, with a modest move to the higher side. Price changes and volume remained small, and aside from some interest in a few low-price issues, the airlines and railroads, trading proved inconclusive.

How a writer gets inspiration for a book, how to gather folk tales and what subjects can be made poetical were some of the questions posed yesterday by youthful panels at the second day of the New York Times Fifth Annual Boys and Girls Book Fair.

PARIS, Nov. 15--Both the Soviet Foreign Minister and his masters in the Kremlin have now had a week in which to repent of Andrei Y. Vishinsky's amusement at the Western Big Three's disarmament plan and it seems safe to predict that no further sounds of Soviet laughter will be heard at the Palais de Chaillot, in this connection at least.
Philip L. Graham, publisher of The Washingtan Post, declared last night that the legal profession had failed to meet its obligation to support individual freedom and ...
BALTIMORE, Nov. 15 (AP)--The combination of County Delight and Eddie Arcaro was tabbed by the odds-matters today as the probable favorite for tomorrow's fifteenth running of the Pimlico Special.

When the corn has been taken in and the cut stalks, stripped of the heavy ears, are gathered into shocks, the gardener pulls his jacket about him, surveys his autumnal labor and finds it has been good.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 15-- President Truman declared today that the reported murder of United States prisoners of war by Chinese and North Korean Communists was the most uncivilized thing that had happened in the last century--if it is true.

BOSTON, Nov. 15--President Truman cautioned New Englanders today against "misinformation" concerning the government's indus try dispersal program, asserting that it was a common-sense approach to national security and consistent with the American system of competitive business enterprise.

A resolution by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, calling for the dismissal of teachers who are or were members of the Communist party or who advocate communism or fascism, created an uproar at the Board of Education yesterday with opponents of the motion and board members exchanging bitter charges and countercharges.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15--A charge that a Congressional subcommittee is seeking to "debauch" the Federal Reserve System and make it subservient to the Treasury Department was made today by W. Randolph Burgess, chairman of the executive committee of the National City Bank of New York, in an address before the Bond Club of Chicago.

The production of Verdi's "Rigoletto" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, with new scenery and costumes by Eugene Berman and stage direction by Herbert Graf, was one of the most interesting and exciting interpretations of this work that we have seen. There was a very fine cast, with four successful debuts, a freshly conceived and highly dramatic presentation of the music.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 15--Dr. Richard Kennan, executive director of the Commission on the Defense of Democracy through Education, urged the delegates to the annual convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs today to keep control of schools in local communities to thwart communism.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 15-- Opinion in West Germany's highest governmental circles has hardened against the payment of occupation costs after the end of the current fiscal year and is united against further "concessions" to the Western powers in the talks on the Federal Republic's new status.
A check for $90,126 was turned over yesterday to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, national chairman of the Crusade for Freedom, by Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the crusade in Michigan.
Texas pulled into the lead in the race to fly relief into pelicanless London when Louisiana balked at the first red-tape barrier, holding her pelicans for British instructions.
One must resist a natural temptation to be cynical about the request by Premier Mossadegh for a loan from the United States to tide the Iranian Government over its present difficulties.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 16--General Matthew B. Ridgway ordered a thorough investigation yesterday to determine the facts behind the announcement made by Col. James M. Hanley, Eighth Army Judge Advocate, in Pusan that more than 2,500 United States prisoners of war had been killed by Chinese and North Korean Communists since last November.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 15 --Leonard Costa, 37 years old, was found guilty here today of maintaining Costa's Barn in Lodi as a gambling casino. A jury of ten women and two men returned the verdict to Superior Judge Leon Leonard.
William H. Draper Jr., trustee of the Long Island Rail Road, issued a statement yesterday with gloomy implications for the road's future under private enterprise.

Saks-34th Street held the second of its fashion shows yesterday for women who work. Holiday glamour was paraded on a runway in the McAlpin Hotel while a box-lunch was served at a nominal cost to 300 who made reservations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP)-- Secretary of the Interior Oscar L. Chapman announced plans today for an independent study of conflicting estimates of the cost of producing liquid fuels from coal.

The United States Steel Corporation, traditional pattern-setter for the steel industry, announced last night it did not expect to reach a voluntary wage agreement with Philip Murray's United Steelworkers of America, C.I.O.

City Council President Rudolph Halley announced yesterday that he would press for an investigation of conditions at Kings County Hospital. He announced this at a meeting of the Board of Estimate just before he voted with his colleagues for a pay rise of $600 a year for nurse anesthetists in all city hospitals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--Officials responsible for administering economic foreign aid acknowledged today that the $1,440,000,000 program was bogged down in an interdepartmental com mittee that Congress thought it had abolished but that had been quietly revived recently by W. Averell Harriman, Director of the Mutual Security Agency.
In a five-to-one majority opinion a teen-age panel of high school students agreed yesterday that the cost of living was outracing the ability of their families to maintain living standards.

The state fact-finding panel investigating the recent wildcat strike by longshoremen in an effort to find a solution to the intraunion dispute continued yesterday to delve into the manner in which a new two-year contract between the union and employing stevedores was ratified.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 15-President Truman left the door wide open today for a public endorsement of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1952. He declared, however, that continuation of his Fair Deal program would be the keynote of next year's Democratic platform regardless of who was nominated as the standard bearer.
A plan to make reckless drivers conspicuous by placing red symbols on the windshields of their cars was proposed yesterday by a New Jersey official at a regional conference on highway safety.

Monthly shipments of magnesium metal have doubled during the last year and are now almost three times the pre-Korean rate, it was reported here yesterday by Dr. J.D. Hanawalt, manager of the magnesium department of the Dow Chemical Company.

NAPLES, Italy, Nov. 15--The official European contract bridge team took heart last night when it whittled away successfully at the impressive lead held by the United States bridge squad in the twoteam match being played here at the Hotel Vesuvio for the 1951 contract bridge world championship.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 15 --Four nuclear scientists--including two young chemists from the University of California--were announced today as winners of the Nobel Prize, along with Par Lagerkvist, 60-year-old Swedish author.

The Reid Foundation announced yesterday it had awarded grants of $5,000 each to five newspaper men and one newspaper woman to travel and study abroad on fellowships during 1952. The foundation was established by Ogden ...
KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 15 (AP)-- President Truman accepted the resignation of Eric Johnston as head of the Economic Stabilization Agency today "with real regret" and "extreme reluctance."
PARIS, Nov. 16--For at least one section of the French populace the two-week-old sixth United Nations General Assembly has already been a smashing success.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP)-- Federal and District of Columbia narcotics agents launched a series of precision raids tonight to clean out nests of illegal drug peddling in slum districts almost within the shadow of the nation's Capitol.
DAYTON, Nov. 16-The National Milk Products Federation at the closing session of its thirtyfifth annual convention here today, told Congress what it wanted, and did not want, for the American farmer.

Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien ruled yesterday that the city's Bureau of Smoke Control must disclose what action it has taken on complaints of "flagrant" violations of the smoke abatement regulations.
One-man art shows of the week include one of Haitian themes, one of Maine landscapes, one that draws on the Far West for material and another of sculpture.
Leaders of the nation's industry and finance took their annual grapefruit in the face last night-- and loved it.
TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 17 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 1,070, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A.M. (4 P.M., Friday, Eastern standard time):

The Wicks' Committee, created last winter by the State Legislature to investigate the horse racing industry, confined its business yesterday to an open hearing on the harness racing situation in New York State.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange lost 30 to 48 points net yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon, one of the internationalist Republicans seeking to "draft" General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the party's Presidential nomination, welcomed today the entry of Gov. Earl Warren of California into the race.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 16-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer asked the Constitutional Court of the Federal Republic today for permission to ban the Communist party and the neo-Nazi Socialist Reich party in West Germany.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 16 (UP)--A woman who spent two weeks alone in a wrecked Cessna airplane in a cold wilderness more than 306 miles west of here was rescued today after her pilot had walked thirty miles through the snow for help.

The corner store and apartment property at 1714 Second Avenue has been sold by Ernest Stegeman to a syndicate represented by Joshuah Sidney Shultz, attorney. Harold M. Silverman and the Amal Realty Company were the brokers. Roth Roth were attorneys for the buyers.
LONDON, Nov. 16--If Mohamed Salah el-Din Pasha, Egyptian Foreign Minister, will make practical proposals for a plebiscite in the Sudan, the British Government will consider them carefully.

LONDON, Nov. 16--Prices weakened again in nearly all the stock markets here today. The volume of business diminished appreciably. This drop was attributed to the fact that investors are concentrating on the new Unilever issues or are awaiting an appeal for new capital by other big companies.

PUSAN, Korea, Nov. 16--The information chief for the United Nations command in Tokyo came out of a secret conference here tonight with "no comment" on the disclosure three days ago that the Chinese Communists had killed more than 2,500 American prisoners of war.

Sale of new postal paper by the United Nations and the United States Post Office Department ushered in the three-day Third National Postage Stamp Show yesterday in the Seventy-first Infantry Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.
Youthful-looking, alert and gentle, Dr. William Heard Kilpatrick, who will be 80 years old on Tuesday, is not ready to retire. He insists he never will. There's too much to do in the world.

BOSTON, Nov. 16--A complete revision of radio rates, in some instances upward, was suggested here today by Edgar Kobak, business consultant, permanent head of the Broadcast Advertising Bureau and advertising veteran. Speaking at a luncheon of the Radio Executives Club, he criticized the grow

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 16--The White House announced late today that President Truman had requested and accepted the immediate resignation of Theron Lamar Caudle, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's Tax Division.

LONDON, Nov.16--Both in Parliament and in the press this week there have been increasing signs of restiveness and disquiet among the British people over the failure of the negotiations to produce a cease-fire order in Korea. The question is being raised seriously whether it is American or Communist intransigence that is at fault.

PARIS, Saturday, Nov. 17--Facing the prospect of defeat upon domestic economic issues in the National Assembly, Premier Rene Pleven just before 6 A.M. today asked for a formal confidence vote --a move that puts off the final decision on the life of the Government until Tuesday.

Directors of the Kennecott Copper Corporation lifted this year's disbursements to $6 from $5.50 paid in 1950, with the declaration yesterday of a year-end distribution of $2.25. The dividend will be paid to common stockholders on Dec. 19.

Columbia will match its passing attack against Navy's strong forward wall today when the two teams clash at Baker Field. The game will start at 1:30 P. M., forty-five minutes after 1,400 midshipmen parade onto the field.

ALBANY, Nov. 16--More people bet more money at the state's flat and harness racing tracks during the season that ended yesterday than ever before in New York's twelve years of legalized parimutuel wagering.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--A continuing nation-wide campaign to interest high school girls and boys in science and engineering was agreed upon today by the first conference on that subject held at the call of the Office of Education of the Federal Security Agency.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 16-- India's atttiude on the recent rival disarmament proposals put before the United Nations General Assembly by the Western powers and the Soviet Union is likely to be made known shortly.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 16 (UP)--Tony Trabert of Cincinnati and Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, the only American Davis Cup players who competed in today's singles matches at the New South Wales tennis championships, easily gained the third round with straight-set victories over Australian opponents.
TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 17 (UP) --Following is the text of the statement by Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway on release of the "Hanley report" regarding Communist atrocities:

PARIS, Nov. 16--Egypt offered today to submit the future status of the Sudan to a plebiscite conducted by the United Nations on the condition that the British, as well as the Egyptian, armed forces and officials be withdrawn from that territory during the vote.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 16 (AP)-- Tennessee and Maryland, both undefeated and untied, accepted invitations tonight to meet in the Sugar Bowl football game here Jan. 1.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 16--The contest between liberty and the twin bugaboos of "growing socialism and government control" was held up today by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio as the "greatest domestic issue before the people."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--Average primary market prices remained unchanged over the week ended Nov. 13, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index, 177.2 per cent of the 1926 average, remained at a level 12.9 per cent above the pre-Korean average (May 24-June 25, 1950).

A group of high Navy officers stepped shakily from their plane at 9:25 A. M. yesterday at Floyd Bennett Naval Air Station and voiced unreserved praise for Lieut. Comdr. William W. Christine, their pilot.

What might easily be very important news to children throughout the nation appeared yesterday. Spencer Kellogg Sons have come forth with the announcement that they have developed a substitute for castor oil. Castor oil, it seems, has been in short supply ever since the beginning of the Korean war.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 16 (AP) --Ohio State's Buckeyes hope to throw a road block tomorrow in unbeaten Illinois' path to the Rose Bowl and the Big Ten title.

PALEBANG, Indonesia, Nov. 16--Indonesia's oil production is nearing pre-war levels as foreign producing concerns complete restoration of facilities damaged in the Japanese war and security returns to areas disturbed as the result of fighting between the Dutch and Indonesians.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--The Soviet Union promised today to return by the end of this month two United States icebreakers that the State Department had been trying to retrieve for more than two years.

Magistrate Hyman Bushel, sitting in Lower Manhattan Court, dismissed yesterday a summons charging that a local clothing store had knowingly sold "a reject" under its original brand name at more than $20 lower than the fair trade price.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16-- Ethel Barrymore, who now is working in the new Bing Crosby picture, "Famous," at Paramount, is giving serious ccnsideration to an offer to participate in a television program to be known as the "Ethel Barrymore Theatre of

David S. Ingalls of Cleveland, chairman of the Taft-for-President campaign committee, predicted yesterday that Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio would be nominated for President at the Republican National Convention. Mr. Ingalls

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--Archbishop Richard J. Cushing of Boston and Bishop Thomas K. Gorman of Reno were elected today department chairmen in the administrative board of the National Catholic Welfare Conference.

ST. LOUIS Nov. 16 (AP)--Senator James P. Kem, Republican of Missouri, charged today that General Motors is shipping $210,000 worth of truck and automotive parts to Communist Poland with the State Department's consent.

PARIS, Nov. 16--Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, who sought to dismiss the Western Big Three disarmament proposals eight days ago with a statement that he had not been able to sleep for laughing, attempted to come back today with new counter-proposals.

The huge banana terminal being built in Weehawken, N. J., just north of the Lincoln Tunnel, for the United Fruit Company is more than 50 per cent completed and will be ready for occupancy next year, according to the New York Central Railroad, co-sponsor of the project with the fruit company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP)-- Price control officials emphasized today that retailers who raised the price of a single bottle or can of beer because of the higher excise tax were violating price regulations.
A grand jury investigation into the alleged organized racketeering on Brooklyn's waterfront was ordered yesterday by Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16-- Pennsylvania is expected to present a revised offensive line-up when the Red and Blue opposes Army tomorrow on Franklin Field The kick-off is set for 1:30 P. M.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 17--Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, United Nations commander, in a formal statement this afternoon confirmed the charges of the Judge Advocate General section of his army that the Chinese and North Korean Communists had slaughtered United Nations prisoners in the Korean war.

Earl Wild is bursting with potential--both for gratifying his audience, which he did in his recital in Carnegie Hall last night, and for fulfilling the demands of the music, which he did less completely.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 16--Impending vacancies in two jobs generally conceded to be the most thankless in the controls program confronted the Administration with one of its toughest recruiting problems tonight.
Excitement ran high yesterday among cat fanciers as the thirty-fifth annual show of the Empire Cat Club opened at the McAlpin Hotel. All the exhibitors were speculating from the ...
A forum for discussion of world problems was proposed yesterday by Newbold Morris, chairman of the Young Men's Christian Association campaign for $4,000,000.

In a setting of white chrysanthemums yesterday afternoon in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church Miss Catryna Van Ness Ten Eyck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barent Ten Eyck of 127 East Ninety-fourth Street, was married to Whitney North Seymour Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour of New York and Stockton, N. J.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP)--Wisconsin's Walt Deike took the individual championship, but the Badgers were dethroned by Michigan State for the team honors of the Big Ten cross-country run today.

SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, Nov. 16--From a sheltered pine grove nostalgically named El Reposo, the strum of guitars marks fiesta time in the area occupied by the only South American unit in the United Nations army as the men of Colombia's battalion--described by Gen. James A. Van Fleet as magnificent--sing of home, wine and love.
One of the books published today is "Mobilization and Inflation," by Frederic L. Simmons, economist of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 17-- Communist jet planes, virtually absent from North Korean skies for a few days, were back in force south of the Yalu River yesterday. The MIG-15 pilots avoided fights with United Nations fliers and, when pressed, turned tail and fled back into Manchuria.
